SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: H.M.O.'s Could Save Your Life

BYLINE: By Susan Love; Susan Love, a breast surgeon, is the author of "Dr. Susan Love's Hormone Book." She expects to earn her M.B.A. this fall at the Anderson School of Management at U.C.L.A.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The future of health care in this country is about to be decided yet again by advertising campaigns and sob stories. Some lobbyists and public relations firms, pushing for tougher regulations, are parading patients who tearfully complain of abuse by mean-spirited, money-hungry managed-care companies. Others claim that regulation will only lead to higher premiums and more uninsured people.
Into this murky debate step members of Congress and state legislators, who are falling over themselves to offer legislation that would establish a "patients' bill of rights." For the most part, these bills would force managed-care companies to pay for specific kinds of care, expand a patient's choice of doctors and require plans to document the outcome of the treatment. 
 Such legislation tends to cast managed care as the enemy of good medicine. This is the wrong approach. Although H.M.O.'s definitely need more regulation and oversight, they may still be the best way to insure high-quality care in an efficient, cost-effective manner.
Many doctors and politicians want us to believe that we just have to get back to the good old days. But after 12 years as a surgeon in Boston and an additional six in Los Angeles, I can tell you that the good old days were not always so great for patients or doctors.
In the 1980's, medical costs were spiraling upward and yet the care itself and survival rates were not improving at the same rate. Tests abounded. As Dr. Marcia Angell, the executive editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, once said, if you think you are healthy, you have not had enough tests done yet.
How did this happen? The economic incentives encouraged overtreatment. The more tests, operations and procedures we did as doctors, the more we were rewarded by insurance companies. It didn't matter whether the tests or treatments were necessary.
In most economic markets, it is the consumers who decide when the cost outweighs the benefits. They simply refuse to pay. But in the area of health care, the consumer-patients were not the ones paying the bill. For the most part they had insurance, provided by their employers, that covered all their medical expenses. Patients certainly had no incentive and too little information to question their high-priced and often excessive care.
The system also discouraged preventive medicine. In the heyday of fee-for-service plans, insurance would not cover annual physical exams, birth control, baby care or even immunizations; nor would it cover Pap smears or mammograms.
Radical change was in order. But the transformation felt like a revolution from on high. It seemed as if it was imposed against the public's will, sparking fear, suspicion and mistrust. Today, patients no longer feel as if they have any say in their care. It seems to be controlled by employers in cahoots with the H.M.O.'s. And the public doesn't trust either of them.
Now no longer paid to overtreat their patients, doctors are encouraged to limit care to that which is absolutely necessary. But hiring the cheapest doctors and giving them incentives to keep costs down do not insure satisfactory care or happy patients.
This first phase of the revolution hasn't been perfect, but that doesn't mean it has to be abandoned.
First, H.M.O.'s can develop uniform standards of care and insure that doctors adhere to them. For example, recent studies from the American College of Surgeons have shown that treatment for women with breast cancer varies according to where they live. Obviously, a woman with breast cancer shouldn't be more likely to get a mastectomy simply because she lives in the South. H.M.O.'s are a perfect vehicle to insure that all doctors are using up-to-date treatments.
Second, H.M.O.'s can educate patients on what is appropriate care. Many patients are so used to overtreatment that the proper course can seem like a deprivation. For instance, the overuse of antibiotics to treat colds has led to drug-resistant bacteria, yet patients still want all the drugs they have become accustomed to.
Third, managed care can be more centered around the patient. In the past, appointments were scheduled at the convenience of the doctor or hospital, and -- remember -- patients were made to wait then, too. Now that health plans are vying for members, they have just begun to worry about patient satisfaction -- though they have a long way to go.
Fourth, managed-care companies can broaden the range of treatment. Studies have already shown that H.M.O.'s do a better job with preventive services like mammograms, Pap smears and immunizations. And many H.M.O.'s like Oxford are beginning to cover alternative therapies, like acupuncture and biofeedback.
 Instead of encouraging H.M.O.'s to fulfill this potential, however, Congress and state legislatures prefer to zero in on the abuses, offering quick fixes that will do little to help. Here are some examples of what to avoid:
* Playing doctor. Many states have passed legislation, for example, requiring managed-care companies to allow two-day hospital stays after a mastectomy. But in my years as a breast cancer surgeon, I often sent women home the same day after a mastectomy. They did fine, but they also had a lot of education and support.
"Drive through" mastectomies aren't the problem. It's the lack of a support system and the fact that women don't want their H.M.O.'s telling them what to do. The answer is not for legislatures to decide what the appropriate treatment is, but to give patients a say in their care. This can happen if patients have a place at the table when H.M.O.'s make their policies.
* Creating false demands. In the movement for a patient bill of rights, many members of Congress are touting the expansion of "patient choice." But I am not sure that people are really demanding more doctors to choose from. They just want the best medical treatment. After all, how did they choose doctors in the old system? More often than not, they asked Aunt Mabel or a neighbor. This did not insure quality care.
When we get on a plane we do not choose our pilot. We trust the airline to choose qualified pilots. In a similar way, patients would be much more comfortable if they knew that a certain health plan maintained strict quality control, picking its doctors carefully. So legislation should be more concerned with assuring quality by forcing health plans to reveal how they recruit, select and pay doctors.
* Relying too much on statistics to improve quality. The collection of data on complications and the results of treatment is important in the long run, but it will do little to solve the immediate problem -- the patient's lack of trust in the system. It would be better to require all health plans to publish their guidelines for treatment, along with the supporting evidence. We also need timely, independent appeal procedures to assure that we can challenge those decisions.
Managed care has many problems, but it retains much potential. Going back to "the good old days" or passing quick-fix legislation won't do much to improve medical care. Instead, we must demand that our employers use their clout not just to lower health costs but also to improve quality. We must demand that H.M.O.'s publicize their policies and guidelines, as well as defend them.
In sum, let's not bash managed care, but improve it.

HEADLINE: Telemedicine Getting a Test in Efforts to Cut Costs of Treating Prisoners

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY 

 BODY:
Universal health care is a reality in one part of the United States: prison.
By law, inmates are guaranteed medical treatment. And with the ranks of prisoners rising an average of 8 percent every year since 1990, providing that treatment is an expensive proposition. To control costs and improve security, a handful of states are trying out telemedicine -- health care via telecommunications. With government agencies, managed-care providers and legislators watching, these programs are serving as a proving grounds for broadening the use of telemedicine. 
 After two decades of limited acceptance as a way to provide health care to people in areas where there are few doctors, telemedicine has been embraced by prison officials as a way to minimize the costs and dangers of transporting inmates to hospitals when they need advanced or specialty care. Most prisons are in rural areas, requiring inmates to travel hours, shackled and under guard, to see a doctor.
"With telemedicine, prisoners don't even have to leave their cellblock," said Dr. Steven Viegas, a hand surgeon who oversees the prison telemedicine project at the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston.
Starting in 1994 and covering roughly 100,000 inmates in 12 prisons, the University of Texas telemedicine program is the nation's oldest and largest. Yearly, the on-line network saves about $300,000 in prisoner transportation costs alone.
Prisons generally have infirmaries operated by primary-care doctors or nurses. When an inmate needs more than rudimentary care, the jail's medical personnel use specialized equipment -- like electronic stethoscopes and otoscopes -- to transmit real-time audio and high-resolution video images of prisoners to physicians at hospitals hundreds of miles away. Both the off-site doctor and patient have two monitors so they can see each other as well as their own images.
The hardware costs $60,000 to $100,000 and charges for high-speed phone lines are around $1,000 to $1,500 a month.
Although statistics are hard to come by because prison telemedicine programs are so new and so few, administrators say their economic benefits go beyond savings in transportation and security. Anecdotal evidence suggests that inmates are more likely to seek care when they do not have to travel to see a doctor.
"This lower threshold to getting care probably reduces the likelihood of more expensive acute care later on," said Dr. Michael G. Kienzle, associate dean for clinical affairs at the University of Iowa Hospital in Iowa City, which last year began to extend electronic health care to 4,000 inmates in four state prisons.
Telemedicine also streamlines the delivery of specialty care. For example, the University of Virginia Health Sciences Center in Charlottesville schedules weekly on-line clinics for jail inmates in such medical specialties as dermatology.
"The specialist sits at a computer and sees patients from different units all across the state, one after another," said Richard J. Settimo, deputy director of the University of Virginia's office of telemedicine, which opened last year to serve 5,000 inmates in five state prisons. "The ability to block-schedule prisoners saves a whole lot of time and money."
The on-site medical staff follows the treatment recommendations of the specialist. If the treatment is complicated, the prisoner is then transported to a hospital.
The efficiency of prison programs has not escaped the attention of public and private interests responsible for providing health care to people who are not behind bars. Based on its success in treating prisoners, the University of Virginia received a grant from the Commerce Department in October to set up a $1.2 million telemedicine network to serve Medicaid patients in the state's rural southwestern region.
In January, the University of Iowa's prison project led to a joint venture with a private managed-care company, Help Innovations Inc. of Lawrence, Kan., to provide home health care using telemedicine.
"We are able to point to our experience in the prisons as evidence of the effectiveness of telemedicine," Dr. Kienzle said.
Two managed-care companies -- Partners Health Care System Inc., based in Boston, and Kaiser Permanente, based in Sacramento, Calif. -- had prison programs in mind when they recently established telemedicine networks as an inexpensive way to serve isolated, homebound elderly and chronically ill subscribers.
"We knew of the effectiveness of prison care systems and used them as a basis for carving out our own application," said Eric Menn, corporate manager of Partners' telemedicine division.
The military uses telemedicine, as well. For example, the United States Army has a $30 million system in place in Bosnia, linking the medical staff there to physicians at military bases around the world. Its benefits are aimed less at controlling costs than at keeping doctors out of harm's way, though.
The prison telemedicine systems have provided arguments for reimbursing the expenses of telemedicine when it is used to care for the general population. Currently, telemedicine is generally not covered by Medicare or private insurance.
Testimony from prison administrators before a Senate ad hoc committee on telemedicine led to the inclusion of a provision in last year's Balanced Budget Act that will require Medicare to pay for telemedicine delivered to certain rural areas found to have a shortage of doctors.
"The decision makers have definitely been watching what's going on in the prisons," said Deborah Dakins, editor of Telemedicine and Telehealth Networks, a bimonthly magazine that tracks the industry.
Positive preliminary results from these "test cases" have modestly increased access to telemedicine in both the public and private health care sectors, she said.
But it will take more time and more data before it is commonplace for patients outside prison to stick out their tongues and say "ahhhh" for a computer.

HEADLINE: Bill Sale Is Only Auction by U.S. This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.96 percent and a six-month bill was 5.11 percent.

HEADLINE: CONNECTIONS;
For the Media's Dupes, Perhaps Thinking Makes It So

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
It is going to be difficult to escape "The Truman Show." For weeks, the film, starring Jim Carrey, has been featured on magazine covers and brooded about in beard-pulling advance features. Now it has finally opened, and escape is even less likely.
But after seeing the movie, escape is what I yearn for. Like Mr. Carrey's character, Truman, who has been, since birth, an unknowing subject of a 24-hour-a-day television show, I seek fresh air, open skies, new possibilities. Truman begins to suspect his seaside village is not all it's made out to be; I am beginning to suspect something similar about my cultural surroundings. 
 Here's the problem: I am being told, again and again, that we are a lot like Truman. He is living in a world constructed by the media. He is dominated by their desires, sacrificed to their whims, and he doesn't even know it. It has become almost axiomatic that we are in the same boat. The boundaries between television and reality have broken down. We sit for months watching the O. J. trial as soap opera. Networks interrupt their programming to broadcast a live California suicide. Jerry Springer stages talk-show fights. So, isn't "Truman" true?
This is what we are meant to think. And that is what I want to escape: the numbing insistence that we are the victims of higher media forces that have constructed a prefab stage set, who pull our strings and force-feed us useless products. And we, unknowing, turn from our empty lives to submit to the moguls' intoxicating fantasies. We are insistently told that we are duped, manipulated, controlled.
But I am beginning to suspect that this insistence is the real duping and manipulation; we are duped into believing we are being duped. Don't believe me? Try escaping that message. It is also being drilled in by another recent film, Warren Beatty's political satire "Bulworth."
There, too, television is so powerful it is sometimes difficult to tell whether life is an image of the screen or the screen an image of life. The television interviewer Larry King (who has actually predicted that "The Truman Show" will "revolutionize the art form") books the fictional Senator-candidate Bulworth, on his talk show. And in that film, too, television can seem to undermine perception of the real. In the midst of a mental breakdown, the Senator sits with a television remote in his hand, channel surfing his way into oblivion.
Bulworth, like Truman, tries to free himself from the media's manipulating power. He opposes a television interviewer's attempt to break away to a commercial. He challenges the independence of the questioners on a televised debate, pointing out that they are rich people working for other rich people who are running rich media companies that have subsidized his campaign.
In fact, his villains are the same moguls and producers who put on the televised "Truman Show" in Mr. Carrey's movie, enslaving Truman to a life of staged broadcasts. In Mr. Beatty's fantasy, the conspiracy is even more nefarious, because it extends so deeply into the pockets of corporate America and keeps so many different Trumans in penury.
Who can argue with these films' vision, when our attention keeps being drawn to similar notions even outside films? We blame television for violence, advertising for smoking and the media for political mediocrity. These ideas now form the familiar contours of our culture's seaside village; they provide the foundations for our prefab dystopia. And they offer a seamless web of ready-made interpretation about our masters and oppressors, spiced, in these films, with just enough humor and farce to make the message palatable.
But we, like Truman, can begin to notice certain oddities about this message that is supposedly reiterated for our benefit and insight. There are postures that seem out of place. It may be worth questioning the authority of the voices making proclamations, and perhaps even their noble intentions.
Whose interests, after all, are being served by seeing the world in this way? Mr. Beatty's film believes the Trumanesque victims are inner-city blacks. And Bulworth rescues them by becoming what Norman Mailer once called a "White Negro." He takes off his suit and tie and smashes the oppressive bourgeois mold. He dresses in baggy shorts for a television interview, swigs liquor during a television debate, raps insults to corporate donors and adopts a vintage 1968 radical political line, promising to lead the poor, particularly the black poor, to economic freedom.
Truman doesn't carry the torch for anyone else, but his way of undermining his handlers is similar: break the mold, act in unexpected fashion, rebel against the constraints of family, job and community (all of which, after all, are phony).
The level of disdain and condescension in these visions is astonishing. Mr. Beatty can envision Bulworth having an impact only when he jettisons all manners, adopts crude political doctrines and becomes a White Negro cartoon. He insults those he claims to champion.
And isn't that true of the makers of "Truman" as well? If we are meant to root for Truman against the delusions peddled by the media masters, why does the film portray ordinary citizens as so horrific? The stage set created for Truman (which he believes to be real) appears to be an ordinary suburban development. But Peter Weir's direction treats the village with winking mockery. When Truman weeds his garden, he wears bright red polyester shorts. His wife, while plugging a brand of hot cocoa or an all-in-one kitchen utensil, is an exaggerated 1950's housewife in a checked dress. Truman's job as an insurance salesman fits the same vintage cartoon. This is a town of Stepford Wives, Children of the Damned, Body Snatchers.
Of course, the town is meant to be cartoonish; the film, after all, presents it as a set made by the mad media masters directing Truman's life. But the filmmakers also want their condemnations to resonate in the "real world." The film even shows us the viewers of the Truman drama, people who are our counterparts, who watch television day and night. And they are even more grotesque than the bourgeois villagers.
Two old ladies pathetically hug a pillow decorated with Truman's picture. Two half-witted parking attendants can't keep their eyes off the television. A corpulent man soaks in a bathtub hypnotized by Truman's escapades. The film's unremitting scorn leaves no one but Truman untouched.
So here is what this vision of moguls and manipulation gives us: a world of flaccid, dull-witted oppressed and untrustworthy citizens who can't see what is in front of their eyes except to watch a screen. They are supposedly saved by visionaries whose rebellion undermines the phony stage set of bourgeois life. But this rebellion, it turns out, is itself full of scorn. Truman may not show it, but his inventors, the filmmakers, do. And so does Mr. Beatty in his condescension.
There is hardly any room in these films for ordinary people with their problems and struggles; either you are a grotesque victim of the moguls or an unmitigated rebel, a Child of the Damned or a White Negro. Nothing seems real.
That is the vision I seek to escape. But the filmmakers and their allies have things locked up tight. They insist that they alone have a true vision. Only they dare to show the reality behind the pap. In these films, behind cameras we never see, are the real heroes who should be hailed for their provocative and courageous films showing us as the dupes we are.
But isn't it peculiar that this courage and provocation are really founded on cultural cliches and papier-mache politics? Meanwhile, the results are so familiar and comfortable, we don't even try to escape.

TITLE: TRUMAN SHOW, THE (MOVIE); BULWORTH (MOVIE)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Battered chip stocks may well have hit bottom, and some analysts are recommending buys.

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
WHEN bad things happen to good companies, many investors start looking for buying opportunities.
Such is the case with semiconductor stocks, which have been battered this year as one formerly stellar company after another has reported earnings disappointments, layoffs and product delays. Chip industry analysts agree that the group may be reaching a bottom, but they differ on when to start buying chip stocks again. 
 For now, the bad news just keeps on coming. The Intel Corporation is expected to be served with an antitrust suit today by the Federal Trade Commission; late last month the company announced that its Merced chip would be delayed. Motorola announced last week that it would cut 15,000 jobs, citing weak demand for cellular phones, pagers and other products using its semiconductors. And National Semiconductor warned that revenue would fall below analysts' estimates, and that it expected to report a loss for its fiscal fourth quarter, ending May 31, and possibly for the first quarter of the new year as well.
While some companies face problems of their own making, like Motorola's missing the shift from analog to digital cellular phones, there are two bigger forces depressing the group as a whole.
First is a glut of personal computers being sold in the United States, created largely by the Compaq Computer Corporation's need to reduce inventory as it moves to a build-to-order business model.
Second is the financial and economic crisis in Asia, which has weakened demand both for personal computers and for all kinds of devices that use chips.
Because no one in the industry saw either the glut of PC's or the Asian trouble coming, chip makers kept building production well into 1997. With supply exceeding demand, prices have plummeted for semiconductor products from microprocessors to memory chips. The personal computer oversupply and the Asia crisis are presumably temporary, but deciding whether and when to invest in chip stocks is difficult without a clearer end in sight.
Mark Edelstone, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, said that chip makers had already cut back substantially on new production, particularly in Asia, and that the PC inventory problems were well past the halfway point.
"You will actually see the demand rate for semiconductors bounce back," he said. "I think that will begin to happen in the next 60 days."
Still, many semiconductor stocks are trading at or near their 52-week lows, Mr. Edelstone said, because the companies' first-quarter earnings were a "disaster, with two-thirds of companies below estimates," and their financial performances are likely to be the same in the second quarter.
"You've got stocks that are pretty beaten up, and from a long-term point of view, attractive at current valuations," he said. "Investors should be getting their shopping lists together."
Mr. Edelstone is currently recommending Neomagic, a maker of graphics-control chips for notebook computers; Rambus, a maker of fast memory devices; Xilinx Inc., a maker of programmable logic devices, and Intel, which he believes will be little affected by the F.T.C. suit or the Merced delay.
"We expect them to be strong in the second half," he said.
Drew Peck, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said that it was too early to begin buying most chip stocks -- that Asia remained an open-ended situation and that the oversupply of PC's was still a problem.
"It would be very easy to say it's got to get better pretty soon, but so far the data that would support such a conclusion are scarce," he said. "I believe it will happen, but that's only blind faith. Having said all that, I think we're going to get a rash of pre-announcements like Motorola's, if not as big, over the next few weeks. At that point most of the bad news will be discounted, and even if it takes a year to get a recovery, most of the risk will be removed."
Even now, Mr. Peck said he recommended some chip stocks that he thought had been unfairly battered. Among them, he likes Analog Devices, which makes chips for processing graphics, sound and other nondigital signals, and Amcor, which makes semiconductor packaging material. For the bulk of the semiconductor stocks, Mr. Peck said the time to buy had not yet arrived.
But, of course, by the time it becomes apparent that the worst is over, prices will most likely have gone up. Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, said he started buying chip stocks last week. "I think we're going to go into a pretty different environment in the second half of the year, where prices will firm up," he said. "We started buying Intel when it went below $75 and took it to 5 percent of our portfolio when it went below $70."
Mr. Murphy is also recommending LSI Logic, Integrated Device Technology, Altera, Atmel and Xilinx. "I think you can pretty much buy anything in the semiconductor area," he said.

HEADLINE: Patents;
A word game that is a cross between Scrabble and the ancient Chinese game of mah-jongg.

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan 

 BODY:
THIS year is the 50th anniversary of Scrabble, the classic spelling game thought up by Alfred M. Butts, an unemployed architect, as he sat in his fifth-floor walk-up apartment in Queens one night.
Is it possible that Mr. Butts's game can be improved? Pingsheng Huang, an inventor in Towaco, N.J., thinks so. 
 Mr. Huang has patented a new type of word game that he describes as a cross between Scrabble and the ancient Chinese game of mah-jongg.
His game, which he calls Magi Compo, uses 144 tiles, as does mah-jongg. But mah-jongg tiles feature abstract symbols that have to be matched up. Mr. Huang's tiles -- like those in Scrabble -- are inscribed with English letters that are arranged to make up words.
But Mr. Huang's tiles are far more complex than those in Scrabble. Each tile has not just a single letter, but also letter combinations. A player can pick which combination of letters he wishes to use. For example, he might draw a tile that has "P," "PE" and "PER" inscribed on it, and then draw a second tile that has "A," "AL" and "AR." From these two tiles, he could choose to form the words "pear" or "pal" or "par" or "peal."
The scoring system is also different, said Mr. Huang. In Scrabble, players reap big points by using letters like "x" or "q." With Magi Compo, the longer the word, the bigger the score, with no weight given to less-common letters or letter combinations. Mr. Huang also includes a number of wild-card tiles that can be designated whatever letter a player wishes.
Earlier this year, Mr. Huang, who is originally from China but has lived in the United States since 1990, quit his job as a marketing director for a computer company so he could promote his invention full time. Last month, he visited China to line up a manufacturer for the game, which he thinks will retail for about $50.
So far, though, Mr. Huang has not found an outlet to sell his game. For inspiration, he might look to the story of Mr. Butts. Scrabble did not come on the market until 1948 -- 10 years after Mr. Butts patented it.
Mr. Huang received patent 5,556,102.
 
A Box to Keep Watches Wound
 Although battery-powered watches are the norm these days, mechanical watches remain popular among timepiece connoisseurs. Many of these are self-winding as the wearer moves his or her wrist.
But what happens if the watch is not worn for a few days? "Once it stops, it can be a pain to reset it," said Jeff Richards, an inventor in Las Vegas, Nev.
Mr. Richards has patented a battery-operated vibrating jewelry box that will keep a watch ticking. "The patent is on the motion itself," he said.
He said that the jewelry box would sell for $250 to $350 but that he hoped to persuade a watchmaker to give away the box with high-end watches. "That's reasonable if someone were to buy a $10,000 watch," he said.
Mr. Richards received patent 5,608,693.
 
Snap-Open Frames For Eyeglasses
 David Wedeck, a former television executive in Teaneck, N.J., has patented what he says is an inexpensive way to make a fashion statement with eyeglasses.
His eyeglasses snap open at the point where the temple meets the lens frame so that the same lenses can be used in several different frames. The interchangeable frames can be either plastic or metal, Mr. Wedeck said, and take less than a minute to snap out and put in.
"It's an inexpensive way to get yourself a variety of styles and colors," he said.
Mr. Wedeck, who said he would like to license his invention, received patent 5,760,866.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HDTV Encounters Trouble As Its Debut Approaches
Digital high-definition television broadcasts and the sale of HDTV sets will begin by November. 
 Even so, the new crystal-clear programming promised by the HDTV technology will not be available on those sets if the programming comes in on cable. This is just one of several problems that have become apparent in the final weeks before the transition to digital broadcasting. Page D5.
 
Telemedicine Cuts Costs for Prisons
With the ranks of prisoners rising an average of 8 percent every year since 1990, providing health care for them is an expensive proposition. To control costs and improve security prison officials are using telemedicine, or health care via telecommunications, as a way to minimize the costs and dangers of transporting inmates to hospitals when they need advanced or specialty care. The world's six largest accounting firms have set up corporate law practices in many European countries by hiring lawyers or merging with law firms, but European lawyers are not happy about it. D2.
 
NBC Ends Ban on 'Dirty Work' Ads
Don Ohlmeyer, the president of NBC's West Coast division, had ruled that the network would not accept commercials for the movie "Dirty Work" because it starred Norm Macdonald, a former comedian on "Saturday Night Live." Service Plans to Recruit on the Web
The Wall Street Journal and Korn/Ferry International plan to start a service to recruit managers via the World Wide Web and match them with prospective employers. D6.
 
Poll Says Cable News Gaining
Americans now watch news programs on cable television networks about as regularly as those on broadcast networks, according to a survey by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. The researchers also found that the number of people who get their news from the Internet is rising rapidly and they estimated that almost as many people use the Internet on a typical weekday as spend time reading a magazine. D7.

HEADLINE: Rooted in Old Sod, Music Grows All Over;
A Festival Points Up the Universal Appeal of Irish Culture

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
It's not quite the musical analogue to Thomas Cahill's "How the Irish Saved Civilization," the best-selling book blending Irish history, folklore and myth making that argues that Western culture would not have survived without the Irish monks who saved and spread the works of antiquity.
But there is clearly something that transcends music at the second American incarnation of the Guinness Fleadh, billed as "the ultimate Irish Music and Culture Festival" and scheduled for Saturday and Sunday on Randalls Island and then moving on to Chicago and San Francisco. 
 The Fleadh (pronounced FLAH) -- with its blend of Irish (Sinead O'Connor, the Chieftains, the Corrs) and distinctly non-Irish (Los Lobos, Tracy Chapman, Patti Smith, Chumbawamba) music, Irish literary readings, crafts and exhibits -- is partly a glimpse of the new, high-concept dynamics of summer festivals, which have evolved a long way from the time when all it took to draw people was loud music, tight halter tops, hot stadiums and cold beer.
But it is also a window onto the remarkable renaissance of Irish and Irish-American culture, all the more striking in light of the optimism that followed last month's peace referendum. The inspiration for the Fleadh (the word means festival) is the traditional Irish musical celebrations going back centuries. But if its roots are traditional, it highlights two revealing contradictions in contemporary Irish culture.
The first is the remarkably ecumenical quality of Irish culture: how music that is so intensely rooted in Irish soil seems to travel so well and include so much far-flung music amicably under the same tent. The second is the odd way that traditional Irish culture seems to be blossoming, often in all sorts of unlikely amalgams, in an Ireland that, for better or worse, is finally becoming integrated into the rest of the world.
The Irish experience, in the United States and at home, of course, has had more than its share of brutishness and intolerance. Indeed, the welcoming qualities of the music have often been at odds with numbing parochialism, whether in Northern Ireland or South Boston.
But from the plays of Martin McDonagh and the poetry of Seamus Heaney to the enormous success of Frank McCourt's memoir, "Angela's Ashes," and pop Irish folk culture like "Riverdance," to Irish music, which is flourishing in diverse forms as never before, the Fleadh seems well timed to catch a cresting moment of interest in all things Irish.
"I think there's always been a very deep current of affection for the Irish in American culture," said Mr. Cahill, "but Ireland was too oppressed and bedraggled and concerned with its own troubles and inferiority complex to take advantage of it.
"What's happened in the late 20th century is that Ireland has come into its own as a place that could support the arts, so now you see Irish culture taking off like crazy, and not just there or in the U.S. You go to Italy, and they're just nuts for Irish music right now."
Music is definitely at the center of the Fleadh, which will include about 60 acts on three music stages plus a fourth for literature and theater Saturday and Sunday on Randalls Island. There will be about 30 acts for each of the one-day festivals June 20 in Chicago and June 28 in San Francisco. Among other acts scheduled this year are the Irish musicians Tommy Makem, the Saw Doctors and Altan and Mary Black, and non-Irish musicians like Nanci Griffith, John Lee Hooker, Wilco and the Indigo Girls.
Long before anyone envisioned huge, big-bucks marketing extravaganzas, the fleadhs existed in Ireland as loose-knit musical celebrations. They careered along amiably for centuries as provincial festivals with musicians playing in pubs and on street corners, became more institutionalized in the 1950's, often including musical competitions, and have continued to grow from there.
"I played the pipes at my first one in Mullingar in 1950," said Paddy Moloney, of the traditional Irish band the Chieftains. "It was a wonderful thing, but no one expected it to grow into what it's become."
In 1990, the English promoter, Vince Power of the Mean Fiddler Organization, staged the first of his London Fleadhs, which have been a huge annual event ever since. The first American Guinness Fleadh was staged last year on Randalls Island by Mean Fiddler and Festival Marketing of New York and produced by Joe Killian, who founded the Central Park Summerstage concerts and was director of concerts for Radio City Music Hall.
It doesn't take a cynic to think that commercial as well as artistic instincts went into the decision to build the American fleadhs around both Irish musicians and big-name non-Irish performers.
But one of the most remarkable aspects of the event is the way the intensely Irish focus meshes so well with acts ranging from the Latino rock of Los Lobos to the Texas honky-tonk of Joe Ely to singer-songwriters like Ms. Chapman or Ms. Griffith.
Musicians say that partly reflects the nature of much American music, which has deep roots in Irish and Celtic folk songs and ballads, and the musical affinity between so much of the music of the Western world and Irish music.

Music as 'Part Of the Genetic Code'
"I'll tell you something, we felt more at home in Ireland than we did in South America," said Steve Berlin of the eclectic rock band Los Lobos, who appeared with the Chieftains two years ago on "Santiago," an album that explored the Gaelic and Spanish music of Northern Spain.
"I'm not sure what it is," he said. "But there's a specific and almost palpable similarity between Irish culture and Mexican culture. Maybe it's the way that music is everywhere. It's part of the genetic code of the culture."
The affinity no doubt also mirrors the way the Irish diaspora and its traditions suffuse American life. Thus, bands at the Fleadh include groups like the Prodigals, New York-based Irish-Americans who borrow from both cultures but whose music is still indelibly Irish.
But others say Irish music travels so well because at its roots the culture has always been both intensely local and possessed by a sort of visceral pantheism. Mr. Cahill says Irish culture from antiquity has always had the same ecumenical qualities as it does now.
"From the start, Irish culture was always a mix of pagan and Christian; it's always had very emotional ties to the earth, to cosmic events, to the idea of the world as a magical place," he said. "In that sense it's very flexible, protean, transportable. So the druidic aspects of Irish culture have a lot in common, for example, with the nature religions of North America."
The other striking aspect of the Irish music at the Fleadh is how amazingly diverse it is, but how much even the most stridently modern music is still animated by traditional Irish sounds.
Thus, for example, the Saw Doctors, a popular, raucous Irish rock band who got together in the small Galway County town of Tuam in 1987, include both primal rock sounds with melodies and instrumentation -- pipes, flutes, tin whistles -- that could be nothing but Irish.
"We're the first generation of Irish people to have grown up listening to traditional Irish music in the age of mass media," said Leo Moran, a guitarist and singer in the group. "We're the first generation who grew up with TV and radio, who could want to mix the Ramones with traditional Irish songs. So I like to borrow from all my favorite kinds of music: Hank Williams, Steve Earle, English punky stuff. But I've still got traditional Irish music in my blood, I guess."
The prosperity, economic and cultural, of course, could be short-lived and the Irish sense of tragedy is deep enough to make anyone wonder how long this vogue lasts.
Still, the current moment feels like a wry, Irish joke on history.
"We've always been the the victimized, not the victimizers, the colonized, not the colonizers" said Andrea Corr of the Corrs, three sisters and a brother from Dundalk, Ireland, whose band combines modern pop and traditional Irish sounds. "And now, in music, in literature, the Irish seem to be everywhere. It's very ironic, isn't it?"

HEADLINE: Milosevic Agrees to Let Diplomatic Observers Into Kosovo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has agreed to allow diplomatic observers to enter and move through the province of Kosovo, where Serbian troops and policemen have been attacking the ethnic Albanian majority, senior Administration officials said today.
The first observer missions could take place as early as Monday, the officials said, after weekend negotiations in Belgrade, the Serbian capital, between Mr. Milosevic and the American Ambassador to Macedonia, Christopher Hill. 
 Mr. Hill will be allowed to escort the chief negotiator for the ethnic Albanians, Fehmi Agani, and presumably bring journalists along to view areas where the Serbian military and police have been operating, the officials said. Mr. Milosevic's forces have prevented foreigners from traveling in Kosovo, Serbia's southernmost province, and Mr. Agani was denied access to those areas on Thursday.
But the officials stressed that the new agreements did not absolve Mr. Milosevic of responsibility for using fear and force to drive residents from villages along Kosovo's border with Albania, an operation apparently intended to prevent the infiltration of arms and new fighters from outside Kosovo.
 In Kosovo, members of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army said Serbian troops were removing bodies from areas observers might visit and concealing other evidence of their attacks.
"Ethnic cleansing, whether as a goal or a tactic, is still a crime," a senior American official said. "We cannot ignore that extraordinarily grave events occurred last week, and we cannot allow Milosevic to get a breather because some diplomatic observers are let in."
The official said Washington and its allies continued to insist on the withdrawal of Serbian special police and Yugoslav Army units from Kosovo and on full access for other foreigners. "Just having some diplomatic observers who come back and say, 'Gosh, this is terrible and they've destroyed the place,' isn't sufficient," the official said.
In the last two weeks, Mr. Milosevic, the former President of Serbia, has ordered a crackdown against the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and, in particular, against the Kosovo Liberation Army, which is fighting for independence. Western governments do not support independence for Kosovo, fearing that it would reopen the Balkan ethnic and religious caldron.
While at least 250 people have been killed, 10,000 refugees have fled into Albania and 50,000 people have been displaced from their homes, according to an estimate given in London today by the British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook, the West has done little but plan new meetings.
"President Milosevic over the past week has crossed the threshold," said Mr. Cook, whose Government holds the rotating presidency of the European Union. "The use of tanks, of artillery, of the might of the military army against civilian centers of population is wholly unacceptable within the modern Europe."
Mr. Cook and Prime Minister Tony Blair have decided to push Washington and the West "to a much tougher policy, both politically and militarily," a senior British official said. Mr. Blair told his Cabinet on Thursday that the use of force may be necessary to get Mr. Milosevic to respond.
The British are circulating a draft Security Council resolution at the United Nations that would authorize NATO to use force "in or over Kosovo," the official said, a move intended in part to put pressure on Russia to act more aggressively against its traditional allies, the Serbs.
"I hope the British are prepared to be out there themselves," a senior American official said today. "I have the feeling they want to be sure that we're out there."
On Monday, the British will be host to a European Union foreign ministers' meeting to press for the imposition of tough economic sanctions -- especially an investment ban, as well as the more symbolic freezing of Serbian assets abroad -- that were suspended at Washington's request when Mr. Milosevic agreed to open talks with Ibrahim Rugova, the leader of Kosovo's Albanians.
Those sanctions were never imposed, because Washington used their suspension as an inducement to Mr. Milosevic to open the talks with Mr. Rugova, even though just a week earlier Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pressed American allies to agree to them.
Washington, too, is now ready to impose those sanctions and to discuss new ones, American officials said today. They said Mr. Milosevic had used the suspension of sanctions as an excuse to crack down in Kosovo, embarrassing the Americans and making a next round of talks with him impossible for Mr. Rugova.
The Americans insist that dialogue -- together with the pressure of new sanctions and the ultimate threat of NATO action -- is the only avenue to a peaceful solution in Kosovo, and that it will continue. But some officials, both American and European, fear that the Milosevic crackdown may mean that any opportunity for a solution is already lost, and that Mr. Rugova's credibility has already suffered too much as the Kosovo Liberation Army gains strength.
The so-called Contact Group on the Balkans -- the United States, Britain, Germany, Italy, France and Russia -- will meet on Wednesday in Paris at the political director level, and could impose the suspended sanctions, officials say. The group will meet at the foreign ministers' level in London on Friday, along with Japan and Canada, and there is a NATO defense ministers' meeting on Thursday in Luxembourg, where Kosovo will be a prime topic.
NATO has already asked for military options and accelerated planning for deployments around Kosovo to prevent a possible regional conflagration. But the British, especially, feel that the problem is within Kosovo, not around it.
Already, the Pentagon has made it clear that it does not favor any new troops to be sent to the Balkans, even as the American forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina are reduced.
And an American threat to Mr. Milosevic of a military response to a crackdown in Kosovo -- a warning first issued by President George Bush and repeated by the Clinton Administration to Mr. Milosevic in 1993 -- remains "on the table." But this threat is "not now a topic of real discussion," a senior official said.
One American official said that in contrast to Bosnia, where Washington let the war go on for three years before acting and involving NATO, the United States has engaged much more rapidly in Kosovo, even if not quickly enough to satisfy the British.
The push for Milosevic-Rugova talks, backed by sanctions and then backed by NATO action if the violence continues, is a strategy that can work, the American official insisted. But as in Bosnia, he said, there is a great reluctance in the White House "to move further into the Balkans, rather than out of it."

HEADLINE: Train Blast Kills 23 and Pakistan Blames India

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 7

 BODY:
A bomb exploded this morning on a crowded railroad train in southern Pakistan, killing 23 people, and the Government immediately blamed Indian secret agents.
The explosion occurred a little after 4 A.M. near Khairpur, in the southern province of Sindh, as the Khyber Mail train was making its run from Karachi to Peshawar. 
 The blast went off under a seat in the middle of a crowded economy-class passenger car, wounding about 32 people in addition to the 23 who were killed, Pakistan Railway officials said.
The dead included four women and two children.
"The bomb blast on the Khyber Mail today is an abominable RAW-sponsored terrorist act," a Foreign Ministry statement said, using the initials of the Indian intelligence organization, the Research and Analysis Wing. "We condemn it."
The Pakistani Minister of Information, Mushahid Hussain, said his Government would provide "hard proof" of Indian involvement.
Indian officials denied the accusation.
The Indian Foreign Ministry, in a brief statement late today, said, "The reported statement of the Pakistan Information Minister regarding India's alleged involvement in the unfortunate train blasts in Sindh province of Pakistan are baseless and false," Agence France-Presse reported.
The railroad's general manager, Naseer Alvi, said the explosion was a case of "clear sabotage."
The explosion and the swift Pakistani reaction appeared likely to increase tensions between the two countries -- longtime enemies that have just stunned the world by setting off rival nuclear tests.
Each has blamed the intelligence services of the other for planting bombs and stirring up trouble among the region's many fractious religious and ethnic groups.
Mr. Hussain, Pakistan's Information Minister, said the Government had an Indian agent in custody who had been captured near the Indian border.
He said the Indian had confessed to similar acts of terrorism, including 10 bombings in a 9-week period this year that resulted in 16 deaths and that wounded another 93 people.
He suggested, too, that a bombing earlier this week in a movie theater in Lahore, which killed three people and wrecked the theater, was part of an Indian-sponsored series of terrorist acts. He said the main suspect was an Indian citizen.
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, on a tour of Persian Gulf emirates and Saudi Arabia in hopes of garnering financial support in the face of impending sanctions, announced plans to visit Britain, Canada and the United States in an effort to build support among Pakistani expatriots. He is scheduled to be in New York on June 16.
Money sent home by Pakistanis working abroad is one of the main sources of income in the country's beleaguered economy.

HEADLINE: Aeromexico Strike Marks Transition

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 7

 BODY:
Alejandra Barrales Magdaleno's views about unions and labor were forged flying into American cities as a $700-a-month Aeromexico flight attendant, often alongside those from United States airlines whose salaries were four times as high.
Now as the leader of Mexico's 2,000-member flight attendants' union, Ms. Barrales symbolizes the more independent and vigorous labor movement emerging here a year after the death of Fidel Velazquez, the union czar who kept workers submissive for decades. 
 With Mexico's economy strengthening after years of crisis, Ms. Barrales brought to a modestly-successful conclusion on Saturday evening the first nationwide strike by one of the politically independent unions that formed a new federation last year. These unions are an important element in Mexico's democratic transition.
"This strike strengthened not just our union but the entire workers' movement," Ms. Barrales told hundreds of cheering flight attendants in an assembly that approved a new salary and benefits package by a unanimous vote.
The contrast could hardly be more dramatic between Mr. Velazquez, who was anti-communist, anti-American and -- when he died last year at the age of 97 -- antediluvian, and Ms. Barrales, who is 30 years old, politically independent, and an admirer of the American, Canadian and European labor movements.
"She's an impressive, dynamic new leader," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who has met her to discuss new alliances among North American unions. "She's the kind of new labor leadership we're seeing in Mexico."
There are now fewer strikes in Mexico because so many have been crushed. In fact, the Government helped management during the flight attendants' strike by seizing control of the airline to keep planes flying.
But during a week of picketing and negotiations, Ms. Barrales marshaled middle class support and focused international pressure on management, finally wringing modest salary increases and new benefits from the airline.
Despite Mexican workers' reputation for being among the world's most long-suffering, the outcome suggests that after nearly two decades of falling wages, some want to lodge more aggressive demands.
Graciela Bensusan, an academic who studies the labor movement here, said that during years of economic turmoil, strikes have declined dramatically -- from 675 in 1982 to 39 last year -- partly because "workers have been willing to accept huge salary cuts to save their jobs."
"This strike is emblematic," she said, "because it shows that now some workers are willing to return to mobilizations as a way to improve working conditions."
The Mexican Workers Confederation, known by its initials in Spanish, C.T.M., which Mr. Velazquez headed, is still Mexico's largest labor body by far, representing some 10 million workers. But last year Ms. Barrales helped found a rival federation, the National Workers Union, which now represents some 1.5 million members and appears to be growing fast.
Francisco Hernandez Juarez, the leader of the telephone workers union, is president of the new federation. "Mexico's labor system was designed for control," he said in an interview. "The unions were taken from the workers and given to labor leaders who work with the Government and the company owners.
"The leaders get rich, and the Government and owners use the unions to impose economic programs and to keep labor costs low. We think its time to even things out. We want Mexico to compete and grow, but people can't eat macroeconomic indicators. They need better salaries."
During the first decades after Mr. Velazquez helped forge the post-revolutionary labor movement in the 1930's and 1940's, his official federation, which forms one wing of the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, won important improvements in wages and working conditions in exchange for turning out the vote on election day.
But after 1982, the year of a watershed debt crisis, Mr. Velazquez's official unions worked mainly to discipline workers into tightening their belts as inflation and devaluations cut into real wages.
Sidney Weintraub, an economist at Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies, cited Government statistics in a recent article outlining the extraordinary erosion of Mexican wages. In 1980, he said, Mexican manufacturing workers earned 22 percent of what their American counterparts earned. By 1996, Mexican wages had fallen to 8 percent of American wages, he said.
Few groups of workers have felt this decline more painfully than the country's airline employees. In the wake of a 1988 privatization, two-thirds of Aeromexico's 12,000-member work force were eliminated and workers who managed to keep their jobs lost pensions, seniority rights, and virtually every other benefit.
"I tried to get help from the union," recalled Ms. Barrales, who was 21 years old and had been flying with Aeromexico for two years at the time of the privatization. "But there was no strength, no support, and we had to begin again at zero."
If some Aeromexico workers viewed the sacrifices as an investment in the company's future, the altruism soured in 1994, when Aeromexico's high-flying chief executive suddenly fled Mexico after Government accusations that he had embezzled $72 million from the airline. He, in turn, through his lawyers, accused PRI officials of shaking the airline down for $8 million in election year contributions even as the company was sliding into bankruptcy.
Since Ms. Barrales was elected president of her union in 1995, she has been watching Aeromexico's balance sheets, which have been improving. She said the company earned nearly $100 million in profits last year. An Aeromexico spokesman declined to divulge the official figure.
Before the strike, Aeromexico's most senior flight attendants earned about $7,400 a year, compared with about $42,000 on United States airlines, according to union statistics. Saturday's agreement will raise salaries by 18 percent and establish a retirement plan.
"You're going to see more unions ready to defend worker's interests," Ms. Barrales said.

HEADLINE: Religious Leaders Urge Clinton To Press China On Persecution

BYLINE: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

 BODY:
From Tibetan Buddhists to Roman Catholics to evangelical Christians, a broad array of religious leaders is urging President Clinton to use his summit meeting later this month in Beijing to press the Chinese Government to end the repression of religious believers there.
Religious persecution abroad has increasingly become a major cause of concern among members of the American clergy, many of whom say that China is one of the most consistent violators of religious freedom. Now rights advocates long concerned about the Chinese occupation of Tibet have joined forces with Christian clergy pushing for more freedom for Chinese churchgoers. 
 More than 200 American religious leaders have signed a letter to the President asking him to put pressure on the Chinese Government to release all religious prisoners, to rescind decrees forcing Christian churches to register with the Government, and to open negotiations about the future of Tibet with the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan Buddhists' exiled leader.
"This summit," the religious leaders say in their letter, "will certainly have great benefits for future economic and trade relations between the United States and China. As important as these issues are, however, human rights, and religious liberty in particular, must not be ignored."
The letter, drafted by the Center for Jewish and Christian Values in Washington, is signed by people whose names rarely appear on the same page. They include two Roman Catholic cardinals and more than a dozen bishops, a spokesman for the Church of Scientology, Reform and Orthodox rabbis, evangelical Christian ministers and broadcasters, Muslims, Tibetan Buddhists, Southern Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians, African-American religious leaders and Orthodox Christians.
"It is hard for us, as Americans, to imagine what it must be like to live in a country that denies its citizens basic human rights," said Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua, Archbishop of Philadelphia, who signed the letter along with John Cardinal O'Connor of New York. "For that reason, I join my brother bishops and other concerned religious leaders in strongly urging President Clinton to help open the door to religious liberties for the Chinese people."
Thousands are expected to attend a rally for Tibet in Washington next Monday. The rally, which will follow a sold-out benefit concert over the weekend, was organized by a slate of pro-Tibet groups. Mr. Clinton is to travel to China on June 24, and advocates for Tibet see his trip as the best chance yet to press China to enter negotiations.
"This time," said Bhuchung K. Tsering, director of the International Campaign for Tibet, "we want the President to come back from Beijing not with another statement saying they are ready to talk, but with concrete assurance from the Chinese side that they will sit down with the Dalai Lama and resolve the issue of Tibet."

HEADLINE: Report Tying Abortion To Welfare Is Rejected

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
A team of Rutgers University researchers hired by the New Jersey government to examine the effects of the state's new welfare policy found that it has contributed to an increase in abortions, but the state has rejected the findings, and asked for revisions of the report.
In a December report, commissioned by the State Department of Human Services and the Federal Department of Health and Human Services and obtained by The New York Times, the Rutgers researchers said the welfare overhaul provision known as the family cap, which was enacted in 1992 and cuts off extra benefits from welfare recipients who have additional children, has caused some women to abort their pregnancies. 
 "The Family Development Program does appear to exert a small but non-trivial effect on abortion rates, adding about 240 abortions per year over what would be expected due to trend and population composition changes," the report said. There were 31,860 abortions in New Jersey in 1996.
The Rutgers findings are likely to add new fuel to the nationwide debate over welfare because 20 other states have imposed family caps similar to New Jersey's.
Welfare recipients generally have abortions at a higher rate than other women: In New Jersey, in the quarter ending December 1991, the abortion rate for the welfare population was 27 per 1,000 compared with 4 per 1,000 for all New Jersey women of child-bearing age. And although the abortion rate in New Jersey, and nationwide, declined between 1991 and 1996, the abortion rate among New Jersey's welfare recipients rose during the same period. By 1996, the Rutgers report found, the gap had widened further, with 29 abortions per 1,000 women receiving welfare, compared with 3 per 1,000 women in the general population.
But the state has not accepted those findings, calling the report a draft that needs substantial revision.
In a May 14 letter to the research team, the Department of Human Services said the document should be labeled a draft, criticized the methodology and asked for a re-working that would explain all the difficulties of determining whether it was the welfare policy that had caused the increase in abortions. The letter also questioned the validity of studying the behavior of the welfare population before and after the law changed, since the changes themselves may have altered that population, causing some recipients to get off welfare, and other people to avoid it.
But the lawyers challenging the family cap provision contend that the state's response reflects political problems, not methodological ones.
"We think this is a final report that the state is trying to cover up by saying it's a draft," said Martha Davis, a lawyer with the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, one of the groups challenging the family cap. "And we think the real reason for their objections is concern about what legislators will do if they see the conclusions the Rutgers researchers have drawn."
Jacqueline Tencza, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Human Services, denied that interpretation. Rather, she said, the state is committed to understanding what effects the family cap has had, and is concerned about the release of draft findings based on a methodology that the state says is flawed.
"This is just a draft," she said. "Neither of the two clients, us or Health and Human Services in Washington, has approved it, and it's not final until it's approved. We want to make sure that what we get is good social science research that is clear about the effects of the policy."
The question of how welfare recipients' reproductive decisions are affected by a family cap, removing any financial incentive to have more children, has been one of the most hotly argued issues in the debate over welfare.
Some conservatives have argued that family caps help discourage welfare recipients from having more babies than they can support, and prevent long-term welfare dependency. But in an unusual political alliance, the Roman Catholic Church and conservative Christian groups joined with advocates for the poor to argue against family caps, on the ground that they would encourage abortion and increase child poverty by forcing welfare families to stretch their meager benefits too far.
New Jersey's family cap went into effect in 1993, under a Federal waiver allowing the state to conduct welfare experiments. Two years later, the Federal welfare overhaul bill opened the way for any state to adopt such a policy, and family caps are now in effect in 20 other states.
"The Rutgers findings have very serious implications for children in every state that has instituted a family cap," said Regina Purcell, a spokeswoman for the Catholic Conference of New Jersey. "It's important to remember not only the number of babies that were aborted due to the family cap, but also the number of children born who were denied assistance. As of December, more than 25,000 children in New Jersey had been denied cash assistance because of the family cap."
Last year, Ms. Davis's group, along with the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey and Gibbons Del Deo, a New Jersey law firm, filed suit charging that the family cap violated the state constitution by interfering with women's reproductive rights and treated children differently depending on their birth status.
In late February, in the course of preparing a summary judgment motion in the case, Ms. Davis said, the lawyers asked the state whether the final report from Rutgers, which had been long scheduled for release in December, was available.
A lawyer in the Attorney General's office gave them a copy of the December report, which they shared with representatives of the Catholic Church and others who oppose the family cap at a May 12 meeting. Ms. Davis said the lawyers challenging the cap had also asked for, and been granted, permission to talk to the Rutgers researchers.
But, she said, on May 14 -- the same day the department's letter went out to the researchers -- the Attorney General's office called to say that the report was only a draft and to withdraw permission to talk to the researchers.
"This is a report filed in December, and there was plenty of time for back and forth about the methodology before May," Ms. Davis said. "The timing, together with the fact that this was in no way labeled a draft, as an earlier interim report had been, lead us to conclude that something else was going on here."
Ms. Tencza said there were no political machinations involved: discussions of the methodology had gone on since the report was filed, she said, and the May 14 letter only reflected continuing discussions. And she said that the lawyer for the Attorney General's office who gave out the report was simply unaware that it was a draft.
"It was an oversight, and it should not have been released," Ms. Tencza said. "This is very complicated, very important social science research, and there are many serious concerns about methodology. We're not confident that there is any methodology that would result in establishing a cause-and-effect relationship. That's one thing we've learned through this process."
The letter questioned the researchers' use of trends in abortion and birth rates to estimate what those rates might have been without the welfare changes, and the suggestion that the welfare changes may have caused the difference. And it said that the researchers need not redo the study, but should submit a revised version making clear the difficulties of determining causality.
Michael Camasso, the lead researcher on the $1 million evaluation project, declined to discuss the specifics of the December report or the re-working now under way.
"We have three different studies of the family cap, this pre/post research, a cost-benefit analysis, and another using an experimental group and a control group," he said. "All I can say is that the final reports on all three, which are not that far off, will present the most comprehensive view possible of the effects of the family cap."
The lawyers challenging the family cap are convinced that the policy encourages abortions, both from the Rutgers research and from interviews with welfare recipients.
"We showed the report to outside experts, including statisticians and economists, and they agreed that it shows that the family cap is causing women to have abortions," said Lenora Lapidus, legal director of the New Jersey A.C.L.U. "In a state where there's been this strong effort to cut back on access on abortion, there's a real irony here. This state now has two choices, they can backpedal and try to change the study. Or with the Governor leading, they can take the high road and reconsider the policy."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI TO PLACE DISABLED MOTHERS IN WORKFARE JOBS

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
In an ambitious and controversial effort to increase the number of welfare recipients participating in New York City's workfare program, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will soon begin requiring physically and mentally disabled mothers to work for their welfare checks.
The new policy began quietly this weekend when city officials ordered about 800 disabled women to report to welfare offices for screening into the new 20-hour-a-week workfare program. The women, who showed up at city offices clutching plastic pill bottles and crumpled medical forms on Saturday, had already been examined by city doctors who classified them as permanently or temporarily unemployable since they suffer from seizures, mental illness, severe arthritis and other ailments. 
 But under the new rules, the mothers will be required to work in jobs tailored to their specific impairments by nonprofit groups accustomed to working with the disabled, including Goodwill Industries of Greater New York. Women who cannot walk, for instance, might type or stuff envelopes. Only those women with disabilities severe enough to qualify for Federal disability benefits will be exempt.
City officials say the old system, which allowed the disabled to stay home until city doctors certified that they could work, denied job training, work experience and career counseling to people who desperately needed those services. State officials, who will help finance and oversee the new program, say about 12,000 disabled mothers will participate in workfare initially, with the first group starting in two months. The remaining 21,000 disabled welfare mothers may follow if the program works well, city officials say.
But the policy shift, coming five months after Mr. Giuliani vowed to move virtually all city welfare recipients into workfare jobs, was quickly condemned by advocates for the poor, who said it violates state law and endangers the lives of the sickest and most vulnerable New Yorkers.
The clash between advocates and city officials over the issue marks only the beginning of a contentious debate that will likely land in civil court, and one that already swirls across much of the nation as states like Florida, Oregon and Wisconsin push disabled people on public assistance into the workplace. "The ethic has changed and a lot of states are trying to reach into that population," said Jack Tweedie, who tracks welfare policy for the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Under Federal law, mothers on public assistance can receive welfare checks for only five years, regardless of whether they are disabled or not. State officials may exempt 20 percent of their welfare mothers from the time limit, but many are still pushing as many women into work as they can, fearful that more than 20 percent will still need benefits when the deadline hits.
"The clock is ticking and we want to help more participants work," Mr. Tweedie said of the disabled on public assistance. "The hard part is figuring out how to do it."
In New York City, where welfare officials have been sued for assigning people with less serious medical ailments to workfare jobs that threaten their health, advocates for the poor found the new policy particularly alarming.
Last month, a state judge ordered the city to create a process that would allow welfare recipients to challenge work assignments for health and safety reasons. But that process would apply to welfare recipients without severe medical problems, workers with asthma who can answer telephones but cannot scrub dusty garages, for instance. This group is classified as employable, but with limitations.
The city's new policy is directed toward a group that city doctors say are actually unable to work, and advocates say it will be impossible to find suitable work for this group. About 4,000 welfare mothers have been deemed permanently unemployable by the city's medical contractor, Health Services Systems. About 30,000 have been classified as temporarily unemployable, meaning they cannot work for three to six months.
They are young women like Daisy Rivera, 28, who was deemed permanently unemployable because she suffers from severe asthma and weighs 400 pounds. They are older women like Evelyn Valle, 39, who hobbled to the welfare office, leaning hard on a scratched wooden cane because of the arthritis in her hip. Or like Aglaee Muniz, 57, who takes medication for severe depression and diabetes and was also classified as permanently unable to work.
Advocates for the poor say state law clearly exempts such people from participating in work activities.
"This is mind-boggling," said Susan Sternberg, a staff attorney at the Brooklyn Neighborhood Office of the Legal Aid Society, who represents the workfare workers with medical limitations in their suit against the city. "These are people who the city has already found to be unable to participate in work activities. This means hundreds more people are going to be sicker and risk death."
But state and city officials say the policy is perfectly legal because the law also requires disabled people who have "the potential to be restored to self-sufficiency" to participate in vocational rehabilitation programs.
City officials say the new program has been carefully planned to meet the needs of this population, which was unable to participate in the traditional workfare program along with the 32,000 current participants. The work sites will be chosen by officials at four groups, Goodwill Industries, the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, the National Center for Disability Services and the Federation Employment and Guidance Service, who will safeguard the health and safety of the new workers.
All told, the groups must place at least 228 mothers in unsubsidized jobs for at least 90 days by March 1999.
"We have to be concerned about the disability, but that doesn't mean these people are not worthy of being given an opportunity to be productive members of the community, to use the talents they have," said Debra Sproles, the spokeswoman for the Human Resources Administration, which runs the city's welfare programs.
"This is a whole group that was forgotten about," Ms. Sproles said. "We want to proceed cautiously, but this is a great step toward bringing these people back into the fold."
On Saturday, caseworkers for the four groups used a two-page questionnaire to screen hundreds of mothers, who were either temporarily disabled or permanently disabled women who had been denied Federal disability benefits.
Those with serious disabilities were given an appointment for a more complete evaluation, which will be reviewed by the State Office of Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals With Disabilities. Most of those women will ultimately work 20 hours a week for three months, and 35 hours a week after that, while receiving career counseling, job search training and other services. Twenty other New York counties, including Westchester and Onondaga, also received state financing for similar programs.
Those welfare recipients who are determined to lack serious disabilities will be re-examined by city doctors and may eventually end up in the traditional workfare program, although they can appeal that decision, city officials said. And those with the most severe medical problems will be told to apply for Federal disability benefits.
No one knows how smoothly the new process will work. Advocates for the poor in Wisconsin, which has also eliminated broad work exemptions for the disabled, said they have not encountered widespread problems. Jason A. Turner, the recently appointed chief of New York City's welfare agency, was the architect of that state's welfare program.
But the sheer size of New York City's welfare population makes the job infinitely more complex. Wisconsin has only about 9,000 adults on public assistance statewide, while New York City has about 200,000 mothers on welfare, including the 33,000 disabled women.
Hundreds of those women filled the waiting rooms of the city's welfare offices on Saturday, sitting on hard, plastic chairs as they thumbed through plastic bags and time-worn envelopes for their medical records. Most seemed stunned to learn that they were going to work after city doctors had told them that they could not.
"I work with people who can't see, who can't hear," a caseworker from one of the nonprofit groups told a doubtful woman, who said a stroke left her with chronic seizures. "I work with people who have only one leg, in wheelchairs. We're here to help you find jobs."
One 30-year-old woman, who said she suffered from mental illness, said the interview gave her hope that she might be able to work for the first time. "People think just because there's something wrong, you can't work," said the woman, who refused to give her name. "That's not true. You can work."
But other women left the city welfare offices fearful that they would be unable to function in the new program.
"I don't understand it," said Ms. Rivera, the woman with asthma who weighs 400 pounds, as she fumbled in her backpack for the letter from the city doctor who determined that she was permanently unable to work.
"They say I'm a sick woman," she said helplessly. "I don't know how I'm going to handle this."
