HEADLINE: Praise for Dissident Turned President;
Korean-Americans Welcome Kim Dae Jung to New Jersey

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

DATELINE: CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., June 7

 BODY:
The initial shock has worn off, a schoolteacher named Joung Pyo Jyoung said today, but she still marvels at how Kim Dae Jung, the longtime dissident, came to be elected president of South Korea, her homeland.
"It is a surprising thing," she said at the very moment that Mr. Kim entered a Cliffside Park banquet hall where she and 500 other Korean-Americans had gathered to honor him today, his first full day of a state visit that is to take him across the United States this week. 
 Ms. Jyoung was hardly the only one here to express amazement at a political odyssey that can be compared to the triumphs of Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia and other champions of lost causes.
Successive South Korean dictators tried to have Mr. Kim killed, coming extremely close more than once. In 1980, the military regime then in charge sentenced him to the gallows, but chose instead to send him into exile in the United States. Even after he returned home in 1985, and after South Korea then nurtured a fledgling democracy, he seemed destined to spend the rest of his years in permanent opposition.
But there he was today, his country's leader since February, walking triumphantly into the banquet hall with a slight limp, the legacy of an assassination attempt.
"Some people now say that after all he went through, maybe he was meant to be president," said Ms. Jyoung, a public-school teacher from Bayside, Queens. "When you go through so much, maybe you become a better person."
His tortured road to political power was clearly on Mr. Kim's own mind as he spoke to the crowd for 35 minutes. "It's a funny thing," he said to laughter as he began his remarks in Korean, "but nobody believed that I'd be standing here as president."
A Roman Catholic, he told of how after his election he had called on Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, South Korea's prelate. The Cardinal, he said, had observed that his election should stand as a model to young Koreans of how perseverance can lead to success.
That's true, Mr. Kim said he replied, but something else counted, too. "It is important to live long," he said.
Mr. Kim, 74, seemed to enjoy wading through the crowd and shaking hands with the Korean-Americans, many of whom had left South Korea 20 or 30 years ago but still had deep emotional and economic ties to their homeland.
It would be an exaggeration to say that they greeted him with wild enthusiasm.
He was applauded warmly and often by the invited guests -- for the most part businessmen, academics and clergymen who came from New York City or from this part of Bergen County, N.J., where thousands of Korean-Americans have settled. He was also ardently praised as a fighter for democracy by Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey.
But there was an underlying restraint. It was a sharp contrast to the emotional outbursts that Mr. Kim, a gifted speaker, is capable of producing, especially in crowds from Cholla Province, his native land in the southwest corner of South Korea.
Some who came to the Palisadium banquet hall, on the Hudson River, said they would probably not have voted for him if they had had the chance. They were not sure at first, they said, that he was the right person to guide the country through its most serious financial crisis in decades. Like millions of South Koreans, they had long heard military-dominated governments denounce Mr. Kim as an irresponsible populist -- and soft on North Korea's Communists, to boot.
But now, in his fourth month in office, he seems to have won over even the skeptics. And if the applause was not boisterous, it was nonetheless ample. The most frequently expressed opinion was that Mr. Kim had thus far handled the crisis well.
"We are expecting a lot of things from him," said Augustin Chi, who owns a Burger King outlet near the banquet hall. "We give him heartfelt support -- I can say 100 percent."
Jay Kim, a health statistician for the Federal Government, noted Koreans' well-earned reputation for being political battlers, but said everyone had to rally around the new leader now. "It's a very tough time," he said. "We can't afford to fight among ourselves." Referring to President Kim, he added: "I can't say we are all enthusiastic and want to hug him. It's more: 'Please do well.' "
President Kim arrived on Saturday and stayed overnight at the Intercontinental Hotel in Manhattan under tight security, which was equally intense in Cliffside Park. In the morning, he attended Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, and met with John Cardinal O'Connor afterward.
This evening, he was honored at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan, where he helped dedicate a new gallery of Korean art.
On Monday, Mr. Kim is scheduled to visit the New York Stock Exchange, where he can be counted on to underline a likely theme of this visit: reassurance to foreign investors that South Korea is fundamentally sound. After New York, he goes to Washington for meetings with President Clinton and a speech to Congress, before journeying on to Los Angeles, a center of Korean-American life.
Mr. Kim told the Korean-Americans here that his Government supported "with its heart" their choice to resettle in the United States. He spoke about his financial-recovery measures. But he also said the emphasis that past Korean leaders put on national security and economic growth, to the exclusion of almost everything else, was not good enough.
"Democracy and open markets are the basic policies of Korea now," he said.
It was a reminder of his credentials as a pro-democracy campaigner, not that anyone here needed that lesson.
Ms. Jyoung, the schoolteacher from Bayside, talked with a reporter who said, only half in jest, that the Korean words he knew best were "down with the military dictator," a phrase that echoed through thousands of anti-Government protests.
"They already did it," Ms. Jyoung said as Mr. Kim entered the room. "The dictatorship is gone, and I hope we don't hear those words anymore."

HEADLINE: City Council Says It Can Make Up Shortfall

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
The skirmishes over New York City's next budget continued yesterday as City Council leaders ventured into the labyrinthine world of property taxes to patch a $251 million hole that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had blown into their budget a day earlier.
Meanwhile, Mr. Giuliani's aides fiercely attacked the Council's budget as illegal. They described Council members as spendthrifts who had increased spending on themselves in the last four years even as the Mayor's office had substantially lowered its own expenses. 
 These were the latest shots in a budget battle that erupted on Friday, when the Council defied Mr. Giuliani by adopting a budget without his endorsement. On Saturday, the Mayor countered by announcing that expected revenues for next year would fall short of earlier estimates by $251 million. The move was intended to force the Council either to accept eventual spending vetoes by the Mayor or raise property taxes -- the only tax over which the legislative body has control -- to balance the budget.
But aides to Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, said last night that the Council had another response up its sleeve. It will meet this morning and, turning to an arcane section of the city's property tax law, draw the $251 million from a reserve fund that covers property tax shortfalls, the aides said. Taxes will not go up, they insisted.
"Nobody will pay more as a result of the actions that the City Council is taking," said Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director. "Property tax is the most complicated tax in the world, and it's being used by the City Council to one-up the Office of Management and Budget," the Mayor's budget office.
Earlier yesterday, the Mayor and his top aides hunkered down inside City Hall, as Mr. Giuliani prepared to use, for the first time in his mayoralty, his line-item veto power and slash up to $200 million from the $34.08 billion spending plan. In the budgetary tit for tat, the Mayor's office said that it had conjured up "six scenarios" to respond to any maneuver by the Council, and predicted victory as long as the Council did not come up with a seventh counterattack.
Also, the Mayor's aides said the Council's budget violated the City Charter by not declaring how much money each Council Committee would receive; the Speaker deliberately left that information out, the aides said, to allow him to covertly move money around to punish disloyal members and reward loyal ones.
"The public has a right to ask, 'Where's the money, City Council?' " said Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations. "Because right now you can't tell how the City Council spends its money, how much goes to each committee, how much is doled out in member goodies to individual members of the City Council."
Mr. McMahon said the information was left out because it was too cumbersome, and added that the Mayor's office had never complained about this practice in the past.
The escalating fight over $251 million -- which represents seven-tenths of a percent of the $34.08 billion budget -- underscored yet again how political hostilities have complicated the annual budget negotiations between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone, who until now shared harmonious relations and, in the recession of the mid-1990's, were able to agree on deep cuts in services in almost every area of the city.
In a normal year -- and especially this fiscal year, which is expected to end June 30 with a record $2 billion surplus -- budget officials from both sides might have settled such picayune differences over drinks at one of the many bars near City Hall.
But budget talks collapsed last Monday amid much chest-beating and a political deadlock. The Mayor, who wants to use city money to help build a new home for the Yankees, possibly on the West Side of Manhattan, wanted Mr. Vallone to drop his call for a November referendum on the issue. But the Speaker refused, saying the referendum had nothing to do with budget talks. Mr. Vallone is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, and his political base strongly opposes any suggestion of moving the Yankees out of the Bronx into Manhattan; what's more, in a general race against Gov. George E. Pataki, a referendum on the November ballot would increase voter turnout in Democratic strongholds like the Bronx and Manhattan.
So on Friday, the Council passed its own budget for the first time since it acquired the authority to do so under the City Charter revision of 1989. But the Charter gives the Mayor a crucial advantage because only he can determine so-called revenue estimates for the budget -- the amount of nonproperty taxes the city expects to collect and the amount of money the city expects to get from Washington and Albany.
In passing its own budget, the Council used the revenue estimates projected by the Mayor in April; hours later, the Mayor put the Council's plan in disarray by saying that the revenues were actually $251 million lower, mainly because of state and Federal money the city had expected but was not granted.
Last night, Council officials said they would take $251 million from a property tax reserve fund. On average, residential and commercial property owners pay $10.36 for every $100 that their property is worth -- giving the city a total of $8.1 billion in revenues, Council officials said.
But not all of that amount is used in the city's budget: for example, only $7.4 billion is included in the budget for the next fiscal year beginning on July 1. The rest, about $700 million, is put into the reserve fund, which exists to cover up any shortfall in property tax collections, Council officials said. Taking $251 million from that fund would keep it around the level where it has been, $494 million, since 1990, officials said.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Hardest Hit by Asia Crisis Are Those at the Margins
The most common and desperate victims of the Asian financial crisis have been those already at the margins of society -- those who had almost nothing before and who now, somehow, have even less. Reports from aid workers and anecdotal evidence suggest significant increases in death rates, school dropouts and malnutrition. Some experts say that the legacy of the crisis will be felt long after the region's economies are purring again. A1
 
Tale of Two Cities in Italy
Pompeii, the famed Italian town that holds both ancient ruins and a religious shrine, is expecting an infusion of money and visitors as the millennium approaches. But the prospect is inflaming a longstanding rift between two sides of the town -- one crawling with tourists, guides, and archeologists, and the other where the unemployment rate is 30 percent and stray dogs sleep in the sun. A4

HEADLINE: $34 Billion Merger Expected By Norwest and Wells Fargo

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
In the banking industry's latest megamerger, the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis and Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco plan to join forces and may announce a $34 billion deal as early as today, according to people close to both companies.
Although the transaction is structured as a so-called merger of equals, Norwest's chief executive, Richard Kovacevich, will run the combined company as chief executive while Wells' chief executive, Paul Hazen, will relinquish that post. The new bank will be based in San Francisco and retain the Wells Fargo name. The new bank, with combined assets of $185 billion, will rank as the sixth largest in the nation if all other bank mergers announced this year are completed. 
 The logic of the merger follows a now familiar pattern: Many banks, stuck in an industry with little revenue growth and heightened competition from brokerage firms, mutual funds and credit card companies, see size as a solution to their woes. By bulking up, banks believe they can become more profitable by dominating certain markets and enjoying greater economies of scale.
It is the latest in a string of bank-related blockbusters this year that have surprised Wall Street, including the mergers of Citicorp and Travelers Group, BankAmerica Corporation and Nationsbank Corporation and First Chicago NBD and Banc One Corporation.
Mr. Kovacevich, considered to be one of the most disciplined and talented executives in banking, said in a recent interview that he felt no need to merge with another bank and that he found the recent prices being paid for banks to be exorbitant.
On the other hand, Mr. Kovacevich has said he would buy another bank if the price was right, and in this case it apparently was. Norwest will exchange about 10 shares for each Wells share, representing a premium of only about 10 percent to Wells' closing price on Friday. Big Wells investors, such as Warren Buffett, were apparently willing to accept a slim takeover premium based on the combined company's prospects. As of December, Mr. Buffet owned 7.87 percent of Wells Fargo.
Wells would have been unthinkable as a takeover target a few years ago, when it emerged as the victor in a hotly contested battle for the First Interstate Corporation of Los Angeles, but Wells botched the integration of the two banks. That cost Wells precious profits and customers, and brought Mr. Hazen, long considered a skilled manager, some unaccustomed criticism from analysts and Wall Street. And it left Wells vulnerable.
There had been speculation that Wells might be taken over by U.S. Bancorp, a Minneapolis rival of Norwest. But given the well-known and longstanding animosity between Mr. Hazen and John Grundhofer, U.S. Bancorp's chief executive, most bank advisers dismissed the rumors. Now, there will be considerable pressure on U.S. Bancorp to find a partner if it wants to be one of the banking industry's big survivors.
Norwest, the biggest mortgage underwriter in the country, has been one of the few banks with a solid track record in bundling, or "cross-selling," financial products like mortgages, credit cards, and annuities to its customers and likes to compare itself to Wal-Mart. It has plans to expand its sales of insurance, already the largest such operation among banks.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP PROFILE: FRANCE '98 -- The Master of the Quick Fix;
An Enigmatic Milutinovic, an Equally Enigmatic Nigeria

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
ELINCOURT SAINTE MARGUERITE, France, June 7 -- His top goalkeeper has a broken arm. The news media are demanding his head. In recent exhibitions, his players have done nothing creative with their feet. And for democracy to overcome military rule in Nigeria, some believe, it is better for his team to fail than to succeed in the World Cup.
Bora Milutinovic is coaching his fourth team in soccer's world championship, and if he is concerned about any of this, he hides it well, beneath his Beatle haircut and glasses that are as thick as the intrigue surrounding Nigeria's slumping entrance into the world's most popular sporting event. 
 At lunch today, fewer than 48 hours after Nigeria was humbled by 5-1 in a friendly match with the Netherlands, Milutinovic laughed and joked and played Ping-Pong with his star midfielder, Sunday Oliseh.
"How can I make you happy, my friend, by losing a game to you?" he said to Oliseh.
Those who know him well believe Milutinovic is using that same sandbagging approach to artfully prepare for Nigeria's Group D World Cup opener against Spain on Saturday.
While his friends certainly do not believe he has deliberately been outscored by 13-1 by Germany, Yugoslavia, the Netherlands and the Swiss club team Grasshoppers since late April, they do believe that Milutinovic has been experimenting, using decoy maneuvers and smartly trying to lower expectations for a team that advanced to the second round of the 1994 World Cup and won the gold medal at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
The Serbian coach is famous for his craftiness and his evasiveness. His previous three teams -- Mexico, Costa Rica and the United States -- all advanced beyond the first round of the World Cup. And Nigeria hopes to exceed its performance of 1994, when it led Italy until the final minute before losing in overtime in the second round.
"Bora always tries to keep the big picture in mind," said Steve Sampson, the head coach of the American team and Milutinovic's assistant in the 1994 World Cup. "He's using friendly matches to prepare his team and his opponents psychologically, although I do think he has a legitimate concern with the goalkeeper situation."
In the buildup to the 1998 World Cup, Germany Coach Berti Vogts predicted that Nigeria would be the "secret surprise" and that, at some positions, "Nigeria has even better players than Brazil." No team from Africa has ever won the World Cup, and some think that Nigeria has the ferocious attacking style, the skill and depth to be the first. It is this kind of hyperbolic anticipation that Milutinovic is trying to deflate.
"One month ago, there was so much talk about Nigeria," Milutinovic said today at Nigeria's headquarters, the Chateau de Bellinglise, located about 60 miles north of Paris. "Now we have a better situation. Public opinion is that Nigeria doesn't have a chance."
The Nigerian news media would like to seize something else -- Milutinovic's job. He was hired in December at a salary of $35,000 a month, according to the Nigerian soccer federation, plus a bonus of $250,000 if the Super Eagles win the World Cup. But the nation's news media are in full panic, certain that Nigeria will be lucky to win a game against Spain, Paraguay and Bulgaria.
It is a notoriously impatient country, where coaches are changed like shirts. Milutinovic's predecessor, the Frenchman Philippe Troussier (now the coach of South Africa), was ousted in September. Now Milutinovic is hearing the thumbs-down jeers of the Nigerian media.
"Bora has nothing more to give the Eagles," The Guardian newspaper of Lagos wrote after Friday's humbling defeat to the Netherlands. "Sacking him would serve the team better."
Said The Vanguard newspaper: "The pompous Olympic champions who used to walk with high shoulders and bouncing steps left the Amsterdam area like wet hens. Nigeria's World Cup hopes appear to have been shattered without any hope of them being retrieved."
This is familiar criticism in a sport where passion is fanatical and job security is tenuous. Milutinovic, 53, was fired by Mexico last fall, even though his team did not lose a single game in the final round of qualifying for the 1998 World Cup. Before that, he was dumped by the Americans. He is not likely to coach Nigeria beyond the World Cup. People call him a soccer gypsy, but he really is a mechanic, a master of the quick fix.
After only two months as head coach, he took Costa Rica to the second round of the 1990 World Cup. Four years later, he took an American team, half of whose players had no professional experience, and also made the second round. Patience is what he asks for from the Nigerians. A little patience.
"It's important for you to do what you need to do, not what people think you should do," Milutinovic said.
Of course, there are real concerns. The defense, a Milutinovic trademark, has been shaky. His top goalie, Ike Shorunmu, is out with a broken arm. And he cannot know yet about the reliability of his magnificent striker, Nwankwo Kanu, who was found to have a deformed heart valve after the Atlanta Olympics.
Kanu underwent surgery at the Cleveland Clinic -- his countrymen donated money for the operation -- and he has made a comeback at age 21 that many thought was impossible. If he stars in the World Cup, he will become an international hero. But Kanu played rarely this season for Inter Milan, his club team in Italy, and Milutinovic wonders about his stamina.
"He's a good kid, a good player, but we just don't know," Milutinovic said.
Because his players have been spread out across Europe, playing for club teams in England, France, Switzerland, Italy, Spain, the Netherlands and Turkey, the coach has had his full team together only for seven or eight training sessions. There is much to work on and little time.
"I don't like to make excuses, but in the United States we played together for three years before the World Cup," Milutinovic said. "Here, we will have 15 training sessions."
The outcome of the World Cup will have ramifications far beyond soccer for Nigeria. Politics is knottily intertwined with sport. Nigeria withdrew from the 1996 African Nations Cup in South Africa, after that country's president, Nelson Mandela, criticized the military regime in Nigeria for its poor human rights record and its halting move toward democracy.
The European Union applied sanctions against Nigeria, including a ban on sporting contacts, after nine rights workers were executed there in 1995, including the writer Ken Saro-Wiwa. Glenys Kinnock, a British member of the European Parliament, called in February for Nigeria to be tossed out of the 1998 World Cup.
Some fighting for democracy in Nigeria are actually hoping for defeat of the soccer team, The Economist magazine suggested recently, believing it could be an important step in further destabilizing the military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha.
"Sport is one thing and politics is another," Milutinovic said. "I am not political."
Should his team advance beyond the first round, he said, "anything is possible." And his players seem to be sticking with him. While some observers have suggested that Milutinovic is too conservative and defensive-minded for Nigeria, Oliseh, the midfielder who plays for Ajax in Amsterdam, said: "I don't want to criticize my boss. It's up to the players to play."
If recent defeats have brought a hail of criticism, they have also brought an absence of overconfidence, said goalkeeper Peter Rufai.
"If a coach doesn't know what he is doing, you see him losing the branches of his tree," Rufai said. "But Bora knows what he is doing. We are still with him. His branches are still fresh."

HEADLINE: At the C.I.A., What Intelligence?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The threat of sanctions was an appropriate instrument for trying to deter India and Pakistan from exploding nuclear weapons, but sanctions after the fact are injurious to United States economic and strategic interests (news article, June 3). 
 Faced with a deteriorating economy made worse by sanctions, Pakistan might improve its economic position by exporting more drugs to the United States or by exporting nuclear technologies to rogue states like Iran and Libya. India can expand its trade with France, Russia, Germany and other countries that have not imposed sanctions, to the detriment of American exporters and workers.
Sanctions turn both countries against the United States, making it more difficult for it to play a role in lowering tensions within the region.
 
MYRON WEINER
Moretown, Vt., June 3, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: For Some Families, Wage Increase Hurt

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bob Herbert (column, June 4) asks for explanation of how raising the minimum wage is a bad thing since a study of the most recent increase found that wages of a large number of workers went up "without causing job loss." 
 David Neumark of Michigan State University, who did a study with Mark Schweitzer and William Wascher of the Federal Reserve, found an answer: Although raising the minimum wage does increase the income of some poor families, "the entire net effect of higher minimum wages is to increase -- not decrease -- the proportion of families that are poor."
Even a study Mr. Herbert cites shows how poorly crafted minimum-wage increases are in assisting the poor. Besides, census data show that fewer than half of the families in the bottom 20 percent of income even contain a worker.
 
KEN DEAVERS
Washington, June 5, 1998
 
The writer is chief economist at the Employment Policy Foundation.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Constance C. R. White 

 BODY:

Saint Laurent Passes a Rein
Certainly, several of the recent designer hires at French fashion houses have been more sensational than the appointment this week of Alber Elbaz as the designer and creative director for Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche. But none have been as ripe with sentiment.
Mr. Saint Laurent is, after all, a legend, a living one, and a monument of French culture. Pierre Berge, Mr. Saint Laurent's business partner of almost 40 years, has continually suggested that no one would ever replace the groundbreaking designer in his own house while he was still alive. Amid the swirl of designer dust-ups, the house of Saint Laurent seemed stubbornly determined to survive on its memories. 
 Yesterday, Mr. Berge acknowledged that time had caught up with the house. Mr. Saint Laurent, who is 62 and has become increasingly reclusive, was relieved to be giving up the reins to Rive Gauche, the house's ready-to-wear line, Mr. Berge said in a telephone interview from Paris.
"The ready-to-wear in France has completely changed, and it was difficult for him," Mr. Berge said. Mr. Saint Laurent, who Mr. Berge said was unavailable for comment, will continue to design the haute couture collection. Mr. Elbaz will direct the ready-to-wear, diffusion lines like Encore and Variation and the licensed accessory lines.
In his new position, to begin in November, Mr. Elbaz will report to Mr. Berge. There was no thought, Mr. Berge said, that Mr. Elbaz would work with the man whose name was on the door. "I think he could be paralyzed," Mr. Berge said of Mr. Elbaz, 37. "I'm ready to accept what he will create. He has wonderful technique, and he likes women. It's not a question of replacing Saint Laurent; it's a question of bringing something new."
Mr. Berge's head was turned by Mr. Elbaz's work at Guy Laroche. Mr. Elbaz was at the Laroche studio in Paris yesterday overseeing the production of his last collection for the house, which hired him two years ago from Geoffrey Beene, where he was the assistant designer.
Mr. Elbaz immediately stamped his imprint on the French line with a fresh, light interpretation of a style that had become cloying and out of date. His floor-sweeping, jewel-toned mohair skirts and sweet embroidered tulle dresses buoyed up the beached house of Laroche.
The approach is consistent with the Saint Laurent esthetic. "I love that he makes women beautiful," Mr. Elbaz said, adding that he had not yet met Mr. Saint Laurent.
Born in Morocco, a favorite inspiration of the older designer, Mr. Elbaz grew up in Israel and moved to the United States when he was 25. His appointment to the house of Saint Laurent, with a three-year contract, is not a dream come true, he said. "It's my only dream," he said.
 
Pier 94 to Open in July
Fashion will have another home in Manhattan when renovations are completed on Pier 94, a 175,000-square-foot space at 755 12th Avenue (55th Street). Formerly a parking garage, the site, to be called the Unconvention Center, is to open on July 26 with the Collective, a men's-wear trade show produced by ENK International. ENK presents some of fashion's premier trade shows.
Elyse Kroll, the president of ENK, who has a financial interest in the development of Pier 94, is overseeing the transformation from garage to fashion center. The Unconvention Center is being developed at a cost of about $3 million, Ms. Kroll said.
The new space is a result of a two-year search that Ms. Kroll undertook after presenting her shows primarily in hotels, like the Omni and the Plaza. Accommodations for midsize trade shows have become scarce, she said. With the tourist boom, several city hotels are now turning trade groups away, she said. Last year, ENK shows were spread out over Piers 88, 90 and 92. " 'Titanic' came out, and all of a sudden the piers are fully booked with cruise ships," she added.
In her search, Ms. Kroll turned for help to the city's Economic Development Corporation. The piers are owned by the city and leased to private businesses like Port Parties and the International Terminal Operating Company, which together will operate Pier 94 for a fee.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Treasuries Flat Ahead of Greenspan Talk

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday, as some investors took profits after Friday's gains. Few investors were willing to make large bets ahead of tomorrow's scheduled Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32, to 104 29/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 5.78 percent. 
 At yesterday's regular weekly auction of new Treasury bills, the three-month issue was sold at an average rate of 4.995 percent, up from 4.945 percent last week, while the six-month issue was sold at an average rate of 5.155 percent, up from 5.110 percent.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Let's Play

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Since everyone is giving President Clinton travel advice, I'll chime in too: On your way home from China, stop in Iran. Yes, Iran. Invite yourself. Don't make this upcoming trip to China just about the last crisis. Make it about the next one. Looked at a map of South Asia lately? China's got the bomb. India's got the bomb. Pakistan's got the bomb. Let's see, who's next to Pakistan . . . Iran.
It's probably only a matter of time, a decade or less, before Iran, for its own geostrategic reasons, develops or acquires a nuclear device. Who knows, maybe Pakistan, reeling from sanctions, will sell Iran one. The only question is what regime will be in power in Teheran with its finger on the trigger. There is a struggle now under way in Iran over exactly that question. The outcome of that struggle is a vital American strategic interest. It must be defined as such, and it must be acted upon as such. 
 If Iran obtains a nuclear bomb and the most radical ayatollahs are in charge there, it will further undermine stability in the Middle East. If Iran obtains nuclear technology and the moderate forces now on the rise there can consolidate their hold on Iranian politics, it is possible that Iran can once again be a bulwark for stability in the region.
It is time the U.S. stopped debating whether to try to bolster the moderate -- yes, moderate -- new Iranian President, Mohammed Khatami, and started thinking about far-reaching ways to strengthen him and the popular forces behind him. Washington should be doing everything it can to encourage U.S.-Iran contacts -- from soccer to diplomatic dialogues to cultural exchanges -- and to lay out a specific road map of what it wants from Iran now, and what Iran could expect in return. It's time for a Nixon-to-China-like, bold U.S.-Iran initiative.
Stopping, or at least slowing down, Iran's acquisition of nuclear technology must remain a top U.S. objective, even if it means sanctioning Russian nuclear-export companies. It is necessary for the stability of the Middle East, but it is not sufficient. If we focus only on preventing Iran from going nuclear by isolating it, without also focusing on who in Iran has his finger on the trigger, we will be making a strategic blunder.
Wake up! Smell the Turkish coffee! The Iranian people stunned Teheran's hard-line leadership last year by rejecting the conservative candidates and electing Mr. Khatami in a landslide, embracing his platform of permitting greater cultural, personal and political freedoms. Ever since then, a low-grade civil war has been under way in Iran between the pro- and anti-Khatami forces.
Last month two senior clergymen on Iran's watchdog Council of Guardians attacked Mr. Khatami for his policies of opening Iran to the world. Two weeks ago Iran's supreme religious guide and chief hard-liner, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suddenly showed up at Teheran University to address the students in an effort to puncture the huge outpourings of support there for President Khatami. After the Commander of the Revolutionary Guards told a closed meeting of his officers that he would "cut the necks and tongues" of Iran's new liberal press, he was denounced and had to back off his remarks, saying he had been misunderstood.
"The most important forces in Iran today are the students, the women and the middle classes broadly defined," said Shaul Bakhash, an Iran expert at George Mason University. "Those forces, all of which are militating for a more open society and the rule of law, are strengthened today, not weakened, by Iran's economic development and its interaction with the West. The way to strengthen these forces further is by helping Khatami further open Iran internationally and to develop it rapidly."
Nothing would advance American interests in the Middle East more than if this struggle is won by those who want to see Iran become a law-abiding member of the world community. The U.S. cannot bring about an end to Saddam Hussein, or produce a radical Arab-Israeli breakthrough, or really prevent the spread of nuclear technology in the Middle East, without a different Iran. Whether Iran is actually capable of being a pivot of stability is unclear. It needs to be tested. But the potential is there. Unlike elsewhere in the Middle East, Iran is the only country where the people themselves are now leading a genuine movement for change.
For the first time in 20 years, Iran is in play. So let's play.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Yen Continues Its Slide, Threatening Other Asian Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Japanese yen weakened to 140 to the dollar for the first time in seven years yesterday, extending a yearlong decline that is now threatening the economic recovery of the emerging markets in Asia that were battered by their currency devaluations last year.
Despite the fallout from the weakening yen, many currency traders and strategists expect its value to decline further because the Japanese Government has not come up with a convincing program to stimulate the economy. Many economists have already said Japan is in a recession, which could be confirmed Friday when Tokyo is expected to report its second consecutive quarterly decline in growth. 
 Economists and analysts said the falling yen was hurting Asia's recovery in two ways: One, the decline is a reflection of a weakening Japanese economy that means Japan will not be a big buyer of products from the troubled countries of South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia.
The weakening yen also means South Korean, Thai and other Asian manufacturers will have a harder time competing against Japanese goods sold elsewhere, especially in the United States.
A weakening currency makes that country's products less expensive abroad. But the advantage that South Korea and other Asian countries gained with their devaluations has been reduced by the 18 percent fall in the yen since last July, when the Asian crisis began.
"The competitive edge that South Korea has obtained is minimal," said Desmond Lachman, the head of emerging-markets research at Salomon Smith Barney. And, he said, "If the yen slides toward 150 we can be sure we are going to have real regional currency turmoil."
He said that one important unknown was how the Chinese would react to the yen's weakness. The Chinese said they would not devalue in the wake of the Asian devaluations. But Mr. Lachman said that he believed China's restraint was based on the assumption that the yen would remain relatively stable and not damage China's competitiveness. A Chinese devaluation now could set off another round of devaluations.
The yen's latest decline came after Koji Tanami, Japan's Vice Finance Minister, indicated that finance ministers in the Group of Seven industrialized nations were not going to discuss the yen's problems in Paris today and tomorrow. In addition, Mr. Tanami said it was unlikely that the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada would take action to support the yen.
"The main topic of the meeting will be Russia," he said.
In late trading in New York, the dollar cost 140.71 yen, up from 139.75 Friday. The dollar also rallied against the German mark, rising to 1.7794 marks from 1.7745.
In contrast to its strength against the yen, the dollar had been falling in value against the mark since April.
"There is not a whole lot the G-7 can do for the yen without the Japanese Government providing the policy for support," Mr. Lachman said. Even a surprising round of central bank intervention to support the yen after these comments would only have a temporary impact if Japan's policies are not changed.
Despite a succession of fiscal stimulus programs, the Japanese Government has not yet done enough to stimulate the economy or to deal with the mountain of bad loans that is undermining its banking system, said Jeremy Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston.
"Fundamentally, there is no reason why the yen should strengthen," said Mr. Fand, who is forecasting that the dollar could strengthen to 180 yen in the next 12 months. But he also said that the yen had fallen so much recently that it might be in line for a sharp rebound in the near term before resuming its decline.
The impact of the dollar's strength was also highlighted yesterday in a report by the Bank for International Settlements, which coordinates the activities of the world's central banks. The bank said the dollar was overvalued by 33 percent against the yen and 21 percent against the mark, which makes American exports less competitive and increases the likelihood that the American trade deficit will keep growing.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
The Dow Shifts Gears a Bit, Rising a Modest 31.89 Points

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Major stock market indexes rose modestly yesterday, extending their gains for a third day. Among the leaders were financial services companies, propelled by merger news, and pharmaceutical stocks, lifted by a positive outlook for new drug products.
After soaring more than 167 points on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.89 points yesterday, to 9,069.60. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 1.86 points to close at 1,115.72. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 4.85 points, to 1,787.77. The Dow and S.& P. advanced more than 1 percent on Friday. 
 Although investors' current bias seems to be to move prices higher, analysts say, stocks are not expected to gain much ground in the coming weeks as the earning season nears, said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Inc.
Despite the three days of gains, broad market indexes are lower than they were at the beginning of May, with the Dow more than 142 points away from its May 13 closing high of 9,211.84.
Yesterday, corporations offered investors mixed signals about the outlook for the market. On the one hand, merger activity continued at a brisk pace, improving the outlook for corporate profits in several sectors. The Norwest Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company announced plans for a $34 billion merger that would produce the nation's seventh-largest bank. The news helped lift other financial shares like First Union, BankAmerica and Chase Manhattan.
Renaissance Energy, a Canadian oil producer, said it planned to purchase Pinnacle Resources for more than $720 million, and Just For Feet, a sneaker retailer, announced plans to buy the rival Sneaker Stadium for $43 million in assumed debt.
On the other hand, earnings warnings from several companies and other negative news tempered investors' enthusiasm.
Galey & Lord, a denim manufacturer whose customers include Levi Strauss, the Gap retailer, and the designers Calvin Klein, Liz Claiborne and Polo Ralph Lauren warned that fiscal third-quarter earnings would not meet forecasts because of lower sales in the United States and Europe.
Michael R. Harmon, the company's chief financial officer, said that earnings were hurt because denim sales did not pick up as much as expected. In addition, the company also has excess corduroy inventory.
Adding to the weakness in the semiconductor industry, Galileo Technology, an Israeli maker of digital semiconductors, warned that second-quarter revenue could fall 20 to 25 percent because of slowing demand, price declines and product delays. And shares of Premiere Technologies fell more than 26 percent after a BancAmerica Robertson Stephens research analyst reduced second-quarter earnings estimates and questioned whether the telecommunications concern would realize savings this quarter from a recent acquisitions.
Nabisco Holdings, owned by RJR Nabisco announced a sweeping revamping plan yesterday, aimed at saving $100 million a year. But the company warned that the measures could significantly reduce earnings this year.
"What maintains the trading range is that you have earnings estimates that are still too high and are coming down," Mr. Cripps said. "Profits are being squeezed at the margin because of higher costs." However, stocks will continue to move higher because "I don't know where else you put your money," he said.
Near term, however, investors are unlikely to place big bets on stocks, said Andrew Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. Instead, stock prices are likely to tread water this week as investors await the testimony of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before Congress tomorrow, as well as May retail sales and producer price reports due later this week, he said.

HEADLINE: Fight on Milk Prices Is Making Its Way to Capital

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: CARLISLE, Mass.

 BODY:
Do not be fooled by the virtuous grins on all those celebrities with the white mustaches. The question "Got Milk?" and its corollaries "How much?" and "At what price?" are fueling what economists call the most contentious, most political battle over agricultural policy in the East, if not the nation.
The fight involves Mark Duffy's dairy farm -- the home of cows named Oprah and Cher -- 20 miles northwest of Boston. It has already burst through a score of other statehouses and is expected to flare in the New York Legislature this week. And it will soon play itself out in Washington, pitting East against Midwest, farmers against dairy processors, those who want to preserve farm land against those who want to preserve lower milk prices. 
 The focus of these milk wars is the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact, a treaty-like agreement among the six New England states. It guarantees their dairy farmers a higher price for milk for drinking than the one dictated under the system the Federal Government has been using to set farmers' milk prices since the Depression. Created by Federal law, the agreement acts something like a regional minimum wage for farmers.
The compact, which went into effect last July, is meant to shore up the region's remaining dairy farms, whose numbers have dropped by nearly half over the last decade to about 4,600. By April, the compact had paid New England farmers a total of $33 million more for their milk than what Federal pricing would have paid them, the commission that runs the compact says.
The price of milk in New England stores, meanwhile, has jumped about a dime or 15 cents a gallon to an average of $2.88, said the commission's executive director, Ken Becker. He figures the compact has cost New England's 13 million residents about $2.50 each since it went into effect.
That seems acceptable to some, but not to opponents of the compact, who include advocates for consumers and the poor, groups of dairy processors who must pay the higher prices and Midwestern farmers, who are worried that if New England's milk production rises and increases the national supply, the prices for milk outside New England will drop.
These opponents say the agreement has fulfilled several of their Economics 101 projections that when the price rises, so does the incentive to produce, thus swelling supplies, while demand drops. New England's production this spring was up by 2.4 percent over 1997, Mr. Becker said, while the national average was up less than 1 percent.
That is another problem because the compact specifies that if New England milk supplies jump disproportionately and the compact is determined to be the cause, the New England states must reimburse the United States Department of Agriculture for buying up the extra supply to keep it from affecting the national market. Already, the compact commission has held back a total of $1 million from farmers.
"This thing has backfired," said John Schnittker, an economist with Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a consumer advocacy group in Washington. "We've got consumers paying more; we've got surplus production; we've got government cost, and the extra revenues the consumers are paying are being directed back into the Federal Treasury. This is a lose-lose-lose policy right now."
The compact's backers, however, say that other factors besides price are at work: El Nino brought bad weather to the West and warmer weather to the East, they say, and the mild winter combined with better feed harvests has increased cows' milk production here.
Mr. Duffy, whose farm in Carlisle is about average for New England in its milking herd size -- 60 cows -- said the compact had brought him $5,570 extra so far, raising his milk receipts by about 3 percent. But he said his production was up because of the mild winter and a good harvest of corn for feed last fall, not because of the price.
"I didn't go out and buy a single cow," Mr. Duffy said. Rather, his family decided to use the extra money to invest in modernizing some stalls and equipment.
Already, the compact commission is working on altering its rules in order to discourage big increases in production and is discussing ways to direct the payments more to small farmers and less to big farms, which already enjoy economies of scale.
"This is a work in progress," said Jay Healy, Massachusetts Commissioner of Food and Agriculture and a backer of the compact for its potential to save disappearing farm land.
The compact has already altered its rules in response to criticism that higher milk prices hurt those who can least afford it. Participants in the Women, Infants and Children nutrition program were compensated for higher milk costs from the start; school lunch programs will be as well, beginning this August.
But the compact will be hard put to compensate for another predictable result: New Englanders are drinking about 2 percent less milk than a year ago, compared with a slight increase in the rest of the country, said E. Linwood Tipton, president of the Milk Industry Foundation, a Washington organization of milk processors, manufacturers and marketers that is leading the charge against the compact.
"There's a word," he said. "It's spelled m-a-r-k-e-t. It actually works and that's what the rest of the dairy industry is living with, and they seem to be surviving and thriving."
The conflict also touches on the question of whether, at a time when the Federal Government is moving away from supporting prices for commodities like corn, wheat and milk, consumers should be asked to help provide American farmers with a new economic safety net. Many see the compact as insurance for farmers as the Federal Government fiddles with its own complex system for pricing milk across the nation. But the dairy compact itself is facing an imminent deadline. Under Federal law, the compact expires next April. Unless it is re-authorized, it dies.
But while the Federal fate of the agreement may be up in the air, other states are jumping on the compact bandwagon.
More than a dozen Southern states, from Tennessee to Texas, have expressed interest in forming a Southern dairy compact, and several of their legislatures have passed laws to that effect.
In the East, New Jersey, Maryland and Virginia have passed laws recently seeking to join the existing dairy compact. The Federal law creating the Northeast compact left it open to future participation by New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Delaware but only as contiguous states. The focus of the political fight over the compact has thus shifted to Albany, because if New York does not join, neither can New Jersey and the rest.
The New York State Senate passed a bill calling for the state, with its 9,000 dairy farms, to join this winter, and Gov. George E. Pataki endorsed the idea despite complaints that it helped upstate farmers at the expense of downstate consumers.
But in the Assembly, where the bill's fate is expected to be decided this week, the compact suffered a major blow last month when William Parment, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, withdrew his sponsorship of it.
"I don't know that I want to jump into something that's not well-tested and has the potential for negative impact for both consumers and farmers," Mr. Parment said in a telephone interview.
Andrew Novakovic, director of Cornell University's Program on Dairy Markets and Policy and a leading expert on the dairy industry, said he believed the compact could be made to work.
In his assessment, retail prices have risen only slightly thus far to a level not unusual in other parts of the country, while farmers have gotten a definite lift; but it is worrisome that there are reports of a surplus that can drive prices down elsewhere.
He was gloomy about the compact's prospects for a Federal extension, but then immediately hedged his bet, noting that he had bet his house the compact would never pass in the first place.
"It's good thing nobody took me up on it," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Korean President Sees a Western Cure for Economic Ills

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea told New York business leaders yesterday that his country's once-prized economic miracle was nothing but a "house of cards" and that his people now needed American help to rebuild the economy in a more Western image.
Mr. Kim, a former dissident who assumed the country's highest office in February, lashed out at his predecessors for creating an economy characterized by collusion and corruption. Now, he said, South Korea has turned decisively to democracy and it has opened its borders to foreign investment and trade. 
 "My greatest purpose in coming here," he said, "is to plead with the American Government and businessmen to invest in South Korea, to tell you that we are doing everything we can to open" the economy. He joked with an audience of executives, diplomats and scholars at the Council on Foreign Relations in Manhattan, saying, "If each of you today could invest just $100 million, that would be a great help."
Once one of Asia's most successful growth machines, South Korea has been a major victim of the economic turmoil that has swept the region. Last year, the International Monetary Fund arranged a $58 billion rescue package. Since then, the country's foreign currency reserves have rebounded sharply and interest rates have stabilized.
But Seoul is scrambling to find a solution to its huge private-industry debt problems, which have crippled financial institutions and bankrupted several leading conglomerates.
Mr. Kim, who is in his 70's, looked haggard during back-to-back appearances today, beginning with breakfast at the New York Stock Exchange. He walked stiffly and stayed seated during a question period after cutting short his lunchtime speech. Later, he left for Washington, where he will meet with President Clinton and top economic advisers.
But Mr. Kim was energetic in promoting his Government's friendly new attitude toward foreign business. He stressed that he had committed South Korea to open capital markets and relaxed investment rules as the cornerstone of economic recovery.
Many of New York's top business leaders turned out to hear the President's remarks, including Sanford I. Weill, chairman of the Travelers Group; Jon S. Corzine, co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group.
"He said all the right things -- very direct, very positive," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "It will take some time for businesses to respond, but the direction is right on."
Mr. Kim outlined new rules that permit hostile takeovers of Korean companies. Foreign executives can now run South Korean companies and foreign investors can own land on the same terms as Koreans, a first for a country that long maintained one of capitalist Asia's most protectionist economies.
Some critics have contended that Mr. Kim has stalled on a basic economic overhaul and allowed old practices -- including bailouts for the some of the country's biggest countries, instead of allowing them to fail. But the President insisted that he was carrying forward with a "full-scale restructuring."
His recited a list of measures straight out of the International Monetary Fund's guide book: abolish cross-guarantees of debt among related companies; require better disclosure and accounting standards; give shareholders more power; force companies to focus on core businesses rather than peripheral investments.
To emphasize his welcoming attitude toward foreign investment, Mr. Kim said he considered the Dow Chemical Company's decision to build a $1 billion plant in Malaysia instead of South Korea a "serious mistake," adding that his Government would not allow bureaucratic resistance to derail important foreign investments in the future.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
South Korean Recovery: A Mixed but Gloomy Picture

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
Six months after Koreans elected Kim Dae Jung as President, economic pain is mounting with few signs of a turnaround in sight.
Output has fallen even more sharply than predicted -- 3.8 percent in the first quarter, while unemployment has outstripped economists' forecasts, reaching 6.7 percent at the end of April. 
 The situation is likely to get worse before it gets better, most analysts believe. "They're breaking with a social contract that's been in place the last 40 years," said Linda Tsao Yang, the United States representative to the Asian Development Bank. "It's going to be painful."
Still, some discern seeds of growth. "The process of growth is probably already under way," said the United States Ambassador here, Stephen W. Bosworth. "It's just overwhelmed by the more visible pain of restructuring."
Mr. Bosworth and others say anyone who anticipated an overnight transformation was simply unrealistic. "I think we built expectations too high, and when you do that, you are sure to disappoint," said You Jong Keun, governor of North Cholla province and economic adviser to President Kim. "We could not have moved any faster."
The International Monetary Fund, which provided $58 billion in December to stave off Korean default, still claims South Korea as its star pupil in Asia and says that the Government is ahead of schedule on many required changes.
"What you're seeing is the first stages of restructuring in the financial system and the corporations, and those reforms are going to have a negative impact," said John Dodsworth, senior resident representative of the I.M.F. here. "At least in the next few months, they could be quite disruptive."
The banking system's bad debts have continued to rise as debt-laden South Korean corporations continue to borrow. And many of the chaebol, the sprawling conglomerates that dominate the economic landscape here and are widely blamed for South Korea's structural woes, seem determined to continue doing business as usual.
By one measure, companies are paying a total of $6 billion a month to service their debts, an amount equal on an annual basis to more than half the nation's export income last year. Asset sales, which would help eliminate debt, have been sporadic.
The foreign investors that South Korea so desperately needs apparently still need to be convinced that the reforms under way are substantial. But because the Government of President Kim, a former political prisoner, is determined to act in a democratic fashion, its ability to enforce change in private business is limited.
The Government cannot, for example, force the banks to make more rational lending decisions or order the conglomerates to sell their assets, as it could in the past.
"Our role has been reduced to that of a referee," said Hyun Oh Seok, general director of economic policy at the Finance and Economy Ministry. "The Government sets up the rules, but others are the players."
And although officials bulldozed virtually the last remaining barrier to foreign investment last month, foreigners greeted the news by pulling so much money out of the stock market that it hit an 11-year low. The market has since recovered somewhat, but remains shaky.
External factors beyond the Government's control have complicated matters, particularly the decline in the value of the Japanese yen against the dollar, and the weakness of the Japanese economy. Concerns like Samsung Electronics, Daewoo and Pohang Iron and Steel compete head to head with Japanese companies, and the cheaper yen means much stiffer competition. The Japanese market is also less able to absorb Korean goods.
The yen's decline has made many aware of the soft underbelly of Korea's surging trade surplus -- the hard-currency flow that keeps Korea's foreign-exchange coffers full.
South Korea's trade surplus is due more to a precipitous drop in imports than to increased demand for its products abroad. The fall in imports has investors worried because it means that business at home is suffering badly. Companies have not been importing the raw material, components and machinery they need, largely because modest size businesses have had difficulty finding financing.
"Many small and medium-sized companies that are doing well are going down because banks are rushing to recall their loans or they don't have access to the credit needed to do business," said Yoon Young Mo, international secretary of the Korea Federation of Trade Unions, the more militant of the nation's two labor groupings.
Although there are signs that the credit shortage is starting to abate, it has already put hundreds of thousands of people out of work. The country's 30 large conglomerates get most attention when it comes to labor issues, but they employ only about 5 percent of the work force and have thus far not resorted to sweeping layoffs.
Workers and small-company owners have borne the brunt of the restructuring, not the conglomerates for which the changes were intended. "Despite the fact that everyone is calling for reform in the chaebol system, what is happening is that because so many small and midsized companies are going under, the Government is rushing to prop up the conglomerates to avoid making the situation even worse," Mr. Yoon said.
The Government says that the conglomerates are in fact restructuring but that the process is exceedingly slow. Foreign companies have been buying their Korean counterparts' stakes in joint ventures, but only a handful of outright asset sales have taken place.
These include the recent sale of the Hanwha group's power-plant operations to the AES Corporation of the United States for $874 million, the highest price paid so far for a Korean asset.
 The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company intends to invest $1 billion in Korea Life, giving it as much as 60 percent of the privately held insurer, the companies said on Monday.
 Also on Monday, Reuters and Bloomberg News reported, Samsung Heavy Industries said it had signed a contract to sell its forklift truck business to Clark Material Handling of the United States for $30 million. This follows the sale early in May of Samsung's construction operations to Volvo for $720 million.
The practice of "cooperative financing" -- loans and loan extensions offered by bankers to big companies that would otherwise go bust -- continues with little apparent slackening. The practice has delayed corporate restructuring by giving otherwise insolvent companies a new lease on life and added to the woes of the banking system. Although Government officials have declared that such loans would stop, $600 million in new loans were granted last month to the Dong Ah group, raising fresh doubt about Seoul's commitment to banking reform.
No one is sure how vast the pool of nonperforming loans is. Mr. Hyun of the Finance Ministry conceded that raising enough money to cover potential bad loans would be an uphill battle. But action on this and other structural issues is necessary for the economy to recover, many analysts say.
"Now that the reform process has begun, investors are beginning to look more closely on a micro level as to precisely what changes are taking place," Ms. Yang, the American delegate to the Asian Development Bank, said. "They'll have to see those changes before they're convinced."

HEADLINE: At Drug Summit, Clinton Asks Nations to Set Aside Blame

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 8

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the debate over who bears responsibility for the world's drug problems has gone on too long and called for drug-producing and consuming countries to cooperate in stanching the supply and demand for illegal drugs.
Addressing a special summit-level session of the General Assembly convened to discuss ways to counter drug trafficking and use, Mr. Clinton said that pointing fingers has not advanced the fight against drugs. 
 "It does not dismantle a single cartel, help a single addict, prevent a single child from trying and perhaps dying from heroin," Mr. Clinton said.
President Clinton said the lines between countries that produce, transit and consume drugs have blurred. "Drugs are every nation's problem, and every nation must act to fight them," he said.
But Mr. Clinton heard a blunt rejoinder from President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico, who is still fuming over an American undercover operation that led to the indictment of 26 Mexican bankers last month on charges of laundering more than $110 million in drug profits. Mexican officials were not informed of the investigation, apparently for fear that it would jeopardize the plan and the safety of American agents inside Mexico.
President Zedillo said today that all countries share the same rights and obligations to fight drug trafficking. "We all must respect the sovereignty of each nation so that no one becomes a judge of others, so that no one feels entitled to violate other countries' laws for the sake of enforcing its own," he said.
While a overwhelming part of the world's demand for drugs comes from "countries with the largest economic capacity," Mr. Zedillo said, "the human, social and institutional costs in meeting such demands is paid for by the producing and transit countries.
"It is our men and women who die first in combatting drug trafficking," he said. "It is our communities that are first to suffer from violence, our institutions that are first to be undermined by corruption. It is our governments that are the first to have to shift valuable resources needed to fight poverty to serve as the first bulwark in this war."
Later this afternoon, President Clinton met privately with President Zedillo, and the two agreed to improve cooperation and communication and to strengthen ways to deal with drugs trafficking and money laundering. But the communique released after their 25-minute meeting gave no indication that the dispute over the sting operation was resolved.
The President of the Dominican Republic, Leonel Fernandez, said the problem was rooted in the law of supply and demand. "The demand is what makes the existence of the market possible," he said, explaining that the illegal trade it creates is highly profitable and attractive.
He cited an intelligence estimate that 33 percent of the drugs smuggled into the United States from South America passes through the Caribbean, and 15 percent through the island of Hispanola, which his country shares with Haiti.
Prominent among voices pressing to reduce demand was Britain's Deputy Prime Minister, John Prescott, who spoke on behalf of the European Union. "It is no use stopping opium cultivation in one place just to see more grown elsewhere," Mr. Prescott said. "We gain nothing by closing one trafficking route to see another opened."
President Jacques Chirac of France urged a counterattack on every front. "Drug elimination cannot be left to a single category of country, whether it be producer or consumer," Mr. Chirac said. "Supply and demand must be reduced simultaneously."
Mr. Clinton said his Administration would request more than $17 billion in the next Federal budget to fight drugs, $6 billion of which will be earmarked to reduce demand.
Announcing several smaller steps, he said he would ask Congress to extend a new advertising campaign to discourage children from using drugs. The program got under way last fall with an initial $195 million budget, but Mr. Clinton promised to expand this to a $2 billion campaign through 2002, with part of the money donated by the private sector.
He also said the Government would create a "virtual university" on the Internet to make available drug prevention and treatment videotapes and will launch an international training course in New Mexico next month on reducing the demand for drugs.
The General Assembly session on reducing production, trafficking and use of illegal drugs, the first in 10 years to be devoted entirely to the subject, was initially proposed by Mexico, which has become a transit route for more than half of the cocaine smuggled into the United States.
Representatives of 150 countries, from presidents to government ministers and other senior officials, are scheduled to speak before the special session ends on Wednesday, with a joint declaration pledging to drastically reduce the demand for drugs worldwide in 10 years.
So far, the speakers have made clear that legalizing drugs will not become an option. "There will always be those who are ready to throw in the towel," Mr. Annan said in his remarks opening the special session. "But we must never give in to the human toll illegal drugs are taking on our societies.
Secretary General Kofi Annan estimated that 21 million "victims" around the world abused cocaine and heroin and 30 million abused amphetamine-type stimulants.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton attended a drug summit meeting yesterday with other United States officials, including the American delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, left; and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Intel Case Gives Antitrust Law a New Twist

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
The antitrust laws are designed to protect an industry from monopolists that use predatory or other illegal tactics to extinguish rivals. The odd feature of the antitrust complaint brought yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission is that it accused Intel of victimizing putative rivals that are also customers.
In separate instances involving the Intergraph Corporation, the Compaq Computer Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation, the Intel Corporation is accused of withholding technical data about its processors from companies that were designing computers around Intel chips. 
 What will make the Government's case difficult is that only one of those companies -- Digital -- ever seriously competed with Intel. What is more, the information that Intel freely acknowledges it withheld from those companies may have had no direct bearing on competition in the chip industry.
The question, antitrust experts agree, is whether the commission can create a strong factual case for its accusations. Given the oddity of the charges, that task will not be easy.
Intel controls more than 80 percent of the market for the microprocessor brains of computers. When it designs a new chip, Intel gives advance information to its customers -- computer manufacturers -- to give them time to design new machines that will run the next generation of Intel's processors.
Intel acknowledges that it withheld vital information from Intergraph, Digital and Compaq, with which it was engaged in continuing patent disputes, but it says that it was not about to share intellectual property with customers that were suing it over intellectual property.
The company argues that it is not compelled by the antitrust laws to disclose proprietary information to customers that could exploit that information in subsequent patent disputes.
The commission says that while the three companies may have indeed been customers, they were also rivals and that it is illegal for a monopolist to exploit its market power to force them to cave into Intel's patent demands.
Intel insists that its hardball tactics were in pursuit of business objectives that were perfectly legitimate.
The dispute with Intergraph, for example, was a negotiation between buyer and seller. Intel wanted a free license to use Intergraph's chip technology. Integraph wanted proprietary information. Intel asserts that the Government has no business intruding on this negotiation.
Carl Shapiro, an economics consultant to Intel from the University of California at Berkeley, acknowledges that there may be areas of rivalry -- Digital, for example, produces a microprocessor that competes with Intel's Pentium chips in a very limited market -- but argues that the behavior under challenge by the commission is overwhelmingly limited to the relationship between the chip maker and its customers.
William Baer, the director of the trade commission's Bureau of Competition, says that it is unlawful for monopolists to injure rivals without an efficiency-enhancing business justification -- for instance, resulting in lower prices or superior products.
In fact, Mr. Baer says, Intel's decision to punish the three manufacturers was done only to compel the companies to settle their patent dispute on Intel's terms.
But to win its case, the commission must show that Intel not only hurt rivals, if any of the three companies are in fact rivals, but that it also hurt competition within the microchip industry.
That could mean proving that Intel's behavior drove its rivals into extinction. It could mean showing that Intel's behavior persuaded rivals to spend less on research and development, thereby undermining their ability to innovate as fast as Intel. Or it could mean showing that Intel's behavior convinced actual and potential chip makers that they could not survive because any computer company that needed to do business with Intel would be punished if it also bought chips from Intel's rivals.
In one respect, the trade commission's case mirrors the suit the Justice Department filed last month against the Microsoft Corporation. In that case, the Government pointed to cross-marketing and other exclusionary contracts between Microsoft and its partners that would be perfectly legal by nearly any other company. But Justice Department lawyers argue, with ample precedent, that those same tactics are illegal when used by a monopolist to shut its rivals out of a market.
Likewise, the commission is saying that Intel's refusal to do business in the midst of a legal dispute would be perfectly legal in nearly any other context but that the same tactic is not legal when embraced by a monopolist seeking to drive potential competitors out of contention.
The difference between the two cases will lie in facts, not theory. In the Microsoft case, the Government is offering evidence that the software giant's contracts directly affected actual competitors.
The trade commission, on the other hand, may be relegated to proving a counterfact: that Intel drove away potential competition. That is a hard case to win, especially when only one of the three alleged victims was ever a significant competitor in any sense of the word and all are among Intel's biggest and best customers.

HEADLINE: Sinn Fein Enters Campaign For New Ulster Assembly

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 8

 BODY:
The campaign for the new Northern Ireland Assembly began in earnest today as Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, abandoned its traditional policy and announced formally that it would field candidates even though the assembly is almost certain to have a Protestant unionist majority.
Sinn Fein, a predominantly Roman Catholic party, had said until two months ago that it would never take part in the new assembly, which is being set up under the Northern Ireland peace agreement approved in referendums on May 22 here and in the Irish Republic. 
 The 108-member assembly, to be elected on June 25, is to return this predominantly Protestant British province to self-government and to set up a body in which the North and the Irish Republic will cooperate. The British Government took direct control of the province's government during sectarian disorders in 1972.
The new peace accord is intended to change Northern Ireland politics, giving minority Catholics a fairer share of power and giving the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic added influence in Northern affairs.
Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, began the campaign by warning that the entire peace effort could be disrupted again by violence provoked by Protestant patriotic parades through resentful Catholic neighborhoods. The parades, celebrating a Protestant victory over Catholic forces in 1690, have led to clashes with the police and costly vandalism. The parade season reaches its peak early next month.
Mr. Adams, at a news conference, referred to Catholic hopes, saying: "Following the events of the last year, the expectations among nationalists is that these parades should be banned and that nationalists' rights should be upheld. If we are to avert a major crisis in the coming weeks then the Irish and British Governments need to move now to resolve the situation."
Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, Mo Mowlam, said, "I think if we all, after the Assembly elections, do everything we can to make sure that the parades pass less violently this year we have a chance in Northern Ireland that hasn't been seen for many, many years."
The chance, Ms. Mowlam meant, was for an increase in foreign investments in the North. She spoke as she met Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who is leading a group of 17 American executives on a tour of Ulster and the Irish Republic.
"I don't think there is any question that violence and support of violence by political people or organizations would go a long way to dissuade companies from investing," Mr. Daley said. "Every day the guns are silent, business confidence goes up."
About 100 American companies operate in Northern Ireland, and 500 in the Irish Republic.
The largest Protestant group, the Ulster Unionist Party, also began its campaign today. Its leader, David Trimble, alluding to a volatile issues that the Assembly will face, said it would be several months after the election before the Assembly would form a government.
Another issue that the Assembly will wrestle with is whether Mr. Adams will be made a Cabinet minister. He is almost sure to be eligible under the election rules apportioning power in the Assembly.
The prospect pleases most Catholics and angers many Protestants, who still see him as the mouthpiece for the I.R.A. In the campaign Sinn Fein will be competing for the Catholic vote with the Social Democratic Labor Party of John Hume. In recent elections Sinn Fein has become the third-strongest party in the province, behind the Ulster Unionists and the Social Democrats, but ahead of the hard-line Democratic Unionist Party of the Rev. Ian Paisley.
