HEADLINE: Is the Music Live? Probably Not;
A Guitarist (Free This Saturday) Loses Gigs to Deejays

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
With a nod to the audience, Jeff Ausfahl got ready to play. As gigs go, the crowd was awfully young. Appropriately, he began with "I'm Popeye the Sailor Man."
The hubbub of chatter stopped. As Mr. Ausfahl strummed his guitar, the roisterous kindergartners at Public School 114 in the Bronx lifted their faces in delight. Accompanying him were Brian Grice on the drums and Sue Terry on the flute. They performed an Aesop fable set to music, distributing maracas for the children to shake along. 
 Between songs, they taught the rudiments of their instruments. (What's a guitar made of? How many strings does it have?)
"It's a far cry from a real gig, huh?" Mr. Ausfahl said as the children filed out. "Isn't the club date business great?"
Such is the sharply altered shape of the musician's life in a world more in thrall to canned music than live.
Jeff Ausfahl has played the guitar professionally for 25 years. He is what is known as a club date musician, who primarily performs at single engagements like weddings and private parties. A highly malleable guitarist, he can play everything from dance to rock to classical to merengue to polkas. He plays songs of contagious cheer and songs with a lot of ache in them, though he no longer gets to perform anywhere as much as he would like to.
That is why, at 43, Mr. Ausfahl finds himself doing about 75 gigs a year in front of schoolchildren, arranged through Music Outreach, a nonprofit outfit that puts on music demonstrations in public schools in New York. The audience is highly appreciative. He needs the work.
There has been an evolving decline in jobs for live musicians, caught in the undertow of disk jockeys spinning CD's on much improved sound systems and a more thrift-minded economy. Local 802, the New York chapter of the American Federation of Musicians, to which Mr. Ausfahl belongs, says union club dates in the city have tumbled to about 6,000 a year from as many as 15,000 15 years ago. The union reports that the bar mitzvah business and lower-end weddings have been almost totally lost to deejays, who generally cost a fraction of what a band does. Far fewer musicians find themselves able to play full time anymore. Many teach. And it has become axiomatic among union musicians that they must accept nonunion jobs to eat, a practice the union tolerates.
It is not strictly economics that has brought on this state of affairs. Many people do not want to hear someone who sounds like Bruce Springsteen or Elton John. They want Bruce Springsteen or Elton John, even if he is coming out of a box.
One can sometimes go to a $200-a-plate dinner today and be entertained by a music system. Years ago, the size of the band was a mark of the status of an event. The work was so copious that it was hard to find enough musicians. Bands enlisted "phantoms," nonplayers who simply held instruments to swell the size of the band. Saxophone players were known to pick up violins and apply soap to the bows so no sound would emerge as they "played."
These days, musicians have come to feel like very expensive bottles of wine, tasted less and less often.
It was a languid Monday void of gigs, and Mr. Ausfahl was working on the attic of the tidy Teaneck, N.J., house that he shares with his wife, Janet, and a parakeet named Henry. Mr. Ausfahl is a sinewy, genial man with longish hair and sharply chiseled features.
"I did a wedding yesterday with just a flutist," he said ruefully. "We played just the ceremony. When we left, the deejay started."
The subject of deejays causes him to snort with indignation. Brusquely, he said: "It does bug me. It bugs a lot of people. I'm not mad at anyone. I just want to make a living. You know, it started out that the records were to sound like the bands. Then it got to where the bands were supposed to sound like the records. Now they just need the records."
Ten years ago, Mr. Ausfahl played 250 to 300 club dates a year. These days he is lucky to get 100, plus his school jobs. His single biggest source of work is Lester Lanin Orchestras, the society band group. "I also work for his competitors," Mr. Ausfahl said. "I have to."
His year of greatest income was 1993, when he made about $60,000. The next year, he earned less than half that, but lately he has rebounded to about $40,000 a year. "I had some 10 years or so where I would be idle at most one or two Saturday nights," he said. "Now I'm idle 20 or more Saturdays."
He never imagined this constricted condition when he embarked on his free-form career. He was born in Peoria, Ill., where his father was a factory manager for Caterpillar, the tractor maker. Mr. Ausfahl started guitar lessons when he was 10. At 13, he was playing in a band at school sock hops. "When you're young, you want to find your self-worth somewhere," he said. "I tried a bunch of things and I was good at this."
He eventually received a degree from Berklee College of Music in Boston, after several interruptions. For a spell, he played rock music at bars and Holiday Inn lounges. For eight months in 1975, he joined a band in Chicago called Even Steven. The musicians wore silver satin suits and played soul music. One summer, he journeyed to Virginia Beach, Va., and played military bases and wet T-shirt contests.
In 1979, he drove from Boston to New York. He knew no one. He thumbed through the Yellow Pages to "Bands & Orchestras" and began dialing numbers. Some places hung up on him. Others invited him in for a tryout. One contractor asked him if he was free Saturday. He was free indefinitely. "Put yourself down," the man told him. "You've got two weddings." He picked up a third later the same week. Within a year, he was subbing in Broadway plays. He felt good about his footloose choice of career.
Mr. Ausfahl now regards himself as one of the car mechanics of the music business, someone who can be relied on to do solid, reliable work. "The way my career turned out, I'm not George Benson," he said. "I'm not a star. But I can really play."
He has never recorded his own album, though he has been on a few bootleg records. In the past, he appeared at many familiar New York nightclubs like CBGB and the Bitter End, but he has forsaken that scene.
"It's totally not lucrative," he said. "They think you should work for a piece of the door because of the exposure and then their guy counts the door and you never seem to get what you should. You're better off staying in your basement."
He went on: "At Christmas time, company parties were insane years ago. No more. I used to do a lot of industrial jobs -- I.B.M. sales conferences and stuff. They've all cut back." He performed at a fair number of debutante balls, but they have dried up, too. "The ones I do," he said, "instead of a parade of girls, I see six." Another nearly defunct source of steady work is songwriter demos. These days they tend to be done on a computer in a home studio.
Work used to flow worldwide. "Once I was playing a party north of London," he recalled, "and the bass player nudged me and pointed out that there was the Queen." Nowadays, he travels very little.
He considers himself hard-boiled about social trends, but he has made adjustments. He had done some music teaching, but doesn't much care for it. He took classical guitar lessons and has been picking up more classical and jazz gigs at restaurants and parties. "Instead of working with bands, I find myself playing solo classical," he said. "The trouble is, when you play solo dates, you're living wallpaper."
Within reason, he will take whatever comes along. He has a steady Friday night gig at a university club, where he plays swing and dance music and also sings. Once he played a divorce. A man was so elated when his divorce papers were signed that he threw a party. In exchange for a free checkup, he recorded a song written by his dentist to be entered in a contest to anoint a state song for New Jersey. (It lost.)
He did a funeral in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. In her will, a woman specified that a Dixieland band was to play at her final appearance. Mr. Ausfahl was among the musicians hired to fulfill her wish. As the coffin was carried out of the church, they struck up some slower Dixieland numbers like "Just a Closer Walk With Thee." A weeping woman came up to Mr. Ausfahl and sobbed, "Mother would have loved it."
Saturday parties pay about $200 (weekdays are about $170), and if he leads the band, it's $100 more. There is a $10 bonus if he lugs along his own amplifier, which he always does. When he plays solo guitar in a restaurant, he has trouble getting more than $125. A jazz club pays him no more than $50 to $75. In these days of depleted jobs, fees can get insulting. Not long ago, Mr. Ausfahl rebuffed an offer to play jazz in a prison in Albany for $80.
He finds it hard to comprehend why more people do not insist on live music. "To me the difference between a record and live music is night and day," he said. "When you play in a band and it all works right, it's like floating on a cloud."
The splendiferous Bedens Brook Club lies at the end of a curving road in Skillman, N.J., on the outskirts of Princeton. On a recent Thursday evening, the Princeton class of 1953 had gathered for a reunion dinner and dance. Don Anderson, a grizzled, 67-year-old band leader and piano player, had hired Mr. Ausfahl and three others to provide the evening's entertainment.
The elder classmates moved peristaltically across the floor, most of the men in their Princeton orange sport jackets. The band members were in black tie. The bass player, Michael Battiston, said, "I feel like a piece of dirt in a glass of orange juice."
Mr. Anderson spelled out his plan for the evening: "We'll play some stuff here. If nothing happens, we may assault them." "Assault" meant they would stroll from table to table and play.
As the cocktail chatter proceeded, the band stayed with background music, beginning with two Princeton songs. A woman strutted over and asked Mr. Anderson to tone it down; it was hard to talk over the music. "Ah, they love us," Mr. Ausfahl said.
He gazed at the crowd. "We're talking people in their late 60's," he said. "This seems to be what I get. I don't get the young groups anymore."
On they played: "East of the Sun," "Anna," "Blue Moon." Mr. Anderson sang "New York, New York," sounding not even like the treasurer of the board.
Mr. Ausfahl did a solo, and a woman stopped by to coo: "He can just do that all night long. I'm going to take someone like you home with me."
Mr. Anderson quickly handed her a business card. "I don't want to be pushy," he said, "but this is what we have to do." When she had gone, he said, "One year, in 1986, I grossed $400,000. Now I can do maybe a 10th of that."
Mr. Anderson strapped on his accordion and announced that they were going to stroll.
Mr. Ausfahl looked stricken. He abhors strolling. He is not much for repartee with the audience. When you stroll, people get up to sing -- often in unknown keys -- and won't sit down. One table requests a popular song like "Memory" and then all the other tables request it. You wind up playing it 25 times.
Here, it was the same Princeton standard that everyone wanted: "Going Back to Nassau Hall."
After dinner had been ingested, the band got heavy into dance songs. The alchemy was just right, and they were clicking. The reunion-goers rose from their chairs. Good drink had oiled reluctant limbs.
Even as the evening waned, the floor was seething with dancers. The musicians had smiles on their faces. By no means was Jeff Ausfahl wallpaper tonight. He was making music.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expresses Support for NATO Action to Halt Serb Attacks

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The United States said today that it would support a British resolution in the United Nations to authorize a NATO military intervention in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo, and that Washington would press NATO to speed up planning for such an action.
American officials said that military action is not imminent, and that Washington would act only through NATO. But they said that a credible threat of such action is an important part of NATO strategy to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to end his army's attacks on civilians in Kosovo. 
 The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said early today that American military intervention "is not something that is on the table." But American officials said later that he meant that unilateral American action is not being considered, and that military planning would be left to NATO.
Today the United States joined the European Union in imposing a ban on new investment in Serbia and a freeze on Yugoslav and Serbian government assets abroad. Washington and the European Union, pressed by Britain, acted after a continuing crackdown by Serbian special police and Yugoslav Army units in Kosovo that has caused at least 250 deaths, driven at least 10,000 ethnic Albanians into Albania and displaced tens of thousands of other people.
The sanctions were approved last month but were suspended at Washington's request when President Milosevic agreed to open talks with Ibrahim Rugova, leader of Kosovo's ethnic Albanians.
After a first round of talks, however, Mr. Milosevic began his crackdown, aimed at defeating guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army and creating a cordon near the Albanian border to prevent infiltration of arms and recruits into Kosovo. Mr. Rugova and his team said they could not continue the talks while the violence continued because it would undermine their credibility and their search for a negotiated solution.
Regarding the United States decision to approve the sanctions, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said today: "In the light of the indiscriminate use of violence over the last two weeks, and the way such violence has undermined the basis for talks, we are proceeding to implement these bans while calling on both sides to continue the talks."
The investment ban will hurt Mr. Milosevic because he depends on the sale of state industries to finance his Government, Western officials said. Government credit for private companies to invest in Serbia was already banned. The asset freeze is largely symbolic, since Belgrade has few assets abroad. But it will also serve as a disincentive for future investments, because it will mean that Belgrade cannot open bank accounts overseas. Both the European Union and American officials said they were ready to consider other sanctions and measures.
The 15 nations of the European Union acted first today, when foreign ministers agreed to put the sanctions in place and called on the United Nations and NATO to consider authorizing military action to force Mr. Milosevic and Serbia to stop its attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, where they make up 90 percent of a population of about two million.
Given that Kosovo is internationally recognized as a part of Serbia -- unlike Bosnia, which was recognized as independent -- Western officials believe that a Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force would be necessary. The resolution would come under Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows intervention to deal with a threat to international peace and security, the same authority used in the war with Iraq. The British are consulting key countries on a draft of a resolution, American officials said. All key Western countries are working to persuade Russia, which has a veto and is a traditional Serb ally, to go along.
Russia, fearing the precedent that an independent Kosovo could set for Chechnya and other restless parts of the Russian Federation, is very sensitive to any suggestion of Western backing for Kosovo independence.
In Bonn tonight, Chancellor Helmut Kohl was expected to try to persuade the visiting Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, to agree to the resolution, which would serve as a strong deterrent to Mr. Milosevic.
That effort will continue when senior officials of the so-called contact group -- the United States, Britain, Germany, France, Italy and Russia -- meet in Paris on Wednesday. The NATO defense ministers will meet in Brussels on Thursday.
The defense ministers could authorize planning for air strikes against targets in Serbia, a NATO diplomat said, in addition to working on plans for "preventive deployments" around Kosovo to try to prevent the fighting from spreading.
Mr. Milosevic's crackdown has served to accelerate the recruiting efforts of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which draws many of its members from among ethnic Albanians in Germany and Switzerland.
"With every day he makes the mistake of using force rather than finding the wisdom to negotiate, Milosevic becomes the membership chairman" of the K.L.A., Mr. Rubin said today, "because he continues to push the people of Kosovo into a more extremist posture than they would otherwise be."
Under the pressure of the K.L.A.'s popularity, even Mr. Rugova advocates independence for Kosovo, while Washington and the West favor only more political autonomy for the province within a federal Yugoslavia. But the federal Yugoslavia is already breaking apart, with Mr. Milosevic having driven Montenegro into virtual independence and Kosovo rising in rebellion.

Diplomats Report Devastation
 DECANI, Yugoslavia, June 8 (AP) -- Devastation reminiscent of wartime Bosnia greeted diplomats allowed into western Kosovo on Sunday, they said today.
The region has been sealed off by Serbia, and it was the first look for outsiders since the latest Serbian campaign began. The diplomats saw charred ruins everywhere -- but few people, except for armed Serb policemen. "What we've seen is all sorrow, all grief," said the Dutch Ambassador, Jan Sizoo.

HEADLINE: Lively Council Race in Newark Pits Experience Against New Blood

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 8

 BODY:
Runoff elections rarely set pulses racing. But the one being played out Tuesday in Newark's Central Ward may prove the exception.
The race for the City Council seat from the neighborhood that was ground zero in Newark's 1967 riots and the setting for rebuilding in the last 15 years, is between a veteran politician and a 29-year-old newcomer with Ivy League and Oxford credentials. As New Jersey's largest city continues its steady struggle back from the turmoil of the late 1960's, the Central Ward contest is not just about young versus old and outsider versus insider, but about the glitter of things hoped for against the solidity of things known. 
 The passion excited by the election was evident after a candidates' forum last week, when Darlene Parker argued with a neighbor about the merits of one candidate, George Branch, a 69-year-old, four-term incumbent. Mr. Branch had, by virtue of his experience and his quiet but constant presence in the ward, earned re-election, she said. He had paid his dues, she went on, and this country ought to respect such people.
But her debating partner, DeTwayne Holmes, retorted that Mr. Branch's 29-year-old opponent, Cory Booker, had impressive educational credentials: Stanford University, Oxford University, Yale Law School. Mr. Holmes said he saw Mr. Booker as just the kind of "young, innovative, educated" candidate that the now resurgent ward and city needed. "We need new blood," he stressed.
Tuesday's runoff was forced by the May 12 municipal election, in which no candidate in a three-way race attained a majority in the Central Ward voting. Mr. Branch finished 340 votes ahead of Mr. Booker, out of 7,700 votes cast.
In terms of its energy level alone, the runoff shows a new fervor about politics and the city's future among the ward's 27,000 registered voters.
"It's to Newark's credit that there is this runoff," said Raymond Codey, director of development for the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit housing and economic development group in the Central Ward. "Residents didn't just vote for the older guy, but are intelligently evaluating the candidates. It speaks well for Newark that we can attract a candidate like Cory Booker and give residents this kind of choice."
Tuesday's ballot also features a runoff in the West Ward and a runoff among eight candidates for four at-large seats on the City Council.
But Mr. Booker's presence in the Central Ward race has generated the most interest. He could have been sent by central casting to typify a product of the black middle class who grew up in an era of integration and civil rights gains. A cum laude graduate of Stanford University, a Rhodes scholar and 1996 graduate of Yale Law School, he was raised in Bergen County's affluent Harrington Park, where his family had to invoke anti-discrimination laws to buy their home. His only early connection to Newark was through an uncle who lived and practiced dentistry here.
Then, two years ago, he moved to Newark with a fellowship to do legal work for the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, a nonprofit group. He says he soon saw politics as a surer route to change. Through school contacts, he had entree to city corporate and business leaders. Soon his name was on all their lips as someone who bore watching, and that buzz, as much as anything else, placed him as a new star in the city's political firmament.
"I picked a community which was in incredible distress and which at the same time had amazing human beings," Mr. Booker said, in explaining why he chose to come to Newark and to run in the city's Central Ward. "I'm in the top 1 percent educationally of this nation -- black or white -- and I have been taught that to he who much is given, much is expected."
Mr. Booker has raised and spent more than $140,000 so far, an extraordinary amount for a Council race in Newark, which rarely sees more than $50,000 spent. Much of it was raised from a network of friends and associates from Stanford, Oxford and Yale.
Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, who is supporting Mr. Branch, has styled the Central Ward contest as a race between the Rhodes scholar and the "road scholar" in an effort to burnish Mr. Branch's street smarts and long service in the city.
Mr. Branch, a former youth coordinator with the Newark Housing and Redevelopment Authority, is also a former lightweight boxer who amassed a professional record of 28-8. They were mostly decisions, he said in a recent interview, noting that he patterned himself after Sugar Ray Robinson, and was not a flashy knockout artist.
This style has characterized his political career as well, say supporters like the Rev. Jason Guice, pastor of Hopewell Baptist Church. Mr. Branch played a role in making sure that the privately financed, middle-income town houses of Society Hill/ University Heights got built and was one of the first buyers, Mr. Guice noted. He also helped bring about the construction of apartments by church-sponsored nonprofit groups and town houses by the city's housing authority, Mr. Guice said.
In addition, he has performed the traditional constituent service in solving problems for the elderly, helping start youth programs and getting homeowner tax abatements. "He has been there, and that is why the ministers of the Central Ward are supporting him," Mr. Guice said.
By most accounts, Mr. Branch and his supporters were lackadaisical before the vote on May 12. But by the end of last week, Mr. Branch had raised and spent more than $100,000 himself in an effort to beat back the challenge in the runoff.
Now, Mr. Branch and his supporters are pressing hard to stick the "outsider" label on Mr. Booker, as well as tie him to downtown and business interests whom they deride for having moved many of their operations, and in some cases their residences, from Newark to the suburbs.
The Rev. Jonah Nixon, vice chairman of the Newark North Jersey Committee of Black Churchmen, said that these unnamed interests now want to return and reclaim a prominent place in the city, as it seems to be rebounding with such amenities as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
"Those who have deserted the city would like to come back, and these are the people who are supporting Cory Booker and giving him most of his money," Mr. Nixon said.
While Mr. Booker and his backers do claim the support of business leaders who have holdings in Newark but live elsewhere, they brand as ridiculous suggestions that they are his only supporters.
Mr. Booker's claim of broader support is borne out in part by the results of the May 12 election. Mr. Branch won most of the middle-income, homeowner areas and precincts with large numbers of elderly people, if only by slim margins. But it was Mr. Booker who won the poorer areas dominated by the city's last remaining high-rise public housing complexes.
Ms. Parker and Mr. Holmes never resolved their own debate.
"Newark is not moving as fast as it could," Mr. Holmes said. "We need young people, educated people with vibrant new ideas."
Ms. Parker shot back, "Education is not enough by itself. You can be an educated fool, you know."

HEADLINE: Of Ill Mothers, 36% Are Held Able to Work

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
After evaluating hundreds of disabled welfare mothers for a new city workfare program, officials at four nonprofit agencies said yesterday that most of the women could not work because they were too ill, had to care for disabled children or lacked enough interest in the program.
Of the 410 mothers screened on Saturday, only 36 percent will be considered for the work program, the officials said. The agencies will continue to interview disabled women over the coming months for the program, which is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's newest welfare initiative. But while the officials stressed the importance of the project to the mothers who will participate, they now have doubts about how many will. 
 "I don't think there are going to be as many people participating as we had thought," said Linda Turner, director of rehabilitation services at Goodwill Industries of Greater New York. "There's a significant percentage of these folks that are quite seriously disabled."
The preliminary reports from the agency officials came yesterday as city officials and advocates for the poor fiercely debated the value of the new program, which will require disabled welfare mothers to work in jobs tailored to their specific impairments.
The new policy began this weekend when city officials ordered about 800 women to report to welfare offices for screening into the new 20-hour a week workfare program. It was unclear last night why only half of that group actually showed up for interviews, but state officials, who helped finance the project, said as many as 12,000 mothers may ultimately participate.
Under the old system, disabled mothers were exempt from workfare requirements unless a city doctor certified that they could work. City officials contended that, as a result, those women were denied desperately needed job training, work experience and career counseling.
But advocates for the poor say the new system endangers welfare mothers who have already been classified by city doctors as permanently or temporarily unemployable.
Officials at the four nonprofit agencies conducting the screening said they found some women eager to work and some who appeared to be too severely disabled to participate. The agencies are Goodwill Industries, the Federation Employment and Guidance Service, the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service and the National Society for Disability Services.
The federation agency found 116 mothers who will likely participate in the new program. Most suffered from mental illness, asthma and chronic back pain. They were given an appointment for a more complete evaluation, which will be reviewed by the State Office of Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals With Disabilities.
Those women will ultimately work 20 hours a week for three months, and 35 hours a week after that, while receiving career counseling, job search training and other services.
"In our experience, a lot of them don't think they're up to working, but they welcome the opportunity," said Al Miller, chief operating officer of the federation agency.
On the other hand, officials at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service found only three employable mothers in a pool of 60.
"They're pretty seriously disabled, and work may not be appropriate for them," said Norma Martin, assistant executive director of the Brooklyn bureau. "We're not here to try to force people who are severely disabled to work if they can't work."
Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the Human Resources Administration, which runs the city's welfare programs, said she could not comment on the private agencies' findings without reviewing them first. She could not say what would happen to those disabled mothers who did not enter the workfare program.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Intel Sued; U.S. Cites Harm to Computer Makers
The F.T.C. filed antitrust charges against Intel, accusing it of threatening and injuring three computer makers, including Compaq, the leading maker of personal computers. The Government contended the company withheld information about its microprocessors that are at the heart of a personal computer in an effort to coerce the three companies to turn over rights to patented technologies.
Intel contended the suit was "based upon a mistaken interpretation of the law and the facts." Page A1.
 
Intel lowered prices on its Pentium II microprocessors for desktop computers by 12 percent to 20 percent and introduced a faster version of its low-end Celeron processor. It cut the price of its older, slower model by 32 percent. D6. 

U.S. Approves Rail Freight Plan
The Government approved a sweeping restructuring of the nation's rail freight system east of the Mississippi River, allowing CSX and Norfolk Southern to divide Conrail's nearly 12,000 miles of track. Officials saw cost savings and less pollution. B8.
 
Dow Industrials Up 31.89 Points
Stocks extended last week's gains, rising modestly, led by financial service and pharmaceutical stocks. The Dow industrials gained 31.89 points, to 9,069.60. D9.
 
Treasury securities were little changed. Investors were cautious ahead of tomorrow's scheduled Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. D9.
 
Strike Idles Two G.M. Plants
General Motors sent 4,500 workers home at two plants as a four-day strike by the U.A.W. at a metal stamping plant in Flint, Mich., threatened to halt the company's vehicle production. A18.
 
Honda and Ford Fined on Pollution
Honda will pay a record $12.6 million environmental fine, Federal prosecutors announced, because of bad programming on the pollution-control computers in 1.6 million Honda and Acura models. Ford will pay a $2.5 million fine for selling 60,000 Econoline vans that emit more nitrogen oxides at highway speeds than they do on treadmill tests. A1.
 
Roche Recalls Posicor Heart Drug
The prescription heart drug Posicor was pulled off pharmacy shelves in 38 countries by its maker, Roche Laboratories. The F.D.A. cited mounting evidence of dangerous, possibly even lethal, drug interactions. A12.
 
AOL to Buy Chat Service
America Online will pay at least $287 million for Mirabilis, a small Israeli company known for its highly regarded on-line chat service that enables users to detect when fellow users are on line and to communicate instantly with them. AOL's stock rose 2 percent on the news, which was viewed by analysts as a shrewd move. D3.
 
State Farm to Issue Rebate
State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, said it would return $891.6 million to its policyholders in 35 states and the District of Columbia. Accident claims have fallen. D2.
 
Bell Atlantic Plans Data Network
Bell Atlantic plans to begin building a $500 million network to carry Internet and data traffic as it awaits regulatory approval. D3.
 
Korean Economic Pain Mounts
South Korea's economic pain is mounting with few signs of a turnaround. Economic output fell 3.8 percent in the first quarter, and unemployment reached 6.7 percent in April. Both numbers exceeded forecasts. D4.
 
President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, who assumed office in February, told New York business leaders that his country's once-prized economic miracle was nothing but a "house of cards" and that his people now needed American help to rebuild the economy. D4.
 
Weak Yen Imperils Asia Recovery
The Japanese yen weakened to 140 to the dollar for the first time in seven years. Its yearlong decline is threatening the recovery of the emerging Asian markets from last year's currency devaluations. C9.

HEADLINE: NEW CHAPTER IN NIGERIA: THE OBITUARY;
Sani Abacha, 54, a Beacon of Brutality In an Era When Brutality Was Standard

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Gen. Sani Abacha, who died yesterday at 54, was the seventh Nigerian officer to come to power by force since the country gained independence from Britain in 1960. But even against this background, General Abacha established a distinctive record of brutal rule.
Nigerian human rights groups, clandestinely active in the country and openly critical in exile, have charged that more people were arrested in his five and a half years in power than in the five decades of British rule. 
 General Abacha regularly expressed his authority through fiat or intimidation, but rarely revealed much about himself, giving no interviews and keeping to his official mansion, known as Aso Rock. He would arrive at his office late in the day and work through the night, staying aloof even from his own ministers and military advisers.
A 1995 article in The New York Times reported that "journalists who have gotten too close to the subject of General Abacha's personal life are often arrested." And even in Nigerian circles, little was known about the dictator's life beyond the terse entries in the public record.
But his face, always obscured by dark glasses, was seen throughout the country on billboards that proclaimed, "Abacha is the Answer." Public works projects were named for him or his wife, Maryam, with whom he had nine children.
He was born on Sept. 20, 1943, in Kano State in the northern Muslim area that has produced most of the country's leaders. He attended school in Kano and just after independence was admitted to the Nigerian Military Training College in the northern city of Kaduna. In 1963 he received his commission as a second lieutenant after studying at the Mons Defense Officers' Cadet Training College in Aldershot, England.
In 1967, when mostly Ibo forces tried to wrench their region and its oil riches out of a federated Nigeria and gain independence as Biafra, the young officer fought in the civil war, and the secessionists were defeated. After the war, he continued his military training in England and then in Monterey, Calif.
Though his superiors recommended in 1971 that he never be promoted above the rank of colonel because he was "not considered stable enough for higher command," he nonetheless rose steadily. He was made a brigadier in 1980, a major general in 1984 and a lieutenant general in 1987. He was also involving himself in political affairs.
As oil, the country's main source of revenue, fell in price in the early 80's, President Shehu Shagari, who was elected in 1979, was toppled by the military on Dec. 31, 1983. It was the first of three coups in which General Abacha had a leading role, this time collaborating with Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.
The plotters installed Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari as leader. He was unable to reverse Nigeria's economic trials and showed little concern for human rights.
As things continued to worsen, General Babangida and General Abacha sent troops out to depose the man they had enthroned. General Babangida took over as head of state, and General Abacha became Chief of Staff of the Army.
General Babangida opened a nationwide debate on the form the government should take once democracy was restored. Local elections were held, and national elections were scheduled, but he decided that political traditions in the country were harmful and banned all 13 parties. In their place he created two factions, "one a little to the left" and the other "a little to the right," both under his control.
Elections were finally held on June 12, 1993. It appeared that Moshood K. O. Abiola, a wealthy businessman who was a member of the southern Yoruba people, had won. General Babangida annulled the election.
When widespread protests erupted, General Babangida resigned a day before he had promised to cede power to a civilian government. He gave the presidency to Ernest Shonekan, a civilian if unelected leader, who was also a Yoruba. General Abacha was the only member of the Babangida Government to stay on, as Defense Minister.
President Shonekan lasted only two and a half months. On Nov. 17, 1993, as he was preparing for a meeting with striking labor leaders, General Abacha staged his third coup, taking the top post himself.
A day later he outlawed the two government-sponsored parties and banned political activity. "We will not condone or tolerate any act of indiscipline," he declared.
In June 1994, Mr. Abiola declared himself to be the rightful president. A day later he was put in jail, where he remains.
Oil workers struck, calling for democracy. The military responded with violence and broke the strike within two months. In the summer of 1994, General Abacha imprisoned labor officials, journalists, politicians and rights activists. He announced decrees that put his Government above Nigeria's courts and permitted preventive detention. He shut down three major newspapers.
In March 1995, his Government announced, to some skepticism, that it had squelched a coup, and it was reported that within a month between 60 and 300 officers were executed along with 40 civilians.
At the same time General Abacha ordered the arrest of Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, who in 1979 had been the only Nigerian military leader to have ever voluntarily turned over power to an elected official. Along with 39 others, he was charged with treason, leading to appeals from Pope John Paul II and Margaret Thatcher for leniency. On Oct. 1, 1995 General Abacha announced that he had lifted the death sentence on the 40 men.
He did not, however, accede to appeals for clemency in the case of Ken Saro-Wiwa, a writer and human rights activist, who was hanged along with eight of his associates on Nov. 10, 1995. He had been charged with provoking assassinations.
Many of the Government's critics believed that he was killed because of his role in the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, which sought a share of oil money for the ethnic group whose traditional lands lie over oil deposits. General Abacha is widely believed to have amassed a personal fortune from oil.
In January 1996 a group calling itself the United Front for Nigeria's Liberation claimed responsibility for a plane crash in which the general's 28-year-old son, Ibrahim, was killed.
The United States has imposed various levels of sanctions, banning flights because of security concerns, cutting assistance after the annulment of elections and again because of charges of Nigerian Government involvement in drug trafficking.
When Walter Carrington, the American Ambassador, was leaving his post last year, his farewell party was broken up by the police.
As General Abacha was being chastised by world leaders, he sought to establish Nigeria's military might as the peacekeeping power of West Africa. In February, Nigerian troops took Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, chased out a junta and, in a seeming paradox, paved the way for a democratically elected president.
In March, Pope John Paul visited Nigeria, calling for greater democracy and human rights in the country. A month later, parliamentary elections were held, but at many polling places soldiers and policemen outnumbered voters as the opposition called for a boycott. Pro-democracy groups claimed that General Abacha had rigged the list of candidates.
The general himself was preparing to run for President in August in an election in which he had in effect selected token opponents.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Dividing Conrail to Increase Competition

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The Federal Government approved a sweeping plan today to restructure the nation's rail freight system east of the Mississippi River, a move officials said would take trucks off the road, reduce air pollution and lower the cost of goods for the New York City metropolitan region and much of the rest of the nation.
Today's vote by the Surface Transportation Board gave final approval to a proposal by the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation to divide Conrail's nearly 12,000 miles of track, stretching from Boston to St. Louis. CSX and Norfolk Southern jointly bought Conrail, which operated mainly in the Northeast, for $10.2 billion last year in one of the largest rail mergers in the nation's history. 
 The plan approved today creates two railroad giants that will dominate rail freight shipping throughout the nation's eastern half, allowing direct competition between the two companies in several places, including much of New Jersey and parts of western New York State.
"This carefully crafted, privately negotiated deal injects competition in the entire East like no merger before has ever done," said Linda J. Morgan, the chairwoman of the board. "It will bring competition back to many areas that had lost options through the creation of Conrail."
Aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki hailed the decision, saying it would allow more than one major railroad company to ship goods in and out of New York City for the first time in decades and potentially provide new transportation routes for Long Island businesses that are solely dependent on trucks.
"For the first time in a long time, businesses on the east side of the Hudson will have access to competitive freight rail services," said Bradford J. Race, Mr. Pataki's chief of staff. "It's a significant step forward for Long Island, Manhattan and communities all along the river."
But some members of New York's Congressional delegation said the plan fell well short of what was needed to revitalize the region's rail freight industry, charging that the transportation board had squandered a chance to force much more competition for New York City's huge market. Less than 3 percent of all the goods shipped in and out of the city is carried by trains, compared with about 40 percent in other cities.
"What they agreed to was grossly inadequate," said Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Democrat from Manhattan, who said he might file suit to block the plan. "This doesn't give us any real competition at all."
It was also not clear whether the new plan would have a significant impact on rail shipping in Connecticut, where CSX will take over Conrail's lines. But in New Jersey, where CSX and Norfolk Southern will jointly operate hundreds of miles of former Conrail track while directly competing with each other, shipping costs are expected to decline and rail traffic to increase.
Environmental advocates and New York officials said they were concerned that added rail traffic in New Jersey would lead to an increase in trucks carrying goods from New Jersey rail yards into New York City over the George Washington Bridge even as New Jersey benefits from less trucking over all. The transportation board said today that it would conduct a study to see if that happened.
Today's vote clears one of the last major hurdles for CSX and Norfolk Southern to complete their takeover of Conrail, a monopoly system created by Congress 22 years ago out of the remnants of the failed Penn Central system. The board's decision -- which includes dozens of conditions dealing with labor, environmental and administrative issues -- still has to be set down on paper. After that report is released on July 23, the two companies will have to wait 30 days before the takeover becomes effective. Officials with the two companies have said they might take several months more to put the plan in place.
CSX and Norfolk Southern have said that their plan will cut truck travel on the nation's roads by a million trips a year, sharply reducing air pollution in congested regions like New York City. And while the elimination of Conrail's freight lines will lead to the loss of more than 2,500 union and management jobs, the two companies contend the nation's economy will benefit from lower shipping costs.
"This is going to be good for every consumer and every producer in the East," said David R. Goode, chairman of Norfolk Southern.
Norfolk Southern, based in Norfolk, Va., will grow from 14,400 track miles to 21,400 miles in 22 states. CSX, which is based in Richmond, will grow from 18,300 track miles to more than 23,000 miles in 23 states.
Some unions representing workers who may lose their jobs were expected to protest the plan. And some manufacturing trade associations said that they were concerned that shipping rates might rise in regions where Conrail had once competed with CSX or Norfolk Southern.
The plan calls for CSX to take over Conrail's lines in Connecticut, Massachusetts, along the Hudson from New York City to Albany and running west from there to Buffalo, as well as from Syracuse to Montreal. Norfolk Southern will take control of lines along the New York-Pennsylvania border and throughout Pennsylvania. The two companies will jointly operate much of Conrail's former lines in New Jersey.
Among the provisions the transportation board approved today is a requirement that CSX allow Canadian Pacific Ltd. to ship goods from Canada and parts west along the Hudson to New York City. City officials said that requirement would greatly increase rail competition in the metropolitan region, opening it up more to western markets.
But Mr. Nadler and other members of New York's and Connecticut's Congressional delegations had wanted the transportation board to make CSX allow Norfolk Southern to operate on the east side of the Hudson.
Doing that would not only reduce shipping rates, they said, but would also encourage the two companies to expand the use of barges to carry rail cars across the New York Harbor from New Jersey to Brooklyn. Because there is no rail bridge connecting New Jersey to New York City, rail freight coming from the south has to be unloaded in New Jersey and then trucked across bridges or through tunnels to the city.
The plan is also expected to cut shipping costs in Buffalo and Rochester.

HEADLINE: Strike Idles Other G.M. Plants And Workers Are Sent Home

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 8

 BODY:
With two of its factories running out of essential components, the General Motors Corporation sent 4,500 workers home today as a four-day strike at a metal stamping plant in Flint, Mich., threatened to halt vehicle production for the world's largest auto maker.
While negotiators for the United Auto Workers and General Motors began their fourth straight day of bargaining, assembly factories in Orion Township, Mich., and Kansas City, Kan., were closed because of a shortage of engine cradles, the company and union officials said. Salaried employees remained at the plants. 
 The auto maker said an additional 8,500 workers could be idled on Tuesday with the scheduled closing of a light truck factory in Moraine, Ohio, a car assembly factory in Flint and a second shift at the Kansas factory.
And Thursday is the strike deadline at a second Flint parts-making factory, where 5,000 workers are demanding more job security.
The closings were set in motion by the strike of 3,400 hourly workers at G.M.'s sprawling metal plant in Flint, where the workers contend that the auto maker has reneged on a promise of $300 million in new investments that would essentially guarantee future employment. At least 17 of G.M.'s 29 North American assembly plants use fenders, hoods and engine cradles built in Flint.
"G.M. says the plant is not competitive, but that's their answer to everything," said Dick Shoemaker, the union's vice president for negotiations with the company.
G.M.'s response is that it will not back down until the union lives up to its promise to abolish work practices that give workers a full day's pay for a half-day's work.
Industry analysts estimate that the strike could cost the company $300 million a week in profits. Strikers receive $150 a week from the union. In most states, laid-off workers are eligible for state unemployment benefits, but G.M. typically fights against issuing benefits to U.A.W. workers laid off in a strike. A company spokesman said General Motors was still deciding whether it would challenge the benefits.

HEADLINE: NEW CHAPTER IN NIGERIA: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Dread Rules: An Unpopular Leader Leaves Nigerians Fearful and Divided

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, June 8

 BODY:
Few Nigerians are in a state of mourning over the death of Gen. Sani Abacha, a deeply unpopular leader. But while Nigeria awaits clearer signs of its political future, nearly all of the nation is in a state of dread.
General Abacha's legacy is a demoralized army, a political class whose leaders have been jailed or driven into exile, and a national economy that has been looted into penury. 
 The booby traps he left in the nation's path could violently rend Africa's most populous country, and send shudders through the West African nations that gravitate around this regional giant like so many small moons.
Although the military leadership selected Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, who was promoted from major general and was formerly defense chief of staff, as the country's new head of state, the army remains divided.
"How divided is this military? It is seriously divided," said Bolaji Akinyemi, a former Nigerian Foreign Minister. "What is the strength of each faction? Nobody knows. What is certain is that this is a very dangerous moment."
Today, the very first hints of potential trouble came from within the Nigerian army itself, when early this afternoon journalists were summoned without explanation to the presidential compound in Nigeria's capital, Abuja, and then just as suddenly chased away.
Hours later the military Government officially announced the death of the President, which had taken place early in the day. The lapse reflected deep divisions at the highest level of command about the army's immediate and future roles, according to retired senior officers of the Nigerian military.
General Abacha, who was 54, governing in a style bordering on heightened paranoia, left a military that is both Africa's largest and perhaps its least unified. Wave after wave of purges of senior officers, show trials of suspected opponents and long-sustained ethnic favoritism in the officer corps have left many commanders deeply demoralized and dangerously suspicious of each other.
"There are many of us who have made our lives in the army because we were trained to believe that the military had something vital to offer to the nation," said one senior Nigerian general in a recent interview. "This, however, does not include politics, and we have a bunch of officers who come to think of themselves as permanent politicians. In behaving this way, they are dragging us all down."
With feelings this raw and opinions so divided -- between those who wish to get back to a classic republican army and others who have for years cherished military power as a way to gain access to the country's trough of abundant oil wealth -- many now fear an open and potentially violent split.
General Abacha's unexpected death came less than four months before a long-promised transition to democratic civilian rule. But by the time he died early today, reportedly of a heart attack, even those who had been temporarily willing to believe in the improbable gift of a democratic election had long ago concluded that this stern and secretive military man would destroy the country in his attempt to keep tight personal control.
The seven military dictatorships that have dominated Nigeria's history since independence from Britain 1960 have all put forth plans for a "transition to democracy." Even if the current high command is able to maintain a reasonably united front and advance yet another, there is no sign that the country's political class will meekly sit back and await the results.
Already, in the hours following General Abacha's death there have been impassioned calls for the restoration of the presidential mandate of Moshood K. O. Abiola, the millionaire businessman who is widely believed to have won the country's 1993 elections, which the military then annulled and which international human rights groups have called the most democratic ever held in Nigeria.
"Abiola should be invited to head a government of national unity to organize a sovereign national conference and lead Nigeria to genuine democracy," the Nigerian human rights lawyer, Gani Fawehinmi told Reuters. "The Nigerian people will not allow the military to take over again."
Others, already suspecting that the military has little intention of giving up power, have begun to warn of the possibility of spreading unrest. In the weeks leading to his death, street protests against the military have erupted into small-scale riots, and opposition leaders had already announced plans for a series of strikes and other demonstrations against the army.
Nigerians, still haunted by the 30-year-old memories of the Biafra conflict, one of Africa's bloodiest civil wars, have little difficulty imagining a continuation, indeed acceleration, of their national tragedy.
And throughout West Africa, where Nigeria looms huge, whether by virtue of its 105 million people, its large army or sophisticated economy, these kinds of scenarios are already causing serious worry.
In Sierra Leone, Nigerian soldiers intervened recently to restore the elected President, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, who had been overthrown, and rout a guerrilla force that has been terrorizing much of the countryside. There, people from street vendors to Government officials expressed fear today that disorder in Nigeria would cause that country to lessen its commitment in Sierra Leone, perhaps allowing the rebels to make a comeback.
"Abacha may have been hated in Nigeria, but he saved us here," said one Sierra Leonean journalist. "If things go badly in Nigeria, we will surely suffer again."
In other West African countries mounting concerns about stability in Nigeria have less to do with Nigerian military involvements than with fears of a huge refugee outflow.
"If there is trouble in Nigeria, there is trouble for all of West Africa," said one senior official from Ivory Coast. "A sinking Nigeria is big enough to swamp us all."

Photos: Babangida; Abiola; Saro-Wiwa; Diya
 
1993 -- General Ibrahim Babangida promises to step down and organizes a presi-dential election. Moshood Abiola takes an unexpected lead in early returns and Mr. Babangida annuls the vote. At least 100 people are killed in riots in the southwest, in Mr. Abiola's home area.
 Mr. Babangida does step down but names an interim government of his own choice. Gen. Sani Abacha, defense minister in the interim govern-ment and the most senior officer, seizes power and promises an elected president in three years.
 
1994 -- Mr. Abiola proclaims himself president, is arrested and charged with treason. The army suppresses riots and strikes.
 
1995 -- Ken Saro-Wiwa, a writer, and eight associates are hanged, causing a human rights outcry. The Commonwealth suspends Nigeria. The United States, European Union and South Africa impose arms and visa restrictions.
 
1996 -- Non-party local govern-ment elections are held, the first vote since the annulment in 1993.
 
1997 -- Mr. Abacha's deputy, Lt.-Gen. Oladipo Diya, is arrested in December and accused of plotting a coup.
 
April 1998 -- All five legal political parties adopt Mr. Abacha as their candidate for presidential election, to be held later in the summer. Separately, Mr. Diya and five other senior officers are sentenced to death by a military tribunal.
 
May -- Seven people are shot dead in the southwest city of Ibadan during May Day protests against Mr. Abacha.

HEADLINE: NEW CHAPTER IN NIGERIA: THE OPPOSITION;
With Nigeria's Military Ruler Dead, Concern Is Voiced for the Fate of His Jailed Foe

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
After the death of Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, the daughter of Moshood K. O. Abiola, the opposition leader who was imprisoned after being elected President in 1993, called today for the military to step aside and for her father's immediate release.
"It's the end of an era, and I hope, the end of military rule," said Hafsat Abiola, his 23-year-old Harvard-educated daughter who has worked with other opposition figures to protest military rule in Nigeria. 
 But Ms. Abiola, who works for the Special Olympics and lives in suburban Maryland with 5 of her 18 siblings, said she is concerned about her father's welfare.
"Abacha wanted to use my father as a hostage, to keep him close by so that if he was ever attacked he'd attack my Dad," she said in a telephone interview.
Asked whether she thought her father should take over the reins of power in Nigeria now that General Abacha is dead, she replied, "I just want my father released. I am very concerned about his safety."
Other Nigerian opposition leaders called for Mr. Abiola to be installed as President of a transitional Government in Nigeria.
Wole Soyinka, the exiled Nigerian playwright, told reporters in Jerusalem today, "There's only one choice for Nigeria -- that's a democratic option. And the structure is there. The President-elect is waiting."
Mr. Soyinka added that the general's death presented an opportunity for the military to step aside.
"The people were sick of military dictatorship," he said. "So it's up to the military to recognize this -- and up to the international community to say that we're sick and tired of the degeneration of a potentially great society."
Until that happens, other countries should increase diplomatic pressure and economic sanctions on the military Government, Mr. Soyinka said.
Mr. Soyinka, who won the Nobel prize for literature in 1986, fled Nigeria in 1994. He was charged in absentia with treason last March in connection with bomb attacks aimed mostly at the military, which left two people dead and about sixty people wounded.
The view that it was time for the military to step aside was echoed by the son of Ken Saro-Wiwa, a human rights activist and writer who was executed by the Nigerian Government.
 "This is an opportunity for the opposition and an opportunity for democracy to be restored to Nigeria, though how that actually happens is anybody's guess," Ken Wiwa told Britain's Channel Four television news.
 "One hopes that democracy will have a chance to establish itself," said Mr. Wiwa, whose father was hanged in 1995 with eight others.
But he said it was unclear whether Mr. Abiola was well enough to assume power.
"We are really not sure how healthy and fit Moshood Abiola is." Mr. Wiwa said. "Reports say he himself is close to death."
Ms. Abiola said that she was not ready to embrace the call of other opposition leaders like Mr. Soyinka for her father to assume the leadership of the country.
"We know he is not doing very well and have to attend to his medical needs first," she said. She said that he suffered from high blood pressure, a pinched nerve and had trouble moving his left leg.
The family has not seen her father in well over a year. When they saw him in January 1995, "he had been tussled, beaten around and looked very disheveled," she said.
But Ms. Abiola said that her father was the only person who can bring democracy to Nigeria.
"The only person who can move the country beyond the point where it is peaceful and democratic is my father," Ms. Abiola said. "He is the only person chosen by the people to do so."
Mr. Abiola has been in jail since mid-1994, after he was charged with treason by a federal high court in Abuja for declaring himself President. He was chosen by popular vote in election that was annulled by the military.
One of his three wives, Kudirat Abiola, Ms. Abiola's mother, was killed two years ago while working to free her husband from prison, in what her daughter called a political execution.
Ms. Abiola, who has spent nearly a third of her life in the United States, said she was ready to go home if she could feel safe again. "I want to be able to welcome my father back to our house," she said.

HEADLINE: NEW CHAPTER IN NIGERIA: THE OVERVIEW;
NIGERIA DICTATOR DIES AFTER 5 YEARS OF RUTHLESS RULE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Gen. Sani Abacha, the dictator of Nigeria, whose ruthless suppression of opponents, human rights and democracy led to condemnation around the world and seething discontent at home, died early yesterday. His defense chief of staff was quickly sworn in to lead Africa's most populous nation.
Reports of the death were sketchy, but American officials said they had no evidence of foul play. 
 General Abacha had not left a clear successor, but Nigeria's top military leaders convened and selected Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, apparently averting a protracted power struggle for leadership in the oil-rich nation of 115 million, a country wracked by decades of harsh, corrupt military governments and the effects of Western sanctions imposed in a futile effort to hasten democracy.
The swift selection of another military leader came in the face of appeals by exiled Nigerians and world leaders in Washington, London, Paris and other capitals, who said the general's death heralded an opportunity for Nigeria to release hundreds of political prisoners, cancel executions set by kangaroo courts and restore civilian government.
"Abacha's death is not going to bring my father back," said Ken Wiwa, the son of the playwright and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, who, with eight other opponents of the general, was publicly hanged for "treason" in 1995 while a worldwide outpouring of appeals for mercy was icily ignored.
Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright who won the 1986 Nobel Prize for Literature, fled to exile in Paris in 1994 and was recently charged in absentia with treason, said from Jerusalem that the general's death was an "incredible opportunity" for Nigeria to resurrect democracy.
In Washington, the White House offered no comment, but the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, offered sympathy to General Abacha's family, reaffirmed the United States commitment to promoting democracy in Nigeria, and urged a "peaceful transition to civilian, democratic rule."
After a morning of rumors and confusion in which heavily armed soldiers sealed off the general's compound in the capital, Abuja, General Abubakar announced in a brief communique that the 54-year-old Nigerian leader, who had seized power in 1993, was dead.
The swearing-in of General Abubakar took place about 4 A.M. Nigerian time.
"I appeal to all Nigerians to put all hands on deck to move our nation forward," he said in a statement issued shortly afterward.
The communique did not specify the cause of death, but news reports quoted family friends and Western diplomats as saying General Abacha had suffered a heart attack. Reports that his health was failing circulated after he canceled a trip to Lagos, Nigeria's principal city and former capital, on Tuesday.
In one of his first official acts, General Abubakar declared seven days of mourning for General Abacha.
But word of the death drew no outpouring of sorrow in Nigeria, where the general had tamed political parties, trade unions and the press, and had an enemies' list that read like a Who's Who of Nigeria.
"God is capable of wonderful things," an opposition political figure in Lagos said from behind a screen of anonymity. "Perhaps Nigerians will be free at last."
General Abubakar, 55, was born in the northern Nigerian town of Minna and later attended the Kaduna Technical Institute in 1963 before enlisting in the air force.
A career serviceman, he transferred to the army in 1975 and received military training in the United States. In 1981 he served with Nigerian troops assigned to a United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon. He was appointed chief of the defense staff in 1993..
General Abubakar has not played a prominent political role, the BBC reported. It said that although he is the highest officer overseeing the army, navy and air force, he does not directly command any large body of troops.
Reports from Kano, the northern city where General Abacha was born in 1943, said thousands of people had lined the streets, awaiting the arrival of the general's body and an escort of senior government and military officials who were to attend the funeral.
"People don't know what to think," a Kano businessman who had closed his shop for the day told Reuters. "It's true some people are sad, but some will not be so sad either. We just worry over what comes next."
That was the question on many minds.
There was a political vacuum yesterday in the absence of General Abacha -- who wielded absolute power for five and a half years and was so haunted by the specter of a coup that he surrounded himself with a 2,000-member personal security force, rarely appeared in public and jailed or executed many leading Nigerians who could form a credible opposition.
The general's former second-in-command, Lieut. Gen. Donaldson Oladipo Diya, who had been seen as a possible successor, was sentenced to death by a military tribunal in April for allegedly plotting a coup. His fate is still in the hands of the military junta.
As Nigeria's leaders gathered in Abuja in a body called the Provisional Ruling Council, the prospects appeared at first to be for a behind-the-scenes struggle during the next few days to see who would lead the Government. Political experts said the likely contenders to succeed the general included General Abubakar; Lieut. Gen. Jeremiah Useni, Nigeria's senior officer, and Maj. Gen. Ishiaya Bamaiyi, the Army Chief of Staff.
General Abubakar, after his selection, was promoted from major general to full general and was sworn in by Nigeria's Chief Justice, Mohammed Uwais.
A coalition of 45 Nigerian groups that had clandestinely opposed General Abacha called yesterday for the installation of a civilian government headed by Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was imprisoned by General Abacha after his annulled election as President in 1993 in what was widely seen as the country's most democratic vote since it gained independence from Britain in 1960.
Mr. Abiola remains in prison.
It is a country of 250 tribal groups. The Hausa and Fulani in the north, the Yoruba in the southwest and the Ibo in the southeast make up 65 percent of the population. The 1960's were marked by a struggle for political dominance among the main ethnic groups, and a devastating civil war almost broke the country apart in the late 1960's.
During the 1970's oil exports helped Nigeria recover economically, and in the early 1980's, with a civilian Government in Lagos, Nigeria became known as a model of African democracy and prosperity. Nigerian arts were the envy of the continent. Its press was one of the freest anywhere. Nigerian diplomacy challenged the United States and Britain over issues like apartheid. The nation's currency was worth twice as much as the dollar.
But democracy in Nigeria died in 1983, and General Abacha, a career soldier who became an infantryman at 18 and attended military colleges in England, the United States and Nigeria, had a role in three coups.
The generals ousted Nigeria's last civilian government in 1983. Hopes for a return to democracy were high in June 1993, when Mr. Abiola, a millionaire businessman, won an election with pledges to return Nigeria to civilian rule. But the Government annulled the vote, and three months later Mr. Abacha overthrew President Ibrahim Babangida.
Mr. Abiola, frustrated over the victory that was stolen from him, declared himself President in defiance of General Abacha and was jailed on treason charges. General Abacha promised democratic reforms and an election in 1996 to bring back civilian government, but the promises proved hollow.
While announcing that he was stretching his rule to 1998, General Abacha began a virtual reign of terror. He cracked down on all opposition, subdued unions, took control of the press, jailed hundreds of people and began a series of trials that sent opponents to prison or the gallows.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa was executed on charges stemming from his campaign to have Nigeria's huge oil revenues shared with the communities where the petroleum was produced. The general's purges also extended to prominent Nigerians and into his inner circle, and many fled into exile.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about the death of Gen. Sani Abacha, the Nigerian leader, misidentified his predecessor. General Abacha took over in 1993 by unseating President Ernest Shonekan, an unelected civilian leader for two and a half months, not Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who had installed Mr. Shonekan.

HEADLINE: HONDA AND FORD ARE FINED MILLIONS

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Honda and Ford have agreed to pay millions of dollars in civil fines for selling cars that were designed to pass emissions tests but run dirtier on the road, Federal prosecutors announced today.
The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency fined the Honda Motor Company $12.6 million for violations of the Clean Air Act. The E.P.A. said the auto maker would also face costs of about $250 million for remedial efforts, including extending warranties and providing free tune-ups for the 1.6 million cars that are affected. 
 The Ford Motor Company will pay a $2.5 million fine for a pollution control problem on 60,000 of its 1997 Econoline vans, the officials said, and $3.8 million in other costs and compensatory measures. Ford began a recall of the vans today.
Both companies denied wrongdoing.
The announcement is an embarrassment to Honda, which in advertising and public statements has portrayed itself as an environmental leader.
The auto maker has voluntarily put extra equipment on hundreds of thousands of vehicles to make sure that they meet California's strict emission standards, even if they are sold in states that enforce the looser Federal standard. Ford also voluntarily exceeds emissions rules on many of its models.
"We are making very clear that cars are a major source of air pollution in this country and it is important for auto manufacturers to assure they are carefully complying with the Clean Air Act," said Lois J. Schiffer, an Assistant Attorney General and head of the environment and natural resources division at the Justice Department. "If they don't do it, we will take strong action against them."
The agreement with Honda covers all of the Honda and Accura vehicles built in the 1996 and '97 model years, with the exception of Passport and SLX, and the 1997 Integra R. For 1995 models, the agreement covers the Accord V-6 and the Accura NSX, 2.5 TL. Accura is a division of Honda.
The prosecutors say Honda was fined for programming the pollution-control computers to ignore spark-plug failures. The computer software would not illuminate the "check engine" light when parts fail and emissions rise, thus allowing the cars to emit twice as much smog-causing hydrocarbons without warning their drivers.
A lawyer for Honda, William R. Willen, said that the problem was one of interpretation of the rules and that the vehicles' diagnostic systems would function if the problem were serious. The "check engine" light would fail to come on, Mr. Willen said in a telephone interview, only in times of intermittent failure.
Mr. Willen said the company's engineers had simply gone too far in their efforts to minimize the number of times the light came on.
But the environmental agency estimated that uncorrected, the cars -- Civics, Accords, Del Sols, Integras, Preludes, NSX's and CR-V's, Odysseys and their Isuzu-brand twin, the Oasis -- would emit eight million extra tons of hydrocarbons in their lifetimes. Total emission of hydrocarbons from all transportation sources was about 10 million tons in 1996.
Prosecutors also said that the cars could grow sluggish without warning the driver that something was wrong and that if a driver took one to a garage, the mechanic would have a harder time diagnosing the problem.
David E. Alexander, a lawyer with the E.P.A. enforcement division, said suppressing the dashboard warning light made life harder for all drivers, even those who were relatively knowledgeable about cars.
"The idiot lights are for all of us," Mr. Alexander said.
In Ford's case, the 60,000 Econoline vans are equipped with a feature that makes them emit more nitrogen oxides at highway speeds than they do on treadmill tests.
In addition to paying $2.5 million in civil penalties, the company will buy pollution credits from other sources for $2.5 million, and will spend $1.3 million on fixing the Econolines, with a goal of completing the work on at least 70 percent of them.
A Ford spokeswoman, Sara Tatchio, said the company had changed the pollution systems on Econolines on its assembly line and in dealer lots as soon as the Goverment raised its objections early last year.
The investigation also called into question the pollution control systems on 1.7 million Ford Escorts sold between 1991 and 1995, but the agreement did not require any corrective action to those cars. Ford sold 6.9 million vehicles worldwide last year and had earnings of $6.9 billion.
Honda was also notified of the problems last year and has also corrected it for vehicles now in production.
The software in the affected Hondas is burned into the computer chips, and correcting the problem would mean replacing the chips, at a price the Government put at $500 million. The package that Honda agreed to -- including free oil changes, to lure drivers in for their free tune-ups -- was more effective, the E.P.A. said.
In addition to tuneups and engine checks, Honda will extend the warranty on the pollution-control systems to 14 years or 150,000 miles. Depending on which part was involved and where the car was sold, the existing warranties ranged from three years or 36,000 miles to eight years or 80,000 miles.
In spite of the Justice Department estimate, Honda said it did not know the cost for the remedial actions because no one had ever guaranteed car parts for that long. Honda's payment will be spread over 14 years, which will significantly reduce the financial impact on the company. Honda sold two million vehicles worldwide in 1997 and for the fiscal year that ended March 31 had a profit of $1.96 billion.
The largest previous case was the $45 million in fines and remedial actions that the General Motors Corporation agreed to in 1995 for producing Cadillacs that passed emissions tests but violated pollution standards on the road.
The Honda problem was discovered by officials of the California Air Resources Board, which serves as the Environmental Protection Agency's surrogate for certifying that Honda vehicles meet Federal standards.
The California board tested one vehicle that had been on the road for several months, and found that it did not diagnose engine misfires, in which the fuel-air mixture fails to explode and is shoved out the exhaust system, sometimes damaging the catalytic converter on the way.
On closer examination, California engineers found that the system was designed not to work.
Honda said owners with questions could call its Consumer Affairs Department at (800) 999-1009.

A front-page article on June 9 about defects in the pollution control systems of Hondas misstated the amount of additional hydrocarbons that the Government predicted would be emitted without corrective action. It was 8,000 tons of hydrocarbons, not eight million tons.
