HEADLINE: New York Pizza, the Real Thing, Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
NEW YORK pizza is a phrase synonymous with pizza greatness, yet for years New Yorkers could find the genuine article in only a few isolated spots. Now pizza lovers can rejoice: the true New York pizza is back in town.
I'm not talking about the by-the-slice pies congealing in neighborhood display windows as they await reheating or the sodden boxes delivered to the door. I'm talking about classic New York pizza: pies cooked quickly in extremely hot ovens, generally coal-fired, until the thin crust achieves a gloriously charred, smoky crispness. The dough is prepared daily; the mozzarella is real, not packaged; tomatoes are the best quality, and toppings are simple and used in moderation -- no pineapple or Thai chicken. The pizzas are cooked to order and never sold by the slice. 
 As recently as 10 years ago, the classic pizza was on the endangered list, treasured as an artifact of old New York but bypassed by a culture that preferred its pizzas fast, cheap and delivered. Just a few pizza landmarks, most famously John's Pizzeria on Bleecker Street, Patsy's Pizza in East Harlem and Totonno's Pizzeria Napolitano in Coney Island -- all presided over by rival clans -- zealously preserved the traditions. Disciples were required to make pilgrimages to these hallowed halls for a taste.
Today, those three families, plus a newcomer, are almost entirely responsible for a pizza renaissance in New York. The landmarks have been joined by a new set of great names: Grimaldi's under the Brooklyn Bridge; Lombardi's on Spring Street; Nick's in Forest Hills, Queens, and Rockville Centre, on Long Island; Candido on the Upper East Side; Polistina's on the Upper West Side; Zito's in the East Village and, most recently, Angelo's on West 57th Street. What's more, the landmarks have themselves branched out. There are now John's, Patsy's and Totonno's in many Manhattan neighborhoods.
Why the renaissance? It's driven, I think, by the same sense of renewed connoisseurship that gave rise to the microbrewery boom, for example. And as with the ponds of microbrews measured against oceans of Budweiser, it's easy to forget that the number of classic pizzerias amounts to no more than a leaf of fresh basil in a sea of canned tomato sauce.
At its highest level, pizza making is a labor-intensive, artisanal craft requiring dedication and training. The coal ovens, more than twice as hot as the gas oven at the corner pizzeria, demand an apprenticeship to master their intricacies. Good pizza makers, or "stick men," are artists, shifting and moving the pies within the oven as they cook, equalizing the effects of hot spots.
Ferreting out the freshest mozzarella cheese, building relationships with tomato suppliers and sausage makers, starting dough fresh each day, rather than in advance, being willing to jettison ingredients past their prime -- all this takes rare dedication when it's so much easier to buy long-lasting factory-made mozzarella or to make a week's supply of dough and freeze it.
Environmental regulations also make it hard to build new coal ovens. Nowadays in New York City, coal ovens can only be rebuilt or replaced under an environmental grandfather clause -- not installed from scratch. Pizza makers have become architectural historians, seeking out spaces that once housed a coal-burning oven, like old bakeries or restaurants.
The determination to make pizza the hard way seems to come from being born and bred into a pizza-making tradition. New York pizza did not exist before 1905, when Gennaro Lombardi, a Neapolitan immigrant, began to sell pies in his grocery store in Little Italy. Lombardi's was by most accounts the first New York pizzeria, and Mr. Lombardi, who hired and trained a series of other immigrants, became the sturdy tap root of a tree of family and acquaintances that would go on to define great New York pizza.
The legendary pizza makers -- John Sasso of John's, Patsy Lancieri of Patsy's and Anthony (Totonno) Pero of Totonno's -- are all said to have learned their craft at Lombardi's brick-walled coal oven. Nearly a century later, their descendants, including Lombardi's grandson, are fueling the expansion. New York's pizza dynasties are now in their third and fourth generations, and counting.
Yet, a lot of the energy has come from new blood, the Angelis-Tsoulos clan, which joined the pizza pantheon just a few years ago. In 1994, Nick Angelis, the son of a Greek pizza maker who learned the art in Naples, opened Nick's Pizza in Forest Hills. It is dedicated to preserving the tradition of New York's great pie men. Paradoxically, he uses a new kind of gas oven that can achieve the high heat necessary for the best pies. No matter. It's hard to imagine a better crust than Nick's: blackened and barely crisp, glistening and golden, with a faintly smoky flavor. The crust is matched by the other ingredients: pure, creamy mozzarella, delicious roasted peppers, terrific sausage. Mr. Angelis has since opened a second branch in Rockville Centre.
Meanwhile, Nick Tsoulos, his brother-in-law, seeing how well Mr. Angelis was doing, decided to bring such a pizzeria to Manhattan. He made an arrangement with the owners of the East Harlem Patsy's to use that name and in 1995 opened Patsy's Pizza at 509 Third Avenue, near 34th Street. The smooth, blackened crust lacks that classic smoky flavor, but the toppings are superb: wonderfully mellow mozzarella and excellent sauce made of plum tomatoes. The three other Patsy's that have since opened in Manhattan are just as good.
In April, the clan combined forces and opened Angelo's at 117 West 57th Street, named after Mr. Angelis's father and run by Nick and John Pashalis, Mr. Angelis's cousins. The pizzas are excellent, very much like the Patsy's pies.
Not surprisingly, these new pizzerias have heightened tensions among old-line pizza dynasties, which regard one another with all the sunny warmth of rival boxing promoters. Yet, faced with newcomers, they band together with a universal sneer at Mr. Angelis and Mr. Tsoulos as imitators.
More serious is the battle over the name Patsy's. The original Patsy died in the 1970's, and his widow sold the East Harlem pizzeria to longtime employees in 1991, to the chagrin of Patsy Grimaldi, her nephew, who opened a Patsy's in Brooklyn in 1990. He got even angrier when the Tsoulos Patsy's began to open in Manhattan. Finally, in a fit of independence -- not, he insists, through any legal coercion -- he changed the name of his pizzeria to Grimaldi's. Nor is there any love lost between the East Harlem Patsy's and all the others.
If the mantle of Patsy Lancieri were awarded on quality alone, Grimaldi's, at 19 Old Fulton Street, near Front Street, under the Brooklyn Bridge, would win hands down. The crust, bready and dense, is excellent, and the fragrant tomato sauce, the fresh mozzarella and the home-roasted peppers are spectacular. Sadly, the original Patsy's, in a picturesque storefront in a remnant of an Italian neighborhood at 2287-91 First Avenue, near 118th Street, has not kept up with its estranged cousins. The pizza is good, but the crust lacks snap, and the flavors lack liveliness.
In addition to Nick's and Grimaldi's, my favorite pizzerias include the original John's at 278 Bleecker Street, and Lombardi's at 32 Spring Street. John's has three other branches in Manhattan, but the ramshackle Bleecker Street site is best for the expert economy of its pizza: crust just crisp enough, with a wonderful smoky flavor, creamy mozzarella and perfectly spiced tomato sauce. There is no excess.
At Lombardi's, opened by old Gennaro Lombardi's grandson and namesake, diners revel in tradition. The handsome brick and stucco dining room is adorned with old photographs, and when you eat the pizza, with its gloriously light, thin, crisp yet elastic crust, you feel you are devouring history.
What's more, Lombardi's also serves great clam pizza, a style original to New Haven that is a worthy departure from New York traditions.
Totonno's, the third of the old New York institutions, offers a slightly different style of pizza, whether at its simple bastion in Coney Island or its duded-up new quarters at 1544 Second Avenue, near 80th Street. The crust is puffy and thick, bready, rather than thin. I'm not the biggest fan of this style, but its partisans love it. Totonno's is planning to open an Upper West Side branch in the fall.
The newcomers have all added their distinctive notes to the chorus. Zito's, 211-13 First Avenue, near 13th Street, comes from the bread-making tradition of Zito's bakery on Bleecker Street. Its crust is smooth and proper, without the slightly gritty quality of the traditional style, but superb just the same. Candido, at 1606 First Avenue, near 83d Street, produces a terrific thin-crusted pizza that is most distinctive for its lightness. You can easily put away three slices without the overstuffed feeling that comes with an ordinary pizza. The hallmark of the pie at Polistina's, which opened over the winter at 2275 Broadway, near 82d Street, is a thin crust that achieves a consistent crispness and pleasantly grainy texture.
Ultimately, in the pizza-making stratosphere, it may be nitpicking to quarrel over whose mozzarella is the freshest or whether the billowy Totonno's pie is better than the thinner John's crust. But it sure is great to have so much to choose from.
 
A Geography of Pizza: Simple, Stuffed and Carried Away
New York is not the only place that has given its name to a style of pizza. Following are some others.
 
NEW HAVEN
New Haven's claim to pizza fame is the clam pie. As made at Frank Pepe's, it is elemental and delicious: whole clams with garlic, olive oil and oregano, on a thin, brittle crust. Many New Haven pizzerias call their pies "apizza," pronounced a-BEETS. Jesse Sheidlower, a slang specialist in the reference division of Random House, suggests that comes from a dialect spoken in Catania in Sicily, where Frank Pepe was from. In Manhattan, Lombardi's at 32 Spring Street, serves a superb version.
 
NEAPOLITAN
Pizzas made according to the rules of the Naples Pizza Association, a trade group based in Italy, are different from New York pies. They are smaller, 9 to 10 inches in diameter, and the crust is softer and breadier than the crisp New York version. Neapolitan pizzas must also be made with buffalo mozzarella, San Marzano tomatoes and a special flour, and baked in a wood-burning oven. In the United States, only La Pizza Fresca, at 31 East 20th Street, and Antica Pizzeria Napoletano in Los Angeles have received the association's certificate of authenticity. Many designer pizzas made in fancy restaurants are closer to Neapolitan pizza than to New York pizza.
 
SICILIAN
These pizzas, traditionally rectangular, are significantly thicker than the Neapolitan versions, with typically puffy, breadlike dough. In New York, Sicilian pizza can be sampled at Matese Pizzeria, 26-15 Francis Lewis Boulevard, Whitestone, Queens.
 
CHICAGO
Deep-dish pizzas, as made famous by the original Pizzeria Uno and still served at the chain, are Chicago's signature. They have thick, bready crusts and chunky toppings and may be of Sicilian origin. They have grown baroque, with double crusts encasing all manner of foods.
 
CALIFORNIA
Wolfgang Puck, the Los Angeles chef, must take both the credit and the blame for California pizza. In his hands, crisp, thin-crusted pizza became a vehicle for unusual and delicious toppings like duck sausage and goat cheese and sun-dried tomato. But in less tasteful hands, the California pizza has become a cliche for bad marriages, like ham and pineapple. California Pizza Kitchen, 201 East 60th Street, serves many examples of the genre.

Most true New York pizzas, baked in intensely hot ovens, can be traced to Gennaro Lombardi.
 
GENNARO LOMBARDI
Opened Lombardi's, perhaps the first pizzeria in the United States, in 1905.
 
JOHN SASSO
Opened John's Pizzeria in 1929, after being trained by Gennaro Lombardi.
 
AUGUSTINE and PATRICK VESCE
Sasso's nephews. Took over John's in 1947.
 
PETE CASTELLOTTI and BOB VITTORIA
Sasso's grand-nephews. With Pete's wife, Madeline, took over John's in the mid 1970's.
 
PETE JR. and LISA CASTELLOTTI
Sasso's great-grand nephew and niece. Share ownership of four John's in Manhattan with the previous generation since the 1980's.
 
ANTHONY (TOTONNO) PERO
Opened Totonno's in Coney Island in 1924, after being trained by Gennaro Lombardi.
 
JERRY PERO
Anthony's son. Took over Totonno's in the 1940's.
 
COOKIE and JOEL CIMINIERI
Jerry's daughter and son-in-law. Took over Totonno's in the 1980's, and opened a second branch in Manhattan last year.
 
LAWRENCE CIMINIERI
Cookie and Joel's son. Has managed both Totonno's since 1994.
 
GENNARO LOMBARDI
Grandson of the original Gennaro. Opened a new Lombardi's in 1994 in Manhattan.
 
PASQUALE (PATSY) LANCIERI
Opened the original Patsy's in East Harlem in 1933, after, some say, working with Gennaro Lombardi.
 
PATSY GRIMALDI
Nephew of the original Patsy. Opened his own place in Brooklyn, now called Grimaldi's, in 1990. Patsy Grimaldi also learned by watching Jerry Pero at Totonno's.
 
JOHN BRECEVICH and FRANK BRIJA
Employees of Patsy Lancieri. Bought the original Patsy's in 1991.
 
ANGELO ANGELIS
Opened Pizza Chef, a successful pizzeria in downtown Brooklyn, in the 1960's.
 
NICK and JOHN ANGELIS
Angelo's sons. Operate Nick's Pizza in Forest Hills (1994) and Rockville Center (1997). Nick Angelis also observed Patsy Grimaldi's operation.
 
MIRENE ANGELIS and NICK TSOULIS
Angelo's daughter and son-in-law. They licensed the Patsy's name from John Brecevich and Frank Brija, and opened four Patsy's Pizzas in Manhattan in the 1990's.
 
JOHN and NICK PASHALIS
Angelo's nephews. Trained with Nick Angelis, and just opened Angelo's in Manhattan.
 
GODFREY POLISTINA, RALPH SCAMARDELLA, MICHAEL RONIS and JOHN DeLOACH
Restaurateurs. Opened Polistina's in Manhattan (1998), with advice from Nick Angelis.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Even with many big cities like Chicago adding to capacity, hotel rooms can still be hard to get.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
HOTEL room rates are expected to rise slightly this year, even though occupancy rates will decline slightly, but travelers should not be lulled into thinking they need not book well in advance. With the economy still chugging along, rooms will continue to be hard to come by in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Chicago and other business cities.
Chicago, for example, just added the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place, a 33-story property. All of its 800 rooms are expected to be open next month; more than 500 are already open. Even with that capacity, the hotel already projects that more than 100 nights will be sold out through the end of June 1999. 
 Designed for business travelers, all rooms have desks, ergonomic chairs and power strips with grounded outlets. There are also 53 suites, including 5 for entertaining clients. The hotel has an indoor heated swimming pool with outdoor sun deck and a health club with sauna and cardiovascular and strength training equipment.
 
Poor Skiing in 2050?
A warning for skiers: According to predictions at the recent World Congress on Snow and World Tourism, climate change caused by global warming will cause the snow line to withdraw significantly up the mountains and snow cover can be expected to last for fewer months. But there is no need to panic just yet, since the effects are not expected to be felt for 30 to 50 years.
 
Cruise Update
Remember when cruise passengers wanted to leave their worldly cares behind? They still can, but only if they don't turn on the television in their cabins. More and more ships are offering live news and sports via satellite, as well as an array of reruns for children and adults. Princess Cruises, part of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of Britain, has CNN and ESPN live, and is adding BBC reruns to its television schedule. It will also, of course, continue to show reruns of the "Love Boat" series, which was filmed on the original Sun Princess and two other Princess ships, and ran on ABC television from 1977 to 1986.
As one indication of how the cruise industry has grown, literally, consider that the Sun Princess was 17,000 tons while the Island Princess and Pacific Princess were 20,000 tons. By contrast, the Grand Princess, which made its debut May 26 and is currently sailing European waters, is 109,000 tons. While in nautical terms a ton is not a measure of weight -- more formally known as a gross register ton, it represents 100 cubic feet of internal capacity -- it is worth noting that any of those earlier ships would fit comfortably in the Horizon Court, the 24-hour restaurant aboard the Grand Princess.
Speaking of huge ships, two days ago Cunard Lines -- recently bought by the Carnival Corporation and a group of Norwegian investors -- said it was going to build "the grandest and largest liner ever built." Details will be announced.
 
Airline Update
In the last 10 days, Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines have begun nonstop service to Japan -- Northwest with two flights a week connecting Tokyo and Las Vegas, Nev., and Delta with daily nonstops between Atlanta and Tokyo. On Oct. 2, Japan Airlines will operate twice-weekly nonstops from Tokyo to Las Vegas. The Northwest and J.A.L. flights are largely a response to growing Japanese tourism to Las Vegas, while the Delta flights reflect the growing Japanese investment in the Southeast, which amounts to almost $14.5 billion, and the region's exports to Japan, which exceed $5.5 billion a year.
Air New Zealand and Ansett Australia have agreed to join the year-old Star Alliance in 1999, bolstering the alliance's access to the Pacific, especially the South Pacific. The current alliance members -- United, Air Canada, Lufthansa of Germany, Scandinavian Airlines System, Thai Airways International and Varig Brazilian Airlines -- already serve some 650 destinations worldwide, and alliance flights average a takeoff every 15 seconds around the clock.
Alaska Airlines is again offering special summer fares to and from three of the five cities it serves in the Russian Far East. Round-trip fares to Vladivostok or Khabarovsk range from $585 from Anchorage to $635 from Seattle, Reno or the San Francisco Bay area to $735 from Las Vegas, Phoenix and greater Los Angeles. Round trip to Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk is an additional $250 from each of those American cities. Fares represent savings of 48 percent to 69 percent, and as usual, restrictions apply.
Best Western International and the Arizona Biltmore Resort and Spa are the newest members of the frequent-flier program of America West Airlines.
Austrian Airlines is offering trans-Atlantic round-trip passengers a one-week car rental from Budget Rent-a-Car in Austria for $163.80 a week, or less than $24 a day, including unlimited mileage and taxes.

HEADLINE: From Palau to Kyrgyzstan, Leaders Agree: The Scourge Is Drugs

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 9

 BODY:
Palau's President describes his nation as an island paradise, with the world's best scuba diving in pristine South Pacific waters, abundant seafood, safe streets and a growing economy.
"One might think that our paradise is free of drug problems," President Kuniwo Nakamura said in a statement to the General Assembly's special session on illegal drugs. But an imported form of methamphetamine -- nicknamed "ice" -- has begun to entice users as young as 13 and 14 years old. 
 "Although our law enforcement is well trained and respected, we lack the technology to effectively combat this terrible problem," said the President's statement, which was delivered to a largely empty chamber by Palau's representative, Hersey Kyota, on Monday night.
Oratory from big nations like the United States dominated the opening of the special session on Monday. But the full scope of the drug problem has unfolded in sometimes poignant testimony by smaller and poorer countries like Palau, the United Nations' newest member. They have lined up to recount how drug trafficking and consumption have corrupted their struggling economies and societies and why they are hard pressed to stop it.
A result has been more candor than characterizes most General Assembly sessions. Former Soviet republics have complained of rising drug use in the wake of the heady arrival of democracy. Caribbean nations have recounted the dangers of being overrun by drug smugglers. Many countries have asked for financial and technical assistance and a greater effort by developed countries to reduce the demand for drugs.
Prime Minister Kubanychbek Jumaliyev of Kyrgyzstan said today that "while two or three years ago people in Kyrgyzstan had only a theoretical idea of what heroin is, nowadays it has become one of the main drugs on the illegal market."
Since Armenia found itself on the drug trafficking route from Central Asia, its Foreign Minister Vartan Oskanian said, local drug seizures have risen thirtyfold since 1993 and narcotics-related crime in Armenia is up by 150 percent. New-found democratic freedoms left many Armenians vulnerable to drugs, Mr. Oskanian said, "not just of personal use but for quick and easy financial gain."
Prime Minister Basdeo Panday of Trinidad and Tobago said his island nation's proximity to South America made it vulnerable to cocaine trafficking. Among the results, he said, were a rise in serious crime, the recruitment of unemployed people as drug traffickers and users, and a dramatic escalation in addiction.
Latvia's Prime Minister, Guntars Krasts, said that 80 percent of Latvian high school students surveyed have tried drugs at least once, and that drug abuse had claimed the lives of an increasing number of young Latvians. Deputy Prime Minister Josef Kalman of Slovakia agreed, saying, "We have noticed an increasing number of consumers coming from lower and lower age levels."
No nation has proposed legalizing drugs. The Danish Health Minister, Carsten Koch, said law enforcement works when combined with primary drug prevention and social intervention. "No government should jeopardize this situation by considering to legalize narcotic drugs for other purposes than medical and scientific ones," Mr. Koch said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Many Internet Shares Rally, but Major Indexes Are Mixed

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A three-day rally in stocks fizzled yesterday and left major market indexes mixed, illustrating Wall Street's renewed concerns about the corporate earnings outlook and some wariness about the near-term prospect for interest rates.
But a rally among some Internet-related shares pushed technology stocks higher, as the Nasdaq composite index closed above 1,800 for the first time since May 22. Falling energy prices pushed up transportation stocks, and news concerning prescription drugs continued to buoy pharmaceutical shares. 
 Blue-chip issues bore the brunt of the declines, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 19.68 points, to 9,049.92. Financial services companies like American Express, J. P. Morgan and Wells Fargo, as well as some multinational companies such as McDonald's, which had been higher in recent days, had some of the largest retreats.
Concerns about today's Congressional testimony of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, also helped weaken blue-chip issues, analysts said, as investors expressed some concern that the Fed could still raise interest rates sometime soon.
"The consensus seems to be that rates will not be going higher," said Charles W. Johnson, a managing director and head equity trader at Blaylock & Partners. "But there is that nervousness in the marketplace that maybe the Fed sees something that we don't," which would justify an interest rate increase, he said.
A continuing flow of earnings warnings from companies is keeping investors worried about the outlook for corporate profits, analysts said.
Yesterday, Billing Concepts, a billing agent for the telecommunications industry, warned that earnings could fall below expectations in its third and fourth quarters because of a decline in demand. Arrow International, a maker of disposable medical products, said fiscal third-quarter sales are likely to increase less than expected because of slowing international orders.
A decline in oil prices pushed the stocks of companies like Chevron and Exxon lower after the Paris-based International Energy Agency forecast a decline in Asian demand for oil. However, the oil-price drop lifted stocks of transportation companies, particularly airlines. Gains in such carriers as Alaska Air Group and US Airways Group lifted the Amex airline index 4.1 percent and the Dow Jones transportation average 3.11 percent, its biggest one-day gain this year.
Led by a 4-point rise in Pfizer, the Standard & Poor's 500 index inched up 2.69 points, to 1,118.41. Pfizer soared to 112 7/16 on news that the Food and Drug Administration said the company's impotence-treatment drug, Viagra, did not directly cause the deaths of 16 users.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 12.99 points, to 1,800.76, pulled higher by a broad rally in Internet stocks on news of a deal between General Electric's NBC and the struggling Web service Cnet, which shot up 12 1/8, or 37 percent, to 45 1/8. Lycos, Yahoo, America Online, Netscape Communications and Earthlink Network all rose. Lycos also gained after receiving a patent for its "spider" search technology.
But some Internet-related shares that had caught investor attention in recent weeks are now languishing. K-Tel International, which soared to 33 15/16 after the company announced in April that it would sell music on the Internet, fell 33/64, to 11 1/4.
Other prominent losses yesterday included Chromatics Color Sciences International shares, which fell about 49 percent before partly recovering to close at 6 1/2, down 2 5/16. The company develops technologies to scientifically measure skin color in order to detect jaundice in infants.
Asensio & Company, a firm that bets that stocks will go down, recommended selling the stock yesterday. Asensio said that Chromatics' principal product had no sales and licensing potential and that irregular trading activity might have occurred in the stock among owners, including two Dreyfus micro-cap mutual funds that have sizable holdings in Chromatics.
A Dreyfus spokesman called the allegations "unsubstantiated." And Darby Macfarlane, the chief executive of Chromatics, said the company was "working diligently to put out a detailed report" to counter the Asensio claims.

Treasury prices were little changed yesterday for a second consecutive session as investors awaited today's Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

HEADLINE: THE N.B.A. FINALS;
After Its Rapid Demise, Jazz Seeks Resurrection

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 9

 BODY:
Four days ago, they were the most economical and efficient team in basketball. One minute away from putting Michael Jordan's team in a two-game hole on its home floor, the Utah Jazz appeared to have all the artillery necessary to end the Chicago Bulls' championship reign.
Now, Karl Malone and John Stockton are 48 minutes away from going down, 3-1, and being devoured by the Bulls. They will take the United Center floor on Wednesday night for Game 4 of the league championship series searching for their confidence and anything resembling an offense. 
 "We don't have to be told that tomorrow is a must-win game," the reserve center Greg Foster said today. "You can sense it and feel it. Giving away another game would be like giving up our hopes of winning a title."
In the worst loss in finals history, a 96-54 defeat in Game 3, Utah scored the fewest points in a National Basketball Association game -- playoffs or regular season -- since the inception of the shot clock in 1954.
After leading by 1 point with less than a minute remaining in Game 2 before falling to the Bulls, the Jazz has essentially gone from putting Chicago on the ropes to desperately needing a victory on Wednesday.
The Bulls, meanwhile, have no intention of going back to Salt Lake City for either Game 6 or 7, preferring to end the series in five games on Friday in Chicago.
"We've always responded well after a tough loss like that, so there's no reason to think any different," Malone said. "I like our attitude now."
Indeed, the Jazz has dealt with adversity well in the playoffs this season. Utah was down, two games to one, to the Houston Rockets in a three-of-five-game first-round series. The Jazz rebounded and won in five games on its home floor. In the second round, Utah was annihilated by San Antonio in Game 3 at the Alamodome before coming back to win Game 4 and close the Spurs out in Game 5.
But that was Houston and San Antonio. This is Jordan, Scottie Pippen and the ring dynasty. If the Bulls win Game 4, Chicago will almost be assured of winning its sixth title in eight seasons.
"If we can create distance between them and us, we can put ourselves a step closer," Jordan said. "We can put them closer, put their backs closer to the wall, put them in a panic situation."
The Bulls have made the necessary adjustments after a Game 1 loss in overtime, letting Pippen play off his man and operate as a roving help defender. Dennis Rodman has plastered himself on Malone's elbow, and no one on the Jazz roster has been able to contend with Jordan physically.
About the only good news for the Jazz going into Wednesday's game was that its power forward did not skip practice on Monday to hang out with Hulk Hogan and a cast of professional wrestling blowhards in Detroit. Rodman is indeed at it again.
Chicago's irascible forward caused so much of a distraction by skipping practice and flying to Detroit on Monday to participate in a World Championship Wrestling extravaganza, the parties involved almost forgot they had a game to play on Wednesday night at the United Center.
While Coach Phil Jackson and the Bulls welcomed their wayward forward back with open arms, Jerry Sloan and the Jazz simply could not relate. Instead of dealing with how they might recover from their record loss, Sloan and his team wondered aloud how a flamboyant role player could make a mockery of the league championship series.
Asked how he would discipline Rodman for his latest transgression, "First of all, I wouldn't have him," Sloan said. "That's what makes the question real simple, because Dennis, everybody knows what he's about. Winning has never been that important to me. I'd just as soon lose if I had to be put in that situation.
"There are things I can deal with. Guys have a problem once in a while, I can deal with that. But I can't deal with it when winning is the only thing there is."
Though the Bulls and the N.B.A. were each planning to fine Rodman $10,000, the implication from the Jazz seemed to be that the Bulls organization was letting Rodman make a mockery of the finals, that Chicago would put winning before proper, old-school decorum.
"We always talk about where this league is going without Michael Jordan," Sloan said. "I think it's important to realize, if we want it to go in the other direction, where there is no discipline and no respect, then those things will be important. To me, they aren't. I know how corny it sounds, but when that is more important than the game itself, we've lost our whole reason for being here."
The Bulls were not buying that theory. Jackson said, "In the end result, Dennis always comes back and tries extra hard to please."
Bulls center Luc Longley said: "I like having Dennis as a teammate. The things he's brought to this team are far greater than anything he is taking away from the team. Some of those long road trips, he spices it up a little. He's a good bloke to have around."
Longley added: "Anyway, aren't we supposed to be talking about basketball today? I would think Game 4 is fairly huge for the Jazz, wouldn't you?"

HEADLINE: Clinton Rejects Pleas to Avoid Tiananmen Ceremony

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
President Clinton rejected appeals today that he avoid an official welcoming ceremony in Tiananmen Square in Beijing when he visits China this month, saying that he could not dictate to China's leaders how he should be received in their country.
Appearing at a news conference with President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, Mr. Clinton said appearing at Tiananmen Square, the scene of a deadly crackdown on democratic protesters nine years ago this month, did not signal that he was endorsing Beijing's suppression of dissent. 
 Last week the House voted, 305 to 116, to approve a nonbinding resolution demanding that the President avoid the plaza on his trip to China, which is to begin on June 25.
"My own view," Mr. Clinton said today, "is that if this is going to be a state visit to China and I am going to be the guest of the Chinese that they should be designing the terms of the arrival ceremony, not me. And I simply don't accept the proposition that observing their diplomatic protocol in any way undermines my capacity to advance the principles of the United States."
Addressing another issue that has generated opposition to his policy toward China, the President said his approval this year of China's launching an American satellite over the objections of the Justice Department was "a pretty routine decision" made on the recommendation of other agencies.
This was the first time that Mr. Clinton has addressed questions from the press on the satellite deal, which is the subject of a Congressional investigation. Lawmakers are seeking to learn whether American national security was harmed by the decision and whether the President was influenced by large campaign contributions from Bernard L. Schwartz, chief executive of the satellite maker, Loral Space and Communications Ltd.
The White House has rejected a call from 152 members of Congress that Mr. Clinton postpone his China trip until questions about the satellite deal have been resolved.
On Korea, Mr. Clinton rebuffed gentle pressure from Mr. Kim to ease American economic sanctions against Communist North Korea. Mr. Kim has argued publicly and privately that the United States sanctions are counterproductive, driving the fearful North Korean leadership further into isolation and alienation.
Mr. Kim said reconciliation between the Koreas and an improvement in United States-North Korea relations "should be promoted in harmony."
But Mr. Clinton said Mr. Kim had not directly asked him to lift the sanctions, adding:
"What he asked me to do was to work with him to support a policy of reciprocity, which would enable us to move forward with the reconciliation of the North and the South. And I said that I would be prepared to do that."
He said easing sanctions would require Congressional approval, but did not pledge to seek such changes. He hinted at some "executive flexibility" in some categories of economic punishment of the North, but did not promise to exercise his authority. "What I told President Kim I would do is to work with him," Mr. Clinton said.
The President also announced the resumption of loan guarantees for American companies doing business in Korea, after seven years of their being suspended by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Mr. Clinton said improved conditions for workers warranted the lifting of restrictions on the loan guarantees.
Mr. Clinton also said he and Mr. Kim had discussed a bilateral investment treaty, an "open skies" agreement for unrestricted airplane service between the United States and South Korea, and South Korea's recent decision to order $1 billion worth of Boeing airliners.
Much of the discussion between the two concerned South Korea's economic crisis, both a symptom and a cause of the financial panic gripping much of East Asia. Last year, the International Monetary Fund arranged a $58 billion rescue package for South Korea, helping stabilize exchange rates and slowing the downward slide of the economy.
Much of Mr. Kim's nine-day visit here is devoted to rebuilding investor confidence. On Monday in New York he visited the New York Stock Exchange and addressed American business leaders, reassuring them that South Korea was undertaking a sweeping reorganization of the economy, rooting out decades of corruption and featherbedding.
Mr. Kim's visit to the United States is his first since he became President in February, after a lifetime in opposition to what had for decades been a one-party state.
At an elaborate arrival ceremony at the White House this morning, Mr. Kim, who 17 years ago was under a death sentence from Seoul, was met by a 21-gun salute and warm praise. Mr. Clinton compared Mr. Kim to former protesters and political prisoners who rose to the leadership like Lech Walesa of Poland, Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and Nelson Mandela of South Africa. They are heroes who changed the world by their courage, Mr. Clinton said.
The President added, "Standing with me today is living proof, Kim Dae Jung, a human rights pioneer, a courageous survivor and America's partner in building a better future for the world."

LENGTH: 1422 words

HEADLINE: In Bilingual-Schooling Setback, Educators See Another Swing of Pendulum

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
With the defeat of bilingual schooling in California, educators around the country are examining that program's ill-fated path and drawing parallels to the outcome of other educational innovations of recent decades.
They say the story of bilingual education -- its rise in the 1960's, preceded by little research or experience in it; its mushrooming bureaucracy; the passion of its ill-prepared implementation, and, in California at least, its sudden abandonment for an equally unproved method -- is the story of American education. 
 Whether the issue is reading or mathematics, outcome-based education or open classrooms, public schooling in this country lurches from one trend to its opposite with alarming speed and little forethought, they say.
"It is the pendulum-swing approach to educational reform," asserted Patricia Albjerg Graham, professor of the history of education at Harvard University. "Bilingual education exemplifies the American enthusiasm to find a complete solution by going to extremes, when most solutions in fact are in the middle."
Chester E. Finn Jr., a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, put it this way: "Bilingual education, like every interesting idea, was eventually carried to a pernicious extreme and created its own backlash. It began for humane and reasonable motives. But it got distorted, twisted and turned into a caricature, with its interest groups and zealots and funding streams. The view was, If one year of bilingual education is good, two years must be better."
Bilingual education -- teaching immigrant children in their native language while they simultaneously learn English for several years -- has hardly vanished overnight. It exists in most states and has many backers and practitioners.
But it was decisively rejected last week by California voters, many of them Hispanic. Barring a successful court challenge, then, bilingual education will end in the state that is home to 45 percent of the nation's children with limited English skills. And other challenges to it, in the states and in Congress, suggest that its days as a widely hailed solution to the complex problems of immigrant absorption are numbered.
Yet the program that will replace bilingual education in California -- one year of so-called structured English immersion for all limited-English students, with minimal instruction in other subjects during that period, all of it in English -- comes equally untested. That was the main reason many of California's political leaders and editorial pages gave for opposing the anti-bilingual ballot initiative, Proposition 227.
"So much of what we do in education is a reaction to what we just did," said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, in Washington. "A lot of people I know would have supported Proposition 227 if it had included two to three years of English immersion rather than one, which is seen as draconian and hard to implement."
There has been a similar pattern in reading instruction, which has moved, on and off, from traditional phonics (the sounding out of words) to so-called whole language (looking for contextual clues to meaning). The same has been true of mathematics, where the tradition of drill and practice yielded to a more conceptually oriented approach of word problems and team solutions before emerging to the fore again.
The reading wars are not new -- Jeanne S. Chall, now retired from an education professorship at Harvard, wrote a book on the debate in 1967 -- but they have grown so intense that a committee of experts commissioned by the National Research Council sought to put an end to them by studying the issue. In a recent report, the committee said there was merit to both approaches and to a mixture of them.
"So often," Mr. Finn said, "the truth about these things can be summed up with the word 'both.' "
Theodore R. Sizer, chairman of the Coalition of Essential Schools, a group advocating educational innovation, said being a teacher could be frustrating. "They tell you not to use phonics or whole language," Mr. Sizer said, "when in fact a good teacher uses both with an eye on who the kid is. We have this bad habit of giving simple encyclicals to define very complex issues."
That tendency appears to have grown more common in recent decades, with tugs-of-war inside the educational system serving increasingly as proxies for battles over larger societal concerns. (Larry Cuban, education professor at Stanford University, sees an analogy to the religious wars of earlier societies.)
This has been the case to some extent since public schooling was made compulsory in the last century, but even more so since the 1960's, when education began to be viewed as a means toward national as well as personal well-being. "The answer for all our national problems comes down to a single word," President Lyndon B. Johnson declared in 1965. "That word is 'education.' "
As a result, the war on poverty, absorption of immigrants and preparation of a new multicultural generation are all viewed as appropriate goals for the educational system. At the same time, parents look to schools as a cornerstone of their children's credentials and financial future. Each set of forces creates pressures to innovate, but not necessarily in the same direction.
One factor in the failure of some innovations is the unacknowledged difficulty of undertaking them. Since reform often comes in response to a pressing problem -- immigration, delinquency, international competition -- adjusting the system to meet the need is like repairing an airplane in midflight.
In "The Right to Learn" (Jossey-Bass, 1997), Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor of education at Columbia University, noted that after the Soviet Union launched Sputnik four decades ago, American policy makers felt an urgent need to improve teaching. But despite research showing that approaches like "discovery learning" and team teaching prepared students to think more critically than did the rote approach of previous years, efforts to incorporate the new methods largely failed because teachers were not properly instructed in them.
"Perhaps the single biggest obstacle to maintaining progressive reforms is the extensive skill needed to teach both subjects and students well," Dr. Darling-Hammond wrote.
This is evident in the current examinations of what has gone wrong with bilingual education. Finding teachers who were fully bilingual was itself difficult, let alone making sure that they were also skilled and fully trained.
Catherine Snow, a professor of education at Harvard who was chairwoman of the National Research Council committee that examined the teaching of reading, said the trouble with many reforms is that "there is inadequate recognition of how much professional quality it takes to do a good job of them."
Most education research, Professor Snow said, is done by giving bold new ideas to first-rate teachers. Their successes produce "lots of descriptions of extremely wonderful, exciting classrooms and relatively few of average classrooms," she said. Far too little research, she added, takes the somewhat jaundiced but essential perspective: not of how good an approach can be when well done, but of how bad it will be when badly done.
Other experts say methods are less important than the presence of dedicated and thoughtful teachers.
"Many educational practices succeed by dint of our wanting them to succeed," argued Philip W. Jackson, professor of education at the University of Chicago.
Gerald Graff, a colleague of Professor Jackson at Chicago, says the cloistered nature of the classroom lets ignorance, misinformation and paranoia flourish among the general public outside. Educators, Professor Graff says, must acknowledge a growing and legitimate public concern over education and take initiatives to explain themselves better, or face ill-informed tinkering by politicians and voters.
"The main experience of education historically is that of failed efforts," he said. "The more we fail, the more we try new things, and so you get these desperate swings.
"We fail partly because democratic education is such a tough challenge. It is a relatively new idea in the world to educate anything more than the elite. But the more people see they have a stake in it, the more fighting over it there will be. Something this valuable and expensive is going to be fought over politically, and we educators have to be prepared to take part in that fight."

HEADLINE: Wage Gap Between the Sexes Is Narrowing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The strong economy and an increase in the minimum wage have helped narrow the wage gap between the sexes by about 3 cents on the dollar since last spring, the Clinton Administration has reported.
"White, college-educated males have always done the best, but as the economy gets tighter, other people get more opportunities," Rick McGahey, the Assistant Labor Secretary for Policy, said on Monday. 
 With unemployment at its lowest level in 28 years, companies are scrambling to find and keep workers, opening higher paying jobs and promotions to women and members of minorities.
In addition, since women still tend to be concentrated in the lowest-paying jobs, the increase in the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour last summer is also credited with helping to improve their earning power compared with men, Mr. McGahey said.
In the 12 months ending March 31, the median weekly wage for women working full time grew 6.6 percent, to $455 from $427, the department said. Men's median wage grew by 2.4 percent, to $596 from $582.
As a result, women earned 76 cents for every dollar men made in the first quarter of 1998, compared with 73 cents in the same period of 1997.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Signing Bonus Now a Fixture Farther Down the Job Ladder

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Unable to hire enough teachers, the Dallas school board voted last month to lure them with $1,500 signing bonuses. Corporate recruiters paid out much larger bonuses -- averaging $17,500 -- to Cornell's business school graduates. Even Burger King has got into the bonus game, offering $5,000 in some cities to hire away restaurant managers from rival fast-food chains.
The signing bonus is proliferating in America, and growing ever larger as employers bid for scarce workers. A recruiting tool that had been limited to upper-level managers, highly skilled technicians and athletes, it is spreading today to many others, even civil servants. The Labor Department, for example, is for the first time offering a bonus of up to $4,000 to attract young economists. 
 The hiring bonus appears to be flourishing because employers, faced with the lowest unemployment rate in a quarter-century, have shifted some of the bargaining from wages to the less costly one-time payments. And job applicants, accepting the shift, often welcome the bonus as a windfall to pay off accumulated debt, or as a measure of their value -- and status -- in the eyes of their new employers.
One 30-year-old woman, recently hired as a consultant at Price Waterhouse, accepted the proffered $85,000 salary without challenge, but balked at the $5,000 signing bonus. "I barely had to say that $5,000 was not enough, and they said, 'Fine, would $10,000 make you happy?' and I got that," she said. She declined to give her name out of concern, she said, that other newly hired consultants at Price Waterhouse who got smaller bonuses might be resentful.
The hiring bonus is just the latest tool that companies have turned to in recent years to hold down wages. The others include profit sharing, flexible schedules, tuition subsidies, stock options, health club memberships and "performance" bonuses in lieu of raises for those already on the payroll. While wages are now rising a bit faster than they have in a decade, hiring bonuses are ballooning and spreading across the work force -- absorbing some of the pressure for still-greater income.
"Signing bonuses are certainly rising faster than starting salaries," said Stephen Johansson, director of career services at the Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University. "It is much harder to raise the starting salaries because you end up having to pay people coming in the door more than those who have been there two or three years and have done well. Most companies have avoided raising wage scales."
The American Management Association, in a new survey of its corporate members, found that 44 percent of the 344 who replied paid signing bonuses to employees hired in the last year. That was up from 30 percent last spring, the first time the association even asked about the practice in its surveys.
"A lot of our clients offer the base pay up front, and then the bonus in a second interview as the kicker to get people in the door," said Jamie Hale, an executive at Watson Wyatt, the management consulting firm. "The bonuses range from 5 to 15 percent of a year's salary. In some cases, people have to pay them back if they leave within six months. But if you attach too many strings, the bonuses are not going to do what they are supposed to do, which is get people on board."
For all its growing popularity, the signing bonus is hard for the Federal Government to track and is not calculated as part of the Employment Cost Index, a broad Federal measure of worker compensation. The index converts the various forms of income and benefits into pay per hour. For the bonus, however, that cannot be easily done, officials explain, because it has already been paid by the time a new employee starts working.
That means people have more spending money than the income statistics suggest. In addition, labor costs may be putting greater pressure on companies to raise prices than the Employment Cost Index now indicates. The Federal Reserve considers the index an important indicator of whether inflationary pressures are building up sufficiently to justify an increase in interest rates to slow the economy.
One measure of the bonus's popularity is its spread over the last year or so to most fast-food companies. "If you are going to get good people, you have to take them from a competitor, and the way to get them is the bonus," said Anthony Austin, vice president for human resources at Burger King, a unit of Diageo P.L.C.
Not that every Burger King employee gets one. Rarely are they disbursed in Montana, say, or in other places where unemployment is not so low. But in the tight labor markets of a Milwaukee or a Tampa, Fla., the company finds itself paying an $8,000 to $10,000 bonus to recruit a $50,000-a-year area manager, and $3,000 to $5,000 to win someone to a $35,000-a-year job as a restaurant manager.
"Someone else will pay the bonus if you don't," Mr. Austin said.
But counter clerks, earning $6 or $7 an hour, are not yet in the loop. The odds are too great that they would take a $200 bonus and quit within a week, Mr. Austin said. Instead, they get that amount as a "retention" bonus if they stay for six months.
Sometimes, when a worker shifts to a new employer, the signing bonus compensates for a benefit lost at the old job. That happened to Sarah Peters, who joined the Principal Financial Group in Des Moines last month as a writer in the public relations department, earning more than $35,000 a year. She shifted from a similar job at Mid-American Energy, a Des Moines power company.
"Principal recruited me," said Ms. Peters, who is 25, "but I have my wedding coming up in October and I hesitated to accept; it meant giving up the vacation time I had accumulated for my honeymoon."
As a signing bonus, Principal granted her a one-time-only extra week of paid time off, to be taken whenever Ms. Peters wishes. Normally, an employee at Principal, a big insurance company, earns one paid day off, to be taken as vacation or sick leave, for each two months of work. "Principal is the employer of choice for anyone in Des Moines," Ms. Peters said, "but without that vacation bonus, I would have definitely thought twice about taking the job."
No one is more a target of the signing bonus than the college graduate -- not only those receiving an M.B.A., but even those getting a simple bachelor's degree. Rather than push against stiff resistance to a higher salary, they are often satisfied, some experts say, to pocket a fat up-front bonus because they feel they will move on anyway to another job in two or three years.
Three of every 10 graduates at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte got bonuses this spring, up from one in 10 two years ago, according to a school survey. And at Cornell's management school, which had 260 graduates this spring, 90 percent of the new M.B.A.'s who responded to a survey said they had received bonuses from their new employers. That was up from 63 percent two years ago.
More striking were the skyrocketing amounts. The $17,500 average bonus for this year's Cornell M.B.A. class was nearly double the 1996 average of $9,400, and 43 percent above last year's $12,200.
The bonus is spreading, for the first time, to the public sector. The Labor Department has just started to use it, in the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as has the Census Bureau. An act of Congress is required to raise Civil Service pay scales, but bonuses are legal under a rarely invoked provision in the law. In recent months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has paid bonuses of $2,000 to $4,000 to nine newly hired employees, seven of them economists.
"I hired one guy and there was a competing bonus from another agency," said Michael Allen, a personnel specialist at the bureau. "The compensation packages were basically equal and he wanted to work with us, but without the bonus he would not have accepted."
Short of teachers, the Baltimore Board of Education voted last month to pay $5,000 to new teachers buying a home within the city. There are two strings attached: The bonus must be used for the home purchase and must be paid back if the teacher leaves the job in less than five years.
In Texas, the school boards in Dallas and Fort Worth are engaged in what amounts to a bonus war. Fort Worth led off earlier this year with a set of bonuses starting at $500 and rising to $2,000 for applicants who signed contracts by June 1.
The Dallas board countered last month. Faced with 900 openings for the coming school year, the board authorized a flat $1,500 for each new hire. More than 200 signed up at a job fair on May 30, including Linda Livingston, a 50-year-old English teacher who had taught public school before and wanted the $28,500-a-year job to help put two children through college.
"The bonus is kind of nice," she said, "but that is all; you can go through the money pretty fast."
But for Vicki Parker, a junior high school teacher currently on leave who lives in Winifred, Mont., the bonus being offered by Dallas made all the difference in the world. Hearing of it on a radio news broadcast, she immediately applied and her papers are being processed. "I have cousins in Dallas," she said.
Montana has a surplus of teachers and Ms. Parker, who is 40 and single, has never earned more than $17,000 a year in the state.
"Whenever a school system is willing to offer a bonus, there is a need," she said. "The $1,500 isn't so much, but they are probably willing to do extra things for me, because they need me, which is not the case here."

HEADLINE: Logjam on Bill To Cut Smoking Starts to Unclog

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Signs developed today that the Senate's weeks-long impasse on anti-smoking legislation might be broken.
The Senate voted, 52 to 46, for a Republican amendment to use some of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices on drug abuse programs. The vote was the first on the legislation in three weeks, and plans were made to vote on Wednesday on proposals to use other money from the tobacco legislation for income-tax cuts. 
 No one involved was prepared to assert that the bill was out of the woods. But in a brief interview, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said, "If we're going to start having some votes, then something might happen."
This was a different tack from the one Mr. Lott took on Monday, when he said the bill was such bad legislation that it should be withdrawn. Approval of the anti-drug measure, along with expected adoption of the tax cuts, "does change the mix," he said tonight.
In a telephone conversation just before President Clinton's news conference this afternoon, Senator Lott told the President of the progress. When he was asked about the legislation, the President said:
"I do believe that the possibility of getting a comprehensive bill out of the Senate is greater now than it was this morning. There are still problems, to be sure. But we are getting closer to, I think, a principled compromise."
Senator John McCain, the chief sponsor of the bill, agreed. "Reports of the death of this legislation were premature," he said. But Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona, quickly added that "a lot of difficult hurdles" remained before the bill could be brought to a final vote.
The basic bill, meant to discourage teen-age smoking, would raise the price of cigarettes by at least $1.10 a pack over five years, expand Federal regulation of tobacco marketing and advertising, and require the cigarette makers to pay stiff penalties if youth smoking did not fall to specified levels.
Most Democrats have argued that it is the most important public health measure to come before Congress in years. Republicans have countered that the legislation is a futile effort to deal with a public health problem by raising taxes and creating new Government programs.
The measure to be considered on Wednesday would give tax breaks to couples filing joint returns and to self-employed workers who must pay for their own medical insurance. That and the anti-drug measure approved tonight give Republicans the opportunity to argue that they have turned the legislation into one that fits Republican principles.
Republican leaders in the House are still unenthusiastic about the direction the legislation in the Senate is taking. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, told reporters today that his associates were working on a stripped-down bill that would not raise the price of cigarettes.
The Congressional elections this fall are a motif that influences the entire debate. Democrats have made clear that if strong anti-smoking legislation does not pass, they will accuse Republicans of doing the bidding of the tobacco companies. But Democrats have been forced into supporting income-tax cuts to keep the Republicans themselves from having a strong campaign issue.
The logjam in the Senate came unstuck today during a series of private meetings that followed an unsuccessful Democratic move to cut off debate on the legislation. The Democratic effort, called cloture, was rejected by 56 to 42 -- 18 votes shy of the 60 needed for approval.
All the Republicans who voted, even such anti-smoking stalwarts as John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Mr. McCain himself, opposed stopping the debate, treating the matter as a challenge to the Republican leadership. All the Democratic senators who voted were in favor of cloture except for two from tobacco states, Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky and Charles S. Robb of Virginia.
Both sides agreed that the cloture vote had caused senators to focus on the issue. Senator Lott said Democrats had become willing to compromise because "they saw we wouldn't crack on cloture."
Democrats had a different explanation. They said Senator Lott's hand had been forced because he knew he could not keep Republicans who favor tobacco legislation in line on future votes to cut off debate. New cloture votes are set for Wednesday and Thursday.
One of the most ardent opponents of the legislation, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said tonight that the changes being made might swing him around. "This is a step in the right direction," he said.
The Republican amendment approved tonight, on what was virtually a party-line vote, would spend part of the money raised from higher cigarette prices to beef up Federal efforts against drug trafficking and to give vouchers to children who are victims of drug-related crimes so they can attend private or parochial schools. The amendment would also prohibit Federal money from being used for needle-exchange programs.
After approving the Republican amendment, the Senate rejected, 53 to 45, a Democratic alternative that would also have put more money into drug interdiction programs. The Democratic proposal would not have included vouchers for schoolchildren, however, and would have limited the moratorium on needle exchanges to one year.
Senator McCain said that beyond the drug and income-tax issues, only a few contentious topics remained. One involves the kind of assistance that would be given to tobacco farmers and to communities whose economy is dependent on tobacco farming and cigarette manufacturing.

HEADLINE: House to Vote Today on Legislation for Bankruptcy Overhaul

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The House is preparing to vote on Wednesday on the first major overhaul of the bankruptcy system in two decades, legislation that could allow the credit and banking industries to reap billions of dollars.
Coming at a time when credit-card lending is among the most profitable sectors of an intensely competitive banking industry that has little room for growth, the legislation has prompted the credit-card and banking businesses to spend millions of dollars to push the bill. 
 The theory of the measure, sponsored in the House by Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, is that thousands of people are shucking their responsibilities, driving up their debt and then declaring themselves insolvent under Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code, which forgives most debts. The legislation would make it more difficult for consumers to use Chapter 7 while giving banks, credit-card companies, department stores and other lenders more authority to recoup what they are owed.
The industry estimates that of the 1.37 million people who filed for bankruptcy last year, 15 percent to 25 percent had the means to pay their debts. It says that the debts of these dishonest people are passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices and higher interest rates that cost every American household about $400 a year. The industry estimates that by reducing the number of people who file under Chapter 7 and putting others on a more rigorous repayment schedule, it could recoup $4 billion a year.
Many Democrats in Congress and consumer advocates have criticized the bill as a billion-dollar bouquet to the credit-card industry. They say that while companies complain about people not paying their debts, they also send out more than two billion "pre-approved" credit-card solicitations annually -- 12 for each person in the United States. Critics say this can tempt vulnerable people to borrow more.
"They could easily see a billion a year in windfall profits from this legislation," Elizabeth Warren, a professor at Harvard Law School and strong critic of the bill, said of the credit-card industry. "They will do it by squeezing hard-pressed families out of the bankruptcy system and continuing to collect from them $50 here and $50 there."
That could add up to billions, Professor Warren said.
The full Senate is to take up a more lenient version of the bill this summer. Both versions would apply only to people filing for bankruptcy whose incomes are above the national median of $50,000 a year for a family of four. Those earning less, could file under Chapter 7, or under Chapter 13, which allows a judge to set a repayment schedule.
Under the House bill, debtors who are deemed able to repay 20 percent of their debt over five years would not be allowed to file under Chapter 7. The Senate version gives the bankruptcy judge more leeway in setting a repayment plan.
If committee votes are any indication, the House and Senate will pass their versions of the bill, and will have to reconcile them. The Clinton Administration has said it opposes the House bill in its present form.
In a May 21 letter to Congress, Jacob Lew, acting director of the Office of Management and Budget, objected to a provision that would impose what he described as "a rigid and arbitrary" income test to determine who could file for bankruptcy.
Both President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have also expressed concern that the legislation would force debtors to repay credit-card companies before making alimony and child-support payments.
The bill is clearly a priority for the industry. Last year alone, over 100 financial-services companies spent more than $40 million to push it and other banking legislation through Congress, according to lobbying-disclosure records. Much of that money rained down here on the K Street corridor of professional lobbying firms. The records do not include the undoubtedly higher amounts spent so far this year, when scores of lawyers and industry lobbyists swarmed over the House and Senate Judiciary Committees as they gaveled the bankruptcy bill to approval.
The bankruptcy issue has been cooking along behind the scenes on Capitol Hill for a couple of years. But even as it has drawn closer to the floor, it has been overshadowed by tobacco legislation and other matters. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, described the bankruptcy bill as "a freight train going 90 miles an hour."
Referring to the hordes of financial-services lobbyists who have been packing the Capitol corridors, Mr. Dodd added: "It's hard to find someone on K Street who hasn't been called in to work on this bill."
Virtually anyone who is owed money has spent money lobbying for the bill. Included are department stores like J. C. Penney, which spent $500,000 on banking legislation last year, and Sears Roebuck, which spent $240,000, according to records on file with Congress. The International Council of Shopping Centers devoted $360,000.
The reports for the first six months of 1998 are due in August.
Eager to see this legislation are the credit-card companies and other money lenders. Visa spent $1.3 million last year on lobbying, according to records, and Mastercard International spent $390,000. The Money Store, a financial services company based in Union, N.J., with a loan portfolio of $10 billion, spent $1.2 million on lobbying last year.
Many interested parties turned to experienced K Street lobbyists to push the issue. The American Financial Services Association, the main trade group that provides credit to consumers, paid $600,000 to the firm of Barbour Griffith & Rogers.
Haley Barbour, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, is a senior partner in the firm. The association also helped organize fund-raisers for Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, and Representative Bill Jenkins, Republican of Tennessee, who co-sponsored the legislation.
In addition, the industry has increased its campaign contributions to members of both houses who are playing major roles in the bill's move through Congress. Under the banner of the National Consumer Bankruptcy Coalition, the industry has given $1.6 million to House and Senate candidates so far in the 1997-98 election cycle, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics.
Bruce Markell, a bankruptcy specialist at Indiana University Law School, said the bill was a priority for lenders because credit cards were so profitable. Three-fourths of all households have at least one, and three-fourths of those carry debt from month to month at high rates of interest, often around 18 percent. The prime audience for credit cards, he said, is women 25 to 40.
"They make money on being able to target those people who incur debt and can barely pay it off," Mr. Markell said, noting the widespread opportunities to use credit cards these days to buy almost everything.
At the end of 1997, Americans owed $422 billion in credit-card loans, twice as much as at the end of 1993.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Public Ambition of A Private Firm

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
As the partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company debate whether to turn Wall Street's premier private investment bank into a public company, they might mull over this paradox: They are earning record profits advising clients to do deals they themselves would never do.
As a partnership, Goldman does not issue stock, the basic currency of big mergers and acquisitions. So while it helped link Daimler A.G. to the Chrysler Corporation and brought BankAmerica together with Nationsbank, two of the biggest deals in the global rush to consolidate, Goldman has husbanded its partners' capital and shunned the risky mergers game. 
 All that may change, some Goldman insiders say, if the partners back a plan to go public at the firm's annual meeting on Friday. Going public would help Goldman buy other firms to expand at home and abroad. It would level the playing field with its fast-growing rivals, including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Salomon Smith Barney, all of which are publicly owned.
Some outside bankers say that public ownership might make Goldman a target for big commercial banks, though few expect Goldman would agree to any deal that could compromise its fiercely independent culture.
How aggressive Goldman becomes depends on how partners react to the firm's strategic plan, a study of options drawn up under the leadership of Henry M. Paulson Jr., Goldman's co-chief executive. People familiar with the broad outlines say it explores ways that Goldman, as a public company, could rapidly expand in areas in which it considers itself small or weak.
Among the most likely acquisition targets: a major American or European asset management company or a Japanese brokerage house. Goldman in the past has sought close ties with T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based mutual fund manager with about $100 billion in assets. Some Goldman bankers say the firm should also consider an alliance with Daiwa Securities, Japan's second-largest broker after Nomura and the only leader there that has yet to find a partner.
Goldman wants to add to the mutual funds and other assets it manages so that it can rely more on recurring fees and less on volatile trading and underwriting revenues. Nearly all major American brokers have tried to grab a bigger share of Japan's securities market, especially since that country's long recession has reduced the cost and barriers to entry.
"The question is how to expand more quickly," said a Goldman partner who will participate in Friday's debate and declined to be identified. "No one wants to radically remake the firm. But there is some frustration that we are not a part of all the deal making."
Any shopping spree by Goldman would add to the financial world's consolidation frenzy, especially if the respected banking house puts its seal of approval on the recent trend of combining insurance, commercial banking and investment banking. It would also be a sign that in the race to become global players, even the most successful banks and fund managers need a public currency -- stock -- to make transactions.
By some measures, Goldman has fallen behind leading rivals. It manages $160 billion in assets, well under Merrill Lynch's $450 billion. Goldman's elite client list is the envy of Wall Street. But Morgan Stanley has combined its blue-chip corporate business with a retail brokerage network selling stocks to Main Street investors, earning the steady fees and high margins those accounts bring.
A Goldman spokesman said on Monday that even if the partners decided to take the firm public, that did not mean Goldman would abandon its strategy of growing internally rather than through acquisitions. He rejected as "rumors" the idea that Goldman had an informal shopping list of companies it would like to buy.
The spokesman agreed that to have stock to make purchases was a factor in the debate over issuing shares, but added, "I don't think it's a primary factor." He added, "It's a factor in the sense that you don't know what the world will be like, and this gives you more options."
Goldman has considered and rejected the idea of selling shares as part of an expansion plan half a dozen times in recent years, and it might decide to pass this time as well. Profits, after all, are running at a record level, with the firm set to earn more than $2 billion in this year's first half, compared with about $3 billion all of last year. Most of those profits come from the firm's bread-and-butter business of trading, underwriting and providing client advice.
And even if Goldman could tap public capital markets instead of relying primarily on partners' capital, it would not necessarily follow the path blazed by other Wall Street financiers, like Sanford I. Weill of the Travelers Group. Mr. Weill recently agreed to merge his company with Citicorp, the largest financial deal in history.
"I would think that the idea of being part of Citibank would send shivers up and down the spine of every person at Goldman," said one retired partner, who asked not to be named. "On the other hand, the firm has to have the currency to make strategic acquisitions. It now has its hands tied."
In the past, the firm has tended to grow internally, making only small acquisitions. When Goldman wanted to break into the European asset management fund business, it bought the small British pension fund manager Cinman, a deal valued at the time at less than $100 million. When the publicly traded Merrill Lynch pursued a similar vision last year, it snapped up the leading European player, Mercury Asset Management, paying $5.3 billion.
Similarly, several American investment banks have scrambled to expand their presence in Japan. Goldman has performed well there but has fallen behind rivals like Merrill and Salomon in striking alliances. Salomon earlier this month spent $1.6 billion for a 25 percent stake in Nikko Securities. To date, Goldman has followed a more conservative strategy in Japan, finding partners to help distribute its mutual funds but avoiding major capital commitments.
A small number of current and retired Goldman executives at least loosely entertain the idea of much bigger deals. One possibility is a merger with a commercial bank eager for Goldman's investment banking expertise. Chase Manhattan, J. P. Morgan and BankAmerica, three of the largest American banks, would make the most logical fits, some bankers say.
All of those banks have stock market values so far above even the highest values placed on a public offering by Goldman that they could swallow the Wall Street firm with little trouble. All have strong traditional banking businesses but lag far behind Goldman in investment banking.
If the firm decides to issue stock priced at $20 a share, "then Chase offers us $25 a share, we would at least have to consider it," said one current Goldman partner. "My own feeling is that the way to unlock Goldman's true value is through a merger" rather than a public offering of stock, he added.
But such alliances remain long shots. Even if Goldman decides to go public, it seems unlikely to risk diluting the tightly integrated, highly motivated culture it has nurtured over recent decades by blending itself with a large outsider.
Moreover, Goldman is not only one of Wall Street's most profitable creations, it is also one of its most egocentric. Bankers there say they would never agree to be dominated by a commercial bank, with its eight-hour days and fatter management structure. Thus, Goldman would insist on a difficult reverse merger in any linkup with a big commercial bank, putting its own executives in control of a combined entity.
At any rate, Goldman will probably need all its in-house mergers and acquisitions expertise if it decides to go public. "I wonder if they know the kind of pressure they will be under if they actually pull the trigger," said one outside banker.
