HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Blue-Chip Rally Fades, But Internet Shares Gain
A three-day rally in blue-chip stocks lost stamina, leaving major market gauges mixed. The stumble illustrated some renewed concerns about the corporate earnings outlook and the prospect for interest rate changes ahead of Congressional testimony today by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.68 points, to 9,049.92. But sharp gains among some Internet-related shares pushed technology stocks higher, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 12.99 points, to 1,800.76, its fourth straight gain and first close above 1,800 since May 22. Drug and transportation shares also gained. Page D9. 

Treasury prices were little changed, as investors awaited today's testimony. D9.
 
Boeing to Cut 747 Production
Boeing said it would cut production of its wide-body 747 aircraft in 1999 because of slow growth in Asia. The company also said it would eliminate more jobs than the 12,000 that it had previously announced. D5.
 
Lenders Back Bankruptcy Overhaul
The credit card and banking businesses are spending millions of dollars to push for the first big overhaul of the bankruptcy system in two decades. The House is preparing to vote today on the bill, which would make it tougher for consumers to escape their debts. Lenders could recoup some $4 billion a year. A18.
 
A Key Court Test: Herb or Drug?
A case to be heard in Federal court in Salt Lake City next Monday is being closely watched as a pivotal battle between the Food and Drug Administration and the wildly growing dietary supplement industry. At issue is Chinese red yeast sold here by Pharmanex under the name Cholestin to lower cholesterol. The F.D.A. calls it an unapproved drug. A1.
 
Merger Forms Options Rival
The American and Philadelphia stock exchanges agreed to merge, creating a powerful options trading rival to the dominant Chicago Board Options Exchange. D9.
 
Anti-Smoking Impasse May End
The first signs developed that the impasse in the Senate on anti-smoking legislation might be broken, as the Senate voted, 52 to 46, for a Republican amendment to use some of the money raised from higher cigarette prices on drug abuse programs. A1.
 
Speed Sought in Microsoft Trial
A Federal judge said that he would limit to 6 to 12 each the number of witnesses either Microsoft or the Government may call during the September trial of the antitrust suits filed by the Justice Department and 20 states. The goal is to avert a lengthy proceeding. D6.
 
Court Allows Keating New Trial
Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan executive who became a symbol of the 1980's savings and loan scandals after the $3.4 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings, is entitled to a new trial on Federal securities charges because jurors improperly learned of state convictions on similar charges, an appeals court ruled. D2.
 
Germany's Unemployment Drops
The number of unemployed workers in Germany fell by 223,400 in May, sending the jobless rate down one-tenth of a point, to 11.2 percent. That and last week's report of strong economic growth are expected to help Chancellor Helmut Kohl's struggling campaign for re-election in September. D4.
 
Easier Data Export Curbs Sought
Leading technology executives huddled for two hours in a closed-door meeting with Attorney General Janet Reno and the F.B.I. director. The White House hopes to ease export curbs on data encryption technology. D5.
 
Russian Statisticians Arrested
The Russian Government arrested the head of the State Committee for Statistics, Yuri Yurkov, and his top deputies and accused them of manipulating data to help Russian companies avoid taxes. The arrests bring into question how the Government measures economic performance. A3.

HEADLINE: NEW HEALTH PLANS DUE FOR ELDERLY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Thirty-eight million Medicare beneficiaries will soon be flooded with information about new health insurance options, and most of them are likely to be thoroughly confused, consumer advocates, members of Congress and Medicare officials say.
The new options were created by Congress last year to give beneficiaries a wider variety of choices, like those available to many workers in private industry who receive insurance coverage from their employers. 
 But Michael Hash, deputy administrator of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, who is supervising the new program, said, "Many beneficiaries do not understand the basics of the original Medicare program," much less the exotic variations of managed health care devised by Congress.
The Government plans an extensive education and publicity campaign and will soon send a new Medicare handbook, with a detailed description of all the options, to every Medicare beneficiary's household.
Federal officials said they had tested the materials in "focus groups" of beneficiaries and said the results were not encouraging. Beneficiaries are often overwhelmed by the number of choices, Mr. Hash said, and "even well-educated beneficiaries have difficulty understanding them all."
Illene Gordon, a caseworker for Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, predicted that Congressional offices would "be flooded with calls" from constituents baffled by the Medicare options, which include not only health maintenance organizations, but also preferred-provider organizations, provider-sponsored organizations, medical savings accounts and private fee-for-service plans.
John C. Rother, director of legislation and public policy at the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "Most beneficiaries will have a hard time sorting through the new choices because of their complexity, and because the Medicare population has very little experience with managed care. It's not what they had when they were working. We can anticipate a high level of confusion."
The new options, most of which will become available late this year, offer the possibility of extra benefits, including prescription drugs and other items not covered by the standard Medicare program, the national health care plan for the elderly. But they may also expose beneficiaries to higher costs and more uncertainty.
Equally important, the new options represent a great national experiment in health policy, enabling private health plans to compete with Medicare's Government-run insurance program. Consumers will decide which model works best.
Different options will be available in different parts of the country, and no one knows for sure how many private health plans will enter the potentially lucrative Medicare market. If beneficiaries are satisfied with their health care, they do not have to make a change.
Six million beneficiaries are in an H.M.O. or another type of managed care today. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that the number will soar to 17 million by 2008.
Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, a psychiatrist, said: "I am really worried that when 38 million beneficiaries -- 26 million households -- get the new Medicare handbook, confusion will reign. Our casework staff will be inundated with questions just before the November elections."
Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said the handbook was "a waste of $40 million." In fact, Mr. Stark said, "it could actually be worse than a waste of money because of the confusion it will create for seniors and their families."
An excerpt from the handbook reads: "If you had a supplemental policy and dropped it to enroll in a Medicare managed care plan, or Medicare Select policy for the first time, and you choose to disenroll from the Medicare health plan or Medicare Select policy within 12 months of enrolling, then you can go back to the Medigap policy you had before joining the Medicare health plan, if it is still offered, or purchase Medigap policies A, B, C or F. This protection is only available during the 63 days after leaving the health plan."
Dr. Robert A. Berenson, director of the Center for Health Plans and Providers at Medicare, said he doubted that his 85-year-old mother would fully understand the new options, even though she used to work in a doctor's office.
Judith H. Hibbard, a professor of health policy at the University of Oregon in Eugene, said: "Some of these options are so new and so complex, it's very difficult for anyone to know what is best, or even what questions to ask. It's uncharted territory."
Marilyn Moon, a trustee of the Medicare trust fund, said at least 20 percent of beneficiaries had Alzheimer's disease, memory problems or other mental impairments that would make it difficult for them to understand the new options. And that does not include people with low literacy skills or very poor eyesight, said Ms. Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute.
Nationwide surveys by the Education Department have found that 40 percent of the elderly have very limited ability to read and use printed materials.
On the other hand, many older people are active and alert, well versed in the complexities of medical care and money management. Younger beneficiaries may have had some experience with managed care in their working years.
Most of the health plans will become available late this year. But they may begin enrolling Medicare beneficiaries sooner, if they have signed contracts with the Federal Government.
In most cases, the new plans will receive a fixed amount of Federal money for each beneficiary, regardless of how much care the person requires. By contrast, under the original Medicare program, doctors receive a separate fee for each service they perform, and hospitals are paid an additional amount each time a patient is admitted.
The changes in Medicare have profound implications for thousands of employers who provide health benefits to retirees, supplementing Medicare. Stephen Parahus of the Segal Company in New York, a consulting concern that specializes in employee benefits, said, "Many Medicare-eligible retirees will find the new array of choices bewildering."
Accordingly, Mr. Parahus said, employers "should brace themselves for a torrent of questions and requests for assistance."
The Government will answer questions about the new program on a toll-free telephone line. But the toll-free service will not be immediately available in all states, and consumer advocates predict that callers will face long waits because Medicare has not hired enough operators.
Mr. Hash estimated that the Government would need more than 2,000 people to answer calls at the busiest times of day.
The Medicare handbook will contain detailed information comparing the cost, benefits and performance of H.M.O.'s and other health plans. There will be more than 500 versions of this section of the handbook, each tailored to a specific local market, Mr. Hash said.
Another Medicare official, Jean D. LeMasurier, said, "It's really an absolutely overwhelming project" to compile such data, produce the handbooks and mail them to consumers.
Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, said, "We are very concerned about whether this old-fashioned Government bureaucracy can change in time to do the job of consumer education."
Medicare beneficiaries will also receive mail solicitations and brochures directly from H.M.O.'s and other health plans that want them to enroll.
But William J. Scanlon, director of health care issues at the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said the marketing materials often omitted important information and could mislead consumers.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said it was extremely difficult to compare the costs and benefits of private health plans being offered to Medicare beneficiaries because their brochures did not use a standard format or terminology.
Thus, for example, a health plan that offers to pay for $1,300 a year in prescription drugs might seem more attractive than a plan that covers only $1,000.
But, Mr. Scanlon said, the plans typically measure drug usage in different ways. Some use retail price, some use wholesale price and some use a discounted version of the wholesale price.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: More Choices Planned for Medicare"
 
Older Americans and some disabled people will soon have more health insurance options. Here are the main alternatives authorized by Congress. Different options will be available in different parts of the country.
 
ORIGINAL MEDICARE. Beneficiaries can use any hospital and can go to any doctor who accepts Medicare patients. The Government regulates doctors' fees and most other aspects of the program.
 
HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATION. Patients must use doctors, hospitals and suppliers approved by the H.M.O. But the plan may pay for prescription drugs and other items not covered by the Medicare program.
 
H.M.O. WITH POINT-OF-SERVICE OPTION. Patients meet most of their medical needs using doctors and hospitals on an approved list but may go outside the network if they are willing to pay extra.
 
PREFERRED-PROVIDER ORGANIZATION. Beneficiaries may use any doctors or hospitals, but are charged less if they use those on an approved list.
 
PROVIDER-SPONSORED ORGANIZATION. This plan is owned and operated by the doctors and hospitals that provide most of the services to beneficiaries.
 
PRIVATE FEE-FOR-SERVICE PLAN. Patients may go to any doctor or hospital, but there may be substantial costs for beneficiaries because the Federal Government does not limit the premiums that may be charged. The plan gets a fixed amount of Federal money for each beneficiary. Doctors are paid a separate fee for each service.
 
MEDICAL SAVINGS ACCOUNT. Beneficiaries choose a private insurance policy with a high deductible to cover catastrophic expenses. Medicare pays the premium and deposits money in a savings account, which is used to pay routine medical expenses. Patients may have to use their money to pay medical bills if the savings account is insufficient.
 
(Source: 1999 Medicare handbook; Balanced Budget Act of 1997.)(pg. A26)

HEADLINE: Boeing to Increase Cuts in 747 Production

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company announced yesterday that weakening demand in Asia would force it to cut production of its wide-body jets even deeper than the company had previously indicated, resulting in further job cuts.
Boeing, the world's biggest aerospace company and the country's leading exporter, said it would cut production of the 747 jumbo jet by 30 percent early next year rather than the 20 percent reduction it had hinted at two weeks ago. It will also cut production of the newer 777 to five a month from seven a month. 
 The move surprised Wall Street analysts who follow Boeing because only a month ago the company was saying that strong orders for the 777 might force it to raise the rate above seven a month.
"Things must be moving fairly quickly for this to come out in the form it has," said Byron Callan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
The 747, which carries more than 400 passengers, is the biggest commercial jet on the market and is Boeing's most profitable airplane by a wide margin. But it is mostly used to fly over the Pacific Ocean to and from Asia. Since an economic crisis began to sweep over much of Asia nearly a year ago, air traffic has plunged, and many airlines have delayed orders for new airplanes.
"The continued slow traffic growth in Asia has caused some airlines to negotiate slides in deliveries of their 1999 747 orders or to substitute other Boeing airplane models for their existing 747 orders," said Fred Mitchell, Boeing's executive vice president of airplane production.
Boeing said it would reduce production of the 747 to 3.5 a month in the second quarter of 1999 from its current rate of 5 a month.
The company, based in Seattle, has been plagued by problems since last fall, when it was forced to halt production on the 747 and narrow-body 737 jets because it did not have enough parts and experienced workers to assemble the planes fast enough. The production difficulties have since forced the company to take billions of dollars in charges against earnings.
The great fear on Wall Street was that by the time Boeing recovered the boom in demand for new jets that began in 1996 would begin to subside. That sequence of events may appear to be coming to pass, though many analysts believe that strong demand for new aircraft will continue.
Boeing said yesterday that demand for its narrow-body planes, especially the latest version of the 737, the world's most popular commercial jetliner, remained strong. That is an indication of the continued strength of the economies in Europe and North America, where a larger number of smaller planes are used than in Asia. The company expected to increase production of the new 737 to 24 a month in the second quarter of next year from 21 a month.
Boeing also said that it expected the demand for the 777, which sits between 305 and 386 passengers, to pick up in 2000, when the company expects production to return to seven a month.
But analysts were skeptical. "If this crisis continues and we've had one rate decrease, I think people are going to ask: 'Is another one coming?' " Mr. Callan said.
Boeing said that the cutbacks would force it to eliminate more jobs. Last fall, the company said it would cut 12,000 jobs from the commercial airplane group by the end of this year. The division now employs nearly 120,000.
But Janice Hayes, a Boeing spokeswoman, said yesterday that it was unclear how many more jobs would be lost.
The production-cutback announcement came after the stock market closed. Earlier, Boeing shares rose 25 cents, to $46, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Drug Regulators Make Push To Rein In Herbal Remedies

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: FARMINGTON, Utah

 BODY:
Here at the base of the Rocky Mountains, in a region that is the heart of the nation's herbal and vitamin industry, a stainless steel contraption was hard at work on a recent morning, spitting out clear plastic capsules at the rate of 90,000 an hour. Each contained precisely 600 milligrams of a fine, brick-colored powder that Federal health officials are trying to ban.
The powder, a pulverized strain of rice fermented with red yeast, is imported from China, where it has been consumed for 2,000 years, as an herbal remedy (it is thought to improve blood flow) and a food (it spices up tofu and makes a tasty marinade for duck and pork.) Then five years ago, William McGlashan Jr., a young California venture capitalist, learned that scientists in Beijing were studying red yeast rice for another reason: it seemed to lower cholesterol. 
 Today, Pharmanex, Mr. McGlashan's company, sells the encapsulated red powder under the trade name Cholestin in 37,000 American stores, from health food outlets to the giant Wal-Mart chain. Mr. McGlashan calls Cholestin a dietary supplement. Officials at the Food and Drug Administration call it something else: an illegal, unapproved drug.
On June 15, in the gray stone Federal courthouse in Salt Lake City, United States District Judge Dale A. Kimball will be asked to determine who is correct. The case is being watched as a pivotal battle between the agency, which is chafing at a 1994 law that left it almost powerless to regulate vitamins and herbal products, and the dietary supplement industry, which has been growing wildly since the law was passed.
At issue is not whether Cholestin is dangerous; no one argues that it is. Rather, the agency contends that Cholestin has crossed the increasingly murky boundary that separates dietary supplements from drugs, because it contains an ingredient, lovastatin, that is the key component of a cholesterol-lowering drug. Pharmanex says the lovastatin occurs naturally in the rice and that Cholestin is more akin to a food than to a drug.
The outcome of the case could be reflected in the medicine and kitchen cabinets of millions of American consumers, including many doctors and scientists, who have come to believe that ginkgo, echinacea and St. John's wort, among other natural remedies, are as important to good health as aspirin and antibiotics.
Aside from the turf battle between the supplement industry and regulators, the dispute raises crucial questions: Is there a distinction between these herbal products, which may contain naturally occurring chemicals as potent as those in any drug, and the drugs themselves? Must products like Cholestin be subjected to the rigorous testing that drugs undergo?
"You see more and more dietary supplements sold right next to over-the-counter drugs," said William B. Schultz, the F.D.A.'s deputy commissioner for policy. "There is a risk that the line will blur.
Indeed, it is already blurry. "Foods are medicines; medicines are foods," said Loren Israelson, executive director of the Utah Natural Products Alliance, a trade group based in Salt Lake City that represents 10 of the nation's biggest supplement manufacturers. "If you drink coffee in the morning, why are you drinking coffee? You're looking for the caffeine, a stimulant. That same caffeine is sold over the counter as No Doz. That's a drug when it's in a pill form, and it's a food when it's in coffee. Why is that?"
The Food and Drug Administration struggled with such questions for decades. But with the passage of the 1994 Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act, the law under which the Cholestin case will be decided, the agency's task grew even more vexing.
The new law moved dietary supplements out of the underground and into the mainstream, giving manufacturers like Pharmanex the long-sought right to advertise the potential benefits of herbs, even if the evidence for those benefits was sketchy. Unless the F.D.A. can prove the product is unsafe, companies can say what they wish, so long as they do not claim their products can prevent, treat or cure disease. Thus, Mr. McGlashan can advertise that Cholestin "promotes healthy cholesterol," but not that it "prevents heart attack or stroke."
"For the first time," he said, "we can educate the American consumer about what the product does. We don't have to rely on a person in a health food store to explain it."
Since the law was passed, the agency has received about 2,300 notifications from manufacturers intending to make claims about their products, and has objected to about 150 of them. It has also proposed a rule that would restrict, but not eliminate, the manufacturer's ability to use the herbal stimulant ephedra, which has been linked to more than a dozen deaths nationwide. It has banned one ephedra-based product and it is now trying to ban Cholestin.
Agency officials say the 1994 law, restrictive though it is, gives them the authority to take Cholestin off the market, because it bars companies from bringing dietary supplements to market if they contain the same active ingredients as previously approved drugs. In passing the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act, Mr. Schultz says, Congress did not intend for companies to skirt the drug-approval process by selling medicines under the guise of dietary supplements.
Lawyers for Pharmanex, however, contend that Cholestin falls squarely within the intent of the 1994 law.
"This product was specifically developed to be a dietary supplement," said Daniel Kracov, a company lawyer. "What the F.D.A. objects to is the fact that this product has a drug substance in it, in their view. You may object to that, but our response is: If you don't have a safety issue, don't go after these products."
Whatever the outcome, Dr. David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, says the agency's action will hardly make a dent in the rampant proliferation of herbal remedies that he says are ineffective at best and unsafe at worst.
"Just walk into your pharmacy; it's out of control," said Dr. Kessler, who waged a bitter, unsuccessful battle against the 1994 law as commissioner. "Efficacy is now defined as what sells off the shelves. The agency is powerless."
While the law was a disaster for regulators, it was a windfall for makers of dietary supplements and vitamins. After the act was adopted, annual sales of dietary supplements in the United States skyrocketed, jumping to nearly $12 billion last year from more than $8 billion in 1994, according to the Nutrition Business Journal, a trade publication.
So furious has the growth been that one analyst, Matthew Patsky of the Boston-based investment banking firm of Adams, Harkness & Hill, said some of the biggest pharmaceutical companies were planning to sell their own herbal products.
That worries Mr. Schultz, the F.D.A. deputy commissioner for policy. "If companies that would have tested their products and sold them as drugs are now going to not test them and sell them as dietary supplements," he said, "then we have lost information about the safety and efficacy of those products."
Among the law's beneficiaries was Mr. McGlashan, a 34-year-old Stanford University business school graduate who studied Chinese history. With the aging of baby boomers, Mr. McGlashan saw a growing demand for natural medicines the Chinese have used for centuries.
Mr. McGlashan says he had a vision for his business; he wanted to apply "pharmaceutical rigors" to the dietary supplement industry, using research to persuade consumers that Eastern therapies worked. In early 1994, he met Michael Chang, a former pharmaceutical industry researcher who had set up a plant to produce herbal medicines in Huzhou, China, near Shanghai.
Dr. Chang scoured Chinese research for promising herbal products, identifying 5,000; the list was narrowed to 30. By early 1995, Pharmanex was born, with headquarters in Simi Valley, Calif. Red yeast rice, called hong qu, was one its most promising projects.
"We know hong qu has been used for centuries, but we don't know why it lowers cholesterol," Dr. Chang said. "We need to find out."
The 1994 law, Mr. McGlashan said, made it worth investing in science. The company introduced Cholestin at the end of 1996, after nearly three years of study. Most recently, Pharmanex enlisted Dr. David Heber, director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of California at Los Angeles, to study the effects of Cholestin in adults with moderately elevated cholesterol.
The study, financed by Pharmanex, compared the cholesterol levels of 42 adults who took 2.5 grams of Cholestin every day for three months with the levels in 41 adults who were given placebos. Dr. Heber said the total cholesterol counts of those who took the supplement dropped, on average, from 250 to 210.
Dr. Heber dismisses the contention that red yeast rice is a drug; instead he calls it "a functional food." The same cholesterol-lowering ingredient in lovastatin, he notes, occurs in even higher concentrations in oyster mushrooms, commonly used in Asian cooking. And nobody, he said, is trying to ban mushrooms.
However, Dr. Richard A. Friedman, director of psychopharmacology at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, contends the current distinction between dietary supplements and drugs is based on semantics, not biology, and that both should be carefully regulated.
"If there is a biologically active component in the supplement, to say it is not a drug is illogical because it will have a similar effect," he said. Companies like Pharmanex, he added, "want to be able to implant the idea in the public that the drug is medically beneficial" without the rigorous research.
That kind of science, Mr. McGlashan admits, would cost far too much for a small company like his. Yet with a decent body of research behind Cholestin, he said, he at one time envisioned himself becoming the F.D.A.'s model for good behavior.
Instead, he received a visit from F.D.A. investigators last year; the agency had received complaints that Cholestin contained lovastatin, both from a pharmacist and from Merck and Company, which makes Mevacor, the cholestorol-lowering drug, known generically as lovastatin.
Shortly thereafter, Federal authorities impounded ten tons of red yeast rice. Then on May 20, the F.D.A. notified Mr. McGlashan that it considered Cholestin illegal, a move that led the company to ask for a hearing before Judge Kimball.
"This case is going to determine the extent to which companies can imitate prescription drugs," said Mr. Schultz of the F.D.A., "and avoid the approval process."
But Mr. McGlashan contends that the dispute is an economic one. Cholestin, he said, is intended for use by people who are too healthy for Mevacor. Merck, he contends, is trying to push Cholestin off the shelves -- a charge denied by Jan Weiner, a company spokeswoman.
While the court case is pending, Mr. McGlashan said, sales of Cholestin are booming. Even his mother called, he said, asking, "How am I supposed to get my Cholestin?"
For now, Mr. McGlashan has no answer. Standing outside the low-pressure room where the encapsulating machine was spinning, a lab coat covering his royal blue shirt and Hermes tie, he looked a little wistful. The fine red powder being packed into the capsules, he said, was the last of his supply.

HEADLINE: Bid to Expand Javits Center Loses Ground

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
State officials are scrambling to salvage a $750 million plan to expand the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on the West Side of Manhattan, which has collided with the Giuliani administration's proposal to build a stadium for the New York Yankees and a developer's efforts to erect a sprawling apartment complex.
The state, which controls the Javits Center, had hoped to double the size of the center's exhibition space to 1.5 million square feet by extending the convention hall from 38th Street to 42d Street, a plan that officials and hoteliers said would enable New York to compete with other cities for tens of millions of dollars in convention business and anchor the western end of a rejuvenated Times Square. 
 But discussions between executives at the convention center and the developer, Larry A. Silverstein, who owns a key parcel of land needed for the expansion project, collapsed recently when the Giuliani administration failed to support the state's plans. Any state project north of the convention center would require city assistance to close streets and redirect traffic.
Real estate executives and state officials say Mr. Silverstein decided to go ahead with plans to build apartments on the city after concluding that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would not approve expansion plans that did not include a baseball stadium just south of the Javits Center.
"There's nothing happening with the expansion of the convention center on 42d Street," Mr. Silverstein said. "So we're going forward with our project. To sit and wait makes no sense at all. I couldn't afford to delay this any further." His decision to move ahead on the apartment plan was first reported this week in Crain's New York Business.
Officials of the Giuliani administration insist that the stadium and convention center issues are separate. "We're continuing to consider proposals for the expansion of the convention center," said Randy L. Levine, the Deputy Mayor, "but we are not going to stand in the way of any alternate development."
Even so, officials of the Pataki administration have recently expressed deep frustration with Mr. Giuliani for not helping their cause in trying to expand the Javits Center. And they believe that the city wants a quid pro quo: support for the stadium in return for help with the Javits expansion.
But aides to Gov. George E. Pataki have expressed grave doubt about the West Side plan, and so far the Governor has done little to support it, saying only that he hoped that the team would remain at its historic home in the Bronx.
Real estate executives and state officials said the Javits expansion was only the latest example of how the debate over a future home for the Yankees was overshadowing everything from the city budget to a new location for the New York Stock Exchange.
Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, said he was surprised that the Mayor had been concentrating so heavily on the stadium.
"The Yankees are sucking up all the oxygen at City Hall," Mr. Moss said. "It's shocking to think that a baseball stadium is more important than a convention center or stock exchange. New York's future lies in tourism, finance, communications and entertainment, not in professional baseball."
Mr. Giuliani has revived a plan to build a billion-dollar stadium on the West Side of Manhattan that he said would prevent the Yankees from leaving New York and generate $1 billion a year in economic activity.
The administration has commissioned several studies and recently set up a delegation of nine officials to visit new ball parks in other cities to assess their economic impact. On May 28, the group led by Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, and Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, visited Baltimore and Oriole Park at Camden Yards.
"I guess that says something when folks come out of New York to see how others do it," said Charles Graves, the director of city planning in Baltimore, who met with the delegation. "We talked about design, siting, political and economic issues. And they had a chance to see a first-rate luxury sky box."
Rather than wait for the Javits expansion, Mr. Silverstein plans to build two residential towers with 1,800 apartments on the block along 42d Street, between 11th and 12th Avenues. The apartment complex would form an insurmountable roadblock to what state officials said was the best route for the expansion.
State officials were urging Mr. Silverstein yesterday to reconsider. At the same time, the officials are reluctant to press the Mayor because they want to avoid an open battle with him during Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election campaign.
"The last three years have proven how vital the Javits Center can be to New York," said Robert E. Boyle, chairman of the convention center. "We intend to build on that record. But in light of Mr. Silverstein's plans, we would have to consider less desirable options for expansion."
Real estate executives and state officials say privately that the problems with the Javits expansion are the latest example of the Giuliani administration's almost single-minded effort to resolve the future of Yankee Stadium.
On Monday, the Mayor vetoed nearly $5 million from the budget that the City Council had allocated for itself, surprising Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, who is in a dispute with the Mayor over the stadium. And last month, executives at the stock exchange threatened a move to New Jersey to get the attention of city officials, who the executives said were more concerned with baseball stadiums than dealing with the financial industry. Mr. Levine, the Deputy Mayor, rejected that contention, saying the city was in active discussions with the stock exchange about a future home in lower Manhattan or Battery Park City.
State officials had hoped to reach a compromise with Mr. Silverstein. In discussions with convention center executives earlier this year, he had agreed to swap his land on 42d Street for the right to build a large hotel or apartment tower over the expanded convention center.

HEADLINE: Nigeria's Opportunity

 BODY:
The death this week of Sani Abacha, the corrupt and abusive Nigerian military dictator, is an opportunity for an African giant to begin to lift itself from poverty, fear and decay. General Abacha so discredited military rule that in recent months even many officers began to join ordinary Nigerians in clamoring for a civilian government. Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, who has taken over the Government, was one of those officers. He should put those ideas into practice.
Nigeria, the most populous nation in Africa, should also be the most prosperous. Oil revenues alone, if not depleted by corruption and mismanagement, should provide the basis for sustainable economic growth. It is also a diverse, culturally rich land stunted by years of tyranny. 
 Ideally, General Abubakar should turn the Government over to Moshood Abiola, a civilian who apparently won Nigeria's last democratic elections, five years ago this week. The military annulled the election, and Mr. Abiola was imprisoned in 1994 and has suffered there since.
The military seems to have another plan in mind. A spokesman for the Government said yesterday that it would turn power over to elected civilians by October. If the military holds free and open elections, this would be acceptable as well. But military leaders have repeatedly failed to deliver promised transitions to civilian rule. Even though people who know Mr. Abubakar call him the least corrupt and power-hungry of Nigeria's top generals, Nigerians are right to be skeptical. His first task should be to release all political prisoners and end the persecution of critics.
Outsiders can help with a clear call for democratic, civilian rule. A high-level American delegation bearing such an unambiguous message would be useful. Companies like Mobil, Chevron and Shell, which profit from Nigerian oil, have done little in the past to promote democratic rule. Mr. Abacha's death offers them a chance to use their considerable influence to discourage continued dictatorship. The one favor that Mr. Abacha may have done his country is to clarify that military rule is misrule.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Plans Personal Bid To Defuse Kosovo Crisis

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, June 9

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, seeking to forestall a NATO military incursion in the Serbian province of Kosovo, promised today to undertake a personal diplomatic effort with the Serbian leadership in an effort to defuse the violence there.
Speaking after a day of talks with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, Mr. Yeltsin said NATO action would "destabilize the situation in the Balkans with unforeseeable consequences for all of Europe." 
 At the same time, German officials seem increasingly inclined toward charting a military course to stop the violence in Kosovo, where Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, has cracked down on an independence movement in the province, pitting Government forces against ethnic Albanian rebels.
"The more delicately we proceed, the greater are our chances for a settlement of the conflict," Mr. Yeltsin said. It was not clear when his effort would take place or exactly how it would be carried out.
NATO Defense Ministers are to meet in Brussels on Thursday to discuss the fighting in Kosovo, which has inspired deep concerns here about the likelihood of waves of refugees flooding Western Europe. Germany took in hundreds of thousands who fled during and after the Bosnian war and makes no secret of its aversion to providing shelter for more Balkan refugees.
The "contact group" on the Balkans -- the United States, Britain, Germany, Italy, France and Russia -- is to meet at the foreign ministers' level in London on Friday, along with Japan and Canada, to discuss Kosovo.
Volker Ruhe, the German Defense Minister, said today that it was crucial for the NATO ministers to examine military plans to augment economic and political pressures on Mr. Milosevic.
For his part, Mr. Kohl said at a joint news conference with Mr. Yeltsin that Germany -- Russia's biggest trading partner and creditor -- would offer "decisive support" for Moscow as it seeks to contain an economic crisis and pursues economic reform. "These measures contribute significantly to increasing the confidence of foreign investors," the Chancellor said.
Both German and Russian officials ruled out any further injection of German money, saying Mr. Kohl's backing for Moscow's reform measures was enough. "Chancellor Kohl's personal support, as a major international political figure, is important to demonstrate that our policies are correct," Mr. Yeltsin said.
Germany is Russia's closest European political ally, and Bonn's backing is important as Moscow seeks financial support from the International Monetary Fund. Additionally, Mr. Kohl likes to depict Mr. Yeltsin as a personal friend, seeking to base his diplomacy on a network of personal relationships typified by the special friendship he has declared with President Clinton.
Because of the personal relationships, though, it is often difficult to disentangle diplomacy from domestic politics.
Mr. Kohl, in particular, faces the nettlesome problem of trying to win an unparalleled fifth term of office in elections in September.
Today, his Social Democratic electoral opponents resurrected the criticisms they lodged when Mr. Kohl met with Mr. Clinton last month, accusing the Chancellor of stage-managing media coverage, in this case by barring television cameras from a breakfast today with Mr. Yeltsin and Gerhard Schroder, Mr. Kohl's opposition challenger, who ranks in opinion surveys as Germany's most popular politician.
Government officials denied orchestrating the blackout, saying Russian officials insisted on it to avoid becoming ensnared in Germany's domestic politics.
Nonetheless, Mr. Kohl ruled the sound bites with Mr. Yeltsin, reflecting his campaign strategy of building voter support on his reputation as a statesman -- not only as Europe's longest-serving leader, but also as the key European interlocutor for the men he likes to call "my friend Bill" and "dear Boris."
While not quite so effusive as Mr. Clinton was, Mr. Yeltsin today referred to the German leader's international stature in remarks that seemed intended to feed into the campaign.
Mr. Kohl and his Christian Democrats, in office for almost 16 years, lag behind the Social Democrats in opinion surveys. But in recent days, Mr. Kohl has received some heartening news suggesting that the vote on Sept. 27 will be closer than was assumed a few weeks ago.

HEADLINE: Baltimore Journal;
As City Buffs Its Image, It Keeps a Place for Hons

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
The crowd grew quiet, knowing a solemn moment was finally at hand. Pamela Foresman stepped forward. These were her final minutes as Baltimore's Best Hon, the title she won at the Cafe Hon last year.
"My reign may be over," Ms. Foresman said, handing a bouquet of flowers to Sharon Gill, her successor. "But once a Hon, always a Hon." 
 O.K., so what is a Hon, and why are they beloved enough that 200 people would spend a nice weekend afternoon in a restaurant parking lot to celebrate their existence?
Fact is, Hons are as much a part of Baltimore's cultural landscape as crab cakes, the Orioles and Harborplace. They have earned their sociological niche for greeting friends and strangers alike the same way -- "Howya doin', Hon?" -- and speaking in "Bawlmerese," a dialect indigenous to the area and virtually unknown anywhere else.
At the recent fifth-annual Best Hon contest, Ms. Gill, a 44-year-old legal secretary, defeated two other contestants with her quintessential Hon look: black stretch pants, faux tiger-skin shirt, high-heeled sandals and wildly teased hair that takes her as long as "two arries" -- translation from Bawlmerese, two hours -- to set properly in place.
"This is my very first booty pageant," she told adoring fans.
Of course, the accent, with its mangled vowel sounds and fractured syntax, is not limited to Hons. Included in the day's festivities was the Best Bawlmerese contest, in which one man sang "Home on the Range," where in his version "the deer and the cantaloupe" play. Finishing first was a pair of beehived 11-year-old Honchkins -- Chiari Lattanzi and Leah Platek -- who sang a hilarious Bawlmerese version of "My Heart Will Go On," the theme song from the film "Titanic."
The filmmaker John Waters has made a career of feasting on the idiosyncrasies of Hons, setting "Pink Flamingos" and "Hairspray" in the Baltimore neighborhoods he knew growing up. All his characters speak in Bawlmerese, and many of his female characters dress like Hons.
But Hons and Bawlmerese seem harder find now. As Baltimore has polished its image with downtown redevelopment, new hotels, first-class sports stadiums and reborn commercial centers, the Hon life style, like the old, working-class neighborhoods that spawned them, is slipping into the shadows of progress.
Here in Hampden, a central neighborhood that was once a hotbed of Hons and their families, the main thoroughfare, 36th Street, has taken a decidely upscale turn in the last few years, with new restaurants, shops and refurbished row houses.
"Mainstreets are making a comeback, not just here but all across the country," said Denise Whiting, 39, owner of Cafe Hon who strapped on a foot-high beehive wig for her role as emcee. "People are rethinking cities, to get them back to what they once were, the hub of major activity."
But the changes, here as elsewhere, have not come without pain, especially to residents who find gentrification scary and expensive.
"Older people are afraid of change," Ms. Whiting said. "They don't necessarily see it as positive. They're frightened by it. They even felt more comfortable with the drug addicts and prostitutes."
It was largely to celebrate the old Hon ways that Ms. Whiting opened her 1950's-style restaurant six years ago and began the Best Hon contest a year later. But even that seems to have gentrified, with more faux Hons entering than real ones. The first year's winner seemed legitimate enough, Kelly Gambino, a forklift operator. But subsequent titles were captured by a professional dancer, a medical writer and, last year, by Ms. Foresman, 32, a lawyer who deflates her beehive for the courtroom.
She said she was saddened that Hons were disappearing, "like drive-in thee-aters." But she vowed to continue doing her part to keep them alive, if only in spirit.
"Last year, someone asked me where all the Hons have gone," she told the crowd in parting remarks. "It made me think that a lot of things are gone, and we need to save 'em. Like duck-pin bowling. That should be the state's national sport. Not jousting. I don't get jousting."

HEADLINE: Maine Holds Its Primary Among Modest Spenders

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Maine, June 9

 BODY:
Maine's primary today could be considered a breath of cool, fresh political air after the overheated spending of California's election last week.
The results brought no big surprises. With more than three-quarters of the precincts reporting, Democrats appeared to have selected as their candidate for governor Tom Connolly, a prominent Portland defense lawyer who emphasized social justice in his campaign. He heavily defeated Joseph Ricci, a racetrack owner with a tendency to become unprintably outspoken. 
 Among Republicans running for governor, Jim Longley Jr., a conservative former Congressman and son of Maine's former governor, appeared to have defeated two opponents with a campaign that focused on tax cuts and criticism of the state's economic performance.
Gov. Angus King, an independent, is expected to be easily re-elected in November.
But for politics-watchers still goggle-eyed at the immense sums spent on last week's primary in California -- more than $100 million in all -- the most striking aspect of Maine's primary was its financial modesty.
The biggest spender in the governor's race, Mr. Connolly, had raised about enough to cover a California campaign's dry-cleaning bills: $21,477, according to state records. Mr. Ricci raised $16,385.
Governor King and the state's two House members, John Baldacci and Tom Allen, both Democrats who faced no challenges in their primaries, raised about $200,000. And both contenders in the Republican primary for the 1st District seat in Congress fell well short of $100,000.
That would seem like cause for rejoicing in a state that is considered one of the leaders in campaign finance reform, and is expected to put into effect by 2000 a ground-breaking system that would provide public money to candidates who voluntarily accept limits on fund-raising.
But the coolness of the campaign was a little too cool for some voters. A low turnout -- reported to be below 14 percent -- bolstered the general impression of a campaign so lackluster and a public so apathetic that it was called "the stealth campaign."
"It's an odd election in that there's nothing going on," said Bill Coogan, a political science professor at the University of Southern Maine. "The two parties have conceded the governorship; there's no Senate race; and though there are two Congressional campaigns in the fall, the results are a foregone conclusion."
Maine, it seems, has a particularly potent case of the complacency, even somnolence, that often comes with economic prosperity, political observers said.
In Portland today, when several Maine voters were asked as they left their polling booths in City Hall what issues they wished had been highlighted, none could come up with any.
Governor King is so popular that neither party had reason to believe its candidate could beat him. So the top of the ticket in both primaries appeared to many to be all but moot, and few were willing to give money to candidates who appeared doomed.
"Let's be honest," said Garison Murrell, who had just loyally cast his ballot in the Republican primary. "The gubernatorial nominees don't even have a shot unless Angus King decides to parade naked down Congress Street."
In other races around the country, State Representative Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas defeated Attorney General Winston Bryant in a runoff to become the Democratic nominee for the Senate. She will face the Republican candidate, State Senator Fay Boozman.
In South Carolina, Representative Bob Inglis easily defeated Stephen Brown, a former Republican county chairman, for the Republican nomination to face Senator Ernest Hollings, a Democrat. North Dakota Republicans chose a former state senator, Donna Nalewaja, as their nominee to face Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat.

HEADLINE: Seeing Threat to Casinos, Tribes March on the Capitol

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
In an intensifying battle between California's American Indians and its Governor, more than 100 tribal leaders traveled here this week to try to halt what they call a threat to the survival of their reservations: state action to rein in their casinos.
The California tribes say Gov. Pete Wilson has violated their sovereignty; he says they are violating state and Federal law. 
 With Federal prosecutors, acting at Mr. Wilson's behest, taking steps to seize lucrative slot machines inside the Indian casinos, the tribal leaders appealed today to members of Congress and are scheduled to meet on Wednesday with Attorney General Janet Reno.
The dispute centers on the compacts that Federal law requires tribes and states to negotiate before casinos operate. Most tribes with casinos in California have no compacts.
In other states, where Indians are either seeking compacts or negotiating the renewal of existing compacts, the standoff in California is being watched closely.
Mr. Wilson has demanded that all tribes either sign a predetermined compact that they have called restrictive or shut down the casinos and negotiate a pact that is mutually agreeable. Mr. Wilson has said he will not negotiate with tribes that are operating casinos illegally, or without a compact.
Dan Kolkey, Mr. Wilson's legal affairs secretary, said, "If a tribe was permitted to operate illegal gaming until such time that they entered into a compact with the state, then they would never have an incentive to conclude a compact negotiation."
So far, all but a few of the 39 tribes that operate casinos in California have refused to accept either option, and Federal prosecutors, at Mr. Wilson's request, have gone to court to try to seize some 14,000 gambling machines from the resisting tribes' casinos.
Lanny J. Davis, a former special counsel to President Clinton who was hired to represent the tribes, said that the tribal leaders were in Washington to convince Congress and Ms. Reno that Mr. Wilson's refusal to negotiate was a violation of Indian rights under the 1998 Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
"We're in Washington to ask the U.S. Government to fulfill its historic, legal and moral obligation to act as our trustees in requiring the Governor to come to the negotiating table," Mr. Davis said.
The tribal leaders say the battle is more than an economic or political issue.
"We are trying to head off a potential powder keg," said Mary Ann Andreas, chairman of the Morongo band of Mission Indians, which operates a casino outside Palm Springs and has refused the Governor's terms. The Morongo tribe, like others, Ms. Andreas said, feared losing not only revenues from casinos but also the sovereign rights granted the tribe through treaties with the Federal Government.
"What's at stake is our survival," Ms. Andreas said. "This could mean devastation."
The compacts that Mr. Wilson wants the tribes to sign are modeled after one he signed in March with the Pala band of Mission Indians, a tribe that has never had casino gambling on its reservation, in northern San Diego.
The casinos have proliferated into a statewide industry that employs about 15,000 people and has revenues that some industry experts estimate is more than $500 million. The Pala compact requires gamblers to be at least 21 years old and casinos to meet state laws regarding hiring, workers' compensation and collective bargaining.
But financially, what the tribes say is the issue of most concern is the compact's limitation on the type and number of slot machines they can use, a restriction that they say would cause them to lose about 85 percent of their revenues.
With the slot machines that are now in use, winning gamblers receive predetermined jackpot amounts, and the casino takes a percentage of everything that goes into the machines -- a system used in places like Las Vegas, Nev., and Atlantic City. But California law allows only lottery-style slot machines, which pay winners based on a machine's proceeds and divides the jackpot among the players and the casino.
The Justice Department, which agreed that the tribes were violating Federal law by operating without compacts, began seeking court approval on May 13 to seize machines that did not comply with state law.
The tribes have filed a lawsuit in State Superior Court contending that the Governor lacked the authority to sign the Pala compact because he did so without prior approval from the Legislature. A hearing is scheduled for later this month.
But the issue may be resolved in the November elections.
Californians are being asked to vote on a ballot initiative in November that would supersede the Pala compact and award the tribes a compact allowing them more control over their casinos.
The tribes are expected to spend millions of dollars in support of the initiative, and gambling interests in Las Vegas, where the Indian casinos are viewed as a threat, are expected to spend millions to try to defeat it. Industry experts estimate that as much as 30 percent of Nevada's casino customers come from California, and a new group, the Coalition Against Unregulated Gambling, which includes Nevada casino interests, has vowed to defeat the ballot initiative.
"Politicians like Governor Wilson are robbing the tribes, and Vegas interests are providing the ammunition," said Daniel Tucker, president of the California Nations Indian Gaming Association.
The tribal leaders have warned that the government's hard line and its efforts to remove the machines could lead to a violent confrontation.
"What we have here is the state of California coming in and cannibalizing tribal soil," said Anthony R. Pico, who said that as chairman of the Viejas band of Kumeyaay Indians, which operates a casino near San Diego, signed the compact under duress. "We can't have that. We would die first."

HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
In the Headlights: P.D.A.'s and Virtual Pets

BYLINE: By J. C. Herz; E-mail address: Herz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE Georgia World Congress Center in Atlanta contains 35 football fields' worth of exhibition space. During the Electronic Entertainment Expo in May, it contained the equivalent of 35 football fields filled with video games -- PC games, console games and handheld games -- peripherals and accessories of all descriptions, as well as thousands of developers, software publishers, retailers, investors and journalists.
Crammed with 12-foot screens and massive speakers, looming exhibition domes, lasers, showgirls and video game mayhem at every turn, it's sheer heaven or sheer hell, depending on your personality. But whether you wallow in the spectacle or run screaming, E3 is a once-a-year chance to view the universe of interactive entertainment and to see what's on the horizon for Christmas and early '99. Here's a report from the trenches: 

GAME MACHINES -- No new ones this year. Sony and Nintendo are sitting tight with their consoles. The PC standard for gaming has stabilized with the Pentium II and a 3DFX graphics accelerator card. That is a good thing for consumers and developers alike because people get to catch their breath and concentrate on great games instead of racing to catch up with the hardware.
Sega is coming out with a new machine for Christmas 1999 that promises the moon -- superfast graphics, multiplayer on-line games, E-mail, chat, 3-D audio and a Windows CE operating system (and breakfast in bed?) -- for less than $300, but for now, we are in the eye of the technological hurricane. So content is king. Hallelujah.
 
PERIPHERALS -- Stable platforms have brought dozens of accessory manufacturers out of the woodwork. It is now possible to buy video game controllers in every color of the rainbow and hundreds of ergonomic configurations, like game pads, joysticks, headsets, gloves and racing wheels. Force feedback -- a tactile sense of explosions, body blows or the torque of a racetrack through a controller -- is the cool technology du jour. All the new joysticks are going to rumble, rattle and throb.
More significant in the grand scheme is a new crop of video game storage devices. Interact's Dex Drive, for instance, hooks into your PC. Pop a Playstation or Nintendo memory card into the drive and you can upload game saves, characters or sports rosters to your computer, then E-mail the data or post it to a Web site. Anyone else with a Dex Drive can download the information, plug it into a console and play with your levels, characters or teams, modifying them or mailing back new ones. At $40 (less than the cost of a Nintendo game), this peripheral knits together the console, PC and the Internet in an accessible way and could make game saves and video game characters as tradable as baseball cards.
Along the same lines, the Sony P.D.A. (personal digital assistant) is a $30, key-chain-size device that plugs into the Playstation like a memory card. After downloading game data, the P.D.A. converts into a portable gaming device. It has a calendar and a clock as well as an infrared transmitter that lets you beam data -- words, symbols and animations as well as game information -- across the room to other P.D.A.'s. You can transfer secret moves, trade weapons, play head to head and pass notes to your friends. This device will no doubt be the bane of every schoolroom from Seattle to Miami.
 
WORLD-BUILDING FOR THE LAITY -- It used to be that if you wanted to build your own levels of a PC game, you had to be a programmer. No more. A slew of computer games, particularly first-person shooters, will include built-in point-and-click-level editors that let you create your own versions of a game by importing geometric shapes into a void and giving them qualities like size, weight, hollowness, texture and lighting effects. It's the holodeck, more or less.
GT Interactive's Unreal and Sierra Studio's Half-Life are standouts in this respect, allowing players to create their own game worlds and distribute them on the Internet or play them on line. Building these worlds becomes a game in itself -- perhaps a more rewarding pastime than the original code (witness the sprawling virtual community of amateur Doom designers).
 
ARTIFICIAL LIFE -- Bad news for grown-ups: the virtual pet is not a passing fad.
Digital creatures are only getting stronger, more numerous and more sophisticated. From monster-breeding combat games to Cyberlife's sequel to Creatures, virtual vermin abound. Nintendo is releasing its own menagerie this fall. They're called Pokemon (a portmanteau word derived from "pocket" and "monster"). They live on your belt loop and come in 150 flavors, each with its own plush doll counterpart. Tamagotchi meets Beanie Babies. Be very afraid.
 
THE S-WORD -- After Silicon Valley's disastrous first date with Hollywood, synergy is back. Fox Interactive is trotting out a series of showbiz titles -- Alien vs. Predator, an X-Files game, Die Hard Interactive and the Simpsons' Virtual Springfield. Activision is transforming "The Fifth Element" into a console game. GT Interactive is bringing "Beavis and Butt-head" to the PC and the Playstation. Acclaim is tackling "South Park," and MGM is animating James Bond in Tomorrow Never Dies. Movie-based games have usually been stinkers, but this time around, developers have used the silver screen as a springboard instead of a crutch. They're finally getting it right. Chalk one up for the media empires.
 
THE SCOTS! -- An economic development agency financed by the Scottish Government has determined that video games represent a new engine for economic growth, so scores of computer science grads and art school students are being funneled into interactive entertainment. The result? A convention hall teeming with game designers in kilts. Bagpipes on the concourse. Interactive renditions of "Braveheart."
"The object of the game is to become the king of Scotland," said Wai Ming Yuen, the Glaswegian producer of Tartan Armies, a strategy game based on 13th-century clan warfare. "And then you get to invade England."
 
FEMALE PROTAGONISTS -- From Lara Croft to the trash-talking, gunslinging truck-stop waitress in Panasonic's Space Bunnies Must Die and the heroine of Square Soft's epic Parasite Eve, female game characters are shooting first and asking questions later.
As one game designer so eloquently put it, "There's something about a chick with a gun."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New games were trotted out at the Electronic Entertainment Expo. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economic theory won't provide easy answers in the drug war.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF the war on drugs is indeed a battle of good versus evil, then Satan is gaining some impressive allies. An open letter to the United Nations Secretary General, on the occasion of the General Assembly's special session on drugs, asserts that "the global war on drugs is now causing more harm than drug abuse itself." Among the signers of the letter were Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former Secretary General; Robert Strauss, the Democratic Party's lobbyist-lawyer; George Shultz, the former secretary of everything to Republican presidents, and even Walter Cronkite.
More striking from the parochial perspective of this column, the list includes high-profile economists ranging from Milton Friedman (the Hoover Institution) to Jagdish Bhagwati (Columbia) to Gavin Wright (Stanford). 
 On second thought, perhaps it is not so surprising. Most economists these days are alert to the unintended consequences of regulation. And in the case of drug policy, they do not have to look far. "The harmful side effects -- everything from the spread of AIDS to violent crime to abuse of civil liberties -- simply overwhelm the benefits," said Jeffrey Miron of Boston University.
The only way to reduce illegal drug use is to reduce the supply or the demand. Consider supply-side strategies first.
Common sense says the place to start is at the border, or even in farmers' fields. But in this case, suggests Peter Reuter of the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy, common sense is a ticket to frustration.
Smugglers of low-bulk drugs have adapted easily to interdiction efforts, he says. Confiscation of large quantities at sea or at the border has only modest impact on importers since the value of the drugs outside the country is so much lower than the value once they cross the border.
By the same token, discouraging drug production by subsidizing alternative crops is a fools' game. Drug entrepreneurs can always afford to pay more since the cost of the raw material is a minute fraction of the wholesale price of the delivered product.
What about disrupting wholesale and retail markets on this side of the border? It can and has been done through policing efforts -- though at a cost that makes economists, as well as legislators and civil libertarians, wince. With more than a half-million arrests annually for marijuana possession alone, the bulk of police, prison and court resources is now devoted to drug law enforcement.
Besides, Mr. Miron notes, for supply-side policies to work, drug prices must rise. And if, as most economists believe, the use of drugs is not particularly sensitive to price, the total value of drugs sold actually increases when enforcement is successful. This breeds ancillary crime as users steal to pay for their habits and dealers fight over turf.
If supply-side antidrug policies create a vicious circle of higher prices and more crime, demand-side policies should lead to a virtuous one. Lower demand means lower prices, lower revenue and less incentive to steal and kill.
By no coincidence, then, demand-reducing drug treatment and education have become the centrist politician's mantra. Mr. Reuter acknowledges that treatment is often cost-effective. But he doubts that even the most dedicated treatment policy would reduce addiction by more than one-third.
Mr. Miron points to another problem: pushing addicts off illegal drugs all too often pushes them into legal ones -- methadone, alcohol and tobacco. "You have to be skeptical that the benefits of treatment would exceed the benefits of simply minimizing the adverse side effects of illicit drug use," Mr. Miron said.
For Mr. Miron the best of all possible worlds would be one in which dangerous drugs are legal, with their use discouraged with taxes and social pressure. But many people who buy arguments against the flat-out prohibition cannot stomach policies that would probably lead to greater drug consumption.
For his part, Mr. Reuter argues that legalization has become a straw man that diverts attention from the messy task of reforming regulation. That might include the decriminalization of drug possession without making it legal to sell drugs for a profit. Or the quiet abandonment of expensive border interdiction. And it would certainly mean a more nuanced policy in which the use of marijuana by adults ceased to preoccupy the justice system.
Is the world ready for a change in drug policy as usual? Ethan Nadelmann, the director of the Lindesmith Center in New York, which sponsored the open letter, is encouraged by the growing numbers of very important people ready to take a stand in favor of a fresh start. But he doubts that the United Nations' own drug bureaucracy can lead the way. "It's hard to turn that big boat around," he lamented.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Economic Slump in Asia Spurs Sharp Drop in Dow

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday on concern that Asia's economic slump is causing companies that do business there to report disappointing earnings.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company tumbled after an analyst downgraded the stock, while the Boeing Company and the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation fell after warning of disappointing profits because of a drop in Asian demand. The declines underscored remarks by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who told Congress that Asia's slowing economies could cut into United States growth, potentially driving stock prices lower. 
 Investors accustomed to three years of 20 percent-plus gains in the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 Index will have to lower their expectations as earnings growth slows, said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc., which manages $2 billion. "You can't have the market going up 25 percent when earnings are going up 5 percent."
The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 78.22, to 8,971.70, erasing a 46-point gain.. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.13, to 1,112.28. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with computer companies, slid 27.51, to 1,773.25, its biggest drop in eight sessions.
Earlier yesterday, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slumped 4.9 percent to its lowest level since March 10, 1995, as a weak yen drove up borrowing costs. The yen's slide to a seven-year low against the dollar may cut Japanese investment and lending abroad, causing weakness in other Asian currencies. Japan's Nikkei 225 index slid 1.23 percent.
Benchmark indexes in Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia all tumbled 3 percent or more. Latin American markets also fell. Brazil was down 4.83 percent yesterday and Mexico declined 3.57 percent.
A Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company analyst, Mark Gulley, cut his rating on 3M to "neutral" from "outperform," in part because the company gets 25 percent of its earnings from the Pacific Rim. "The company's earnings are being held hostage to the sliding Japanese yen," he said in a report to clients.
Boeing, like 3M one of the 30 Dow industrials, fell 9/16, to 45 7/16, after the aircraft maker said it would cut jobs because Asia's financial turmoil had prompted airlines to delay deliveries and order smaller planes.
Tobacco stocks slumped. Brown & Williamson Tobacco lost a Florida tobacco trial and was ordered to pay the estate of a dead smoker at least $500,000, an unexpected defeat that could derail the tobacco industry's efforts in Congress to win protection from future lawsuits.
Philip Morris Companies fell 1 7/8, to 38 3/8. B.A.T Industries P.L.C., parent of Brown & Williamson, lost 5/8, to 19 9/16, and RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation sank 7/8, to 26.
The Inktomi Corporation, which makes software designed to reduce Internet congestion as well as a popular Internet search engine, doubled on its first day of trading, reflecting continued enthusiasm for Internet stocks. Shares of the company, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., surged 18, to 36.
Mr. Greenspan also said United States stock prices may be "difficult to sustain unless economic conditions remain exceptionally favorable."
"He said what he probably had to say in this crisis," Mr. Stovall said. "The strong dollar here and the weakening and suspect currencies from Japan and the rest of Asia are all such that he certainly didn't want to say anything to push them over the lip."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Congress Testimony by Greenspan

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress: 
 In short, our economy is still enjoying a virtuous cycle, in which, in the context of subdued inflation and generally supportive credit conditions, rising equity values are providing impetus for spending and, in turn, the expansion of output, employment, and productivity-enhancing capital investment. The hopes for accelerated productivity growth have been bolstering expectations of future corporate earnings and thereby fueling still further increases in equity values. . . .
To a considerable extent, investors seem to be expecting that low inflation and stronger productivity growth will allow the extraordinary growth of profits to be extended into the distant future. Indeed, expectations of per share earnings growth over the longer term have been undergoing continuous upward revision by security analysts since 1994. These rising expectations have, in turn, driven stock prices sharply higher and credit spreads lower, perhaps to levels that will be difficult to sustain unless economic conditions remain exceptionally favorable -- more so than might be anticipated from historical relationships. In any event, primarily because of the rise in stock prices, about $12 trillion has been added to the value of household assets since the end of 1994. Probably only a few percent of these largely unrealized capital gains have been transformed into the purchase of goods and services in consumer markets. But that increment to spending, combined with the sharp increase in equipment investment, which has stemmed from the low cost of both equity and debt relative to expected profits on capital, has propelled the economy forward. The current economic performance, with its combination of strong growth and low inflation, is as impressive as any I have witnessed in my near half-century of daily observation of the American economy. . . .
At this point, at least, the adverse wage-price interactions that played so central a role in pushing inflation higher in many past business expansions -- eventually bringing those expansions to an end -- do not appear to have gained a significant toehold in the current expansion. . . .
The effects of the crisis in Asia will almost certainly damp net exports further, potentially moderating the growth of domestic production and hence employment. The strength of domestic spending that has been been bolstering output growth and the demand for labor also could ebb if recent indications of a narrowing in domestic profit margins were to prove to be the forerunner of a reassessment of the expected rates of return on plant and equipment. Reduced prospects for the return to capital would not only affect investment directly but could also affect consumption as stock prices adjusted to a less optimistic view of earnings prospects. Finally, the clearly unsustainable rise of inventories that has been evident in recent quarters will be slowing at some point, perhaps abruptly. An easing of the demand for labor would be an expected consequence of a slowdown in either final sales or inventory accumulation. Of course, the demand for labor that is consistent with a particular rate of output growth also could be lowered if productivity were to continue to accelerate. And, on the supply side of the labor market, faster growth of the labor force could emerge as the result of delayed retirements or increased immigration. . . .
In summary, Mr. Chairman, our economy has remained strong this year despite evidence of substantial drag from Asia, and, at the same time, inflation has remained low. As I have indicated, this set of circumstances is not what historical relationships would have led us to expect at this point in the business expansion, and while it is possible that we have, in a sense, moved "beyond history," we also have to be alert to the possibility that less favorable historical relationships will eventually reassert themselves. That is why we are remaining watchful for signs of potential inflationary imbalances, even as the economy continues to perform more impressively than it has in a very long time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
