HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A falling yen confronts Japan with bad choices: weak demand, pump priming, monetary inflation.

BYLINE: By Gretchen Morgenson 

 BODY:
THE yen must fall. Even further than it has.
So say several veteran Japan-watchers. While economists argue about when and how the Japanese Government might act to reverse the nation's economic slide, these analysts say it matters not. Japan is in such a straitjacket, their notion holds, that even if the Government takes decisive action, the yen will still plunge. 
 Severe weakness in the yen's exchange value has already taken it from 135.5 yen to the dollar a month ago to 141.43 late yesterday, a 4.4 percent decline. And the Japanese central bank increasingly appears incapable of stopping the plunge. "I don't think an intervention by the Bank of Japan, even a massive one, can reverse the slide," said David Horner, a senior financial strategist with Merrill Lynch in New York. "The worst is yet to come."
Mr. Horner expects Japan's central bank to soon try to prop up the currency. But he expects any intervention to be modest compared with the $25 billion buying spree of yen by the Bank of Japan over Easter weekend. The threat of another intervention has so far been successful, keeping currency traders on guard and speculators reined in. It has also helped make the yen's four-week fall a smooth, not disruptive one.
As a result, the currency may rebound here and there, but the long-term outlook seems grim indeed. Mr. Horner says the yen could fall within eight weeks to a rate of 148 against the dollar, a 5 percent decline from yesterday.
Others agreed. "Japan is in depression," said Robert H. Parks, a former Wall Street economist and a professor of finance at the Lubin Graduate School of Business at Pace University in New York. "And the Japanese are not taking effective action to get out of depression."
If Japan reports tomorrow that the economy contracted again in the first quarter, as is expected, economists will characterize it officially as a recession.
The first thing Japan must do to give its economy some lift, Mr. Parks argued, is to increase demand at home. The current lack of demand shows up in several ways. In May, Japanese wholesale prices fell by 2.3 percent from their level a year earlier. Another measure is inventories. Even considering that Japanese companies normally carry two and a half times as much inventory for each unit of output as American companies do, the inventories overhanging the Japanese economy today are staggering at 22.5 percent above the average level in the 1980's. Corporate inventories are now double the level of their last peak in 1992.
But it is not easy to increase the demand for goods and services in a country where the working population is declining by one-half of 1 percent annually. According to Andrew Smithers of the economic advisory firm Smithers & Company in London, "Even if Japan is very successful, if its productivity paced the rest of the world and it had a higher growth in the standard of living than the rest of the world, it will still grow slower than everybody else."
The result? Japan must stimulate its economy by cutting taxes and spending more on public works projects that are not boondoggles. And, Mr. Parks argued, the central bank must finance these projects with money fresh off the printing presses. If the bank did not create new money and instead sold debt to pay for the projects, it would merely sop up funds that might otherwise go to investment or consumption.
But revving up the printing presses is something the Japanese are loath to do. For one, it goes against a monetary policy in place since 1990. Japan's money-supply growth, running about 4 percent last year, has come down from 20 percent in the early 1970's and 9 percent in 1990.
Printing money is also deemed inflationary by the Japanese and therefore deeply feared. Creating a fresh supply of yen would also push the currency's value down further.
Therein lies the Scylla and Charybdis aspect of the Japanese situation. If the Government were to let the budget deficit run bigger than this year's estimated 3.8 percent of the gross domestic product, the yen's value would fall. If the Government did nothing, it would fall as well. "The yen is tumbling either way," Mr. Parks said. "There's no bottom to a currency in the middle of a depression."
A tumbling yen could be expected to cause another bloodletting among the already wan Asian economies. A serious downward spiral in currencies in Indonesia, South Korea, Thailand and other Asian countries would likely be even more damaging than the devaluations there last fall.
That's because in 1997, most of these countries were still showing growth in their economic output. Now, they are not. China, which is growing, albeit slowly, is voicing its concerns to Washington about the free-falling yen.
Finally, a sharply declining yen would devastate Japanese stocks, already down more than 7 percent this year. Conclusion: investors buying into the Japanese market in the belief that it is the bargain basement may soon learn that they are nowhere near the cellar at all.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Long-Term Interest Rates Fall to 5.7%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as the Asian financial crisis and continuing problems in Russia apparently sent more foreigners to the haven of the American bond market.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, helped the rally when he indicated, in an upbeat assessment of the economy, that an interest rate increase to slow economic growth was not imminent. 
 The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.70 percent, just a tick away from the 5.69 percent closing low it reached in January. That yield for the 30-year bond was the lowest since the Treasury began issuing them in 1977. At the same time, yields on corporate debt approached 30-year lows.
Other interest rates, however, have not fallen back to their January levels, which means that mortgage rates are still above the four-year lows they reached at the beginning of the year.
While Mr. Greenspan said that the American economy was "still enjoying a virtuous cycle," he also said the Asian crisis could lead to a cut in earnings expectations, a key element in the outlook for the stock market.
The Asian crisis, he told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, should lead to both a further dampening of American export sales and a reduction in profit margins because of rising price pressures from cheaper imports. Both developments would cut into earnings.
The stock market plunged in the afternoon, as the Boeing Company and the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation announced that the Asian problems were worsening their earnings outlooks, emphasizing Mr. Greenspan's warning. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 6.13 points, to 1,112.28, while the Nasdaq index dropped 27.51 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,773.25. The Dow Jones industrial average, which has suffered the least in the recent market downturn, fell 78.22 points, to 8,971.70.
Although Mr. Greenspan raised the issue of earnings and the stock market, he did not make any comments that appeared aimed at talking the market down. He has tried that in the past only to see stocks rally after an initial negative reaction.
But in a contorted way -- something that a quick reading of his remarks might miss -- Mr. Greenspan did say that a decline in stock prices would help the central bank avoid an interest rate increase because the fall would probably help curtail the consumer spending that has helped propel the economy.
In listing the factors that could help slow growth and obviate the need for an interest rate increase, Mr. Greenspan said, "Reduced prospects for the return to capital would not only affect investment directly but could also affect consumption as stock prices adjusted to a less optimistic view of earnings prospects."
Analysts did not focus on this part of his remarks, however. They were more taken by his positive outlook. He said that wages had not risen as much as one would have suspected and that productivity gains might offset inflationary pressures.
"He sounded more optimistic about the long-run prospects of keeping inflation down than in his previous testimony," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Most of the surge in bond prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields, came after stock markets dropped sharply in Asia, showing that the economic turmoil there that helped push interest rates to their January lows might be deepening. The price of the 30-year bond rose 1 7/32, to 106 2/3, as the yield fell from 5.78 percent Tuesday.
The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong dropped 4.9 percent, to 7,979.26, a three-year low that brought it below the 8,121.06 low it reached on Jan. 12, the same day that the 30-year bond yield reached 5.69 percent. The Nikkei index in Japan dropped 1.2 percent, to 15,339. Also adding to concerns about the world's emerging markets was the failure of the weekly Russian treasury bills sale. The Government needed to raise $1.1 billion to cover maturing issues but received only $742 million, raising concerns about the Government's ability to pay its debts without new international assistance. A key Russian stock index dropped 6.2 percent.
Even though the yield on the 30-year bond is near its recent lows, other interest rates are not nearly so low as they were in January. For example, the yield on the 10-year note dropped to 5.50 percent yesterday from 5.58 Tuesday. But it is still well above January's 5.36 percent level, which is why mortgage rates have not come down to January levels.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, the average rate nationally on a 30-year mortgage is 6.92 percent, still above the 6.87 percent of mid-January.
And short-term rates are so much higher than they were in January that the 5.50 percent yield on the 10-year note yesterday was below that of the two-year note, 5.52 percent.
One reason that short-term rates are high is that investors still expect the Fed to raise its interest rates target sometime in the next year. In January, when the yield on the two-year note dropped to 5.17 percent, some expected the economy to slow enough for the Fed to cut interest rates.
In some circumstances, a move of short-term interest rates above longer-term interest rates could signal that the economy will be slowing down if the so-called inversion is caused by the Fed's decision to raise its short-term interest rate target.
But in the current circumstances, the inversion is caused more by a fall in longer-term rates that reflects positive views on inflation and, therefore, it is not a warning signal, Mr. Berner said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Seem Ready to Let Banks Fail

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 10

 BODY:
Six months after it retreated from closing weak banks or allowing them to fail, the Japanese Government is once again inclined to administer such shock therapy as a cure for the nation's sick financial system.
Although no bank failures are expected before elections for the upper house of Parliament in July, comments from leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party suggest that they would not rescue financial institutions, some large, that are verging on insolvency. 
 Investors are betting against the survival of at least two of Japan's weakest banks among the top 20 in the country, the Nippon Credit Bank and the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
Lenders and stockholders are abandoning them and other weak institutions. Nippon Credit shares traded here today at 121 yen, down 4 percent so far this week. The Long-Term Credit Bank's stock closed at 176 yen, down 8 percent in the same brief time.
Analysts have resumed handicapping merger possibilities they envisioned last fall, when a string of failures shook the financial system. Those merger possibilities were dropped when Government bureaucrats insisted that no further fallout was evident.
"There seems to be a greater possibility than before that the Government would consider shutting down some banks," said James P. Fiorillo, a banking analyst at ING Baring Securities of Japan.
A week ago, Seiroku Kajiyama, a senior Liberal Democratic Party leader whose outspoken criticism of Government's efforts to fix the financial system have been a source of irritation, said Japan needed only half the number of banks it now has. "Japanese banks can't survive with the current number," he told reporters.
And Koichi Kato, the party's General Secretary and a longtime critic of the Finance Ministry, which oversees the banking system, said last month in Washington that more bank closings "could well be expected."
Japan's banks are struggling with an estimated $600 billion in bad debt, a legacy of the speculative "bubble economy" of the 1980's. Last month, some of the largest banks reported their biggest annual losses ever.
Last fall, the banking system seemed poised for a major overhaul when a number of overly indebted institutions collapsed. Sanyo Securities closed in November, quickly followed by the Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, Yamaichi Securities and a smaller regional bank.
Investors expected more, but the torrid pace seemed to unsettle Finance Ministry bureaucrats, who spent much of December insisting that no more banks would fail.
But market wisdom has held just as stubbornly that just as there is overcapacity in the global auto business that only consolidation will repair, there are too many Japanese financial institutions.
That sentiment has hung over the Japanese economy and stock market, despite a 30 trillion yen rescue package for the financial system as well as several economic-stimulus packages.
With few options left, politicians now seem more resigned to further financial institution failures.
Mr. Fiorillo and other analysts decline to identify which banks they considered candidates for closing.
Last fall, the Government made life difficult for the firms that employ analysts who spoke their minds about specific banks, accusing them of spreading rumors to support short-sellers, or investors who bet on stock declines. Right-wing extremists threatened the lives of two banking analysts who made the names public.
Nippon Credit's problems have been grist for the rumor mill for more than a year. The Government arranged for a bailout for the bank last summer, pressing insurance companies and other banks to recapitalize it by buying preferred shares and issuing subordinated debt, which carries a higher risk of nonpayment than other types of debt.
Nippon Credit now wants to extend the terms on some of those loans because it will have trouble meeting its obligations. Lenders are balking.
One of those, the Nippon Life Insurance Company, sent a clear signal of its sentiments about the banking system when it announced over the weekend that it would no longer make subordinated loans to financial institutions because it considered them too great a credit risk. The Finance Ministry has said it will not protect shareholders or subordinated-debt holders.
The Long-Term Credit Bank's shares have been pummeled, as rumors circulated that its investment banking alliance with the Swiss Bank Corporation was unraveling. Both it and Swiss Bank deny that their relationship is dissolving, but Swiss Bank has also made clear that it feels no obligation to rescue its partner, should it need help.
Mr. Fiorillo calls Long-Term Credit the "hardest call" he has. He said the bank was not in as precarious a position as Nippon Credit because it had no immediate need for additional funds.
Moody's Investors Service currently gives 10 Japanese financial institutions its worst rating for financial strength, including Long-Term Credit, Sakura Bank and Daiwa Bank.
Daiwa is widely regarded as a potential acquisition target for a foreign bank. Tokai Bank and Asahi Bank are often discussed as candidates for potential mergers or takeovers.
And banks are expected to take advantage of changes in the holding-company law to consolidate. Sanwa Bank, for instance, could absorb Toyo Trust and Banking, or Fuji Bank could take in the ever-ailing Yasuda Trust.

HEADLINE: THE STANLEY CUP FINALS;
The Red Wings' Tough Guy Enjoys an Unlikely Renaissance

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 10

 BODY:
Joe Kocur's face didn't make the cover of Rolling Stone, but it takes up about half of page 101 of the current issue.
The music magazine is a strange place to find one of hockey's top fighting specialists, a man who calls himself "a country guy" in reference to both his musical tastes and his boyhood in Western Canada. 
 The black-and-white photograph of his menacing expression illustrates a story about hockey fighting. The magazine's next hockey story might have to include Kocur in a list of players who score important goals in the Stanley Cup finals. Kocur got the first one on Tuesday night to help the Detroit Red Wings to a 2-1 victory over the Washington Capitals in Game 1 at Joe Louis Arena. Game 2 of the four-of-seven-game championship round will be here on Thursday night.
When the Wings won the title last season after sweeping the Philadelphia Flyers, one of their scorers in the first game was Joe Kocur. For a veteran who had washed out of hockey two years ago, Kocur has made a remarkable comeback. The goal was his fourth of this spring's playoffs.
In a career that began in 1984, Kocur had scored only five post-season goals before this spring. He might have even more in this tournament had he not been held out of uniform for four of the six games in the Wings' previous series against the Dallas Stars.
Not that Kocur is complaining. After playing with the Red Wings until the 1990-91 season and with the Rangers until late in the 1995-96 season, he finished with Vancouver and could not find a job in the National Hockey League. Living in suburban Detroit, he played recreationally in what is called a "beer league." He got tickets to Wings games from a friend and hung around the locker room just to remind management that he was unemployed.
"Out of sight, out of mind didn't help," said Kocur, now 33 years old. "I made myself known."
Kocur got a glimpse of life as a former athlete. It enlightened him. "When you see the end is near, you get a second lease on life," Kocur said. "You make the best of it."
He began to notice that fans treated him differently, that the complimentary tickets to shows weren't so readily available. "When your career is over, those people forget about you pretty quickly," Kocur said.
Steve Yzerman, the captain, put in a good word with Scotty Bowman, the coach. At the time, Bowman thought that players such as Brendan Shanahan, Martin Lapointe and Darren McCarty were fighting too much. Kocur, with as many as 377 penalty minutes in a single season and almost 2,000 in his career, could still fight if necessary. More likely, his presence might discourage other teams from starting trouble. Around Christmas 1996, the Wings offered him work.
"He is a really smart player," Bowman said. "He knows how to play hockey. That sounds strange, but he's really got a big sense of the game. And he's got the reputation."
The reputation was that of a scary puncher who might knock a foe unconscious with one swing. His hands, which have had surgery, are legendary for their scars. There have been infections. Sometimes, the knuckles bleed easily. The worst is his mangled right fist.
"It's not a normal hand," Kocur said. "It gets the job done. That's the best way to put it."
This season, he said, he had to fight "maybe a half-dozen times, more out of necessity, when it's called for."
In the playoffs, particularly in the late rounds, fighting is rare. This creates new dynamics when players of Yzerman's skill are bullied by opponents like Dale Hunter of the Capitals, as was the case twice in Game 1.
Although Kocur got penalized for roughing Hunter, the retaliation was not the fistic sort of a regular-season game.
"Yeah, well, in a regular-season game, Hunter wouldn't do that," Kocur said, referring to Hunter's attacks on Yzerman. "You've got to live with it. It's not going to help us to go back after Hunter."
Instead, Kocur suggested, the Wings might retaliate against highly skilled Capitals, such as Peter Bondra and Andrei Nikolishin.
"Show them," Kocur said. "If they are going to go after Stevie, we're going to do it to your guys."
In his first tour in Detroit, Kocur was a friend of Bob Probert's. They were the Bruise Brothers, men about town, as active after games as during them. Now married and a father, Kocur is a team elder, inspiring tough young players like McCarty.
"We don't call him 'Papa' for nothing," McCarty said. "His leadership factor goes well beyond what he does on the ice. Last year, he came in here and taught us what it was like to win a Stanley Cup. A lot of times, he's a soothing voice in here. He takes care of a lot of things."
Kocur won his first Stanley Cup ring with the Rangers in 1994. He won his second last season. Should the Wings win three more games, he will get his third ring to fit over his gnarled fingers, giving him a diamond-studded set on hands that do more than score.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detroit's Joe Kocur celebrating after scoring on Washington goalie Olaf Kolzig in Game 1. (Rick Stewart/Allsport)

HEADLINE: The Silicon Valley Gang;
An Influential Industry With Lots of Money Is Getting Its Way on Capitol Hill

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The topic may have been an arcane change to the securities laws, but there was the sound of old-fashioned melodrama today in a hearing room on Capitol Hill.
Supporters of the legislation talked of protecting the hard-working companies that are trying to cure AIDS, heart disease and other ailments. Opponents talked about protecting "the weak, the frail, the infirm and those not fully able to defend themselves." There was even a mysterious villain in the piece, cryptically referred to by several Congressmen as the notorious "Mr. L." 
 But the subtext of this discussion could not have been more up to the minute: the growing political influence of the companies in California's Silicon Valley, which have begun flexing their political muscles after years of disdaining government and politicians' increasing desire to tap into the glamour -- and gold -- of the booming high-technology industry.
"The technology community has an advantage most industries don't," said Dan Schnur, Republican political director of Technology Network, or Technet, a year-old political advocacy group that represents 140 California companies. "The National Widgets Association would have a much tougher time getting attention, because Silicon Valley is about the future, and I don't know of any politician who has come out against the future."
And the No. 1 issue on Silicon Valley's agenda right now is the Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act, which is the bill that was approved today by the finance subcommittee of the House Commerce Committee. Identical legislation has already passed in the Senate, so if the House approves the bill -- which it seems all but certain to do -- Technet will have scored its first Federal victory.
The actual content of the bill is hardly likely to catch the attention of most voters. Basically, it would prevent investors and their lawyers from filing class-action securities fraud cases in state courts. Instead, these suits would have to be brought in Federal court under strict rules imposed by Congress in 1995 to discourage "meritless" lawsuits. The new rules would apply only to securities traded on national stock exchanges, which supporters of the bill contend should be covered by national, rather than state, standards.
The connection between such legislation and the high-technology industry may not be immediately apparent -- except to those who know that technology companies have been frequent targets of class-action securities frauds suits.
And California is also home to Mr. L. -- William S. Lerach -- who is probably the most feared of the class-action lawyers for plaintiffs. In 1996, he tried to persuade state voters to loosen the rules in state courts to make it even easier for investors to sue companies. The high-technology industry spent $40 million to beat the initiative, in what was by many accounts its political awakening.
Now Silicon Valley wants to make sure it never faces a similar threat, in California or anywhere else. And it is putting its money on the line. In 1995 and 1996, the industry gave $4 million to Congressional candidates. And in the last 18 months, even before the campaign fund-raising season has fully swung into action, computer companies and their executives have already given more than $1.2 million. That includes $150,000 to members of the Senate Banking Committee, which handled the litigation legislation but otherwise has little involvement in technology issues.
"They've really opened up their wallets," said Jennifer Shecter, an analyst for the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research group. "This industry has so much money, and if as a politician you can tap that successfully, you're golden."
For years, the high-technology industry had a reputation for being politically naive. Ms. Shecter said that was no longer the case. She pointed out that Technet, for one, was serving as a conduit for individual contributions, which allowed the organization to get credit for delivering funds while keeping contributions within legal limits.
Last fall, Technet funneled $37,500 to the campaign of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Banking Committee, according to a filing the organization made in March with the Federal Election Commission. The list of contributors from Silicon Valley includes venture capitalists, investment bankers, technology executives and even a couple of political action committees.
Senator D'Amato has also received more than $50,000 from other high-technology executives and corporate PAC's, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. The group's study included information released by the F.E.C. as of May 1, and may understate the amounts because not all donors' professions were identified.
Asked by The New York Times whether there was any connection between Senator D'Amato's support of the uniform standards legislation, which backers say was important to its success, and the campaign contributions, Lisette McSoud Mondello, the Senator's director of communications, called the question ridiculous. "This bill was introduced by two other Senators, passed the Senate overwhelmingly and with strong bipartisan support, was supported by the White House and the Securities and Exchange Commission," she said. "And it's good legislation."
One of the sponsors of the bill in the Senate, Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat, was a sponsor of the 1995 securities litigation reform bill as well. He has raised more than $24,000 the last two years from computer companies, almost all of them from outside Connecticut, according to the Center for Responsive Politics.
Senator Dodd, said Ellen Miller, president of Public Campaign, which advocates publicly financed elections, "has carried enough water for the securities, investment, accounting and high-tech computer industries to fill all of the bathtubs of Connecticut."
That statement is "garbage," replied Marvin Fast, Senator Dodd's spokesman. "Chris Dodd fights for what he believes in. He works for the people of Connecticut, and no one else."
Lobbying involves more than campaign contributions, of course, and Silicon Valley has become more adept at getting its message across. In late May, less than two weeks before his House subcommittee was to take up the legislation, Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio, visited California under the auspices of Technet and met with several companies.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Oxley did not respond to questions about his trip.
Mr. Schnur of Technet said such face-to-face visits, rather than campaign contributions, helped explain his group's success.
Indeed, politicians are falling all over themselves to be associated with high-technology industries, said Mark Gitenstein, counsel for the more traditional lobbying group on this issue, the Uniform Standards Coalition.
"People in policy are attracted by the new economy," he said. "The percentage of jobs they are creating dwarfs the smokestack industries. That's what this is all about. There is no question that the very mechanism by which they flourish is chilled by litigators."
And that is what the 1995 securities law was supposed to prevent: class-action lawyers jumping on a company because its stock tumbled, finding a plaintiff who owned a handful of shares, and rushing to the courthouse to sue for fraud. Companies settled almost all of these lawsuits, arguing that the cost of fighting them was prohibitive.
Opponents of the 1995 legislation, however, said that it would encourage securities fraud and deprive investors of one of the few ways they had to recover money in a fraud.
The fight over the 1995 legislation was extremely contentious, pitting securities firms, accountants and, increasingly, the technology industry, against trial lawyers and consumer groups. President Clinton vetoed the bill; Congress overrode his veto for the first and only time.
The 1995 law requires that when they are filed class-action securities fraud suits contain very specific accusations, and it does not permit plaintiffs to demand information from a company until a judge has ruled on the company's motion to dismiss the lawsuit. It also provided a "safe harbor" that allows companies to make predictions about their business without being legally liable if those predictions fail to come true.
Lawyers for plaintiffs fought back with Proposition 211, which was on the ballot in California in 1996. This initiative would have made it far easier for investors and their lawyers to file securities-fraud lawsuits against companies. At first, it appeared to enjoy wide public support.
In the end, Proposition 211 was roundly defeated -- primarily through a $40 million campaign organized by high-technology concerns, venture capitalists and investment bankers. That effort led to the creation of Technet.
In the meantime, securities lawyers began filing class-action fraud suits in state courts, where the new Federal rules did not apply. The number of such cases jumped from about 19 in 1992 and 41 in 1994 to 70 in 1996, according to a study by two Stanford University law professors, Michael A. Perino and Joseph A. Grundfest, who is also a former commissioner of the S.E.C. More than half these were filed in California.
But in 1997, a funny thing happened: the number of state lawsuits began to decline, falling to just 24 in the first six months of the year. "I still haven't done the final statistics for 1997, but the raw amount of litigation is less than in 1996," said Professor Perino, who has recently joined the faculty at St. John's University in New York City.
Mr. Lerach, the California lawyer, said the number of such suits was declining because state courts had not turned out to be "an effective forum." Not only are the courts overburdened, he said, but it is unclear if one can bring a national class-action case in California.
So why does he think Silicon Valley's executives are so intent on getting the litigation bill passed? "I don't say it in a mean way," Mr. Lerach responded, "but they are intoxicated with their own power, and think they can get what they want."
Silicon Valley's power clearly had an impact on Arthur Levitt Jr., the politically astute chairman of the S.E.C., who reversed himself and agreed to support the litigation bill on the day his renomination was taken up by the Senate Banking Committee. The commission's staff argues that he got some significant modifications to the legislation in exchange for his support, and that the commission wants to encourage companies to provide more forward-looking information for investors, which they have been reluctant to do because of their fears of state lawsuits.
Besides, said one former S.E.C. lawyer, it was impossible for the commission to resist. "This is the most powerful lobbying force in America today," he said.
Consumer groups have tried to stop the legislation, which they argue will deprive investors of their rights. But they are not optimistic. "It's been clear Congress was going to do this, and it's hard to justify making a massive campaign in a future effort," said Barbara Roper, director of investor protection for the Consumer Federation of America.
Just because the opponents are not mounting a big counteroffensive, however, does not mean Silicon Valley's executives are relaxing their push. "One neat thing about our community," said Mr. Schnur of Technet, "is that it is filled with people who don't take no for an answer."

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Calls the Economy One of the Best He Has Seen

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
With a mixture of pride and puzzlement, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, declared the economy to be in extraordinarily good shape today and signaled to investors that he saw no immediate need to strike against inflation by raising interest rates.
"The current economic performance, with its combination of strong growth and low inflation, is as impressive as any I have witnessed in my near half-century of daily observation of the American economy," Mr. Greenspan said. 
 The Federal Reserve chairman sprinkled his two hours of testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress with caveats about how the combination of low unemployment and strong growth could eventually force the central bank to raise rates. But he emphasized that price pressures were subdued and that Asia's financial crisis was already working to take some of the steam out of the American economy.
Just as he has in other public statements over the last several years, Mr. Greenspan spoke optimistically about several economic developments, including his belief that the nation was benefiting from huge investments in technology that were helping companies produce more for every hour worked, holding down overall costs even as wages rise. And he pointed to a "virtuous cycle" in which low inflation had reduced interest rates and stimulated more investment and consumption.
And in what has become a familiar refrain for investors in the stock market, Mr. Greenspan said expectations of stronger earnings had "driven stock prices sharply higher and credit spreads lower, perhaps to levels that will be difficult to sustain unless economic conditions remain exceptionally favorable."
Mr. Greenspan's less direct but more explosive warning about the danger of "irrational exuberance" spooked the markets when he first suggested the market might be overvalued a year and a half ago. But investors largely shrugged off his concerns today -- although reports late in the day from some big American companies about likely earnings weakness because of the Asian turmoil jolted the markets.
Not only has Mr. Greenspan's fretfulness about the market become old news to investors as they have pushed the market higher, but Wall Street is convinced that the Federal Reserve has little leeway to raise rates anyway because of its concerns about the fragility of Asian markets and economies. Underscoring those worries, stock markets fell sharply today in Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and other nations, largely because of concern that the plummeting value of the Japanese yen could further harm the region's economies.
On Wall Street, bond prices rose sharply today, with Mr. Greenspan's comments extending a rally set off when investors in Asian markets sought a safe refuge in United States Treasury securities. After being up much of the day, stock prices ended lower, dragged down in part by a warning from the Boeing Company, the nation's biggest exporter, that weak demand for airliners from Asia would cut into its profits.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the risks to the American economy remained balanced between an Asia-induced slowdown and an inflationary overheating fueled by the surging stock market and strong demand.
Mr. Greenspan said the Fed remained uncertain about whether Asia was stabilizing or whether further economic deterioration there could wash up in the United States later this year.
At the same time, he said, there were signs that consumer price inflation might be picking up from extremely low levels. And without saying so explicitly, he suggested that a continued run-up in the stock market could fuel excess demand and inflationary pressures.
But he said there was almost no evidence of the phenomenon that central bankers fear most -- wage and price increases feeding off each other and creating inflationary pressures that can only be squelched by higher interest rates.
"At this point, at least, the adverse wage-price interactions that played so central a role in pushing inflation higher in many past business expansions -- eventually bringing those expansions to an end -- do not appear to have gained a significant toehold in the current expansion," Mr. Greenspan said.
The crisis in Asia, a slowdown or reversal in the rise of corporate earnings and a reversal of the inventory buildup of the last several quarters could all help slow the economy to a sustainable pace, he said.
Mr. Greenspan was careful to say that he would be as vigilant as ever in looking for early warnings signs of broad-based wage and price increases, especially with unemployment at a 28-year low of 4.3 percent.
"If developments such as these do not bring labor demand into line with its sustainable supply, tighter economic policy may be necessary to help guard against a buildup of pressures that could derail the current prosperity," he said.
The optimistic tone of Mr. Greenspan's testimony put him at odds with a small group of inflation hawks on the central bank's policy-making committee who have been urging a rate increase now. Led by Jerry L. Jordan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, they have been arguing that heading off inflation down the road requires striking now, even if there is little evidence of current price pressure. The Fed will next meet on June 30 and July 1 to consider interest rate policy, and economists say it is extremely unlikely that the Fed will raise rates then.
Mr. Greenspan mused at several points during his testimony about how the old rules and assumptions about the interplay between growth, inflation and unemployment did not seem to be holding up -- although he quickly added that he did not know whether they had been permanently retired or just set aside by temporary factors.
"The fact that economic performance strengthened as inflation subsided should not have been surprising, given that risk premiums and economic disincentives to invest in productive capital diminish as product prices become more stable," he said. "But the extent to which strong growth and high resource utilization have been joined with low inflation over an extended period is nevertheless extraordinary."
One reason for the strong economic performance, Mr. Greenspan said, is an apparent pickup in the growth rate of productivity, or the measure of output for every worker for each period of time worked.
A steep and largely unexplained decline in productivity growth since the early 1970's has been the main brake on economic growth in the United States, and economists have been debating for several years whether heavy investments in computers and other technology have turned the trend around. There is mounting evidence that productivity gains are growing, Mr. Greenspan said, although the extent of the improvement remains unclear.
"Signs of a major technological transformation of the economy are all around us, and the benefits are evident not only in high-tech industries but also in production processes that have long been part of our industrial economy," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Finds Economy Is Extraordinarily Sound
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, declared the economy to be in extraordinarily good shape and signaled that he saw no immediate need to strike against inflation by raising interest rates.
His testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress was sprinkled with caveats about how the combination of low unemployment and strong growth could eventually force the Fed to raise rates. But for now price pressures are subdued and Asia's crisis is taking some of the steam out of the American economy. Page A1. 

Tobacco Company Liability Found
A Florida jury found Brown & Williamson Tobacco liable for a smoker's death and ordered the company to pay $1 million in compensatory and punitive damages. The case was viewed as a major defeat for cigarette makers that could affect the course of Federal tobacco legislation, and tobacco stocks slumped. A28.
 
A Tax Break From Cigarette Money
Giving strength to anti-smoking legislation, the Senate voted to use part of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices to give an income-tax break to married couples with annual incomes below $50,000, to reduce the marriage tax penalty. A1.
 
Big Health Care Companies Merge
Health Care and Retirement and Manor Care Inc. agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $2.45 billion. Analysts applauded the deal, which will create one of the nation's largest operators of nursing homes. D2.
 
Further Decline in Yen Expected
Japan is in such an economic straitjacket, some veteran analysts contend, that the yen must fall even further than it has -- 4.4 percent in the last month to 141.43 to the dollar. Gretchen Morgenson: Market Place. D5.
 
Leaders of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party are suggesting that they will not rescue financial institutions on the verge of insolvency. D4.
 
A Swiss-American Deal in Brazil
Credit Suisse First Boston bought Brazil's leading investment bank, Garantia S.A., for $675 million in cash, making the Swiss-American group the largest underwriter and stock trader in that hotly competitive emerging market. D4.
 
House Votes to Tighten Bankruptcy
The House passed far-reaching legislation to tighten the bankruptcy laws for the first time in a generation, to discourage declarations of personal bankruptcy to erase debts. A22.
 
Republic and Honda Settle Suit
Republic Industries and Honda Motor's American unit said that they had settled a lawsuit and set conditions that would allow Republic, the nation's largest group of car dealers, to buy more Honda and Acura dealerships. D21.
 
Dow Falls on Asian Concern
Concern that Asia's economic slump is causing companies that do business there to report disappointing earnings pushed stocks lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 78.22 points, to 8,971.70. D6.
 
I.M.F. in Warning to Russia
The I.M.F. has told the Russian Government that it needs to slash its budget deficit and overhaul its tax system if it is to qualify for billions of dollars in extra loans, senior Russian officials said. A11.
 
Delta Picks Lufthansa Head
Delta Air Lines has selected Frederick W. Reid, the president of Lufthansa German Airlines, as its new marketing chief. Delta's new chairman is bringing in fresh talent. D2.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Ruling on Use of Education Money

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the decision issued yesterday by the Wisconsin Supreme Court on the Milwaukee Parental Choice Program allowing the city to use public money to send children to parochial or other religious schools. The text was obtained from the Web site of The Milwaukee Journal.
The first issue we address is whether the amended M.P.C.P. violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. Neither the circuit court nor the court of appeals reached this issue. Upon review we conclude that the amended M.P.C.P. does not violate the Establishment Clause because it has a secular purpose, it will not have the primary effect of advancing religion, and it will not lead to excessive entanglement between the State and participating sectarian private schools. 
 The First Amendment to the United States Constitution provides in part that "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof." This mandate applies equally to state legislatures by virtue of the Due Process Clause of the 14th Amendment. The Establishment Clause, therefore, prohibits state governments from passing laws which have either the purpose or effect of advancing or inhibiting religion.
When assessing any First Amendment challenge to a state statute, we are bound by the results and interpretations given that amendment by the decisions of the United States Supreme Court. . . .
The Supreme Court has repeatedly recognized that the Establishment Clause raises difficult issues of interpretation, and cases arising under it "have presented some of the most perplexing questions to come before the Court." We are therefore cognizant of the Court's warnings that:
"There are always risks in treating criteria discussed by the Court from time to time as 'tests' in any limiting sense of that term. Constitutional adjudication does not lend itself to the absolutes of the physical sciences or mathematics. . . . C andor compels the acknowledgment that we can only dimly perceive the boundaries of permissible government activity in this sensitive area of constitutional adjudication."
In an attempt to focus on the three main evils from which the Establishment Clause was intended to afford protection: sponsorship, financial support, and active involvement of thesovereign in religious activity, the Court has promulgated a three-pronged test to determine whether a statute complies with the Establishment Clause. Under this test, a statute does not violate the Establishment Clause if (1) it has a secular legislative purpose; (2) its principal or primary effect neither advances nor inhibits religion, and (3) it does not create excessive entanglement between government and religion. We must apply this three-part test to determine the constitutionality of Wisconsin Statute 119.23.
Under the first prong of the Lemon test, we examine whether the purpose of the state legislation is secular in nature. Our analysis of the amended M.P.C.P. under this prong of the Lemon test is straightforward. Courts have been "reluctan t to attribute unconstitutional motives to the states, particularly when a plausible secular purpose for the state's program may be discerned from the face of the statute."
A state's decision to defray the cost of educational expenses incurred by parents -- regardless of the type of schools their children attend -- evidences a purpose that is both secular and understandable. An educated populace is essential to the political and economic health of any community, and a state's efforts to assist parents in meeting the rising cost of educational expenses plainly serves this secular purpose of insuring that the state's citizenry is well-educated. . . .
Analysis of the amended program under the second prong of the Lemon test is more difficult. While the first prong of Lemon examines the legislative purpose of the challenged statute, the second prong focuses on its likely effect. A law violates the Establishment Clause if its principal or primary effect either advances or inhibits religion. . . .
The Supreme Court, in cases culminating in Agostini, has established the general principle that state educational assistance programs do not have the primary effect of advancing religion if those programs provide public aid to both sectarian and nonsectarian institutions (1) on the basis of neutral, secular criteria that neither favor nor disfavor religion; and (2) only as a result of numerous private choices of the individual parents of school-age children. The amended M.P.C.P. is precisely such a program. Applying to the amended M.P.C.P. the criteria the Court has developed from Everson to Agostini, we conclude that the program does not have the primary effect of advancing religion. . . .
The final question for us to determine under the Lemon test is whether the amended M.P.C.P. would result in an excessive governmental entanglement with religion. Stated another way, it is necessary to determine whether " a comprehensive, discriminating, and continuing state surveillance will inevitably be required to ensure that these restrictions against the inculcation of religious tenets are obeyed and the First Amendment otherwise respected." . . .
The amended M.P.C.P. will not create an excessive entanglement between the state and religion. Under the amended program, the state need not, and in fact is not given the authority to impose a "comprehensive, discriminating, and continuing state surveillance" over the participating sectarian private schools. . . .
The program does not involve the state in any way with the schools' governance, curriculum, or day-to-day affairs. The state's regulation of participating private schools, while designed to insure that the program's educational purposes are fulfilled, does not approach the level of constitutionally impermissible involvement.
In short, we hold that the amended M.P.C.P., which provides a neutral benefit directly to children of economically disadvantaged families on a religious-neutral basis, does not run afoul of any of the three primary criteria the Court has traditionally used to evaluate whether a state educational assistance program has the purpose or effect of advancing religion. Since the amended M.P.C.P. has a secular purpose, does not have the primary effect of advancing religion, and does not create an excessive entanglement, it is not invalid under the Establishment Clause.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Vallone Introduces Bill to Put Stadium Issue Before Voters

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Following through on a pledge that has contributed significantly to his current budget battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, introduced a bill yesterday that would put a referendum about the future of Yankee Stadium on the November ballot.
Accusing Mr. Giuliani of not caring about the opinion of ordinary New Yorkers, Mr. Vallone said he wanted voters to decide whether Government money should be used to help build a new ball park for the Yankees in Manhattan. 
 "The taxpayers of this city have every right to say, 'Yes, I want a new stadium in Manhattan,' or, 'No, I want the Bronx Bombers to stay in the Bronx,' " Mr. Vallone said at a news conference. "That, ladies and gentlemen, is what democracy is about."
The Giuliani administration immediately attacked the bill, saying it was driven by the political ambitions of the Speaker, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. The administration also said the referendum would handcuff the city in its negotiations with the Yankees. The team's owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, said last week that Mr. Vallone's referendum plan had pushed him to the edge of moving the team out of New York City.
"Politics and leadership in politics requires a certain degree of wisdom, and not just pandering constantly to what public opinion polls tell you," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday at a news conference, adding that a referendum would probably increase the Democratic voter turnout for Mr. Vallone in the fall election.
"I think the calculation was he felt he would get 100,000 more votes if he put this on the ballot," Mr. Giuliani said. "So to create a difficult problem in a very sensitive negotiation, which this will no doubt do, for a city that has had a terrible record of keeping sports teams, just in order to get yourself 100,000 votes on the ballot, seems to me the wrong thing to do."
The referendum bill is considered certain to become law, because Mr. Vallone has tight control over the Democratic-dominated Council.
The Speaker introduced the bill as Mr. Giuliani vetoed more than $196 million from a budget that the Council passed on Friday in defiance of the Mayor. The budget negotiations collapsed last week, in part because of the political impasse between the Mayor and the Speaker over the Yankee Stadium issue. The Giuliani administration has insisted that it will not agree to a budget unless Mr. Vallone drops his plans for a referendum.
The deadlock caused the Council to pass a budget without the Mayor's agreement for the first time since it acquired the authority to do so under the 1989 City Charter revision.
Beyond the budget implications raised by the referendum, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone have starkly different views of where a new Yankee Stadium should be and how to pay for it.
The Mayor is trying to block Mr. Vallone's proposal from appearing on the ballot this fall by creating a special commission to recommend changes to the City Charter. By state law, a charter question takes precedence over all other ballot questions, and would block the Yankee Stadium issue from being considered this year.
The Vallone camp, in turn, is also helping a grass-roots organization gather enough signatures in a petition drive intended to put the stadium question on the ballot. If the group gathers 30,000 signatures, the question would be put before the voters separately from the referendum called for by Mr. Vallone's bill, but a charter commission initiative would knock both questions off the ballot.
The referendum fight began after a half-ton steel beam fell on a section of Yankee Stadium seats in April. The Mayor revived a proposal to build a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, a project that by some estimates could run as high as a $1 billion. Mr. Giuliani said he wanted the team to stay in the Bronx, but a new stadium was needed to keep the team profitable, and eliminating the option of Manhattan could push Mr. Steinbrenner to New Jersey.
Saying that a stadium in Manhattan would require both public and private money, the Mayor proposed extending a commercial rent tax that he had previously sought to abolish, a tax scheduled to expire in 2001 that would raise at least $600 million.
But while Mr. Vallone said officials should study the possibility of using public funds to help build a new stadium, he added that the stadium should stay in the Bronx. He said moving the team out of the Bronx would be an economic disaster for that borough and financing a Manhattan stadium would be an undeserved gift to Mr. Steinbrenner, whose ball club has earned him millions.
The Speaker proposed letting the voters decide the issue by having the Council put a referendum on the November ballot. And members of his gubernatorial campaign are helping a grass-roots organization called Keep the Yankees in the Bronx in its separate petition drive to put the stadium question on the ballot, said Peter Ragone, a spokesman for Mr. Vallone.
By pushing for a referendum, Mr. Vallone is likely to derive substantial benefits in his drive to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki. In addition to increasing his name recognition, Mr. Vallone, if he gets his referendum on the ballot, could drive up voter turnout in Democratic strongholds like Manhattan and the Bronx.
In a defensive move, the Mayor created a City Charter Revision Commission to place a question on the November ballot. Under the arcane rules governing the City Charter and the state's Municipal Home Rule Law, a charter question would bump from the ballot any other referendum questions, either from the Council or from a petition drive, said Eric Lane, the executive director of the 1989 Charter Revision Commission.
But because charter revision commissions were set up in the past to review the fundamental workings of city government, Mr. Vallone's aides said they are hoping to prevent Mr. Giuliani's commission from putting a question on the ballot, possibly by arguing in court that the question is not a serious one but merely an attempt to block the stadium referendum.
"There may be legal and governmental reasons why the Mayor's charter commission won't be able to put its proposal on the ballot," said Richard Weinberg, the Council's general counsel.

HEADLINE: Keyboard Is No Cure-All

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Candy Bar, and Skills, Aid County in Job Hunt" (news article, June 7): The people of Henry County, Virginia, are mistaken to think that giving laptop computers to schoolchildren or increasing adult education opportunities will help ease the area's economic malaise. The ideas of creating a curriculum that will help match graduates to the local job market and teaching county residents "skills that new companies might require" sound appealing, but what happens when the local job market changes or the new companies turn out to need skills different from those that were taught? 
 It makes little sense for educators to increase their students' dependence on businesses that have no real stake in the community or interest in the needs of the people they employ or serve. Instead, the county should take a more long-term approach: encourage students to develop their independence and find their own ways of meeting the community's needs, like starting small businesses.
 
MELISSA ALLEN
Madison, Wis., June 7, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

But she told a Senate panel that her agency could not judge whether the less rigorous standards had jeopardized security. A8
 
Chinese Remove Clinton Book
Officials in China ordered bookstores to remove a popular new book that details the sex scandals surrounding President Clinton, who is to arrive in China on June 25. A9
 
Seeking Peace With East Timor
The Indonesian Government, for the first time in 20 years, has signaled a willingness to address one of the sorest points in its international relations: the status of East Timor. President B. J. Habibie proposed that the territory be granted a special administrative status, but ruled out independence. A8

The United Nations General Assembly concluded a special session on the world drug problem with the 150 participating nations promising to work to reduce illegal drugs within the next five years. A13

The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled that Milwaukee could spend taxpayer money to send pupils to parochial or other religious schools. The court said the program "has a secular purpose" and "will not have the primary effect of advancing religion." A1
 
A DNA Sequence Is Decoded
Scientists have broken the genetic code of the tuberculosis bacterium, a germ that kills more people in the world than any other infectious agent. The advance could open new approaches for developing drugs and vaccines against the microbe. A1
 
Death Penalty to Be Sought

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: SENATE BACKS USE OF CIGARETTE TAX TO ASSIST COUPLES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The Senate voted tonight to use part of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices to give an income-tax break to married couples with low and moderate incomes. The vote gave additional strength to anti-smoking legislation that has been before the Senate for three weeks.
The marriage-tax amendment was approved on a voice vote, after a procedural motion to kill it failed on a 50-to-48 roll-call along party lines. 
 The Republican amendment to the tobacco bill would give all couples with annual incomes below $50,000 a new tax deduction of $825 this year, rising gradually to $3,300 in 2008. The amendment was billed as a reduction in the marriage tax penalty -- the additional income taxes some couples owe above what they would owe if they were single.
A Democratic alternative was then rejected, 55 to 43, on another party-line vote.
The Republican amendment would also allow self-employed taxpayers to deduct the full cost of their medical insurance premiums beginning with this year's taxes. Under the current tax law, the self-employed can deduct 45 percent of the cost of premiums, and the percentage will not reach 100 percent until 2007.
The tax relief seemed likely to win more Republican support for the underlying tobacco legislation. Many Republicans have argued that the anti-smoking bill is mainly a tax increase to finance a big-government solution to the problem of teen-age smoking that is bound to fail.
Some of the steam is taken out of the tax argument if, as tonight's amendment would require, one-third of all the revenue generated would be used to provide a tax cut.
Republicans argue that it is bad public policy to impose higher taxes on couples who marry than on those who live together out of wedlock. Party leaders have made elimination of the marriage penalty their No. 1 tax priority this year.
Last week, the House of Representatives approved a budget blueprint that would allot $100 billion to that end over the next five years.
The vote tonight, which followed hours of tense negotiations, was a big step in moving the tobacco bill to final passage by the Senate. That could occur as early as next week.
But serious obstacles remain, especially a serious dispute over whether the Government's price-support program for tobacco farmers should be abolished and how much money should be allotted to ease the financial burden on tobacco growers and communities whose economy depends on tobacco farming and cigarette manufacturing.
And many Republican senators continue to oppose the bill, even with the tax breaks approved tonight.
"The bill is still a tax-increase bill," said Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri.
The legislation, which seeks to reduce the number of young people who start to smoke, would raise the price of cigarettes by at least $1.10 a pack over the next five years, expand the Government's authority to regulate cigarette advertising and marketing and impose penalties on tobacco companies if teen-age smoking did not fall to specified levels.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the House was working on a much narrower anti-smoking bill. He called the measure before the Senate a "dead end."
The purpose of the tax break for couples, said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, the main sponsor of the amendment, was to "help working families shield more of their income."
The new break would not be limited to those who face a marriage penalty. More than half of taxpayers who file joint returns pay lower taxes than they would if they filed as individuals -- what some call a marriage bonus -- but even those with a bonus would be entitled to the new deduction under the amendment approved tonight.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that 25 million such couples receive a "marriage bonus," while 21 million incur a penalty.
As a general rule, the penalty applies when a husband and wife both work and earn approximately the same amount of money. Couples normally get a bonus if only one spouse works or if one earns much more than the other.
All the Democrats who voted favored killing the Gramm amendment, except for Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina. But they were joined by only five Republicans: Senators Susan Collins and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, Connie Mack of Florida and James M. Jeffords of Vermont.
The Democrats' alternative amendment, which failed tonight, would have given larger tax breaks than Mr. Gramm's plan to couples that faced a marriage penalty, but little if any tax relief to couples who now pay lower taxes because they are married.
"There's no rationale for rewarding those who get a bonus," said Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Senator Kent Conrad, a Democrat who is a former Tax Commissioner of North Dakota, said: "We ought to give those who actually experience the marriage penalty the help they really need to overcome it. It does not make sense to give the help to those who benefit from being married in the same way you help those who are being hurt."
Democrats also argued that the Gramm amendment would become so expensive in the second decade of the next century that it would eat into budget surpluses that should be set aside for Social Security benefits.
Senator Gramm said the Democratic plan would have had the effect of penalizing parents who stayed home to take care of children.
Mr. Gramm argued that the tobacco bill, by raising cigarette prices, would impose "a bone-crushing tax on moderate-income Americans." Under his proposal, Mr. Gramm said, "One-third of the money we are collecting in higher tobacco taxes would be given back to working families."
The White House said that President Clinton preferred the Democratic approach but could live with the Gramm amendment.
Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, said that reducing the marriage penalty had not been "a high priority for the Administration," but that President Clinton now supported efforts to cut taxes for some married couples as a way to secure passage of anti-smoking legislation.
The tobacco bill was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee in April on a strong bipartisan vote. But the cigarette makers abandoned the bill as too costly and mounted a nationwide advertising and lobbying campaign to defeat the bill.
For weeks, the bill was bogged down in the Senate. But on Tuesday, senators began to find ways to unclog the logjam. The Senate then attached to the tobacco bill several measures to combat drug abuse, an important Republican issue.

PUB-DATE: June 12, 1998

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 21; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2209 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
"ARTEMISIA," starring Valentina Cervi, Michel Serrault and Miki Manojlovic. Directed by Agnes Merlet (R, 96 minutes). With its painterly cinematography, this high-toned bodice-ripper about the early life and times of the Italian Baroque painter Artemisia Gentileschi, whom feminist art historians rescued from obscurity in the 1970's, is the movie equivalent of a Caravaggio exhibition. A sexy film, which narrowly avoided an NC-17 rating, it gives its title character a split personality. She is not only an early 17th-century Lolita with a big streak of voyeurism, but also a ruthlessly ambitious painting prodigy. The movie, which turns the story of her rape by her art teacher, Agostino Tassi, into a star-crossed love story, is very good at capturing the all-consuming intensity of a passionate student-teacher relationship (Stephen Holden). 

"DEEP IMPACT," starring Robert Duvall, Tea Leoni, Elijah Wood, Vanessa Redgrave, Maximilian Schell and Morgan Freeman. Directed by Mimi Leder (PG-13, 120 minutes). Apparently there is no better aid to family therapy than a murderously large meteor hurtling toward Earth. So this is a more sensitive sci-fi disaster film than most, with lovers bonding and old wounds healing as the summer's first colossal cinematic catastrophe looms. This thriller is vigorously made, but it provides less grisly mayhem than might be expected. As the planet faces extinction, attention is paid to rescuing art, antiques, elephants and flamingoes. Special-effects wizardry provides a suitably devastating tidal wave (Janet Maslin).
 
"FEAR AND LOATHING IN LAS VEGAS," starring Johnny Depp and Benicio Del Toro. Directed by Terry Gilliam (R, 120 minutes). Mr. Gilliam, the visually ingenious cinematic maestro behind "Brazil" and "12 Monkeys," has filmed Hunter S. Thompson's 1971 classic of gonzo journalism with an astonishing fidelity to the book's psychedelic phantasmagoria. But if this is as close to recreating the sensory world of an acid trip that a mainstream film has ever come, the movie packs the book's vignettes together into an overstuffed hodgepodge. Where the book conveyed a spirit of open-ended adventure in which each new caper could be spun out into its own little movie, the film rarely gives the book's appallingly funny anecdotes room to breathe. Mr. Depp, who has been made partially bald for the role of Raoul Duke, turns in a clever performance. And Mr. Del Toro's portrayal of Raoul's gun-waving sidekick and "attorney," Dr. Gonzo, is a tour de force of unfettered goonishness (Holden).
 
"GODZILLA," starring Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Hank Azaria and Maria Pitillo. Directed by Roland Emmerich (PG-13, 139 minutes). The ads for "Godzilla" proclaim that "size does matter." But it turns out that bigger doesn't necessarily mean better. The animatronic lizard that rises from the ocean and stomps on a number of New York City landmarks has thundering metallic footsteps but still has the impact of a weightless cartoon monster. The movie doesn't get scary until halfway through, when the beast's eggs hatch (in what's left of Madison Square Garden) and an army of more lifelike baby Godzillas threatens to devour the search party. The storytelling and acting in this $120 million wad of gummed-up popcorn reaches new depths of crudeness and ineptitude for a so-called Event Movie (Holden).
 
"HOPE FLOATS," starring Sandra Bullock, Harry Connick Jr. and Gena Rowlands. Directed by Forest Whitaker (PG-13, 112 minutes). This pajama-party women's picture starts out on a talk show and stays there, raising issues like divorce, single parenthood, mother-daughter relationships, caring for aging relatives and summoning the courage to date after trauma. But Ms. Bullock, who is actually seen cheerleading here, gives her best approximation of American's sweetheart since "While You Were Sleeping," and her winning performance helps make up for the film's cute streak and rosy, commercial glow. Ms. Rowlands does a feisty, down-to-earth turn as the star's Texas mama, even if the story gives her taxidermy for an offbeat hobby. As the post-divorce dreamboat, Mr. Connick is on the tepid side. "The Horse Whisperer" does this kind of serene, resuscitating romance much better (Maslin).
 
* "THE HORSE WHISPERER," starring Robert Redford, Kristin Scott Thomas and Scarlett Johansson. Directed by Robert Redford (PG-13, 164 minutes). There's a blunt soap opera of a movie inside Nicholas Evans's widely popular novel. But Mr. Redford, directing himself for the first time with intelligence and restraint, has found a visually eloquent way to turn it into something much more thoughtful and tranquil. Magnificently photographed by Robert Richardson, this film is a wide-screen love affair with the West, and a story more of peace and healing than of ardor. Though it's long and its resolution is a problem, this is an enveloping film that richly rewards the viewer's attention (Maslin).
 
"KURT AND COURTNEY," featuring Kurt Cobain and Courtney Love. Directed by Nick Broomfield (Not rated, 95 minutes). Mr. Broomfield's latest quizzical documentary has finally surfaced at the Cinema Village, despite various lawyers' best efforts to keep it under wraps. It is -- and is well worth -- a trip. As in his documentary about Heidi Fleiss, Mr. Broomfield burrows into the scuzz surrounding flamboyant public figures to explore a colorful, sordid demimonde, in this case mostly grunge parasites with Nirvana connections. So many interviewees here have grievances to settle or stories to sell that the James M. Cain echoes are stronger than they are in most film noir. And Ms. Love, by fighting and eluding Mr. Broomfield's dogged efforts, turns what might have been a loose, meandering film into "Courtney and Me" (Maslin).
 
* "THE LAST DAYS OF DISCO," starring Kate Beckinsale, Chloe Sevigny, Chris Eigeman and Robert Sean Leonard. Directed by Whit Stillman (R, 112 minutes). Mr. Stillman's smart, fretful, patrician characters turn up midway between "Metropolitan" and "Barcelona" in a film that charmingly mixes post-college career worries with improbable discomania. A delightful cast engages in nonstop flirtation and hair-splitting debate, rendered with Mr. Stillman's usual acuity and humor. Ms. Beckinsale, an English actress with a flawless American accent here and diffidence that's just as perfect, holds court beguilingly at the center of a bright and amusing crowd. The ideal film for anyone willing to entertain the notion that the spread of environmentalism was sparked by the revival of "Bambi" during the disco generation's formative years (Maslin).
 
"THE OBJECT OF MY AFFECTION," directed by Nicholas Hytner. Starring Jennifer Aniston, Paul Rudd, John Pankow and Allison Janney (R, 111 minutes). The latest Hollywood comedy to play house while playing with gender roles is easier to watch than believe. Ms. Aniston is energetic and adorable, too much so for a woman who knows exactly one heterosexual man (a comically unappetizing one) and falls in love with her gay roommate. Pregnant, she asks her charmingly reticent friend (Mr. Rudd) to help her raise the baby, and toothless complications ensue. Whatever the real-life issues raised by such a menage, this stylish but thin comedy isn't up to handling them. Adapted by Wendy Wasserstein from Stephen McCauley's breezy novel of star-crossed relationships, it features welcome worldliness from Nigel Hawthorne as the one wise, rueful figure in the story (Maslin).
 
* "THE OPPOSITE OF SEX," starring Christina Ricci, Martin Donovan, Lisa Kudrow and Lyle Lovett. Directed by Don Roos (R, 100 minutes). Wicked, foulmouthed and very funny, this gleefully acerbic comedy finds that Ms. Ricci has morphed enchantingly from nasty little Wednesday of "The Addams Family" into Lolita's evil twin. Voluptuous and scheming, her poisonous Dedee narrates this film and announces immediately that she won't be developing a heart of gold. Which is, of course, mostly a lie. The film brutally skewers preconceptions about gay and straight life, then lets its characters intermingle in sweetly unexpected ways. Mr. Donovan and Ms. Kudrow, as unlikely comrades brought together by Dedee's treachery, deliver the zingers from Mr. Roos's screenplay with deadpan panache (Maslin).
 
* "A PERFECT MURDER," starring Michael Douglas, Gwyneth Paltrow ad Viggo Mortensen. Directed by Andrew Davis (R, 107 minutes). The characters may be cardboard-thin in this film, a skillfully plotted update of Frederick Knott's play (and Alfred Hitchcock's film) "Dial M for Murder," but the nasty cat-and-mouse games they play are icily amusing. Mr. Douglas, looking more than ever like a wattled, riled-up rooster, is Steven Taylor, a shady Wall Street bond trader in deep financial trouble who hires his rich wife's handsome lover (Viggo Mortensen), a con man posing as a painter, to murder her. It's as easy as he hopes. Ms. Paltrow, looking chic and twinkly, is the wife, Emily, a translator at the United Nations, who has her own agenda. The story takes enough surprising twists to keep you engrossed, and the high-style ambiance (especially the Taylors' Fifth Avenue apartment) is mouthwatering (Holden).
 
"QUEST FOR CAMELOT," with the voices of Jessalyn Gilsig, Andrea Carr, Cary Elwes, Bryan White, Gary Oldman, Eric Idle and Don Rickles. Directed by Frederik Du Chau (G, 100 minutes). Warner Brothers' shaky entrance into the Disney-dominated sweepstakes of the musicalized animated feature wants to be a juvenile feminist "Lion King" with a musical heart that fuses "Riverdance" with formulaic Hollywood gush. But its characters are too wishy-washy and visually unfocused to be compelling, and the songs (by David Foster and Carole Bayer Sager) so forgettable as to be extraneous. In this variation on the Arthurian legend, a nondescript Celtic farm girl named Kayley with aspirations to be a knight wrests the magic sword Excalibur from the evil would-be emperor Ruber (a Hulk Hogan look-alike) and saves the kingdom (Holden).
 
* "THE SPANISH PRISONER," starring Campbell Scott, Rebecca Pidgeon, Ben Gazzara and Steve Martin. Written and directed by David Mamet (PG, 112 minutes). The most engaging of Mr. Mamet's cinematic puzzles begins with an X-ray at an airport security check. And the audience will wish it had a similar device for reading the characters' sneaky minds. No such luck: the mystery here, in a handsome and Hitchcockian film named for an elaborate con game, stays tricky to the very end. Mr. Scott plays the inventor of a lucrative, stealable scientific process, with Mr. Gazzara as the boss who's in no hurry to compensate him for it. In an ensemble cast working entirely on the calculating Mamet wavelength, Mr. Martin plays a rich, debonair mystery man who tells the inventor all about his pretty young sister. In her performance as a pert, unaccountably off-kilter secretary, Ms. Pidgeon perfectly embodies the film's sleight of hand (Maslin).
 
* "THE TRUMAN SHOW," starring Jim Carrey, Laura Linney and Ed Harris. Directed by Peter Weir and written by Andrew Niccol (PG, 104 minutes). The ultimate in high-concept ingenuity. Hosannas and cartwheels for this ingenious media-age fantasy are over the top, but by comparison with Hollywood's usual notion of summer movie fare, it's definitely a dazzler. Jim Carrey, refreshingly free of shtick, gives an instantly iconic performance as a guinea pig for an entertainment-happy nation, a man whose whole life is a fraud contrived by Mr. Harris's so-called "televisionary." Mr. Carrey's innate edge of volatility gives the material, from a screenplay of transfixing sci-fi intensity, its trace of danger. Ms. Linney, as the actress playing a wife whose bluff could be called at any moment, is the story's spookiest character as well as its perkiest. Mr. Weir unifies the story's many nuances with great finesse (Maslin)
 
Film Series
 
"COMDEN AND GREEN." He was an unemployed actor from the Bronx. She was a New York University theater major from Brooklyn. Their names were Adolph Green and Betty Comden, and their collaboration, which began six decades ago, led to films like "Singin' in the Rain," "On the Town," "The Barkleys of Broadway," "Auntie Mame" and "The Band Wagon." Beginning today, as part of its yearlong "N.Y.C. 100" celebration, the Film Forum is presenting a two-week festival of musicals written by the team of Comden and Green, plus some of their favorite films, presented on Mondays. The festival's opening attraction, through Sunday, is a double feature of Vincente Minnelli's "Bells Are Ringing" (1960), including a five-minute number cut from the original release, and Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen's "It's Always Fair Weather" (1955). The series continues through June 25 at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, the South Village. Screening schedule and information: (212) 727-8110.
