HEADLINE: Reluctant Threat: West's Kosovo Policy Hinges on the Use of Force

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The United States and its allies remain reluctant to use force against the Yugoslav Army, despite NATO's decision on Thursday to put on a display of air power in countries bordering the Serbian province of Kosovo, officials of the United States and other NATO member-nations said today.
But Western policy, as it is being formulated on the run, hinges on the credible threat of force in order to prompt a negotiated solution between the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo, who make up 90 percent of the Serb province. 
 In any case, Clinton Administration and NATO officials do not expect quick Russian approval for a Security Council resolution authorizing any use of force. The Serbs are traditional allies of Moscow, and Kosovo is, after all, an internationally recognized part of Yugoslavia.
But these officials say they are counting on President Boris N. Yeltsin to help persuade Mr. Milosevic, when they meet on Tuesday, to halt the violence against ethnic Albanians and to start negotiating seriously with their representatives.
If Mr. Milosevic ends up embarrassing the Russians by rebuffing Moscow's requests, senior American and NATO-country officials say, Moscow may be more willing to support a decision to authorize NATO to use force in or over Kosovo.
Prompted by Britain, the allies have done much this week to make the threat of force a credible one. NATO has agreed to displays of air power in countries like Albania and Macedonia, and to accelerated planning for a possible use of force in Kosovo, against a backdrop of tough talk today when Western foreign ministers met in London.
Officials are hopeful that the threat of force will be sufficient to deter Mr. Milosevic from continuing his military operations in Kosovo, where about 250 people have been killed, about 10,000 have become refugees and 60,000 or more have been displaced from their homes.
Mr. Milosevic argues that he is using his forces to put down an insurrection by the Kosovo Liberation Army, which is fighting for independence -- much as Moscow tried to put down insurrectionists in Chechnya without NATO's interference.
But the officials emphasize that force, no matter who wields it, will not bring a solution to the Kosovo problem. Only negotiations can do that, they say. And there is a growing consensus that Washington and NATO must press both the Serbs and ethnic Albanians to negotiate -- and to negotiate for an end neither side currently accepts.
The Kosovo Albanian leader Washington favors, Ibrahim Rugova, who favors negotiations for independence, is rapidly losing popular support to the Kosovo Liberation Army, Western intelligence officials say, and few ethnic Albanians favor talks with the Serbs. That suggests that if negotiations with Mr. Milosevic are to work, a representative of the K.L.A. must be involved.
"The problem right now is that you're negotiating with someone, Rugova, who can't deliver the people who have to be delivered to to make a settlement stick," a senior Western official said.
At the same time, the official conceded, little is known about the leadership and structure of the K.L.A. "We need to do a lot more work to figure out who and how" the K.L.A. is represented in any negotiations, he said, given that Mr. Milosevic may be unwilling to meet directly with a K.L.A. representative.
"We need to get a political process going to which both sides are genuinely committed, and right now we don't have that," the official said. Nor is the West acting with a firm agreement on what the outcome should be.
Washington and its allies favor enhanced autonomy for Kosovo within a federal Yugoslavia. But the ethnic Albanians, regardless of whether they favor the approach chosen by Mr. Rugova or the K.L.A., want independence and say a return to the status quo is impossible.
Mr. Milosevic, who took away Kosovo's autonomous status within Serbia in 1989, shows little sign of willingness to grant Kosovo much more than a return to the way things were.
Western officials acknowledge that any settlement must contain protections for Kosovo's Serbs and for the Serbian monasteries, cultural centers and historical sites that are central to the Serbs' self-image and ideology.
Some officials compare Kosovo to Northern Ireland, in the sense that an armed group is fighting for independence and that peace requires that it accept more realistic goals short of that aspiration. But Kosovo and the K.L.A. seem to lack a figure like Gerry Adams, the head of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, who can articulate a set of compromises to the men with the guns.
With divisions about how deep to get involved in Kosovo, Washington has been willing to be driven by the British and Germans toward a more confrontational policy toward Mr. Milosevic, including the imposition of economic sanctions. Still, American officials say they and NATO have been deeply involved with Kosovo policy in the first three months of this crisis, a marked contrast to Bosnia, where Washington kept its distance for nearly four years.
A senior official said, "at least we have the start of a policy." Serious negotiations can begin with stabilizing security in Kosovo and ending the violence, he added. "Then we can talk about political and constitutional arrangements. But there's going to be no quick fix in Kosovo."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXTENDS AN OIL DRILLING BAN ALONG COASTLINES

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif., June 12

 BODY:
Navigating a middle course between environmental advocates and oil companies, President Clinton announced today a 10-year extension of the moratorium on oil drilling off virtually all United States ocean coastlines.
Mr. Clinton also placed several marine sanctuaries off-limits to oil exploration, setting no expiration date. The areas include the Channel Islands and Monterey Bay sanctuaries in California, the Florida Keys, Gray's Reef in Georgia and the Olympic Coast sanctuary off Washington State. 
 The moratorium does not, however, affect areas off the Texas and Louisiana coasts, where extensive drilling has been going on for years, nor does it protect any areas, including the coastline of the southeastern United States, not already covered by the drilling ban first imposed by President George Bush in 1990.
Mr. Clinton, calling the oceans "the world's last great frontier," also signed an executive order today to expand programs to preserve and restore coral reefs in United States waters. He proposed new spending of $6 million to restore 18 damaged reefs in Florida, the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam and Hawaii.
Speaking against the sparkling backdrop of Monterey Bay, the nation's largest marine sanctuary, the President said offshore oil activity threatened fish populations and fragile coastal ecosystems.
Although there have been relatively few drilling-related oil spills in American waters, Mr. Clinton said, "Even under the best of circumstances, is it really worth the risk?"
With worldwide oil supplies plentiful and domestic gasoline prices at near-record lows, extending the moratorium carries little political risk for the President.
The oil industry, always interested in finding new petroleum sources, said the President's decision to ban further offshore exploration worsened the nation's dependence on imported oil.
The ban, issued under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, covers virtually all of the coasts of the North Atlantic, California, Washington, Oregon, southwest Florida, New England, the Mid-Atlantic and the North Aleutian Basin of Alaska, according to the White House.
Drilling in these waters is banned through 2002; the President's action extends that period to 2012.
Environmental groups would have preferred a permanent ban on all drilling but gave Mr. Clinton credit for using his executive authority to halt the activity for 10 more years.
"The President's commitment is impressive and heartening," Mark Massara, director of coastal programs for the Sierra Club, said in an interview today, "but it doesn't go far enough."
Because Mr. Clinton used an executive order to extend the ban, the action can be rescinded by a future President or revoked in a national oil emergency.
"We need legislation from Congress to insure permanent protection," Mr. Massara said.
Todd Steiner of the Earth Island Institute was less generous in his assessment, calling Mr. Clinton's action "a drop in the ocean."
"He's giving us what we already had, a moratorium on drilling," Mr. Steiner added. "It's a politically popular thing to do, but it doesn't really take us anywhere."
The American Petroleum Institute, the industry's largest trade group, reacted more bitterly.
"The moratoria's extension is unfortunate," Chris Kelley, an institute spokesman, said, "because it ignores the near-perfect performance of the American petroleum industry in operating offshore in a safe and environmentally sensitive manner."
"This regrettable decision, which is not in the long-term interests of American consumers, is particularly bad policy at a time of record U.S. energy imports," Mr. Kelley continued, reading a prepared statement. "Ultimately, the extension means a smaller future supply of domestically produced oil and natural gas and a lost opportunity to create American jobs."
Katie McGinty, chairwoman of the White House Council on Economic Quality, said that criticism from environmental groups and the industry was a sign that the President had found a workable compromise.
"The President has charted the most prudent course here," Ms. McGinty said.
Mr. Clinton also used his appearance here, at the first National Oceans Conference, to announce other proposals, including an $800 million fund to repair and expand the nation's seaports and, to help sustain swordfish stocks, a ban on the sale and import of Atlantic swordfish weighing less than 33 pounds.
He also announced the Administration's intention to build two deep-sea observatories and to develop two high-technology undersea probes to explore exotic sea life.
"We propose to provide new submersibles and other advanced tools for mapping and exploring the world's last great frontier," Mr. Clinton said as a sailboat drifted across the bay behind him. "I'd kind of like to go down there myself some day."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Korean Stocks Tumble 8.1% In Recond One-Day Plunge

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12

 BODY:
Investors stampeded out of the Korean stock market today, sending it back to the 11-year lows hit last month when worries about the pace of economic changes and labor unrest hurt share prices.
This time, fears that the Japanese yen's free fall would put pressure on China to devalue its currency, the yuan, unnerved both foreign and local owners of Korean stocks. 
 The key market index fell 8.1 percent, to 302.09, the largest plunge on record. The closing figure was the lowest since January 1987. In an abbreviated trading session Saturday morning, the index rose 1.5 percent to 306.66.
Many investors pulled their money out of the market on rumors that Tiger Management L.L.C, a New York investment fund headed by the well-known manager Julian Robertson, had sold large quantities of South Korean shares. Mr. Robertson has built up his fund's holdings in companies like SK Telecom, South Korea's largest mobile-phone company, and he has led a group of foreign investors pushing for greater shareholder rights in the country. Those efforts had given local investors greater confidence.
But those investors apparently ignored Mr. Robertson's other recent statements that the problems of several Asian countries are not yet close to being resolved. In fact, Tiger Management has been selling some, but not all, of its South Korean holdings recently, including today, according to a financial-industry executive.
In the United States, Fraser Seitel, a spokesman for Tiger Management, declined to comment on the firm's trading activities or positions.
The overriding force driving down the market was the yen's inability to regain its footing against the dollar after remarks Thursday by Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, that were interpreted by currency traders as a signal Japan would get no help defending the yen.
"The major concern is no longer restructuring but currency," said Yoon Doo Young, chief strategist at Daewoo Securities in Seoul. "The yen has been depreciating far more rapidly than the market anticipated recently, and that gives China more reason to consider devaluation."
A weaker yen and a weaker yuan make Japanese and Chinese exports cheaper and increase competition over the long run for the exports of other Asian countries like South Korea, particularly since the Korean currency, the won, has remained relatively stable.
But Stephen E. Marvin, head of research at Jardine Fleming in Seoul, said there was little reason for the won to fall. He pointed to $35 billion held in reserve at the Bank of Korea, evidence of the country's comeback from severe indebtedness late last year.
Mr. Marvin also said concerns over the effects of the falling yen were premature because it took considerable time for currency fluctuations to have an impact.
Moreover, Mr. Marvin said, while South Korea and Japan sell many of the same products, they often cater to different segments of the same market. Korean computer-chip manufacturers, for instance, largely make basic chips, while the Japanese have branched into specialized memory chips and the like.
Additionally, according to Japan's Ministry of Trade and Industry, only 35 percent of Japan's exports are denominated in yen, and most of those products go to Asia. The rest are largely denominated in dollars, German marks and British pounds and, thus, their prices are not adjusted unless the yen moves substantially and over a long period of time.
By some measures, however, the yen's weakness means some South Korean industries are verging on losing their edge against Japanese competitors, if they have not already done so.
Korean steel companies lose their currency competitiveness against Japanese steelmakers when the yen weakens to 9.5 won, and South Korean electronics makers lose their currency edge when the yen weakens to 10.5 won. The yen fell as low as 9 won today.
"We are having a very hard time," Mr. Yoon of Daewoo Securities said.

HEADLINE: Manhattan Hotel Rates Head for the Sky

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Looking for a hotel room in Manhattan? You have plenty of options.
You could book weeks in advance and pay $300 or so a night for a room at a modern midtown high-rise like the Crowne Plaza. If you're willing to pay a bit more -- say, $500 a night on average -- you could probably get something with less of a hassle at the Four Seasons or the Pierre. Or you could do what a growing number of visitors are forced to do: stay in New Jersey. 
 The hotel market in Manhattan, the most expensive in the nation and fresh off a record year in 1997, continued to tighten in this year's first quarter, compared with the first three months of last year, with the average cost of a night's stay creeping closer to $200.
"This is the highest first-quarter average daily rate in Manhattan's history," said Dexter Wood, a hotel consultant with Coopers & Lybrand.
The market has become so expensive that in the last 18 months, five hotels -- the Lowell, the St. Regis and the Carlyle, as well as the Pierre and the Four Seasons -- began charging an average rate of $500 on and off, with some suites running into four figures. No other city in the nation has even a single hotel with an average rate so high, industry experts said.
And even as prices rise, it is still difficult to find a room in New York unless it is booked far in advance. That fact has forced some visitors to stay in New Jersey or not come to the city at all.
"We cannot find a decent hotel room anywhere on Manhattan, it seems, for less than a fortune," said Alan Bennett of Sydney, Australia, who was planning to come to the city in August. "We have searched database after database and rung hotel chains' reservations centers, all to no avail.
"It has got to the stage where we are about to scrap our plans to go to New York and instead split our four or five days there between an extra day or two in Washington and Boston."
Those who do find a room are often in for a surprise.
"Three hundred bucks!" said Susan Jeans of Bayport, Minn., who booked her room at the Crowne Plaza in mid-Manhattan two weeks in advance. "We were expecting like $200."
The average price of a room in Manhattan rose to $189.70 for the first quarter of the year, according to preliminary figures from the Coopers & Lybrand Lodging Research Network. That is a 13.9 percent leap over the $166.58 average room price for the first quarter of 1997 and a smaller jump over the $187.91 rate for all of 1997. By the end of the year, Coopers & Lybrand expects average room rates to rise an additional 10 to 12 percent, surpassing $200, a figure reached briefly for the first time last fall and Christmas, the busiest months of the year for many New York hotels.
Occupancy rates are nearing records, too. For the first three months of the year, which are among the slowest for the industry in New York, hotels were 80.5 percent filled, according to Coopers & Lybrand. That's an increase of 5.4 percent over the first quarter of 1997, and only slightly down from 82 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997, which was the highest since 1979.
"Demand is unprecedented here," said Steven Pipes, general manager of Le Parker Meridien, a hotel in mid-Manhattan. "People wanting a room in the fall, if they don't starting making reservations now, in the early summertime, they will be missing out."
John A. Fox, a senior vice president with PKF Consulting, a hotel and real estate consulting company in Manhattan, said that business was good for many reasons: the strong local and national economies; a continuing shortage of rooms; the city's improved image, and a cheap dollar in many parts of the world, which makes it affordable for foreign tourists to come to the city and expensive for Americans to travel abroad. "The market has been on a steady upward climb since 1992," Mr. Fox said.
The city's decision in 1994 to cut its hotel tax to 15 percent from 21 percent, along with the state's elimination of its 5 percent hotel tax, may have had some impact as well. "When taxes are cut, demand usually rises," said Adam Brachet, a spokesman for Coopers & Lybrand. "It's not the whole potato, but it's part of it.
Bjorn R. Hanson, chairman of Coopers & Lybrand's hotel and casino division, said, "It's a hotelier's dream, rates rising at three to four times inflation."
As a result, 11 hotels are under construction now and 28 more are planned or proposed in Manhattan. It would mean more than 11,593 rooms and a slight increase in hotel jobs. According to the state's Department of Labor, hotel employment in New York City rose by 700 jobs, to 36,200, in April from a year earlier.
Mr. Hanson also said that hotels were curtailing discounts and weekend packages because the markets were so strong. "Everything is priced at a premium," he said. "And we are also finding that guests are spending more money in the hotels."
The city's hotel space squeeze has sent many corporate travel managers scrambling. J.P. Morgan & Company now often books people into the relatively spartan Club Quarters hotel in downtown Manhattan, which lacks amenities like in-room faxes and room service.
And with the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau projecting 32.5 million out-of-towners coming to the city this year, including 5.9 million from abroad, many business travelers and tourists may find that accommodations in New Jersey are their only affordable or available alternative. But even there, the overflow from Manhattan is making it difficult to find a room.
Elizabeth Eismeier, the treasurer of Colgate University, could not get a room two weeks ago. "We tried a dozen or more hotels, plus a travel agent, plus the Williams Club," she said. "Friends checked the Cornell Club and the Yale Club -- no soap.
"So, the agent suggested the Marriott at Newark Airport. "It was just fine. It made me want to see if any of our real estate investment managers were investing in hotel development in New York City. Seems like the city needs that."
The visitors bureau advises people trying to find a room to call the Peak Season Hotel Hot Line at (800) 846-7666, which makes reservations for more than 80 hotels in various price ranges and can give availability information. A person really stuck, the bureau says, should try contacting hotels after 6 P.M. to check on reservations the hotels have canceled that have not been guaranteed with a credit card.
Even with all the new hotels going up, it is probable, according to Coopers & Lybrand, that only 4,000 to 5,000 of the approximately 12,000 rooms that are planned will be built; there are now about 54,600 rooms in Manhattan and 6,000 in the rest of the city.
"It's a drop in the bucket," said Mr. Fox of PKF Consulting.
Jeff Weinstein, editor in chief of Hotels magazine, said, however, that if the economy slipped, demand could fall -- just as additional rooms were being made available.
"And it won't be problematic for just the new hotels -- all hotels will suffer," he said. "Anytime the economy suffers, the hotel industry suffers."

HEADLINE: City's Plans for Governors I. Include Housing and Casino

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration plans to release two reports next week sketching out redevelopment proposals for Governors Island, including housing, schools, parks, a new hotel -- and a casino that would provide millions of dollars to finance the plan.
The reports come as civic groups, preservationists and others have sharply criticized the city and state for failing to move quickly to develop the historic island in New York Harbor. They worry that officials are squandering President Clinton's offer to give the federally owned island to New York City, provided the city and state come up with an acceptable public purpose for the site. 
 Governors Island, a 172-acre military installation for 300 years, was closed last year and is now virtually a ghost town. Its last inhabitants, the Coast Guard, left the island in pristine shape, but preservationists worry that the historic buildings could quickly slide into decrepitude. At the same time, park and playground proponents hunger for the island's recreational potential, and New York University and Columbia are looking at it as a possible home for classrooms and students.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has suggested several times that casino gambling could provide a windfall to finance other desirable development on the island, as well to preserve such historic treasures as Castle William, one of two forts that long guarded the harbor. But that plan has run into criticism from preservationists and some politicians, who have argued that a casino is an inappropriate use for the site and politically unrealistic as well.
The reports by independent consultants that the city will release next week will outline the economic pluses and minuses of various developments, as well as suggest changes to the buildings needed to achieve them, Deputy Mayor Randy Levine said yesterday.
The state, which has not taken a position on the island, said it would follow the city's lead. "We're looking forward to seeing what they come up with," said Michael F. McKeon, press secretary to Gov. George E. Pataki.
Concerned that the island's fate remains in limbo, the National Trust for Historic Preservation plans to include the site in its new list of the nation's 11 most endangered historic places, officials of the organization said. The designation, to be announced on Monday, will group Governors Island with such imperiled treasures as a Civil War battlefield in Virginia and an Art Deco hotel in Nevada.
Richard Moe, the trust's president, said he was worried that the empty buildings could deteriorate quickly. "Governors Island could be on a slippery slope to serious deterioration," he said.
Mr. Moe urged the Governor and the Mayor to appoint a commission to quickly come up with alternatives, before the opportunity to preserve the island is lost. Mr. Levine said the reports would answer this request.
The trust president compared Governors Island with the south side of Ellis Island, which, unlike the north side, has not been restored. Last year, the trust put Ellis Island on its list of most endangered places, an action it believes helped secure a $6 million Congressional appropriation to stabilize the buildings on the south side.
If New York does not take over the island by 2002, Federal law requires that it be auctioned for a price Congress has estimated at $500 million.
Financing is critical to any redevelopment plan. The Urban Land Institute, a Washington organization of real estate professionals, issued a report last year saying any development on Governors Island would probably need an initial infusion of capital to jump-start it. Mayor Giuliani has several times suggested that casino development may be a way to get this investment.
But that idea worries many of the groups most interested in the island's development. "We can't find anyone who thinks a casino will work here," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society. He worries that a bridge from Brooklyn to the island might be necessary to transport the crowds needed to support a large casino.
"You certainly want public access, but you don't want thousands and thousands of people," he said.
A collection of civic groups plan to present a plan in September for a number of uses. Members cite political difficulties with gambling. Marcia Reiss, policy director for the Parks Council, pointed out that gambling would have to pass the Legislature twice and a statewide referendum once. "I don't see it passing in New York," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japanese Economy Weaker Than Believed, Data Show
Japan's economy, the world's second largest, sank at a stunning annual rate of 5.3 percent in the first quarter of this year, the Government said in an official report that painted an even bleaker picture than expected and confirmed that the nation is in a recession.
The report was released after Japan's battered stock market had closed for the day, but the yen kept falling, reaching another eight-year low against the dollar. Although the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 8.29 points, it finished the week with a loss of 301.1 points or nearly 2 percent, and is down 13 percent from its March 2 high. Page A1. 

Korean Stocks Plunge 8.1 Percent
Korean stocks tumbled, returning to the 11-year lows they reached last month. The latest drop comes amid worries about the trade effects of the steep declines in the values of Asian nations' currencies. The key market index fell 8.1 percent, to 302.09 -- the lowest since January 1987. D3.
 
Producer Prices Rose 0.2% in May
Prices paid to producers rose rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May -- the same increase as in April -- largely because of a sharp gain in the cost of prescription drugs. Analysts saw no sign of a pickup in inflation in the data. Another economic report pointed to a slowdown. Business inventories of unsold goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent in April -- the slowest gain in three months. D14.
 
Goldman, Sachs Partners Meet
The 190 partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company met to consider a proposal to turn the firm, Wall Street's last major private partnership, into a public company. A Goldman spokesman said the firm would probably announce tomorrow whether or not the partners backed the plan to go public. D3.
 
Seagram Files for Tropicana Sale
Seagram expects to raise as much as $3.6 billion when it sells its Tropicana juice business in an initial public offering, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Seagram disclosed plans for an I.P.O. on May 21, when it agreed to acquire Polygram, the music giant, for $10.6 billion in cash and stock. D3.
 
Oil Drilling Moratorium Is Extended
President Clinton announced a 10-year extension of the moratorium on oil drilling off virtually all American ocean coastlines. The moratorium does not affect areas off the Texas and Louisiana coasts, where extensive drilling has been going on for years. A1.
 
Big Stake in British Cable Unit Sold
BCE, the Canadian telecommunications company, sold its 14.25 percent stake in Cable and Wireless Communications for 975.2 million ($1.59 billion), in a move to exit the British cable television industry. D3.
 
VW Unit to Buy Lamborghini
A week after Volkswagen won its bid to acquire Rolls-Royce, the German car maker is adding another storied name to its garage: The company's Audi unit has agreed to buy Lamborghini S.p.A., the Italian sports car maker. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts estimated Lamborghini's worth at $111 million. D2.
 
F.C.C. Scales Back Internet Plan
Under pressure from lawmakers who argued that the program would increase long-distance telephone rates, the Federal Communications Commission decided to reduce by more than 40 percent the budget of a plan to connect schools and libraries to the Internet. Long-distance carriers are required to provide most of the money for the program. Under the revised plan, $1.275 billion will be raised this year, down from an original maximum of $2.25 billion. A8.
 
New Global Initiative on Child Labor
The Clinton Administration is supporting a proposed treaty to outlaw the most exploitive forms of child labor. The new International Labor Organization initiative comes 25 years after the body first tried to curb such abuses. The new convention focuses on such extreme forms of child labor as working in mines and prostitution. A5.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
NATO and Russia Set Deadline for Yugoslavia
The United States, Russia and six other major industrial nations that are meeting in London gave President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia until Tuesday to call off Serbian attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. A1 

The United States and its allies are reluctant to use force against the Yugoslav Army, despite NATO's decision to put on a display of air power in countries bordering Kosovo province, officials of the United States and other NATO countries said. A5
 
Democracy Protest in Nigeria
Hundreds of Nigerians demanding democracy confronted a powerful deployment of the police and soldiers at a marketplace in Lagos, in the first showdown with Nigeria's new military leadership. Security forces responded with tear gas and shots in the air, witnesses said. A3
 
Pakistan Rejects Indian Offer
An Indian proposal for talks to lessen tensions on the subcontinent was quickly rejected by Pakistan, but the offer nonetheless appeared to move both Governments closer to direct negotiations over the crisis set off by recent nuclear tests. The United States and seven other industrialized nations said they would act to postpone loans to both countries. A4
 
Toll in India Cyclone Rises

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Up 23.17 As Late Rally Salvages Prices

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market continued to cascade yesterday, falling sharply for the fourth consecutive session on renewed concerns about Asia's economic woes, before a rally late in the day pushed prices higher.
Heightened fears about another round of economic and financial turmoil in Asia have roiled stock markets around the world this week, but yesterday investors finished off a bad spell by buying back into the market in the last hour of trading. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which had fallen as much as 128 points early in the day, ended up 23.17 points, closing at 8,834.94. For the week, though, the Dow lost 202.77 points, or 2.2 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a broader measure, rose 4.26 , to 1,098.84. But the Nasdaq composite index, which is packed with technology issues, fell for the third session, down 4.70, to 1,745.05.
Bond prices, meanwhile, dipped a day after a sharp rise pushed long-term interest rates to their lowest level in about 30 years. Yesterday, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.66 from 5.65 a day earlier.
Although the economy appears remarkably sound, with hefty growth and low inflation, Wall Street analysts said the recent global selloff was once again raising the specter of troubles ahead. Even while yesterday's market eked out a gain, the trend has been unnervingly bearish. "The market's going through this classic Asia crisis meltdown drill," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "There's a fear that Japan and Asia are out of control."
Since mid-April, stock prices have been choppy and largely depressed, unable to gain much ground after a sharp run-up early in the year. Slowing growth in profits and a widespread belief that share prices have grown too expensive are said to be contributing to the weakness. But as Mr. Roach said, now, much like last October, there are reverberations from Asia.
The problem is that economies throughout Asia and the Pacific region are floundering, creating fears that the economic crisis could eventually disrupt the United States economy, which Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Wednesday was as "impressive" as any economy he had seen in his nearly 50 years of close observation.
The crisis in Asia is particularly acute in Japan, which has been sputtering for much of the decade. Yesterday, more bad news came when the Government said the Japanese economy contracted at a 5.3 percent annualized rate in the first quarter, confirming reports that the economy has fallen into a recession.
That downturn has drastically weakened the Japanese yen against the dollar, and economists fear a sliding yen might cause other Asian currencies to plunge, creating a ripple effect that could reduce demand for American products in Asia and cut into corporate earnings, which are already weakening.
Energy and technology stocks have been particularly hard hit in recent months. Oil stocks have fallen sharply with oil prices, and technology issues have slid because of falling earnings estimates partly because of Asia's impact on the industry.
Indeed, in early trading yesterday, the Nasdaq fell a full 10 percent below its all-time high of 1,917.61, a drop that constituted a benchmark "correction" in Wall Street parlance. But analysts said heavy computerized buying programs in the last hour of trading lifted blue-chip issues and even some technology shares.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks, which have long trailed the bigger issues, also fell yesterday, dropping 10 percent below its all-time high and leaving the index virtually flat on the year.
Gail Dudack, the chief investment officer at UBS Securities, said that the continuing crisis in Asia simply exacerbated fears about slowing profit growth in the United States.
"Wages are growing so much faster than pricing," she said. "The big risk is that profits are plateauing. What Asia means is that top-line growth will be hurt; we won't be able to sell them anything, and they'll compete with our products on price."
But Mr. Roach said fears that the yen's weakness would force China to devalue -- setting off a broader competitive round of devaluations -- was overblown. China and Japan do not compete directly in the export market, he said, and the Chinese economy remains strong and will probably be able to withstand the yen's turbulence.
"A lot of people are reacting as if Japan is unexpectedly imploding," he said. "Japan has long abdicated its role as a leader of Asia and an engine of global growth. And even if the Asian crisis continues, I think the global economy will be O.K."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1465 words

HEADLINE: JAPAN'S ECONOMY APPEARS BLEAKER

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12

 BODY:
The world's second-largest economy sank at a stunning annual rate of 5.3 percent in the first quarter of this year, according to official figures released today that painted an even bleaker picture than many economists had expected.
While Japan's economy has been troubled for years, the latest, official numbers confirmed that economic output had declined for two consecutive quarters -- the definition generally accepted by economists for a recession. The numbers mean that for the first time since the oil shock of 1974, the economy declined for a full year -- falling by an annual rate of seven-tenths of a percent for the fiscal year ended March 31. It was Japan's worst postwar economic performance. 
 Concern about Japan's economic problems have been sending shock waves through Asia, weakening the yen and heightening fears that the crisis could spread from Asia to the United States and Europe.
Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, characterized the data as "worse than expected" and reiterated his view that Japan must fundamentally change its financial structure and vigorously stimulate its economy, which is contributing to slumps in Asia, Russia and Eastern Europe.
"The center of the problem is in Japan, and it's a very serious problem for the world," Mr. Rubin said during an appearance in Mobile, Ala.
Japan's troubles are partly the legacy of its speculative economic bubble of the late 1980's, which resulted in $600 billion in bad loans that still hang over its banking system. Many economists say a recovery has been hobbled by a tax increase last year, excessive regulations and a consumer reluctance to spend. Although an enormous package of tax cuts and other stimulus measures is expected to help later this year, economists say the effects may be only temporary.
Japanese officials took care to release today's news after the stock market had closed for the day. Earlier, driven largely by the declining yen, South Korea's stock market fell by a record 8.1 percent, while the Nikkei 225 benchmark index dipped below 15,000 in the morning, before closing at 15,022.33, up 8.29 points. Most other Asian stock markets and currencies ended sharply lower.
A weaker yen makes Japanese products cheaper and more competitive, which could further damage the economies of Japan's neighbors and cause a relentless spiral of currency devaluations. That could destabilize financial markets around the world.
The impact on the United States thus far has been mixed, with consumers benefiting from cheaper imports and lower interest rates made possible, in part, by the slowdown in Asia. But United States corporate profits have declined recently, partly because of the weakness in Asian markets. There is fear as well that continued financial decline in Japan and East Asia could result in a panic that would spread to the United States and Europe.
Japanese officials again warned today that the yen was falling too far and too fast. By late today in New York it took 144.72 yen to buy a dollar, meaning the yen has fallen 3 percent this week alone. Since its peak in 1995, the currency has fallen nearly 45 percent against the dollar.
"I don't think it will cause a minus effect on the Japanese economy," Koji Omi, head of the Economic Planning Agency, said of the weak yen today, according to Kyodo News Service. But it poses problems, he added, "for the whole of the world economy."
Li Zhaoxing, China's Ambassador to the United States, called on the Group of Seven industrialized nations, which includes Japan, to take action to bolster the yen. "They know their situation; they know they have means available," Mr. Li said. "If there's a will, there's a way."
Some economists said Japan's economy may recover in the short term, partly because of the huge fiscal stimulus package. But others said Japan was teetering on the edge of a much greater tumble.
"Things could fall apart very quickly here and Japan could go like other countries in Asia -- completely fall apart, or it could linger on," said Brian H. Rose, an economist at LTCB Warburg Securities Ltd., a venture between Long-Term Credit Bank and the SBC Corporation.
Mr. Rose cautioned that Japan was now in the throes of an unpredictable transition to more of a market economy.
"Like Eastern Europe, if you introduce shock therapy and go from a nonmarket to a market, the short-term disruption is enormous," Mr. Rose said. He added, however, that once the transition was made, Japan could enjoy strong growth again.
Shimpei Nukaya, vice minister of the Economic Planning Agency, which released the economic numbers, said the negative impact on Japan's economy from the Asian economic crisis was bigger than the Government had expected and that the figures "underline the gloomy situation of the nation's real economy."
Sluggish for several years, Japan's economy fell into a recessionary spiral after a tax increase last year, imposed at a moment when the economy instead required a tax reduction, in the view of many economists. They have said that no adequate stimulus has yet been applied.
Sales are down at many medium-sized businesses, and mom-and-pop shops are particularly feeling the pinch.
"I have no customers, even at this hour," said Yasuhiko Sato, a 30-year-old vendor selling tuna fish at lunchtime. "I see shops closing down in this area. My bonus is very low. It's crazy."
Teikoku Databank, a private credit research agency, said today that the number of corporate failures in May rose 37.5 percent from a year ago, to 1,791. It was the highest total for the month of May since 1984.
For Hachiro Hattori, a 75-year-old vendor of wrapping materials, the solution is to put his pension income into his ailing business.
"My wife and I can survive if we buy only food," he said.
Today's announcement offered new data only for the January-to-March period, but since Japan's fiscal year ended on March 30 the new figures meant that over the course of the last fiscal year the nation's gross domestic product fell seven-tenths of a percent.
That was the first annualized decline in output since 1974, when the decline was five-tenths of a percent. If the numbers released today are not revised upward, the 1997 fiscal year would mark Japan's worst economic performance since World War II.
Exports for the first quarter also declined by 3.8 percent, the first drop in a dozen years, as troubled Asian economies drastically reduced imports from Japan.
There are no reliable figures to assess economic performance since then but there is scant evidence of improvement. Still, with parliamentary elections next month, the Government is trying desperately to cheer people up.
The elections will choose representatives to the Parliament's Upper House, which is less important than the Lower House. Still, the election is an important gauge of public sentiment, and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto wants to do well to help his own standing and his ability to retain office.
Today Mr. Hashimoto won an expected victory when the Lower House rejected a no-confidence motion against his Cabinet.
Officials point out that the Government's $111 billion stimulus package seems about to be approved by the Parliament, clearing the way for a rush of public funds into the economy. The governing Liberal Democratic Party is counting heavily on the public money to pick up growth.
But industrial production was down 6 percent in April from the year before, corporate profits have tumbled 25 percent from the previous year, prices are falling ominously, and some economists warn that Japan may be sinking into a deflationary spiral. Economists fear a vicious cycle in which falling prices and profits lead to rising unemployment, which would curb consumption and bring down prices further.
"It's a deflation, that's pretty clear," said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Capital spending for the first quarter fell 5.1 percent, the steepest decline since 1965. The Government also released figures today showing that Japanese manufacturers plan to reduce spending by 4.4 percent on plant and equipment in the current fiscal year, which began on April 1. The decline was the first in four years, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
"It's certainly hard to see a way out at this point," said Peter Morgan, an economist at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd.
Japanese Government officials have annoyed some analysts by seeming to play down the seriousness of the situation. They frequently had argued that the economy was simply "stagnant" or at a "standstill," refusing to acknowledge the decline. Indeed, many foreign-based economists have contended that Japan entered a recession many months ago.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.S. Endorses Treaty On Child Labor Abuses

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 12

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman gave the Clinton Administration's support this week to a proposed treaty to outlaw the most exploitative forms of child labor.
Secretary Herman said she hoped that a mechanism to be included in the treaty calling for follow-up reporting of abuses would encourage countries to abide by their pledges to end economic exploitation of children. 
 The new initiative, at the International Labor Organization, comes 25 years after the body first tried to curb such abuses. But nearly two-thirds of the I.L.O.'s 174 member nations, particularly developing countries, chose not to sign it. The United States itself did not sign.
That convention barred children under 15 from working, except in the poorest countries where the age was set at 13. And no child under 18 could work in heavy industry.
The new convention takes a more limited approach, focusing on such extreme forms of child labor as working in mines and prostitution. The proposal could be ready for nations to sign next year.
Surveys indicate that about 250 million children between the ages of 5 and 14 work worldwide.
Ms. Herman announced that the Administration planned to ask Congress for $30 million -- a large increase over the current $3 million contribution -- for the I.L.O.'s project to help countries cope with child-labor abuses. More than 20 countries have applied for help in eliminating dangerous child labor.

HEADLINE: Lives;
Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By David France; David France is writing a book on F.B.I. surveillance of gay- liberation groups.

 BODY:
Off and on for months, a bulldozer has been scratching around on the grassy lot down near the end of my block, rattling me out of bed before 7 A.M. I would resent it less if I knew why. Dirt has moved from one pile to another, with no discernible program.
The very fact that excavators have arrived in my remote neck of the East Village is testament to the fate of J.R. He was the block's shady patriarch, our enigmatic alpha-neighbor. Until he went "away," as we've learned to say here euphemistically, he protected us from noisy progress. 
 For two decades, J.R headed up a vibrant heroin bazaar on the stoop next to a dingy midblock Laundromat. Appropriately, he and his colleagues dubbed themselves "the Laundromat Crew," and stamped their heroin "Laundromat" too. It was so enduringly popular among college kids that it has been mythologized in literature and music.
The Crew members lived among us -- or we among them -- in a bemused coalition: Puerto Ricans and yuppies, poets and punks. But the teeming sidewalks always belonged to the Crew. The rest of us were greeted vociferously when we passed. But pass we must. If I stopped to tie a shoelace, a firm voice would goose me along: Keep walking, keep walking, guy. I put up with the second-class relegation for 15 years. We all did. As long as J.R. was in charge, we knew, his would be the only crimes here. That was our dirty compromise.
J.R.'s career was a fixation of mine nonetheless. He was the first person who greeted me on the hot afternoon in 1981 when I landed here. He was 26 then and had spent time in the military, his only experience off the block. At 22, I had just arrived from Kalamazoo, Mich. Here we were, both ebullient, with little money and enormous ambition, I thought.
He was less generous. "Great," J.R. spat as I tramped past him in the lobby that day, "another white fag on the block." Over the years, as J.R. went gray and I went bald, his tolerance for me blossomed. I doubt he ever learned my name. But he never threw brickbats again.
Meanwhile, his customers lined up 15 deep outside the Laundromat to crease tiny envelopes into their palms. Rooftop spotters transmitted warnings to the sellers down below using cries of Spanish code words like Feo and Bajando. On some nights, their canopy of cries could seem as mysterious and beautiful as a jungle aviary.
They were purportedly doing $50,000 a week in business, though I often wondered where the money went. J.R. cultivated a Spartan life. He didn't even own a car. I have since learned that he helped many people with rent or veterinary bills they couldn't otherwise afford. But such token charity can't consume $2.6 million a year.
The denouement, when it came two years ago, was a scene out of a dime-store novel. In seeming slow motion, an army of officers arrived just before 11 P.M. A helicopter whirred overhead, projecting a cone of light over the dingy coin-op, where Crew members were handcuffed in clumsy succession. Well after midnight, J.R., then 41, made a Billy Jack-like appearance. The cops cuffed him with a flourish, I'm told by witnesses. His doting mother, who swings an unbending leg when she walks, gripped his shirt sleeve and unleashed a surreal and memorable cry.
I was curious to read that J.R., whom the tabloids would dub "Little John Gotti," didn't spring for a fancy attorney, and instead of fighting the charges, had his lawyer negotiate a plea. He was sentenced last fall to a dozen years, his first-ever trip to jail. The rest of the Crew got stiff sentences, too.
News of their disposition fluttered down upon the block like black organza. And the earth-moving equipment followed. All winter long the speculation was wild about what the new construction might bring. A police station. AIDS housing. N.Y.U. dorms. Last month, the construction crew posted a permit for 85 apartments over six floors, but one of the foremen undermined the sign's authority. "It's 125 luxury units on seven floors," he was telling people.
As I stood over the muddy hole the other day, I marveled at how one gaping mystery has supplanted another. And then a tempting idea entered my mind: What if there's no building at all? What if, somewhere in that turbid crevice, J.R. has stashed his treasure? Could this wheezing and pounding be directed by him, to remove or replace or replenish the hoard?
Then another thought struck: Keep walking, keep walking, guy.
