SECTION: Section 11; Page 3; Column 3; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1409 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Scotch Plains, N.J.;
A Town That Harkens to Simpler Times

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
THE three-block downtown of this community, along Park Avenue and Front and East Second Streets, seems to reach back to simpler times. Its 75 businesses include half a dozen antiques stores, two hobby shops, gift shops, a model-train store, a comic-book store, two shoe-repair shops, a doll hospital and a silversmith. Nearly all are housed in small 19th-century structures.
On Park Avenue and Front Streets, at one end of the downtown, is the Stage House Inn, which has been the town anchor since 1737 when it became a tavern and a stop on the Swift-Sure Stage Line from New York to Philadelphia. Among its early patrons was the Marquis de Lafayette. 
 The building, the oldest section of which was constructed in 1682, is now a French restaurant and it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
"Our downtown is stressing smallness and quaintness," explained Raymond Pardon, who owns a nut store and is president of the Scotch Plains Business & Professional Association.
According to Mayor Joan Papen, the township government and the association are cooperating on a plan to enhance the business district. It includes building a fourth municipal parking lot to supplement the three lots along Park Avenue.
A gazebo, which will serve as a town bandstand, has just been completed on the town green near the Town Hall on Park Avenue and new signs have gone up encouraging visitors to the downtown to "enjoy the hometown feeling."
David F. Drake, the proprietor and chef at the Stage House Inn, said he felt the new development plans were missing the mark. He would like to see the Town Hall moved from Park Avenue to allow expansion of the business district.
"If you want the downtown to prosper," he said, "you have to increase foot traffic. That means you need more stores."
Settled in 1684 by Scottish immigrants, who dissented from the teachings of the Church of England, the area was originally named Scots Plain, after George Scot, the group leader.
The most significant historical event to take place in the township was the Battle of the Short Hills on June 26-27, 1777. The British Gen. William Howe, frustrated by the Continentals' guerrilla attacks on his troops, sought to lure George Washington's 8,000-man force out of the Watchung Mountains, which overlook Scotch Plains.
Howe moved his 12,000 troops from the New Brunswick area to Perth Amboy, feigning an evacuation to Staten Island. Rather than boarding ferries, the British and Hessian soldiers wheeled back toward Scotch Plains, only to be detected by Continental scouts. During the two days of fighting, the rebels suffered more than 200 dead or wounded and 64 captured. The British side lost about 70 soldiers and had 11 captured, but it was turned back.
There are about 100 historic structures in Scotch Plains, 35 of which are on the National Register of Historic Places, with 20 predating the Revolutionary War. There are also several homes with tunnels underneath, where runaway slaves were hidden before the Civil War. But most of the houses in Scotch Plains were built after 1930.
Detached homes make up about 75 percent of the town's 8,000 dwellings. They range in price from about $150,000 for a small prewar colonial or postwar Cape Cod near the business district, up to about $950,000 for some custom colonials on 1.5 or more acres in the southwestern section. Last year, one palatial, six-bedroom house with a five-car garage and five fireplaces in the southern section of town sold for $1.3 million.
Ruth Tate, a sales associate with the Coldwell Banker real estate agency in neighboring Westfield, said that lately she had been receiving multiple bids on houses just days after they hit the market.
AS evidence that Scotch Plains is in a seller's market, Mrs. Tate pointed out a four-bedroom colonial on Oxford Road that sold for $285,000 in 1993 and was resold in April 1998 for $345,000. Another home, a split level on Shawnee Path, went for $216,000 a year ago and is currently on the market for $259,900.
There are half a dozen condominium developments, with a total of about 600 units. The largest and most expensive is the 294-unit gated town-house condominium community of Southwyck Village in the southern section. Depending on location and condition, the units, all of which have three bedrooms, go for between $155,000 and $200,000, according to Mrs. Tate.
At the lower-priced end of the condominium scale are the two-bedroom apartments in the 28-unit King James Court on Front Street, which sell for between $130,000 and $150,000.
The township has just over 1,000 rental units in seven complexes. The largest is the 320-unit Lamberts Mill Village, where one-bedroom units rent for $920, two-bedrooms for $1,150 and three-bedrooms for $1,210.
Among the newer residents are Brian M. Greenberg, 28, and his wife, Sherry A., 29, who purchased a 30-year-old, five-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath split level on the southern side of town and moved in a year ago from Manhattan. Mrs. Greenberg is a clinical assistant professor of nursing at New York University and Mr. Greenberg is a computer consultant based in Manhattan.
"We wanted an easy commute to the city and didn't want a starter house," Mrs. Greenberg explained. "We looked closer to Manhattan and found that the houses in our price range were small."
Although they have no children yet, the Greenbergs said they wanted a town with a good school system. They also like the fact that Scotch Plains has a compact business district.
"Right now, we are not asking much from the town because of our work schedules," Mr. Greenberg explained. "But when we have children, we will. So far, we've found Scotch Plains to be friendly. We have many neighbors in their early 30's."
Scotch Plains and the neighboring Borough of Fanwood share the 4,300-student Scotch Plains-Fanwood Public Schools system. It consists of five elementary schools, two middle schools and the 1,050-student Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School.
The system is headed by Superintendent Carol B. Choye, who was named Superintendent of the Year for 1997 by the New Jersey Association of School Administrators. She was awarded a $1,000 United States Savings Bond, which she said she would give one of the graduating seniors as a college scholarship.
Over the past five years, the system has grown by more than 400 students, due mainly to the construction of about 400 new homes and the turnover of existing homes by empty-nesters to young families. This has led the school system to add modular classrooms to three of the five elementary schools. According to Dr. Choye, 4,350 students are enrolled for the school year starting in September, reflecting a growth of 50 students.
OF last year's 262 graduating seniors, 90 percent went on to higher education. Their combined average verbal and math scores on the S.A.T. was 1060, compared with a state average of 1005, with one Scotch Plains student scoring a perfect 1600.
The class was awarded a total of $1.6 million in scholarships. The high school offers 11 advanced placement courses in English, math, foreign languages, the sciences and economics.
Besides its public schools, Scotch Plains has two co-ed Roman Catholic parochial schools -- the Union Catholic High School and the k-8 St. Bartholomew Elementary School. Annual Union Catholic tuition is $5,256 a child, with a $500 discount for each additional child. St. Bartholomew's tuition for parishioners ranges from $1,825 to $3,730 for one to three children; for nonparishioners it is a flat $2,625 per child.
The community also has a very active Y.M.C.A. and is home to the Jewish Community Center of Northern New Jersey.
Scotch Plains has nine municipal parks, the largest of which are the 29-acre Brookside Park off Hetfield Avenue and the 29-acre Scotch Hills Country Club off Jerusalem Road. Brookside, which was recently remodeled, has a pond, a roller hockey rink, a basketball court and a softball diamond. The annual membership fee at the country club, which has a nine-hole golf course, is $25; the greens fee is $7.
The town is also home to the county-owned Ashbrook Country Club and the private Shackamaxon Country Club, both of which have 18-hole courses.
There are no supermarkets in town. Most residents do their grocery shopping in neighboring Westfield, Watchung or Fanwood and their serious shopping at the Short Hills Mall seven miles away.

CANNONBALL HOUSE: The Historical Society of Scotch Plains and Fanwood has its offices and museum in a small farmhouse on Front Street. It was built in 1740 by the Osborne family. During the Battle of the Short Hills, it was reported to have been hit by Continental artillery by mistake. Two centuries later, when the house was being restored to its 18th-century appearance for the Historical Society, siding that had been added over the years was removed and a Revolutionary War cannonball was found lodged in the side of the structure. The Osborne Cannonball Museum, which consists of three rooms decorated in Colonial era fashion and one room decorated in Victorian style, is open from 2 to 4 P.M. on the first Sunday of every month. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Prices;
Asking Rents for Midtown Office Space Keep Rising

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DEMAND for office space in midtown Manhattan has driven the average annual rental rate to over $40 a square foot for the first time this decade, according to figures compiled by Newmark & Company Real Estate. The average asking rental per square foot rose from $37.99 at the end of last year to $40.25 at the end of March, for an increase in the quarter of 5.92 percent.
Other real estate companies have different ways of measuring the market, but all agree on the direction: up. 
 "Transactions with rents in the 50's are no longer rare," said Franklin C. Speyer, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield. "The economy is good, and there is no lack of tenants willing to pay to stay in New York."
Indeed, officials of Julien J. Studley, a tenants' broker, report that there are at least 15 buildings in midtown where the asking annual rent is over $60 a square foot. Other parts of the city have seen rental rates rise as well, but not to the levels seen in midtown.
Mr. Speyer said that financial services companies, fueled by the booming stock market, were leading the expansion in the use of office space, but added that entertainment, advertising, insurance and other service companies were also contributing to the demand.
In all, an estimated 120,000 jobs have been added in the city since 1993, a period of no new building.
"We have just emerged from the longest period of no new building since World War II," said David W. Levinson, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG. "Building stopped in 1990, and the Durst building won't open until next year," he said, referring to 4 Times Square, the 49-story tower now being built on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets by the Durst Organization.
"That is an extraordinary period of no new supply," he said.
Nor is there likely to be much added, at least in Manhattan, he said. Although three more buildings probably will be built in the Times Square area, the Reuters news agency will occupy most of one -- 3 Times Square, across from the Durst building -- and together they are not expected to have a big impact on the market.
"There are 200 million square feet of space in midtown," Mr. Levinson said. "The most you can add is five percent. Midtown is already built." Midtown is generally defined as the area south of 57th Street to the mid 30's, river to river.
The result, most brokers say, is that the market has tipped decisively in favor of landlords. Not only are asking rents going up, but concessions, notably periods of free rent and allowances for building tenants' offices, are shrinking rapidly as well.
"There is no new space, so the price is going up," said Robert Emden, an executive managing director at Grubb & Ellis. "Buildings that were in the mid-40's this time last year were at $50 by the end of the year. Now the market is being tested again, and the $60 barrier is being broken."
Mr. Emden said that with a robust economy, most companies were more interested in generating more business than in containing costs, although at least one law firm, which he did not identify, is considering putting two associates in each office to conserve space.
"The current market is making it very tough on our clients," said Richard Podos, vice president of Equis New York, a tenants' broker. Mr. Podos said that concessions today were even lower than at the last peak, in 1988. At that time, free rent and work allowances amounted to about 20 percent of the total value of a lease, he said. That rose to as much as 35 percent at the bottom of the office market about five years ago.
TODAY, he said, concessions are only about 10 to 15 percent of the value of a lease. "It's going to get a lot crazier before this bull market runs out," he said.
Mr. Levinson of Insignia/ESG said that some companies were trying to hedge against future price increases by leasing space now in anticipation of future growth. "We have clients who are taking space they don't expect to need until five years from now," he said. "They are going to the trouble of putting in subtenants to protect themselves. That only happens in this kind of an environment."
Many real estate executives warn that a continuing increase in the cost of office space will drive companies to New Jersey and Westchester County, where some speculative building is already under way or planned. And the executives caution that landlords who push for the last penny and adopt arrogant negotiating tactics at the top of the market can expect little sympathy from tenants when the inevitable downturn arrives.
"I find it troubling to be in a market where you can have a handshake on a deal at $40 before lunch, and then the owner goes to lunch, talks to his friends or employees, and comes back and announces that the price is $45," said Mitchell Steir, an executive vice president of the Julien J. Studley company. "This increase in prices will not go on forever. We are in something of a frenzied window now, but people are going to realize that space in Westchester is half the price of Manhattan and they will start to move out."
Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, agrees that the sky is not the limit for landlords. "Rents this year will not increase as much as they did last year," he said. "We're almost to the point where new construction is justified and we will see building in New Jersey and Stamford as long as the financial markets stay strong."
Tenants are not completely without leverage in negotiations with landlords, particularly in renewal leases for space already occupied, said James S. Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a tenants' broker. This is because there is a substantial cost in bringing in a new tenant.
"The owner will have to spend $5 a foot to demolish the space and another $35 to rebuild," he said. "There will be down time, and commissions to be paid. In all, it will probably cost an owner $60 to $70 a foot to bring in a new tenant."
He said that tenants should begin renewal talks with their landlords several years before their leases expire so they can take advantage of the owner's wish to save the expense of finding and installing a new tenant.
And, of course, not all tenants are created equal. Owners want tenants with a strong financial base -- known in the trade as credit tenants -- who will be able to keep up their rent payments even if the economy goes sour.
Such tenants will be able to drive better deals than such service providers as law firms and advertising agencies, which have little in the way of assets and have suffered in past slumps.
During the last boom, midtown south, generally the area south of the mid 30's toto Canal Street, served as a safety valve for midtown, with old loft buildings converted to offices.
That area is largely filled, but there is some speculation that development may shift to the west side of Manhattan, in the 30's. Vornado Realty Trust, for example, has invested heavily in the area around Penn Station.
THAT may occur, but for most tenants that kind of an address is not acceptable, said Andrew Roos, executive vice president of Williams Real Estate. "Most tenants are going to pay a few bucks more to stay where they are, rather than move to a fringe area," he said.
Referring to two of the most discussed ideas of recent years, having employees operate without permanent office space or work from home, Mr. Roos added, "You don't hear much about hoteling and work at home any more. Corporations have found there is a synergy in keeping all their people under one roof."
Many real estate executives agree that the current demand for office space is ultimately driven by the stock market. Not only does the boom in stock values make people feel wealthier, it puts executives in a state of mind that expanding their business is more important than squeezing expenses.
"Interest rates are low and the economy is good, so the mood is expansive," Mr. Emden observed.
But if the stock market were to drop sharply in value, that attitude could be reversed very quickly.
"If the market goes down 3,000 points, all this comes to a halt," Mr. Speyer said. "When the stock market dropped in October 1987, we felt it the next day, even though it took six to seven years to completely play out."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Housing Developers Look Inland From Riverfront

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WHILE housing is sprouting like wildflowers along the Hudson River coastline, it is also taking shape on interior streets in some waterfront communities.
Much of the off-the-river activity is occurring in Hoboken, but projects totaling 1,000 residential units are, or soon will be, going up in Jersey City and Edgewater. Most of the inland projects, like those on the river's edge, involve upscale rentals, which generally are leasing for 10 to 15 percent less than their waterfront counterparts. A few involve condominium apartments and lofts. 
 With much of the waterfront in these communities spoken for, though not necessarily being developed, builders are moving inland in an effort to capitalize on what they say is an increasing demand for housing in these old port towns.
The inland activity is benefiting from a ripple effect from a tight housing market in Manhattan as well as along the Hudson's west bank, where the rental vacancy rate is virtually zero, according to Marketing Directors, a marketing and consulting firm in Manhattan.
Since there is "no massive amount of product" coming onto the riverfront at one time, demand is ahead of supply, said Carol M. Smith, the company's director of marketing. Off-the-river projects, she added, "can get away without water views" if they compensate on price and are close to other amenities, like transit links.
In Hoboken, 933 residences have been completed inland in the last three years or are now under construction and an additional 1,203 have been approved or are proposed, city figures show. Though 2,500 riverside units were approved in that same period, just 196 rentals are under way on the northern end of the waterfront as part of a project called the Shipyard, which eventually will contain 1,160 units.
Developers have focused on the southwestern portion of the city, putting up housing where vacant lots or older residential and commercial buildings once stood. That area, like the riverfront, missed out on the 80's construction surge.
For Brownstone Communities, with offices in Hoboken and Millburn, the area is ripe for the kind of urban infill housing the company builds -- town house and loft-style condominiums. The company is involved in four such projects, totaling up to 130 residences. As its name implies the houses are being designed to recall the brownstones for which Hoboken is known. Dean Marchetto of Hoboken is the architect.
"Hoboken is the most vibrant waterfront community with an established residential core," said Brian M. Stolar, a company principal. "So rather than be an extension of the riverfront we decided to create new neighborhoods."
This week the company is expected to start its newest project -- 14 condominium apartments in seven two-family homes and four loft units in an eighth structure that can be divided into as many as eight units. The loft structure will stand at the corner of First and Madison Streets and the others will extend along either street. Each two-family structure has two garages; the loft building has four parking spaces.
Prices will range from $273,000 to $420,000 for the condominium apartments, with 1,500 to 3,000 square feet of space; and from $170,000 to $479,000 for finished lofts with 850 to 2,300 square feet, which is a full floor.
"We are appealing to professional couples who want or need to be closer to their jobs," said George Vallone, another company principal.
Nearby, work will start this summer on a 301-unit, two-building rental complex called Century Towers. It will rise on nearly an entire city block along Observer Highway, between Park Avenue and Garden Street; the block is now occupied by surface parking, an old truck garage and vacant lots. The project will provide underground parking for 469 cars and a 12,000-square-foot corner park.
"The rental market is strong all over Hoboken," said Richard Miller, a principal of the Pegasus Group L.L.C. of Hoboken, the developer. "And being three blocks from PATH will be an advantage."
Monthly rents for the studio to three-bedroom apartments, with 550 to 1,250 square feet of space, will be $1,250 to $2,800, he said.
THE activity is spreading into the northwestern sector of Hoboken, which, like its waterfront, once was a thriving industrial hub. Last month city officials rezoned the area to mostly residential, as well as retail uses, said Robert K. Drasheff, director of Hoboken's Department of Human Resources, which oversees community and waterfront development.
"The city, which has tried since 1985 to bring industry back to the area, decided to promote what it does best -- residential construction," Mr. Drasheff said. These properties now will be brought back on the tax rolls, helping to expand the city' s tax base, he added. One project proceeding in the area is the Curling Club, which will have 240 two-bedroom rentals in four buildings along Grand Street between 11th and 12th Streets. It replaces the Ferguson Propeller Works, which manufactured propellers for ships. The developer is the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, whose principals are Charles Kushner and his brother, Murray.
"Because the waterfront is so hot the peripheral areas of Hoboken are growing," said Charles Kushner. "They are no longer off the beaten track."
Rents for the units, averaging 1,050 square feet, will start at $1,800 a month. The project, which will have underground parking for 225 cars and a health club, will be completed by the end of 1999.
In Jersey City the focus of luxury residential development is still the waterfront because there is enough vacant land left to develop and it is where the city's high-rise zoning is in place, said Robert Cotter, the city's planning director. So far about 4,200 of the planned 15,000 riverfront units have been or are being constructed.
Still, a few developers have ventured off the river. Four blocks inland, for instance, developers plan to transform a parking lot at the corner of Montgomery and Warren Streets into a 220-unit rental, called the Siena, with a 340-car parking garage. Construction will start in September on the 23-story building, which will also have 20,000 square feet of ground-level stores.
The developer is a joint venture between Panepinto Properties of Jersey City and the Applied Companies of Hoboken. Applied has long been active along the shoreline and is involved either alone or with partners in three riverfront projects, including the Shipyard in Hoboken.
"With the market so strong we see an opportunity to capture the spillover in select inland pockets, which, while not as sexy as riverfront sites, can do well if the right product is offered," said David B. Barry, a vice president at Applied.
Mr. Barry said the site was between two PATH stations and close to Newark Avenue, a major retail strip that is now being upgraded. Rents for the studio to three-bedroom units, with 540 to 1,700 square feet of space, will range from $1,050 to $2,300 a month.
Mr. Cotter, the planning director, said that four-story buildings along two blocks of Newark Avenue between Erie and Grove Streets, whose upper three floors were once used as warehouses, were being renovated. The ground level will remain as retail space, but the upper floors will provide up to 50 apartments.
Stuart Z. Kopperweiss, president of the private, nonprofit Jersey City Economic Development Authority, said that the city upgrades the exteriors at no cost to the owners and provides low-interest loans of up to 30 percent of the cost of interior renovations.
He said that the "slightly more than $1 million" cost of the facade renovations would be borne by sales-tax revenues from the city's Urban Enterprise Zone.
In Edgewater, development is filtering to the west side of River Road, which divides this pencil-shaped community and parallels the river. Construction will start there next month on a four-building, 24-unit rental complex that is to replace a row of empty apartment buildings. The developer is Daibes Brothers, a local concern that, alone or with partners, is also involved in many of Edgewater's riverfront projects, totaling about 1,000 rental apartments.
"There is no question that the market is pushing development off the river," said Fred A. Daibes, who runs the company with his brother, Joseph. "Recyling old residential sites was just a matter of time because they are more valuable now as vacant land."
Rents for the one bedroom apartments, with 650 to 850 square feet, will be $1,400 to $1,700 a month, said Mr. Daibes.
The company also plans to redevelop the now empty Alcoa plant site one block from the river into a rental complex with 410 to 460 apartments.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Towns Implementing Ridge Development Limits

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
TRAVELING along Interstate 91, some motorists tend to slow down as they gaze at the 44 mountains that pass through 30 communities along the central corridor of Connecticut from the Massachusetts border almost to Long Island Sound.
In a symbolic gesture to cooperate in the preservation of these mountains, called the Trap Rock Ridges, 17 towns in their path signed an agreement called the Metacomet Ridge Conservation Compact last April 22, Earth Day. 
 Heavily wooded and largely inaccessible, most of the ridges are undeveloped, visited only by intrepid hikers on the Metacomet and Mattabesett Trails along the crest. That dry, rocky environment is home to the rare electric blue skink lizard, the falcate orange-tipped butterfly, prickly pear cactus, stands of Torrey's mountain mint and delicate purple hair grass.
Recently the relentless push of housing development has begun creeping up some of the mountains, sending the towns scrambling to implement a 1995 state law allowing them to restrict development on the ridges. The measure was co-sponsored by Representative Mary M. Mushinsky of Wallingford and State Senator Thomas P. Gaffey of Meriden, both Democrats.
Several towns have worked on new regulations, and among the compact towns Meriden, Durham, Berlin, Simsbury, Middletown and Farmington have passed or are in the process of passing zoning that limits or prohibits development within 150 feet of the tops of the ridges.
But before the regulations can be enforced maps must be drawn detailing how and where development, clear-cutting of vegetation and any new quarrying operations are to be restricted or prohibited. Existing quarries are not affected.
The rest of the 17 compact communities -- Branford, North Branford, Guilford, East Haven, Wallingford, Middlefield, Plainville, West Hartford, Avon, Suffield and Bloomfield -- are still wrestling with zoning proposals or adding to existing limitations along their ridge lines.
"We encourage the towns to do what they can, whether through purchase, regulations or donations," said Norman Zimmer, author of the compact and a member of the Meriden Conservation Commission.
Historically, royalty and wealthy individuals have favored the tops of mountains as strategic and awe-inspiring sites for castles, fortifications and baronial mansions. But these ridges, said Mr. Zimmer, "must be preserved esthetically and recreationally" because "they are the Central Park of Connecticut."
The significance of the ridges, said Representative Mushinsky, "goes back to the dinosaur era, when they were formed. They rise above the rest of the state -- a continuous series of parallel basalt ridges, which at one time were lava. One side is a sheer scarp, the other side is a slope, but rocky and difficult to develop."
The name trap rock, she believes, evolved from a Swedish word trappa, meaning step, describing the configurations that formed layers of basalt in the Jurassic and Triassic periods.
"What triggered the legislation," she said, "was one landowner who wanted to put his foundation right on a section of Connecticut's Blue Trail system."
Existing development on the ridges varies widely from none at all in Meriden, which is surrounded by seven ridges, to about 30 homes built over several years on Avon's ridges, where 10 additional houses have been approved for construction and an additional eight are in the approvals pipeline. They will be priced from $800,000 to $3 million. Stephen Kushner, Avon's town planner, said that the views justified the prices.
So far, restrictive measures have been hailed by townspeople who regard the majestic chains of mountains as among their most precious assets. In addition, "they are major water-recharge areas," said Mr. Zimmer. "Water percolates down through the ridges to reservoirs at the base of the mountains," he said, adding that development could contaminate the water.
But the new rulings are causing confusion and resentment among individual ridgeland owners and developers who contend that their holdings are being rendered worthless. Contractors, too, who have been mining the century-old ridge quarries, crushing the rock to build roads, houses, hospitals, storm sewers, schools and an endless array of construction projects are suddenly concerned about future supplies.
"The stone that's mined in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire is the best in the world," said Joseph LaRosa, owner of LaRosa Construction in Meriden. "Perhaps they could designate certain areas for new quarries" -- a practice, quarriers say, that has been followed in some Western states.
TOM FRANCOLINE, a developer in Avon and chairman of the Connecticut Developers' Council, is concerned that "building materials in this part of the country are extremely expensive."
"But it will be a lot more expensive," he said, "to bring stone in from elsewhere, adding to fuel consumption and pollution."
Meriden's City Council approved the new zoning last year, based on a model set of regulations that conforms to the 1995 state statute and was distributed to all the towns. But the city's Planning and Zoning Commission rejected the Council's map of some 30 affected properties, the final step required to put the regulations into practice.
"They stated that we ought to work on compensation for property owners," said Stephen Zerio, chairman of the Economic Development Committee of the Council.
Compensation promises to be a major bone of contention. "I need to be compensated for five acres on which I pay $350 a year in taxes," said Ross Gulino, a landowner and developer. Taxes on undeveloped ridge land in Meriden, designated by the town as excess land, are extremely low. and levied at a fraction of the full rate. Assessor Steven Hodgetts said "one person is paying $25 a year on three acres, another with 315 acres is paying $14.50 an acre," or $4,567.50.
Mr. Gulino contends that "pretty much all" of his five acres are within 150 feet of the top. "I planned to market it as a single lot or maybe three lots," he said. "If the legislation goes through I will wind up with 50 feet or less, not enough to build on."
In 1995, as vice president of BRG Realty, a family-owned firm, he was a principal in the purchase of a predeveloped subdivision of 40 lots on 41 acres at the base of the mountain, plus the remainder of the slope including the top parcel. Fifteen lots at the base sold for $60,000 to $100,000 each. "Lots at the top would have added value because of the view," he said.
Pauline Travers, a Meriden widow with 20 acres, lives on the lower half. The rest is within 150 feet of the summit. The new zoning, she said, "will devalue my land -- it won't be very salable for me or my children." Disturbed by what she perceives as insensitivity on the part of thousands of people who favor the new zoning, she said "they don't own -- they just like to look at the view."
No doubt a protracted period of adjustment and probably a spate of lawsuits is in store as the various towns struggle to create regulations that will pass muster at the state level. Of the towns that adopted new zoning, Berlin does not allow quarrying and prohibits development higher than 350 feet above sea level.
Simsbury does not allow clear-cutting and requires replacement of trees in some cases, and Middletown may limit houses to one story or require moving them to lower ground if they interfere with views of the ridge line. Farmington, where development has produced some clear-cutting and "houses that stick out when you look up at the ridge," according to Elizabeth Dolphin, assistant planning director, is trying to deal with existing regulations that have produced disappointing results.
Mark Branse, a Glastonbury lawyer who drew up the model regulations for the 17 compact towns, said that most of the confusion comes from flawed interpretations of the model and ignorance of the state statute. On the subject of compensation, he said:
"General law states that government may regulate land use to protect the public welfare, but it cannot regulate it down to where it has no value. Any regulation will cause diminution of value. What is reasonable is what courts debate regularly."
"Buyers of ridge land knew it was difficult to get up there and to build on it," he continued. "However, the regulations allow what is deemed reasonable use of the property so as not to make it worthless."
In the case of Mr. Gulino, he indicated that the courts might not sanction compensation for losing the use of one piece of property when the owner has sufficient property nearby that is viable and profitable.
"The state statute only allows restriction," said Terry Tondro, professor of law at the University of Connecticut. "If a town had a flat prohibition, affected landowners could go to the state statute, which takes precedence. The statute was designed to protect ridgelines, using the word restrict rather than prohibit."
"The goal of zoning is not the maximum enrichment of property owners," said Mr. Branse, paraphrasing a Connecticut Supreme Court decision.

LENGTH: 1484 words

HEADLINE: Crisis Seen In Housing Of Mentally Disabled

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
ALONG with many other aging parents of the developmentally disabled, 74-year-old H. Arthur Alonso, a widower, is angrily pointing his finger at Gov. George E. Pataki.
Since 1995, when the Governor took office, there has been little money for new beds in group residences to help people like Mr. Alonso's 38-year-old daughter, Jerilyn, one of the 4,000 developmentally disabled people in Westchester and 180,000 in the state. 
 "Everything's on hold, and I'm just getting older and more worried," Mr. Alonso said. "Maybe some people don't consider their mortality, but I need to know that when I die, Jerilyn will be all right."
For now, his daughter, who has Down syndrome and a heart condition, lives at home in Pleasantville and attends day-care programs.
But her father is keenly aware of the fragility of that arrangement. "What will happen to her when I go?" he said.
Earlier this spring, the Governor vetoed a $5.7 million proposal in the budget to pay for additional housing for the developmentally disabled, leaving intact, though, a $15 million allotment.
With a waiting list of 6,400, a growing demand and only 500 new beds becoming available this year for retarded people still living at home but needing to move into a state program, Mr. Alonso said the situation was becoming worse. "It's like climbing a greased pole," he said.
Deborah Sturm Rausch, a spokeswoman for the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities, denied that the situation was as grave as some have portrayed it.
She said that in addition to the 500 new beds, up to 600 already in use would most likely become available this year through attrition.
Despite those figures, advocates for the disabled and people who work with the developmentally disabled are worried. In Westchester, Commissioner Steven J. Friedman of the Department of Community Mental Health, said that 106 people "need to be placed right away." Just three years ago, the county was placing 80 to 100 people a year in group residences. "Last year it was 42, this year only 15 to date," he said.
Rochelle Kessler's son Stuart was born 34 years ago during a rubella epidemic, and like Ms. Alonso he is waiting for a spot in a group residence or for an apartment for the disabled. Hearing impaired and developmentally disabled, Mr. Kessler can dress himself, assist with dinner preparations and work at some jobs, like stocking shelves in a store or putting clothes on a rack.
But his mother, a widow living in White Plains, worries about who will look after him in the years to come. "I need to see him settled," she said.
With the discovery late last month that 26 retarded adults were living in homeless shelters in Westchester, parents like Mr. Alonso and Mrs. Kessler observed that the situation had reached crisis proportions.
Although the precise reasons for their homelessness is not yet known, it is believed that some of the 26 had been living with aged or frail parents who could no longer care for them, and they wound up at the county-supported homeless shelter at County Airport in Harrison.
Sometimes, though, the social and economic problems of the developmentally disabled are complicated by what social workers refer to as a dual diagnosis. In addition to their congenital physical and mental problems, they may have acquired alcohol and drug problems, which precipitated their homelessness -- in much the same way that those problems can result in homelessness in other segments of the population, social workers and mental health specialists said.
At the very least, developmentally disabled adults are an extremely vulnerable population -- especially when they live on the street or enter the homeless shelter system -- and they often become the prey of drug dealers and other criminals, said Linda Venezia, director of Community Services at Westchester ARC, formerly known as the Association for Retarded Citizens, an organization in White Plains providing residences, advocacy, case management and other services for the retarded.
Whatever the causes of their homelessness, the recent discovery of the 26 in Westchester's Social Services system has prompted state lawmakers like Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Greenburgh, to worry about how deep and broad the problem is.
"This may be just the tip of the iceberg," Mr. Brodsky said, announcing that he would seek $275,000 to provide rent subsidies and counseling for the 26 adults. He called the situation "deeply appalling."
State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Republican from Yonkers and for many years the leader of the Senate committee on mental health, said he would seek legislation giving state officials no more than 30 days to place a homeless retarded person in a community residence. "It's atrocious that 26 people with developmental disabilities have fallen through the cracks," he said. Mr. Spano is also organizing a meeting between county and state officials to determine what can be done to prevent future problems.
But for many parents and advocates, the politicians' recent efforts amount to too little too late. "They should have been on the case a long time ago," said Mary C. Green, a board member of GROW, the acronym for Group Residences of Westchester, an advocacy group for the retarded. "They should have been pressing for solutions all along."
The situation was called to the attention of state officials months ago, Commissioner Friedman said. It was identified as a top priority early this spring in the county's mental health report to the state, which reported that there was a group of people with special needs -- including mental illness and drug and alcohol abuse -- who were homeless in Westchester.
"This is nothing new," Mr. Friedman said, speculating that GROW was raising it now as a symbolic issue in the wake of Mr. Pataki's veto.
The State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities said that even though Westchester acknowledged the problem in a report, it failed to alert officials individually at the state level. Nevertheless, Ms. Rausch, the spokeswoman, said her office had dispatched a team of clinicians to Westchester two weeks ago in response to the present crisis.
She said that by the time the group arrived at the airport, 11 of the 26 homeless people had left and their whereabouts were unknown. Of those who remained, one refused service; two, according to the clinicians' assessments, were not afflicted with developmental disabilities; four were referred to other agencies with problems like alcohol abuse; five were in need of minimal support and supervision, and three needed residential care.
In large part, the situation has its roots in what is known as the Willowbrook decree, a 1975 Federal consent order, which inspired a statewide policy shift replacing state institutions with community-based residential care. The decree ordered New York to transfer large numbers of retarded people to group homes, which were to be leased or bought by the state.
But according to a report issued in 1984 by the Community Residences Information Services Program, a clearinghouse for the establishment of group residences, public opposition to the group homes was a significant obstacle to the state's intentions. "Despite legal mandates, public policy, proven benefits of family-like living for clients and the compounding needs for such homes, many local governments and neighborhoods have continued to oppose and impede these homes," the report said.
On the whole, though, the large institutions in New York that served as warehouses for the retarded -- like the Staten Island Developmental Center at Willowbrook, Letchworth Village in Thiells and the Wassaic State School at Harlem Valley State Hospital in Wingdale -- have been emptied in the last two decades.
The need for group homes has not abated, though, since the population of developmentally disabled people who were living at home in 1975 is now aging and in need of vacancies in the community residence system.
Also, as Mrs. Green of GROW observed, new people keep coming into the system. "People with developmental disabilities haven't stopped being born," she said.
Richard Sweirat, the executive director of Westchester ARC, expressed concern about the desperation that was building among parents who have raised their retarded children at home. Some aging parents, he said, are so frantic that they have made suicide pacts "to take their developmentally disabled child with them" because they cannot trust the system to assume responsibility.
"It's a terrible tragedy to face to begin with when you have a child with these problems," Mr. Sweirat said, "but now there are all these other problems on top of that. It's time for this story to get out with all its gory details."
Parents of developmentally disabled children can call GROW's help line at 493-1318.

HEADLINE: New Stamp Honors Mme. C. J. Walker

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
A NEW stamp issued by the United States Postal Service commemorates the country's first self-made female millionaire, Madame C. J. Walker of Irvington, whose riverfront mansion begun in 1916 and completed in 1918 still stands.
Madame Walker, who was black, created a line of hair-care and skin products for black women. The 32-cent stamp was the third in the postal service's Black Heritage series. Previous honorees were the abolitionist Harriet Tubman and Jackie Robinson. 
 "This is the only home I ever want to own," said Harold W. Doley Jr., a 25-year member of the New York Stock Exchange and owner of Doley Securities of New Orleans and Manhattan. In the 1980's, Mr. Doley was an ambassador to the African Development Bank in Ivory Coast.
"It's magnificent," Mr. Doley said of the 34-room ivory Italian Renaissance house, which features marble staircases, a three-story pipe organ and sunken gardens. "And it contains the history of Madame Walker and what she did.
"She's in the Guinness Book of World Records as the first female self-made millionaire in America. Not black millionairess, but the first female of any color to make millions on her own."
Mr. Doley's connection to Madame Walker spans several decades.
"I grew up in New Orleans," he said. "We were at Tuskegee at a picnic at my aunt's home, and I met someone who said he was a great-grandson of Madame Walker. His name was Walker Perry. He talked about Madame Walker and the history. I grew up in a family business, and I wanted to go into business. I was always interested in business history."
Years later, Mr. Doley took his children to visit the great houses along the Hudson River. A stop was made in Irvington.
"So, my interest goes back a long way," Mr. Doley said. "I came here in training in 1968 to be a stockbroker, but I didn't get in to see the house until later, 1991. We lived in Scarsdale. I negotiated with the owner for two and a half years before buying it."
Enrico Caruso, a Walker family friend who often sang at parties at the mansion, named it Villa Lewaro, using the first two letters of the names of Madame Walker's daughter, Lelia Walker Robinson.
"People coming by here used to annoy me at first," Helena Doley, Mr. Doley's wife, said. "I could quit my job and give interviews, lead tours and answer the phone full time."
Kept from the reach of developers' bulldozers in 1988 by preservationists adamant about saving the ancient copper beeches and gingkos on the property, Madame Walker's 20,000-square-foot mansion was a dream come true.
Designed by Vertner Woodson Tandy, the state's first licensed black architect, the house is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
"J. P. Morgan was born across the street," Peter Oley, the Village Historian, said. In a village noted for its history, including its namesake, Washington Irving, Madame Walker's house is notable.
"She said that she wanted to be on Broadway in Irvington, because if you were going to Albany you had to pass," Mrs. Doley said. "She saw it as a symbol to her people."
Born Sarah Breedlove on Dec. 23, 1867, on a plantation in Delta, La., Madame Walker was the daughter of former slaves. Both parents died in 1874 in a yellow fever epidemic, and Sarah moved to Vicksburg, Miss., to live with a sister, Louvenia.
In 1882, at 15, she married Moses McWilliams. Three years later, Sarah gave birth to a daughter, Lelia. Mr. McWilliams died of unknown causes in 1887, and Sarah and Lelia moved to St. Louis.
By 1905, mother and daughter were living in Denver, and it was there that Sarah developed the formula for Wonderful Hair Grower, her first product.
"She claimed the formula was given to her in a dream," Mrs. Doley said. "She was having trouble with her hair. It was falling out. There were very few products for women of color. The texture of black women's hair: there was nothing to condition it. Tugging away at it, and it falls out."
A pomade, the product allowed the user to comb hair without breaking its strands.
"She worked, and she marketed," Mrs. Doley said. Selling door to door, she pioneered a concept that would later be used by other cosmetics manufacturers.
"She was a marketing genius," Mrs. Doley said. "She put out newsletters to her agents telling them how to sell. She got women out of washrooms and kitchens. She gave them good commissions. Some of them opened their own places of business.
"She helped with self-determination. Her parents were slaves and then tenant farmers. She was the first generation born free. We get a lot of interesting letters from women who were agents or the children of them."
In 1906, Sarah Breedlove married Charles Joseph Walker and changed her name to Madame C. J. Walker. Two years later, the Walkers moved to Pittsburgh, where Madame Walker opened Lelia College, a now defunct school of cosmetology. Then they moved to Indianapolis, where she built a factory.
Traveling across the country, selling her products and speaking to black organizations, she divorced C. J. Walker in 1912. She became a grandmother in 1913, when her daughter adopted a young woman named Mae Perry.
After a sales trip to the Caribbean and Central America in 1913, she moved to Harlem in 1916. A year later, she convened the first Madame C. J. Walker Hair Culturists Union of America Convention.
In 1917 she tried to talk to President Woodrow Wilson about making lynching a Federal crime, but her request for an appointment was never granted. Instead, she became the largest donor at that time to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, with a gift of $5,000.
She died of a heart attack induced by high blood pressure on May 25, 1919, at 51, a year after Villa Lewaro was completed. So distraught was her daughter, A'Lelia, who had changed her name, that she seldom visited the house, preferring to stay in her brownstone in Harlem.
During the Harlem Renaissance, the house was opened occasionally for huge parties, attended by luminaries like Langston Hughes, W. E. B. DuBois and James VanDerZee, the photographer who chronicled the Harlem Renaissance.
In 1933, Lelia died at 48, also of the effects of high blood pressure. Lewaro, which had been bequeathed to the N.A.A.C.P., was sold for use as a nursing home, which operated on the site for 55 years. The Doleys moved into the house in November 1993.
Madame Walker's products are again being made by Walker Enterprises at 2701 North College Avenue, Indianapolis, Ind. 46204; (317) 921-1080. Visitors to Indianapolis might want to see the Walker Theater, which Madame Walker had built after she was barred from a whites-only establishment. Information on the theater is available by calling (317) 236-2099.
A designer's showcase to benefit the United Negro College Fund is scheduled from Sept. 12 to Oct. 13 at the house. Information is available at (914) 949-3881.
So inspirational is the Walker residence that one neighbor moved to Irvington just to be near.
"A woman across the road said her mother moved here 30 years ago just to look at it," Mrs. Doley said. "You can't live here and not feel in awe of her, feel her presence and think of her."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

Pavel Tchelitchew Show
A show of more than 70 paintings and drawings by Pavel Tchelitchew opens today at the Katonah Museum of Art, continuing through Sept. 6. 
 Its title, "Landscape of the Body" is appropriate to the artist's obsession with the human form, which he interpreted realistically, surrealistically, anthropomorphically and clinically, lifting innovation in figurative painting to new heights.
Officials at the museum believe that in spite of his genius he has been largely omitted from art history books. This show -- the first major museum exhibition of his work since the 60's, and its 56-page catalogue, which includes a 7,000-word curatorial essay and a chronology of the artist's life -- is expected to make a substantial contribution to the scholarship of American art history.
The Tchelitchew estate and fortune were lost in the Russian Revolution of 1918, causing the family to flee the country. Pavel Tchelitchew lived in Berlin for a time, designed sets and costumes for the Ballet Russe in Paris and came to New York in 1934, where he had his first show at the Julien Levy Gallery.
Several programs related to the exhibition begin next Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., when children are invited for a day of body, face and mural painting, making sculptures from recycled materials, and other artistic pursuits. The fee is $15 in advance, $20 at the door.
Admission to the museum, Route 22 at Jay Street, is $2, free to children under 12. Call 232-9555 for details.
 
Waterfront Planning
The future of Westchester's waterfront towns will be the subject of a conference at Marymount College in Tarrytown on Tuesday from 8:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. For a second year the Historic River Towns of Westchester and the county's Planning Department have convened a conference to review plans evolving from discussions with the various communities and to benefit from exchanges of ideas.
They include the Mayors of Croton-on-Hudson, Peekskill, Tarrytown and Yonkers; Joyce Lanning, the County Planning Commissioner; David Sampson, Executive Director of the Hudson River Greenway Communities Council; Charles A. Gargano, State Commissioner for Economic Development, and people in the construction industry, tourism and environmental preservation.
Some riverfront towns have proposals of their own, which the conference is seeing to fold into a coordinated regional approach, focusing on zoning, views and vistas, waterfront trails, abandoned industrial sites, environmental concerns and the interests of residents weighed against tourism.
The final event will be an artist's exhibition and tea from 3:30 to 5 P.M., when the 11 contributing artists will be present. The paintings, prints, pastels and photographs are representations of the Hudson River and will be hung in Rita Hall on the Marymount campus from 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Tuesday and from 2 to 5 P.M. on Wednesday and Thursday.
Conference tickets at $25 include lunch. They may be got along with directions and more information by calling 747-3600, extension 7300.
 
Public and Managed Care
"Consumer Protection in an Era of Managed Care and Provider Networks" is the topic of a conference on Friday from 8:15 to 11:30 A.M. at Pace University's Graduate Center, 1 Martine Avenue in White Plains.
The increasingly uncomfortable relationship between the public and its health care providers will be addressed by Alexander Grannis, chairman of the New York State Assembly Committee on Insurance; R. Channing Wheeler, chief operating officer and president of tristate operations at United Healthcare, a national health management company; Arthur E. Weintraub, president of the Northern Metropolitan Hospital Association, representing more than 60 health care institutions in the Hudson Valley, and Francis J. Serbaroli, partner in the Manhattan law firm of Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft and a vice chairman of the State Public Health Council.
Topics under discussion will include consumer protection legislation at the state and Federal levels, how quality and consumer satisfaction are monitored within the managed care industry and other issues considered to essential to consumer protection.
To register at a cost of $50 call 422-4298.
 
Evening Party, 1824
Decorations and music for a candlelighted evening party circa 1824 will be ready for visitors at the John Jay Homestead in Katonah on Friday from 6 to 9 P.M. Tours of the home of America's first Chief Justice will be conducted, and refreshments are included in the $5 admission charge. Children will be admitted for $2, people older than 62 for $4.
Visitors may picnic on the lawn as the sun sets and stars appear. The house is at 400 Route 22, and the number to call for information is 232-5651. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: A Million-Dollar Home? Ho-Hum.

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST 

 BODY:
THE million-dollar home -- a phrase that not long ago summoned up images of mansions and perhaps even liveried servants -- has become so commonplace in the most affluent New York suburbs that in some communities more than half the homes now on the market are priced above $1 million.
A $1 million price tag, brokers say, no longer necessarily implies luxury living. Rather, a $1 million house in some areas is almost, well, ordinary. 
 Indeed, in the most sought-after sections of Greenwich, Conn., such as Belle Haven and Round Hill, $1 million is now considered entry level, said Susan Hughes, vice president of David Ogilvy & Associates and president of the Greenwich Association of Realtors.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, describes the phenomenon as a "crowding into the winner's circle."
"Driving the market are baby boomers, who are entering their peak earning years, raising families, and settling into the communities where they want to be for the long haul," said Dr. Hughes. who is not related to Susan Hughes. "And so they're bidding up prices in these areas."
 While new luxury-home developments are common now throughout the region, the proportion of $1 million-plus properties is still small in most towns. But in a few areas, primarily those with established reputations as comfortable havens for the well-to-do, sales of homes for $1 million or more make up an increasingly significant chunk of the market.
These areas include Greenwich, New Canaan, Westport and Darien in Connecticut; parts of Westchester County, including Scarsdale, Rye and Larchmont; on Long Island, the villages on Nassau County's North Shore, as well as the Hamptons in Suffolk County; portions of central New Jersey, including Far Hills, Harding Township, Bernardsville and Mendham Township, and the Saddle River area in Bergen County.
"Basically, what you're talking about is supply and demand," said Mrs. Hughes. "There is such a demand for large family homes with certain amenities that it pokes the prices up. And because land prices are so high, people are also building larger homes and expanding homes, so the high-end stock is growing."
"It's a reflection primarily of the tremendous rise of value in the stock market," said Lee E. Koppelman, director of the Center for Regional Policy Studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
The demand for high-end housing in the suburbs is even more pronounced now than it was during the region's last period of great prosperity between 1979 and 1985, he said. And the high cost of housing in Manhattan is a contributing factor. For those with $1 million or more to spend on housing, Mr. Koppelman said, "it does occur to people that they'll get an even bigger bang for their buck by investing in an estate property in the suburbs."
The trend toward buying more costly and larger homes appears to have gained momentum. In Greenwich, for example, the average selling time for houses priced between $1 million and $1.9 million has dropped 40 percent since last year, to just 86 days, according to Nancy A. MacDonald, manager of the Greenwich office of William Pitt Real Estate. For houses priced above $2 million, the sale time is down 30 percent, to 185 days, she said.
In the first quarter of 1998, 49 homes sold for $1 million or more in Greenwich, about 30 percent of all homes sold, according to figures compiled by William Pitt. Ten years ago, only 17 homes, or 18 percent of first-quarter sales, were sold for more than $1 million. In 1984, the $1 million-plus percentage was zero in the first quarter.
"I maintain that if you bought a house in Greenwich in the early 80's, that was terrific," said Ms. MacDonald. "If you purchased for $200,000, $250,000 you could probably get $1.5 million for that house. And that's pretty darn good."
The ceiling on prices is lifting as well. A 24-room mansion on the Greenwich waterfront sold this year for a record $15 million.
The mansion, called Haroldlyn Manor, is a Georgian-style house with a private yacht mooring on six acres. It was once a summer home for Donald J. Trump, who purchased it for $3.7 million in 1984, according to the Greenwich Town Assessor's office.
"A million dollars will buy you a comfortable family house in Greenwich, but nothing fancy, nothing with extravagant amenities," said Mrs. Hughes. "The fancy bedrooms, a finer kitchen, a very large family room -- houses with these things are generally not available under $1.4 million."
And yet, despite the cost, houses just keep getting bigger, noted Bernard Yudain, a longtime Greenwich resident who is a columnist for the Greenwich Time newspaper. "Even some of the big old houses were never this big," he said. "There used to be more of a sense of proportion of house to lot size. Now we're seeing huge houses on relatively small lots. I said the other day, jokingly, that some of these buyers are bringing the wrecking ball people to the closing with them."
Last Monday the Representative Town Meeting, citing concerns about "oversized houses," passed a resolution urging the Town Planning and Zoning Commission to give the highest priority to amending building and zoning regulations to develop "appropriate" floor-area ratios, lot sizes, coverage and setbacks.
Greenwich is not the only affluent town where the wrecking ball has been swinging. "Fifty percent of buyers are looking for what's here," said Joan Quigg, owner of Joan Quigg Realtors in Saddle River. "The other 50 percent is looking for what they can knock down. That wonderful, classic Saddle River look, which was so understated -- well, all that is now to buyers is just a beautiful piece of land."
"People are very demanding," she added. "They want high ceilings, and a very, very good kitchen -- whether they do takeout for the rest of their lives, it doesn't matter. They want a wonderful master bedroom and bath, and a great room off the kitchen."
More than half the 53 properties currently on the market in Saddle River are priced above $1 million. The shift toward more $1 million homes began in the 80's in Saddle River, Ms. Quigg said, but then stopped during the economic downturn.
The market picked up again in 1994, and has climbed upward since, she said. Last year, the New Jersey Multiple Listing Service recorded 25 sales above $1 million in Saddle River; according to Ms. Quigg, as of May 31 this year, 13 had already sold in that category. And new homes in Saddle River are selling for closer to $2 million, she said. .
In many cases, these buyers are making what Ms. Quigg described as "the leap to the big house." That is because, according to brokers, the typical high-end buyers in the suburbs these days are two-income couples with young children. And often they are purchasing their first home.
"It seems to me my borrowers are getting younger," said Craig Atkinson, a senior financial services officer with Sterling Capital in Stamford. "I'm amazed that people in their early 30's are buying $1 million homes."
On a $1 million house, the usual loan amount would be about $750,000, Mr. Atkinson said. "The mortgage interest deduction is about the only tax deduction any of us have anymore, so a lot of buyers like to maximize the mortgage amount," he said, noting that exceptions are often made to allow a mortgage of up to 80 percent of the sale price for customers with adequate assets and income.
The monthly payment on a $750,000 mortgage at a fixed, 30-year rate of 7.375 percent, said Mr. Atkinson, is $5,180, $4,500 of which is initially deductible as interest. Buyers who opt for an adjustable-rate mortgage at a 6.625 interest rate for the first five years pay $4,802 a month, he said, about $4,080 of which is deductible.
Customers rarely borrow more than $1 million, Mr. Atkinson said, because the maximum deduction allowed is interest accrued on a $1 million mortgage. An additional deduction is allowed for interest on a second mortgage of up to $100,000. "A lot of the really big deals get done in cash or through private loans," he said.
All-cash deals are sometimes used as a negotiating tactic, according to Sheila Rice, director of the Fine Homes Division of Prudential Long Island Realty. Buyers offer to pay in cash as an incentive for the seller to come down on the price. Once the deal goes through, she said, they often refinance.
The high-end market in her North Shore territory, which includes both horse country and beach communities, is enjoying a tremendous upswing after an extended slump that lasted well into 1996. "Then, you could list a home at $1.7 million and it would sell for under a million," Mrs. Rice said. But prices are recovering rapidly, she noted.
ACCORDING to data compiled by Prudential, as of June 1, 14 houses had sold for at least $1 million this year in the villages of Brookville, Old Brookville, Upper Brookville, Matinecock, Mill Neck, Muttontown, Lattingtown, Laurel Hollow, Lloyd Harbor, Lloyd Neck, and Oyster Bay Cove. An additional 36 listed in that price range are under contract, Mrs. Rice said.
Should they all come in at more than $1 million, she said, the five-month total will have already surpassed the 1997 year-end figure of 44 million-dollar sales. In the majority of the villages, more than half the inventory is currently priced above $1 million, Mrs. noted.
Though the hamlet of Locust Valley in the Town of Oyster Bay is often perceived as the center of wealth on the North Shore, Mrs. Rice pointed out that some of the most expensive homes in the area are found in Lattingtown, the Brookvilles and Muttontown. Generally, she said, the closer to Long Island Sound, the higher the home prices.
Million-dollar bank investment properties are moving particularly quickly, she noted, because "buyers think they're getting a bargain on foreclosures." A recent example was a 12-year-old contemporary in Oyster Bay Cove with peeling paint, an overgrown yard and a pool full of murky green water. A foreclosure listed at $1.199 million, the property sold in a single weekend.
North Shore properties often come with two or more acres of land. In contrast, a half-acre is "a lot of land" in the $1 million-plus market in Scarsdale, said Joan Frederick, an associate broker in the Scarsdale office of Julia B. Fee. A couple of new five-bedroom homes going up on .33-acre lots in the Fox Meadow neighborhood close to the village center in Scarsdale recently listed at $1.375 million. In portions of the Heathcote section, which is less densely developed, one-acre lots alone start at $1 million, according to Mrs. Frederick.
Prices fluctuate on either side of the million-dollar mark in the older neighborhoods of Edgewood, Fox Meadow and Green Acres, depending on how well the houses have been maintained and the degree to which they have been updated.
One five-bedroom brick colonial in Green Acres went on the market earlier this year for $1.075 million on a street where houses generally sell for $700,000 to $1 million, Mrs. Frederick said. The 80-year-old house showed so well that the owners received multiple offers and wound up getting $1.202 million. In 1984, the same house sold for $510,000, according to Mrs. Frederick.
About a quarter of the homes now on the market in Scarsdale, or 45 houses, are priced above $1 million. The number of $1 million-plus sales began climbing in 1994, when 22 homes sold in that price range. Last year the number was 33, and this year, as of May 27, 25 homes had already sold at more than $1 million each, Mrs. Frederick said.
MANHATTAN is also experiencing an upswing this year, in what was already a heady high-end market. "Increasingly, when you're talking about the $1 million market, you're talking about every part of Manhattan," noted Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth, Warburg Associates, a Manhattan real estate brokerage. "A spacious three-bedroom apartment can run you $1 million on 110th and Riverside. And certainly there are any number of 2,500-square-foot lofts that can run you $1 million."
Mr. Peters said that $1 million-plus sales by his brokers in the first four months of 1998 on the East and West Sides and downtown indicate that if the current pace continues, volume in that market could be up as much as 80 percent by the year's end.
According to Lawrence Sicular, a broker and appraiser for Brown Harris Stevens, the $1 million market currently accounts for 37 percent of all sales on the Upper East Side and Central Park West. That is up from 33 percent in 1997, and 25 percent in 1996. "It's a strong but conservative market," he noted. "So the biggest price increases are for the best located and largest apartments."
The same is true of properties selling for $1 million or more in the suburbs. In Greenwich, according to Ms. MacDonald of William Pitt, a home that recently sold in the prestigious shore community of Belle Haven was snapped up almost immediately, despite a price that would once have been daunting even by Fairfield County shorefront standards.
"The people had been in the house for 40 years," she said. "It was incredible waterfront property. They probably paid $50,000, if that, and they were holding out for $3 million. I'm sure they got close to that, if not that."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Prolonged Party For 'Annie' at 20-Plus

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
"OPTIMISM!" shouts one of the street people of lower Broadway. "That's something I haven't heard since 1928." Stunned, he is reacting to an orphaned 11 1/2-year-old redhead who insists that "the sun'll come out tomorrow."
It is hard to know if the audience at Tuesday's opening of "Annie" at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which appeared to consist of a trillion little girls, got it. What they did get was the rush of a real live big-time Broadway show and the terrific brassy sound of the old-style score, briskly conducted by Sue Anschutz. Here is a young person's ideal guide to the joys of musical theater. 
 Even though it is being promoted as "Annie: Direct From Broadway," where it closed in October, the show has come directly from Memphis to Newark, the 30th stop on a "20th-anniversary tour" scheduled to conclude when "Annie" will be 22.
Even if this "Annie' is only a retread, the stopover here may be the beginning of a real theater mission for the inviting arts center, for this is the first full-scale Equity production to play the 2,750-seat Prudential Hall.
It is hard to believe that the chaperones and others of a certain age in the audience would be coming upon "Annie" for the first time. It would be best for them to pay no mind to the sanctimonious remarks by Martin Charnin, the show's lyricist and director, about the musical's Dickensian shadings, including child abuse. For such is the retro-cartoony tone of Thomas Meehan's funny book that its lines could well be contained within the balloons of a comic strip. Even given a story of homelessness, rampant unemployment and the power of a billionaire's "war bucks" to heal, "Annie" is an inoffensive entertainment by Mr. Charnin and Charles Strouse, craftsmen who in this case knew musical-theater territory and charted it expertly.
Remarkably, "Tomorrow," the show's signature song and the first one written for it, is the only one Mr. Strouse composed in a post-Beatles style; the rest of the score is period-perfect. Too bad the touring show omits "We'd Like To Thank You" (Herbert Hoover), a lamentation of the Depression, with a Weill-Brechtian edge. "You Make Me Happy," added for Miss Hannigan in the Broadway revival, is also omitted from this staging, which runs two and a half hours even with other minor deletions.
In a cast with talent to spare, Alene Robertson, an excellent Miss Hannigan in the vastly superior 1996 revival at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn. (where "Annie" was born in 1976), is relegated to a series of small roles and understudying Sally Struthers. And Christine Kienzle, who was a sizzling Evita at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn in 1996, is the understudy for Lily, Rooster Hannigan's ditzy accomplice. That's show business: cut songs in one place; waste talent in another.
Ms. Struthers, who replaced an ineffectual Nell Carter as Miss Hannigan in January, may not be the revival's lifeline, but she does give it life. She takes a stranglehold on the role and hurls it right up to the fourth tier, succumbing to the D.T.'s even before she takes a swig from her ever-handy flask ("it's medicinal"), dismembering a doll and stumbling into walls.
There is no question that Ms. Struthers, a well-known spokeswoman for children's rights, is giving a performance, but only to a point. A vamping sex-starved harridan more than a child-hater, Ms. Struthers is not a masterly comic villain, but an emphatically hard-working, heavy-breathing one.
Brittny Kissinger, the 9-year-old understudy who replaced the intended Annie on Broadway two weeks before previews amid a publicity blitz that came to be called "the 'Annie' wars," is in full command of all an ageless runaway must be. She is a belter. She has a wily way with an obscenely rich old man and a woebegone stray dog. She can sell a line, get a laugh and, now, connect with Conrad John Schuck (Oliver Warbucks) in a warm and winning way that eluded them early in last year's Broadway run. Mr. Schuck gives a steely man a thoroughly convincing meltdown, but only for Annie.
With sketchy scrims and sets, from the Warbucks manse to the tenements of Hell's Kitchen, the Performing Arts Center is presenting a well-traveled, truncated "Annie" that exhibits the compromises and the contradictions of theater in the material world: a first-class company going tourist in a sumptuous space.
 
ANNIE
New Jersey Performing Arts Center
1 Center Street, Newark
Today at 3 P.M. Tickets: $15 to $56.
(888) 466-5722
