HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Tighter Leash for Dog Walkers

BYLINE: By INGRID EISENSTADTER 

 BODY:
THREE hundred thousand pooches live in New York City. For dog walkers, that's a lot of plastic bags.
But those who earn a living with a leash are not complaining. They are doing a land-office business. The prices, experience and services of these operations vary widely, and they range from part-time endeavors run from home by unemployed actors to companies with offices and full-time employees. But, though the field is diverse and largely unregulated, few people doubt that it is growing. 
 "There are no statistics about how many individuals walk dogs professionally, but new services seem to pop up every day," said Robin Kovary, director of the American Dog Trainers Network, a nonprofit nationwide referral service. One reason: "In the 90's more people are working long hours, so dog walking is a great convenience," she said.
But growing reliance on dog walkers means that more animals will be lost, injured or even killed on their watch.
Simka, a 1-year-old 40-pound German shepherd mix, ran away from a dog walker on the Upper West Side one evening in March. The walker had a second dog and so could not pursue Simka until it was too late.
"Something must have frightened her," said Phyllis Heller, the dog's owner. "She got out of her collar and ran away."
Ronnie Reiman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that last Christmas her Coton de Tulear, an exotic French breed, got away from his walker. The dog's cost: $2,000.
Although Ms. Reiman got her dog, Valentin, back -- "I put posters on anything that didn't move from Houston to 57th Street, river to river" -- Ms. Heller still has not found her dog, despite similar posterings.
These incidents, coupled with the inclination of businesses to distinguish themselves from one other, are making safety a big subject on the dog-walking circuit.
Consider Flo Phillips, a self-employed dog walker on the Upper East Side. A pet-care provider for more than a decade, Ms. Phillips said she has had one client almost seven years. "I walk that dog twice every day," she said. "He's like my nephew." That means she knows the dog and the dog knows her, in contrast to larger companies, which may assign different walkers to a pet on different days. Such familiarity may make runaways less likely.
Ms. Phillips says her charges are safe for another reason: she walks just one animal at a time. Pack walking may keep prices down for the pet owner and increase income for the business, but, as Ms. Heller learned, a dog walker who is holding one animal can't chase another that is getting away. Moreover, dealing with multiple dogs is not easy. "If something goes wrong," Ms. Kovary said, "you become a human maypole."
Ms. Phillips said she frequently sees dogs left alone on the street while their handler makes another pickup. Doormen will not let packs of nonresident dogs into the buildings, she said. That can leave the dogs vulnerable to theft or injury.
Cliff Zager, owner of the K-9 Club on the Upper East Side, has built a business doing just what Ms. Phillips dislikes: walking dogs in packs. Pets in his care get a two-hour daily walk in groups of 7, occasionally even 10. But he has made efforts to promote safety.
"Each pack has two handlers," Mr. Zager said, and for additional security all the dogs are on chokers. Because these devices tighten when animals pull on them, they help prevent dogs from slipping their leashes and give handlers greater control over the animals. (Virgilio Pires, owner of Mandrake Dog Walking, the service that walked Simka, said that since the dog's loss he puts all his dogs in chokers.) Moreover, all pairs of K-9 walkers report to street-level supervisors who coordinate the pickups and drop-offs on their routes. As a result, Mr. Zager said, dogs in his care are never left alone.
Puddles Pet Service has taken a high-technology route. Its dog walkers are computer-tracked using customized software, said Dominique Brandwen, the owner. When they arrive at a customer's home, they dial an 800 number to log onto the system. The call is automatically matched against the dog-walking schedule so staff members know if the schedule is being met. If the call is not made, the computer will alert office employees.
Puddles walkers carry beepers so they can be called in emergencies and, Ms. Brandwen said, "I have a round-the-clock assistant who carries an alphanumeric pager and a cellular phone at all times."
These devices are most often used for last-minute changes in plan, Ms. Brandwen said. If, for example, a pet has to be picked up at the vet's instead of home, beepers insure that the dog won't be stranded.
Ms. Brandwen said she also conducts background investigations of new employees for criminal records. She offers health insurance to encourage employees to stay and thus build up a corps of capable, experienced workers.
Whether all such practices improve pet safety is unclear. Pet owners and others add to these strategies their own set of safety tips and suggestions. For example, Ms. Heller said, "Always ask your service, 'What would you do if my animal were lost?' "
Owners should make sure an animal has identification. As Ms. Heller has found, a pet can slip out of a collar and tag; for that reason, some pet owners tattoo vital information on the pet or even implant an identifying microchip under its skin.
If an animal is lost, call the Center for Animal Care and Control, which oversees the city's animal shelters. The Manhattan number is (212) 722-3620. Call promptly, because the animals may be destroyed after 48 hours.
Posting fliers can work, too. But when Ms. Heller put up her 2,000 notices, "they were all removed by the Department of Sanitation," she said.
Distraught and desperate, the next day Ms. Heller "papered the whole Upper West Side three times," she recalled.
But still no luck. "I don't have a body; I don't have a dog," Ms. Heller said. "I will feel guilty for the rest of my life."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Kicking Some Sand Into Powerful Faces

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
HERE'S some excellent beach reading: a pair of business books that are light enough to tote (83 and 102 pages, respectively) yet anything but scrawny.
"Team Rodent: How Disney Devours the World," by Carl Hiaasen, and "News Is a Verb: Journalism at the End of the Twentieth Century," by Pete Hamill ($8.95 each), are part of a new series by Ballantine's Library of Contemporary Thought -- short paperbacks by high-profile writers on everything from sports to the Supreme Court. 
 The waxing of Disney and the waning of newspapers are the chosen subjects of Mr. Hiaasen and Mr. Hamill. And well-chosen they are: These terrifically constructed complaints seem to have burst full-blown from some longtime mental fumings.
"Team Rodent" was published last month and immediately made it onto the New York Times business best-seller list. In the book, Mr. Hiaasen, a best-selling crime novelist and a columnist for The Miami Herald, attacks -- informatively and hilariously -- the Disneyfication of the globe, with special attention to Florida and Times Square. (The latter, a once "skanky oozepot" of sleaze, tested our taste and tolerance, he argues. And revulsion, unlike the Mickey and Minnie garden statues at the enormous new Disney Store on 42d Street, is "essential to the human experience.")
The author says that over all, the Walt Disney Company is well run and even progressive in its policies toward its gay employees. And he discloses that he has made the parental pilgrimage to Disney World in Orlando, Fla. So what does he hate about the House of the Mouse?
For starters, its wholesome-image machine. The company produces gritty rap music through its records unit, he notes, and distributes violent movies like "Pulp Fiction" even as it makes "101 Dalmatians." One extremely funny chapter chronicles a frantic day last year when Disney's Hollywood Records division released, then withdrew, an album that contained filthy lyrics by a group called the Insane Clown Posse.
Mr. Hiaasen also condemns the company for the trample of tourists into Florida -- soon to reach about 46 million annually -- and for what he calls endless "roadside schlock" set up to relieve these Disney World pilgrims of any leftover cash. Paradoxically, he says, the only relief now from the ugly sprawl (once cattle ranches and fruit orchards) is the verdant Disney complex itself.
But his biggest complaint is against Disney's sheer power -- over our imaginations, municipalities and media. The company "touches virtually every human being in America for a profit," he writes, with its theme parks, movie companies and television networks. For baby boomers especially, he notes, Disney is the "benign enchanter-protector," an image embedded "in the collective parental psyche."
Mr. Hiaasen's sharp irreverence works wonderfully, as he takes jabs at Disney's new cruise ship and privately owned Caribbean island; its chairman, Michael D. Eisner, and what he calls its "shell municipality" in Florida -- the Reedy Creek Improvement District, a kind of parallel government, a "Vatican with mouse ears," in the words of a friend he quotes.
A special gem is the chapter on the "world's largest press party" given at Disney World to commemorate the bicentennial of the United States Constitution and the resort's 15th anniversary. The 5,200 people in attendance were offered mounds of food and souvenirs. They also got the chance to see a respected colleague -- a weary Nick Daniloff, the U.S. News and World Report writer wrongly jailed by the Soviets for spying -- welcomed back to America with outstretched arms. The furry arms, of course, of Mickey Mouse.
 
TABLOIDS IN TROUBLE "News Is a Verb" gets its title from its author's belief that it's bad business -- not just bad judgment -- for newspapers to compulsively cover the rich or famous when they haven't done anything newsworthy. Our papers, he writes, are "runny with the virus of celebrity."
Mr. Hamill, a novelist and longtime New York journalist who was the editor of The Daily News for eight months last year, loves newspapers. He remembers when tabloids had hard-hitting news missions, social campaigns and beautifully rendered comic strips. And he hates the "reader-driven" coverage that he says dumbs down articles in both tabloids and broadsheets.
What's more, he says, all of this is killing, not reviving, an already ailing newspaper industry.
Profits may be up these days because of a strong economy and robust advertising, he says, but the overall weekday circulation of the nation's dailies has stagnated over the last few decades.
The nation's publishers and top editors know exactly what they're doing, he writes, citing a recent Editor & Publisher poll in which 65 percent of newspaper executives agreed that newspapers cover "politics and personalities at the expense of policy." About 48 percent characterized the national press as "shallow and inadequate."
To get the readers back -- particularly women and immigrants -- newspapers must cover health and safety issues, municipal government and, especially, foreign policy, Mr. Hamill says. And publishers must forge alliances -- with the immigrant press in our cities and with newsstands in unfashionable neighborhoods.
Mr. Hamill's arguments, backed by a fascinating foray into New York press history, are lively, compelling and persuasive. "Sooner or later, the reader wises up" when news isn't newsworthy, he says. "Sometimes sooner. Always later."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IN EUROPE: THE MULTINATIONALS;
For Americans, an Indirect Route to the Party

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
A CASE can be made that one way for Americans to invest in Europe is to buy stock in American companies that do big chunks of business here.
The argument goes like this: As European nations go about marrying their national currencies, the wedding will be catered in large measure from the United States. 
 To understand how, consider the following:
European economies and stock markets are booming. Monetary union and the year-2000 computer problem are forcing European companies to bolster technology investments, which have lagged woefully behind those in the United States. So, with markets still reeling in Asia and with earnings growth slowing in the United States, American multinationals may well be relying more than ever on Europe to maintain profitability.
"The conclusion is that United States companies are uniquely positioned to benefit from these trends," said Joe Rooney, chief equity strategist at Lehman Brothers Securities in London.
That is partly because Europe remains the bedrock of American business overseas, even if Asia has grabbed most of the headlines in recent years.
James E. Carlson, an economist at Merrill Lynch in New York, said direct investment abroad by American companies has been so vigorous in recent years that the value of the goods and services they produce and sell outside the United States is now three times the total value of all American exports. And fully 60 percent of that external activity is in Europe.
Indeed, some global mutual funds are picking the American stocks in their portfolios partly on the basis of their exposure to Europe.
Fortis Global Growth, with $173 million in assets, owns American multinationals simply because they rank among the "best-managed growth-oriented companies anywhere in the world," said Jim Byrd, the Fortis executive vice president who manages the fund. Yet, he added, in his stock-picking, "Asia is a disaster, and Latin America is tied to Asia, so Europe wins by default."
Several American companies in his portfolio have recently expanded in Europe: Tellabs Inc., a manufacturer of phone equipment that plans to acquire the Ciena Corporation; Cisco Systems, a Tellabs competitor; the Enron Corporation, the energy company, and Service Corporation International, the funeral-home chain.
Many analysts say that there is no reason to be indirect about investing in Europe. Buying American stocks to enjoy Europe's boom, they note, can deny a portfolio the benefits that come with diversifying into a variety of markets.
And buying into Europe through the shares of American multinationals can be expensive; companies like General Electric, Coca-Cola or Gillette, all with strong European businesses, also trade at high price-to-earnings multiples, said Doug Wilde, an equity strategist at Merrill Lynch in New York.
"We see real opportunities in Europe by specifically tapping into European shares," he said.
Still, some American companies will reap direct benefits from forces at work in Europe. For example, said Mark Howdle, European equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in London, Europe's retailers and makers of brand-name products are likely to suffer as the euro lets Europeans scour the Continent for the cheapest goods. In turn, he said, benefits will accrue to American pioneers in electronic commerce, like Amazon.com, which recently acquired Internet booksellers in Britain and Germany.
Likewise, said Jeffrey Weingarten, global strategist at Goldman Sachs in London, Europe's big investment in technology will pay off for American companies like I.B.M., Intel and Microsoft.

HEADLINE: Where Single Boomers Are Stayin' Alive

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
THE first time Hara Taicher ventured out to a nightclub on the Upper East Side, she met Jerry Steinberg. No one wants to rush anything, but it appears to be love.
That happy tale would not be so unusual, except for the ages of the people involved. As romantic and social venues, nightclubs these days are generally the province of 20-something hipsters sporting tattoos and black miniskirts. But Ms. Taicher, a therapist, is 43, while Dr. Steinberg, an internist from Israel, is 49. 
 The 17-month-old club where they met, Decade, would never be confused with Balthazar, Spy, Moomba or any of the other night spots of the moment, where gatekeepers barely acknowledge a suit with a comb-over or a skirt with, well, gray roots.
With its elegant menu, wine cellar and late-70's dance music like "Shame" by Evelyn (Champagne) King and "I Will Survive" by Gloria Gaynor pulsating from the sound system, Decade is geared to baby boomers looking to meet the same.
"This relationship is a place I've been really looking to get to for a long time," Ms. Taicher said. "Before I heard about Decade, I would never have gone to a club."
With growing ranks of people over 35 finding themselves single in a social world not set up for them, a niche is arising for clubs that cater to those with more years, more money and more unapologetically discriminate taste.
Never mind that baby boomers -- the original inventors of the New York singles scene back in the 1960's and 70's -- would seemingly have outgrown meeting people at bars. Some, no doubt, have. But plenty of others have been tempted back out again -- sometimes after a divorce, sometimes after years of frustration with less adventurous ways of meeting mates -- by nightclubs specially designed to put them at ease.
Decade is reminiscent of the Stork Club, where cocktails, dining and dancing all came under one roof. Beneath a flattering amber glow, patrons can enjoy a dinner of pan-seared salmon or braised lamb shank in an upstairs dining room that overlooks the dance floor. There is a private dining room in a 4,000-bottle wine cellar, and a room with private humidors for regular customers, at the top of the winding staircase.
"If you've been in a 20-something singles bar, you know that's no place for a grown-up," said Pepper Schwartz, a professor of sociology at the University of Washington in Seattle. "Quite honestly, you wouldn't want to compete in visual attractiveness with people in their 20's and 30's, who are arguably at the height of good looks and good bodies."
In New York City, besides Decade, on First Avenue, in the shadow of the Queensboro Bridge, the over-35 crowd is hanging out at the popular Rhythm Revue Dance Party at the Roseland Ballroom in midtown, a giant monthly high school reunion of sorts that plays 50's, 60's and 70's music for some 2,000 enthusiasts, who remember the words from the first time around. The racially diverse, sold-out crowd likes to get its groove on until the wee hours.
On a recent Saturday, the disk jockey Felix Hernandez, spinning songs like "Mickey's Monkey" by Smokey Robinson and the Miracles, "Cold Sweat" by James Brown, and "Heatwave" by Martha and the Vandellas received raves from the crowd that was jolted back to adolescence.
On the dance floor, crunchy granola met bargain basement chic as the partygoers danced the night away, including those who were emulating the look of Barry White and Chaka Khan. Some people even dug out their 60's radical clothes, including a man in a dashiki, who spent most of the evening cruising the periphery of the dance floor, giving off vibes that were too powerful for the women.
Those who prefer a more staid setting can nurse a glass of champagne at a growing number of revolving singles parties at private homes and upscale restaurants like Tavern on the Green and Maxine's, said Marion Smith, a New York City party planner, who has been in business for more than 20 years. In New York magazine, ads for baby boomer dating parties have doubled to about 30 in the last five years, Nancy J. Fedder, vice president of the magazine's classifieds, said.
Women are more likely to attend these kinds of soirees than men, which makes sense: women over 38 are more likely to be single than men in New York City. In 1996, the latest year for which figures are available from the United States Census Bureau, almost 59 percent of the single baby boomers (born between 1946 and 1961) in the city were women, and just 41 percent men. That's partly because the mortality rate of men in this age group is higher than for women.
"It shows why women in this age group would be nervous about their chances of getting married," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College. "And some of the men who are left are likely to be gay, especially in New York."
Natalie Brody considered this phenomenon when she conceived Decade. "I designed this place with women in mind. I know what it's like to be a single, divorced mother," said Ms. Brody, who has since remarried. "I want women who come here to feel comfortable."
Through its music, Decade allows boomers to recapture the heady, free-love days of the 60's and 70's that evolved into the "disco inferno" nights of the 80's before the AIDS scare -- which essentially erased the singles scene. Studio 54 died. Dinner became the social thing to do in the 80's. Then after the stock market crash in 1987, which marked the beginning of a recession, people started to stay home and rent videos.
"I went to Studio 54," Ms. Brody said. "I'm typical of that era. I have created that environment for people to come with their memories."
While a sexual undercurrent permeates the air, the over-35 patrons who frequent Decade are certainly more cautious about dating than they were in their youth.
Take Alan Stone, for example, a smartly dressed 51-year-old businessman, who has been divorced for seven years and has two grown children. He should know better than to try to meet Mrs. Right at a bar, but he says Decade is different. It draws people who are interested in long-term relationships, he said.
"I was a Woodstock kid," he said. "It was always bell-bottom jeans and crazy shoes. I was down in the Village all spaced out. But you grow up. You get more mature. You have your children. You want a career. So, you tend to mellow out, not rush things."
Robert A. Bell, 52, an investment banker and real estate investor, who lives on the Upper East Side, is a regular at Decade.
"Decade has filled a void, created a niche for people 35 and older on the Upper East Side," he said. "By the time you reach 35, you are somewhat mature. Manners are somewhat expected. People aren't necessarily shy about saying exactly what they're looking for in a person."
Bobby Zarin, 51, a real estate investor and owner of Zarin Fabrics in downtown Manhattan, who is separated, said supper clubs like the Rainbow Room satisfy the refined tastes of some boomers, but it plays big band, not disco.
"Most clubs are like Life in the Village, which has a very crowded dance floor," he said. "They have V.I.P. rooms for stars and actresses, and you just sit back on a sofa and have drinks. At Decade, you have food, plenty of people in my age bracket that now have money to spend. This club is not dealing with kids who have no money. You have the music of my generation in a nice atmosphere."
Anna Glynn, 43, a real estate broker from Staten Island, was at Decade with three friends on a recent Saturday evening to celebrate her sale of a $335,000 house on Todt Hill. She said the atmosphere at Decade was female-friendly, meaning men who were looking for dates were not sizing them up like morsels of meat.
Ms. Glynn, who has been divorced for 12 years and has a 16-year-old daughter, said she planned to return to the club in the hopes of meeting a mate. "My friend met a man there six months ago," she said. "Now they're engaged. Why not come back? Where else would I go?"

HEADLINE: INVESTING IN EUROPE: THE STRATEGIST;
New Currency, New Opportunities

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
FROM his vantage point as the chief investment officer of Deutsche Bank, Hanspeter Ackermann sees expanding opportunities for investors in a unifying Europe. As portfolio manager of the bank's closed-end New Germany fund, a $665 million growth fund invested primarily in midsize German companies, Mr. Ackermann is deploying money to pursue some of those opportunities. And as a Swiss citizen, he sees firsthand the significance of being inside or outside the euro club. SHARON R. KING
 
Q. How will investing in Europe change as a result of the creation of the single European currency?
A. The top-down style of selecting stocks, where you analyze country, industry and then go down to the stock level, probably becomes irrelevant. The opposite of that is a bottom-up manager, which basically is our style. We really don't look at macro themes, but much more company-specific data.
The concept of the country fund itself at some point will probably have to be wider. I can imagine that some funds might consider changing to a more European-based fund.
Q. How should American investors be thinking about the part of their portfolio that they will invest in a changing Europe?
A. Before, you had different countries, like Germany and France, individually fighting for market share. They all looked insignificant relative to a large country like the United States. Now this is changing. You have a major competitor -- let's just call it Europe. It has a much more powerful industrial base. It will not be inhibited by any cross-border taxation or inefficiencies.
What we're going to see here is a major structural change, much higher efficiency. I think that there will probably be more money allocated to Europe than in the past.
Q. What about countries that remain outside the monetary union?
A. For a country like Britain, it's probably less of an issue to be in or out, because it's a much larger economy with much less dependence on Europe. The U.K. has had more cross-border alliances with the United States than with Europe, so it will be easier for the U.K. to stand outside and to remain outside.
In the case of Switzerland, I see difficulties for that country to stay out and to compete with the border restrictions.
I'm not sure how much the financial sector will be affected, but you could see some impact mainly from the currency translation on other manufacturing sectors.
Right now the Swiss franc is relatively strong, and that's obviously damaging the export industry. But currency fluctuations may make it difficult for corporations to plan ahead. For the smaller European countries, sooner or later they're going to be forced into the same situation, where there will be an overwhelming economic case for joining the European Monetary Union. So, my guess will be they're all going to join over time.
Q. Will companies in countries outside of the monetary union have growth problems?
A. Yes. Distribution will be a problem.
I'm from Switzerland. When I walk through customs in Europe, they treat me like any other passport holder. But if you are part of the union, they basically just wave you through.
The same effect will probably occur on any distribution or licensing agreement. You would rather give the members of the union preferential treatment. So obviously there's an advantage to being part of the union.
Q. From an investment standpoint, will countries outside of the monetary union be riskier?
A. They should be. You're dealing with higher currency risk; then you have the economic risk of not gaining access to the same markets. There's even a risk of size, which means a liquidity risk.
Q. How do you pick stocks for the bank's funds?
A. There are five criteria. The most important is earnings momentum, to which we allocate roughly one-third of the investment decision-making.
Another third would be management. We look at the track record and the commitment to enhance the company's value. The final third is split between the financial strength of the company and its overall value versus the industry, the stock's history and the market itself.
Q. What are some stocks you own that fit your criteria?
A. One of our biggest holdings is Adidas. We have 8.6 percent of the fund in that company. They have acquired Salomon, the ski producer. When we look at other companies like Nike, or Puma in Europe, most of them have lost market share to Adidas-Salomon. And this is one of the few true growth stories in Germany, in our belief.
This company has excellent management. We see roughly 20 to 25 percent earnings growth consistently into the year 2000.
What's not included in that figure yet is the effects of the Salomon acquisition. Salomon has had its strength mainly in France, and Adidas has had its strength mostly in Germany. But now there should be a massive benefit from synergies.
We also like Continental A.G. We have about 4.3 percent of the fund in that. Continental has had compound earnings growth of about 25 percent for three years, and I think it has been overlooked by the market.
What's interesting is that they're really a leader in technology. There's huge free cash flow, and 1998 should be a turnaround year for the company as margins increase.
In Europe there are two other major tire companies, Pirelli and Michelin. In our view, there's no room for three major companies in Europe, so at some point you're going to see a merger or an alliance.
In Wella A.G., the beauty products company, we've seen a management turnaround. In the past, Wella's management has not been very open, and they came to a point in 1995 where the management disappointed and earnings fell by about 50 percent. That obviously shocked the market.
The perception was: We cannot trust that firm anymore. But the company did make changes within the management to come back and regain the confidence. I think we were one of the first to recognize that they are pursuing a much more shareholder-friendly attitude.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2069 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IN EUROPE: THE OVERVIEW;
A Joy Ride, So Far, in Euroland

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
AFTER a bout of winter blues that has dragged on for much of the last decade, European business has finally come back to life.
The best evidence is in the Continent's stock markets. From Spain to Germany, market indexes have outpaced those in the United States, with some climbing a third or more in just the last six months. 
 But the boom in Europe is more than a bull market. Europe is going through at least four historic financial transformations -- each of which is likely to alter the investment landscape for years to come, all of them likely to benefit investors:
 
CURRENCY UNION On Jan. 1, some 11 nations led by France and Germany will adopt the euro as a common currency, creating a unified economic entity almost as big as the United States. The euro looms behind every other major trend in Europe, accelerating the broad movement toward greater competition and free-market capitalism.
 
ECONOMIC CONVERGENCE For the first time this century, interest rates and inflation are now almost as low in Spain and Italy as they are in Germany. Thanks largely to the stringent economic requirements for joining the "euro club," governments across the Continent sharply reduced budget deficits and yoked themselves to austere monetary policies. Now the reward is at hand, in the form of faster growth and stable prices.
 
CORPORATE OVERHAUL Under growing competitive pressure worldwide, European conglomerates are embracing Wall Street's priorities: profits and the concept of "shareholder value." Companies that once were opaque to many investors are now listing their shares in New York and opening up their books. They are also slashing costs, selling off businesses that do not perform and merging like mad to shore up the rest.
The revamping has cost millions of European workers their jobs, and companies are still not as profitable, on average, as their American counterparts. But the renewed strength is measurable.
 
A STAMPEDE TOWARD STOCKS Perhaps the most profound change is the surge in equity investing by individual Europeans. As recently as two years ago, Europeans avoided stocks in favor of cautious securities like government bonds. Now they are flooding the stock markets with tens of billions of dollars, and most analysts expect the torrent to become even bigger in the next few years.
Analysts say the deluge has been driven by two big changes. One is lower interest rates, which have eroded returns on bonds. The second is the growing weakness in government-run pension programs, which are amassing mountains of commitments without the means to honor them. The result is a rush to mutual funds and a political trend toward promoting American-style private pension funds, which in turn become huge buyers of equities.
"You are looking at a set of circumstances that occur only a few times a century," said Phil De Cristo, head of operations in Continental Europe for Fidelity Investments. "We look at Europe as being our prime engine of growth over the next five years."
None of that means that Europe is a safe bet. For one thing, prices have climbed so far, so fast, that some markets may already be dangerously overvalued. For another, though most experts are increasingly confident that the new European Central Bank will establish stability and credibility for the euro, there is still ample room for problems. And even if the euro proceeds according to plan, it will create losers as well as winners.
Even so, European economic prospects are better than they have been in years. Total economic growth should reach 3 percent this year, possibly outpacing growth in the United States. Already, annual growth rates for Portugal, Spain and Finland are rising by about 4 percent, while Ireland is up by more than 8 percent.
"If you combine the prospects for economic growth, low budget deficits, low or negligible inflation and low interest rates, you have an economic proposition that is almost embarrassingly rich," said George Hodgson, head of equity research at the Dutch bank ABN-Amro.
 
Here Comes the Euro
Though the debut of the euro next year will have little direct impact on Europe's growth and prosperity, the preparations have had a huge effect on governments, companies and investors.
European political leaders reached the point of no return on May 3, when they formally decided to introduce the euro on Jan. 1 as the currency of 11 countries: Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Austria, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Finland.
Britain, Denmark and Sweden decided to stay out of the monetary union, though they met the qualifications to join. Greece was the only member of the European Union that could not meet the standards, and it hopes to join in several years.
The euro has already transformed economic policy across the Continent, as governments slashed budget deficits and generous social programs. In the process, inflation was nearly eliminated in historically turbulent countries like Spain, Italy and Portugal. Interest rates in these so-called "Club Med" countries have plunged by half in just two years. Not surprisingly, stock markets in Madrid, Lisbon and Milan have soared faster than almost any others in Europe in the last year.
The advent of the euro also promises to alter profoundly Europe's capital markets. Though the actual bills and coins will not begin to circulate until 2002, stocks and bonds will be traded in euros on Jan. 1. In effect, that creates a huge new European market for stocks and bonds that could eventually rival Wall Street in global importance.
"With the European Union, what we are talking about is redefining the idea of a home market," said Mr. De Cristo of Fidelity. "You are creating a massive new entity, which is Europe or Euroland."
For corporations trying to raise capital, that is both good and bad news. On the one hand, it makes it easier to tap a much bigger pool of potential investors. But it also exposes them to bruising new international comparisons.
According to Salomon Smith Barney, for example, the average return on equity for Italian companies was about 9.9 percent last year. By contrast, German companies earned about 12 percent and Finnish companies earned nearly 21 percent. (In the United States, return on equity averaged about 20 percent.)
 
A Scramble for Position
Competition is also heating up in the real world, the market for goods and services. Even though the European Union already permits almost entirely free trade between member nations, the babble of different currencies continues to cloak price differences between identical products in different markets. In Germany, a cottage industry of automobile "re-importers" buys up Mercedeses and Volkswagens in neighboring countries and then re-sells them to Germans at prices lower than those of German car dealers.
In the new Europe, the camouflage disappears and price pressures are expected to increase. "The single currency will put pressure on manufacturers," acknowledged Manfred Gentz, the chief financial officer of Daimler-Benz. "But the benefits far outweigh the disadvantages, and that kind of competition is healthy anyway."
It had better be, because the scramble for position in the pan-European market has contributed to an accelerated pace of mergers and acquisitions. Daimler-Benz's stunning deal to take over the Chrysler Corporation, the third-largest American auto maker, was merely the most visible of many huge deals, others of which have involved European banks, retailers, chemical companies and steel producers. In dollars, the value of European mergers jumped to $484 billion in 1997, from about $170 billion in 1994.
"The whole philosophy behind the single market was to enable European companies to enjoy the same economies of scale that companies in the United States and Japan were perceived to enjoy," said Mark Howdle, head of European equity strategy at Salomon Smith Barney.
When they are not merging, Europe's industrial conglomerates have become increasingly preoccupied with improving their performance. One example: Royal Philips Electronics, the Dutch manufacturer of consumer electronics, saw profits nearly evaporate two years ago as a result of several flopped products and a disastrous alliance with Grundig A.G., the troubled German manufacturer. After severing ties to Grundig and cutting 6,000 jobs, Philips has bounced back with high profits and a soaring stock price.
While individual stories do not add up to a trend, there are broader signs of improvement. Excluding Britain, Europe has seen corporate return on equity climb to more than 14 percent in 1998, from about 11 percent in 1996, according to Salomon Smith Barney.
But that remains well behind performance in the United States, and pessimists interpret the numbers to mean that Continental Europe remains shy about serious revamping.
Optimists, though, see the data as evidence that European companies still have much opportunity for rapid increases in profitability. "The party is only beginning," said Mr. Hodgson.
 
Winning Fabulous Prizes
"We call it the Stock Market Game, but we take it very seriously," said Peter Nemec, host and producer of "3 Sat Borse", Germany's most popular television show for investors. A lot of other people take it seriously, too.
Every Friday night over a six-month period, three investment advisers compete on Mr. Nemec's show, offering their best stock picks. Each adviser is given an imaginary pot of 100,000 German marks, and the one whose pot is biggest at the end of six months wins the game.
Once upon a time, few people were interested. But today, as many as a million viewers tune in. And when contestants tout their newest favorites, traders say, those stocks routinely surge on Monday morning.
"The public has finally discovered stocks," exulted Mr. Nemec, who could barely scrape together 100,000 viewers when he started in 1988. "When I go to shopping on Saturdays, the shopkeepers recognize me and start asking me what stocks they should buy."
It is difficult to overstate the change in mind-set among investors in Germany, and, indeed, across most of Continental Europe. European investors who till recently favored the safety of bonds are a key force behind the bull market. Last year, they poured more than $70 billion into stock-oriented mutual funds, up from just $10 billion in 1996. In Italy, where interest rates have plunged by more than half in the last year, $7 billion flowed into stock funds in April alone. Spanish investors have been on a similar rampage.
In Germany, private households have more than doubled their stock holdings in the last three years, to about $300 billion. When Deutsche Bank started a new mutual fund for small European stocks last April, investors contributed more than $300 million in the first few days.
Such lemming-like behavior often is observed in overripe markets. And Europe's mobilization of money does not necessarily mean that its markets will continue to soar.
"Liquidity can be a dangerous animal," Mr. Hodgson said. After all, in an electronic marketplace where trillions of dollars move around the world every day, mutual fund and pension managers routinely redirect their money when conditions change.
Analysts also note that stock valuations are at historic highs in both Europe and the United States. Spain's red-hot stock market has retreated about 10 percent in the last month, apparently because investors became convinced that stock prices had lost touch with reality.
"European valuations look very rich," said David Bowers, an equity strategist for Merrill Lynch in London. "There isn't much room for disappointment."
But there are echoes in Europe's boom that make many investors take heart. The flood of money, they say, is reminiscent of what happened in the United States during the early 1980's, when inflation finally subsided and the bull market began to take off. As in the United States, European investors have proved dissatisfied with diminishing bond returns and low interest rates on savings.
"People who have gotten along on gilt-edged bonds suddenly realize that they have to get their returns up," said Jonathan Freeman, an investment banker at Beeson Gregory, a London-based stock brokerage firm. "It is a new game for a lot of people, but I think you are going to see it for a long time."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IN EUROPE: THE CHOICES;
The Old World Gets a New Market Map

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WITH the birth of Euroland less than seven months away, it's high time for a deep rethinking of how American investors approach Europe.
Euroland is popular shorthand for the one-currency, 11-country monetary union and financial market area that will come into being on Jan. 1. It brings with it many promising opportunities for companies and investors alike. At the same time, it threatens to make some familiar investing strategies obsolete, and it raises the question of whether betting on just this single-currency market is a good idea. 
 Americans have shown a surging interest recently in Europe, with record flows of cash into European stock mutual funds. But the American financial services industry does not appear to be in a rush to change what it is now offering its investors and seems to be ignoring products like a Euroland index fund or a broad choice of actively managed Euroland mutual funds.
In fact, some argue that focusing on just the 10 active Euroland stock markets (Luxembourg has none) would mean missing good returns elsewhere in Europe.
"The Euroland concept, from a narrow perspective of creating funds, is a flawed one," said Nicholas Bratt, the head of the global equity group at Scudder Kemper Investments. "We would simply buy the best company we could find in Europe regardless of is specific domicile."
Investors face more questions than just geography. The role that indexes and index funds will play in the new region's markets is far from certain. And perhaps most important is the developing shift to a new investing style that selects stocks by sector rather than by country. Here is how these themes may play out in the new Europe.
 
Sectors vs. Nations
Before Euroland, European equity strategists began by picking a country, based on the forecast for interest rates, growth, earnings and inflation. Then they chose stocks in countries with the best outlook.
That system, analysts argue, will not be as effective now, because the new European Central Bank will try to keep interest rates and economic performance more in line for all Euroland countries.
That does not mean there will not be differences within Euroland, but it does mean that the era of making millions by exploiting them is over.
"Now it will be what sectors are most promising and what are the best stocks in that sector," said William P. Sterling, global strategist at BEA Associates, an investment management firm.
This new style spells trouble for popular closed-end single-country funds which, unless they adapt, will struggle to produce attractive returns, some analysts say.
"It slams the lid down on single-country funds," said Michael T. Porter, a country fund analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. (Article, page 6.)
Exchange-listed American depository receipts, another familiar way for Americans to invest in Europe, should remain attractive. Because they are priced in dollars, trade on American exchanges and conform to American accounting rules, they are easy for Americans to follow. (Unlisted A.D.R.'s trade over the counter and need not meet American standards.)
As always, an A.D.R.'s dollar value depends on movements in both the price of the underlying European stock and the value of the currency. Monetary union will eliminate the currency fluctuations among member nations, but their shared currency, the euro, will still rise and fall relative to the dollar.
Only a minority of top European companies trade as A.D.R.'s, however, and for some investors, the exposure they offer may not be broad enough.
For example, the Bank of New York compiles an index of 107 exchange-listed A.D.R.'s for Euroland, but many of the top 10 stocks in market capitalization for each country are missing. The bank is designing a product that would allow American investors to buy the A.D.R. index, but there are no details yet.
 
Seeking a Gauge
American investors love index funds, which simply buy all the stocks in a widely followed index like the Standard & Poor's 500. No Euroland analogue yet exists, and creating one will not be easy. One obstacle will be distinguishing for Americans between Europe and Euroland.
Dow Jones Indexes, along with the French, German and Swiss stock markets, has started a family of indexes for Europe and for Euroland collectively called Stoxx. Morgan Stanley Capital International introduced a 335-stock index for Euroland on April 30. Standard & Poor's, The Financial Times of London and Goldman, Sachs & Company have a 351-stock Eurobloc index, and The Financial Times and the London Stock Exchangehave a 100-stock index.
But these companies have been more successful in selling their indexes to fund managers and institutional investors as benchmarks for performance than in bringing index trading to American investors. None has a retail product ready to see daylight, though Dow Jones is promising one.
Suzanne M. Crosby, director of global marketing at Morgan Stanley, said, "Marketing Europe from a U.S. perspective is not a big revenue opportunity now."
Not even the Vanguard Group, the index fund leader, has plans for a Euroland fund. "We take a long-term view of things," said Brian S. Mattes, Vanguard's spokesman. "It must be a durable investment need, and it must go on for years." The company doesn't think Euroland passes the test.
Index investing by country can be done through the World Equity Benchmark Shares, or Webs, traded on the American Stock Exchange; they are based on Morgan Stanley country indexes. But no pan-European or Euroland Webs are planned.
 
Europe vs. Euroland
While there is hardly a rush to offer Euroland plays directly to American investors, plenty of analysts in the United States and Europe are trying to anticipate Euroland's effects and to spot ways to profit.
One is the index effect. The new indexes that aspire to become benchmarks include stocks that received scant attention in the country-picking era but will now be bought simply because of index membership.
"The visibility gainers are the ones in the smaller countries like Ireland, Austria, Portugal and Belgium," said Mark Howdle, European equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in London.
Euroland will also provoke major shifts in existing portfolios, analysts argue. Money managers in specific European countries who view Euroland as a single market will de-emphasize domestic stocks and buy across borders. This shift, which seems to have begun, will move prices of many issues.
Ian Scott, the European equity strategist at Lehman Brothers in London, noted in a recent report that the weighting for German stocks in a Euroland index would be around 27 percent, but by his estimate, German institutions and money managers now have 70 percent of their assets in German equities.
"On this evidence, there is plenty of scope for German institutions to diversify their portfolios," he wrote.
Some analysts argue that smaller-company stocks will be hurt most, as they are sold by money managers to make room for bigger stocks from other countries.
Murali Ramaswami, global head of equities derivative research at Lehman Brothers, said that while European stocks in general were becoming more sensitive to industry factors than to country factors, some companies and sectors would continue to be country-sensitive. He found commercial banks in France, Germany, Italy and Spain to be in that category.
Conversely, he said, the most industry-sensitive stocks varied from country to country: property and casualty insurance in France; mining, metals and minerals in Germany, and automobiles and utilities in Italy.
An increase in cross-border mergers within Euroland will also buoy some stocks, analysts predict, as consolidation picks up speed in oil, construction and -- especially in Italy -- in financial services.
Consumers taking advantage of monetary union to travel and to buy second homes may help some Euroland companies. On the other hand, the simplification of cross-border comparison shopping may hurt profits of airlines, retailers and brand-name goods makers accustomed to tailoring their prices from country to country.
But analysts point out that these factors do not add up to a night-and-day difference between investment opportunities inside and outside Euroland. American mutual fund managers seem to prefer Europe to Euroland as a playing field in both stocks and bonds.
Analysts agree that the unified Euroland government bond market will be larger and more liquid than the present array of national markets. But many say it is not an attractive bet right now, while potentially more enticing markets for corporate bonds and junk bonds will take time to develop.
Peter Askew, executive vice president of Rowe Price-Fleming International in London, said fixed-income investors would do best in a broader European or international bond fund that can take advantage of European opportunities outside Euroland.
Some analysts are betting on Greece, which hopes to join the union in the second round a few years from now. The required sharp cuts in Greek interest rates would mean big capital gains for bondholders, in the kind of "convergence play" that paid off handsomely as Italy and others prepared for Euroland's birth. (Article, page 7.)
N. Graham Allen, the managing director for global fixed-income at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles, likes Britain, the biggest European player not in Euroland, for the same reason; he thinks Britain will decide to join before too long.
Equity analysts also say it is difficult to ignore Britain. A Euroland stock fund, Mr. Bratt of Scudder Kemper said, "omits the largest stock market in Europe, and that seems undesirable to me." He said his company's closed-end New Europe fund also includes emerging markets like Poland and Hungary that he would be loath to exclude by investing solely in Euroland.
Stock markets are performing well across Europe, so for American investors, the question of Euroland versus all of Europe may seem academic. The important choice is whether to invest in Europe, by any definition, or not.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers.
To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age. 
 Among the winners were three whose work involves innovative perspectives on money matters: a rancher who has taken steps to preserve his Southwestern way of life; a geographer who studies how labor and political issues help mold a cultural landscape, and an economist who aims to apply the ideals of feminism and the left to calculations of productivity.
 
Nancy Folbre
Melding the Political And the Economic
Nancy Folbre has made a career as a feminist and an economist -- and of showing that the two titles are not mutually exclusive.
Since earning her doctorate in economics at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst in 1979, Ms. Folbre, 45, has focused much of her research on nonmarket work, like child-rearing and caring for elderly relatives. She contends that these unpaid roles, often filled by women, should be included when determining a nation's productivity.
Ms. Folbre, now a professor at the university, defines this and other "care work" -- like teaching and nursing -- as largely "first-name-basis" jobs that involve helping others in a close way. Because such work is not valued economically, "care is being driven out of business," she said.
What results is more than just a scarcity of people to fill those unpaid and underpaid roles, but, she argues, a reduction in the quality of the work.
"We've made a lot of progress in getting people to recognize the worth of quantitative work," she said. "But also, what is the quality of it? Is it rich, is it careful, is it high quality? Economists should care about quality as much as quantity."
Nurses, for example, say they have so many patients that "they no longer have time on their job to hold people's hands," she said. She considers quality care a "public good" and likens it to a clean environment: "Everyone enjoys and benefits from it, but it's hard to get people to actually pay for it."
News of the $280,000 award came while she was in Europe attending a conference of the International Association for Feminist Economics, a group she helped found. The European Union and other nations already have plans to survey the worth of nonmarket work; in that regard, she said, "the United States is lagging behind."
Ms. Folbre said she would use some of the grant to support the Center for Popular Economics, a nonprofit group where she is a staff economist that runs workshops for advocates of social change. Its mission of economic literacy is in accord with her conviction that an economy can be changed at the grass-roots level.
"If I didn't believe that, I wouldn't bother," she said. In fact, her first project with the windfall will not be a scholarly work but a revision of her popular book, "The New Field Guide to the U.S. Economy" (New Press, 1995) a cartoon-enhanced review meant to provide intellectual ammunition for people with a liberal bent.
Such individuals, she said wryly, need to be able to refute comments like " 'That's very nice and very sweet but that's not efficient; we can't compete in a global economy if we spend money on health care and education and welfare.' "
Ms. Folbre said: "It's important to give people a vocabulary of economics to be able to engage in debate." JULIE FLAHERTY

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL;
Hospital Nurses' Vote Ends an 18-Month Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
After an 18-month labor dispute, Long Island College Hospital and its nurses' union have agreed on a new contract. The 600 nurses voted to ratify the deal late last week.
Elaine Charpentier, a lead negotiator for the union, the New York State Nurses Association, characterized the contract as a compromise. It offers the nurses better job security and the hospital some givebacks. 
 "The economics are sparse," said Ms. Charpentier, referring to the compensation the nurses will receive. "But with this contract, the nurses worked with the hospital to help it out financially, and the hospital did its part to insure their jobs." For example, the new contract will minimize the hospital's power to lay off nurses, allowing no more than 15 dismissals between now and the contract's expiration in June 2000.
According to Ms. Charpentier, the hospital had planned to lay off as many 180 nurses in the future.
But the contract also includes concessions by the nurses, such as suspending for two years their annual $900 length-of-service, or step, salary increase. That suspension will save the hospital -- and cost the nurses -- an estimated $1.5 million.
The contract, much of which is retroactive to January 1997, includes a variety of other provisions, such as early-retirement incentives for nurses with 20 years of experience.
In a statement, Long Island College Hospital said, "We are pleased to bring this matter to an amicable resolution."
The new agreement came about shortly after Alvin Blyer, the regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, issued a complaint that the hospital had negotiated in bad faith by withholding cost-cutting information during contract talks. The hospital has denied the claims in the complaint, issued June 4. But on Friday, Mr. Blyer said he had signed off on a request by the nurses' union to withdraw the complaint, averting a potentially acrimonious and costly hearing on it in August.
The previous contract for the nurses at the 551-bed hospital expired in January 1997. The hospital, after declaring an impasse in the negotiations in May 1997, imposed a number of cost-cutting measures that it said it needed to stay solvent. These measures, which are invalidated by the new contract, included the reduction of nurses' starting salaries by $4,500. RICHARD WEIR

New Contract
Starting salary: $45,500, rising to $51,500 after 15 months.
Step increase suspended for two years.
A single 3 percent pay increase in January 1999.
A $750 bonus for all nurses on July 1
Maximum of 15 layoffs through June 2000

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Creating a Cosmic Map Worthy of Dr. Seuss

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

 BODY:
COSMOLOGISTS intent on understanding the origin of the universe are faced with an insurmountable problem: there is no way to do a controlled experiment. They can speculate all they like about how the cosmos unfolded from the great explosion called the big bang, but they can't directly test their ideas by growing universes in a laboratory, nurturing them under different conditions and seeing which ones live or die.
Evolutionary biologists are faced with a similar problem -- they can't rewind the tape of history and study the various ways life could have marched forth from the primordial soup. But they are blessed with a powerful fallback. They can study a variety of creatures and, through the process of induction, piece together a persuasive story. 
 There can be no such thing as a cosmological anatomist, jumping from universe to universe gathering data on how different ones behave. With no real universes to study other than their own, cosmologists have turned to the next best thing. They build computer simulations of the original fireball and watch it explode. Last week, at the American Astronomical Society meeting in San Diego, Dr. August Evrard of the University of Michigan described the biggest simulation yet: the entire visible universe, 10 billion light years across, captured in a Cray computer at the Max Planck Society's computing center in Garching, Germany.
Artificial life (simulating living creatures) and artificial intelligence (simulating minds) have been joined by artificial cosmology, the art of creating a universe in a box.
With money coming from many sources here and abroad, Dr. Evrard said, it was hard to put a dollar figure on the project. "Whatever the exact numbers are," he added, "I'm confident that the taxpayers in all countries involved will feel they got the whole universe for a pretty fair price -- especially when compared to the cost of building observatories."
In a mere three days, 10 billion years of cosmic history can be replayed inside the supercomputer, tended by an international team called the Virgo Consortium. What results are colorful computer images showing how the matter in the universe may have been distributed at various times in its life. Each of these snapshots occupies 28 billion bytes of memory and can be compressed to a mere 16 billion bytes, small enough to fit on a few hard drives. One can almost imagine tiny galaxies, solar systems and planets with creatures clinging to them, like Dr. Seuss's Whos of Whoville, faintly calling: "We are here! We are here!"
 
Playing God
If only the grain were so fine. The artificial cosmos is more like the rough simulations of the Earth people have mounted on stands in their offices and dens. By giving the globe a spin in the wrong direction, one can play God and make the sun rise in the west. Though one can see continents and countries and a few of the largest cities and mountains, there are no buildings, people or trees.
The smallest things in the new man-made universe are rather coarse lumps of matter called particles, each representing 10 galaxies. Anything more detailed is washed away. No matter how hard you squint, you aren't going to find the Earth, the Sun, or even the Milky Way. The idea is to concentrate on the big picture, by studying how tiny ripples in the embryonic universe could have been amplified into the sprawling structures that appear today.
In fact, an earthling, digitized and projected into the artificial world, wouldn't see a thing -- not even starlight. For reasons of economy, all that was actually simulated was the invisible dark matter, currently believed to make up as much as 90 percent of creation. In the grand scheme of things, we creatures of luminous matter, the very inventors of the simulation, were deemed irrelevant.
But as computer power and memory size increase, the universe will inevitably be captured with a finer mesh, becoming more detailed and inclusive. One can imagine increasing the resolving power until each separate galaxy snaps into focus. Make the simulation finer still and the swirls and arms would emerge. Then the individual stars would come out. Solar systems would congeal from the stellar dust.
Why stop at the planetary level? The cosmologist Frank Tipler has proposed, to the consternation of most of his colleagues, that life and intelligence are a necessary ingredient in the shaping of the universe. A true simulation would thus have to include simulated creatures -- artificial life.
 
Calling M.C. Escher
So let the simulated atoms cooked up in the simulated stars form molecules and cells and plants and animals. If their nervous systems evolve enough excess brain power, the inhabitants will need something deep to think about. At some point they might start wondering about the world around them, and start building artificial spaceships and probes. They might even mimic creation on their own simulated computers.
Several years ago, the computer scientist Edward Fredkin came up with the entertaining notion that our own universe is a simulation running on some kind of giant computer. Why not have within it the simulation of another universe, and within that the simulation of another, and on and on -- a cybernetic house of cards? Pull the plug on one universe and all those it is supporting come crashing down.
Cosmologists like to tell the story about the little old lady interrupting a lecture by the great thinker, who is earnestly describing the scientific view of the cosmos. In some versions it's Bertrand Russell, in others Albert Einstein. "You've got it all wrong, sonny," the woman says. "The Earth is sitting on the back of a giant turtle."
The scientist, amused, answers, "Oh, and what is that turtle standing on?"
"Another turtle," she says. And before he can interrupt with the obvious objection, she adds: "Don't waste your time asking. It's turtles all the way down."
That's the problem with models of the universe -- it's so tempting to mistake them for the real thing.

HEADLINE: JUNE 7-13;
Abraham Lincoln, Deadbeat

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
House Republicans last week excoriated their fellow Americans as a bunch of deadbeats casually running up debts and then disingenuously pleading bankruptcy to wipe their slates clean.
A record 1.4 million people declared bankruptcy last year -- evidence, lawmakers said, that a tighter law and more personal responsibility were in order. 
 The Republicans did not mention that one of their party's most prominent members was a self-declared "insolvent debtor" who would surely have filed for bankruptcy had the current laws been available to him.
In 1832 a young man named Abraham Lincoln bought a small general store in New Salem, Ill., with a partner. On credit, they acquired the inventory of other nearby stores.
The economy was booming, but the two prairie entrepreneurs could not make a go of it and began sliding into debt.
Lincoln sold his share, but when his partner died he became liable for $1,000 in debts, according to Gerald Prokopowicz, a scholar at the Lincoln Museum in Fort Wayne, Ind.
Creditors hauled Lincoln into court, and the sheriff seized his only assets -- his survey equipment and his horse. The store, in Lincoln's phrase, "winked out."
As a budding state legislator in 1835, Lincoln introduced a bill to provide relief for insolvent debtors. But it didn't pass, and Honest Abe was still repaying his debts "well into the 1840's," said Kim Bauer, curator at the Illinois State Historical Library.
It was so onerous that Lincoln called it "my national debt." KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Camera Angles;
What China Sees in Clinton

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
THE Chinese have an old saying, describing donkey dung, that pokes fun at their culture's obsession with appearances: "Shiny on the outside, smelly within."
Looking good is important, in other words, even when a situation is imperfect. 
 President Clinton's visit to China, scheduled to begin June 25, is likely to be about appearances more than anything else. No real diplomatic breakthrough looks possible, since the United States and China remain far apart on key issues like Taiwan and human rights. With the Clinton Administration extra sensitive to recent accusations that it sold out national security for business interests, no big commercial deals are likely to be showcased either.
 
Showtime
That's fine with China's leaders, who care about appearances above all. Even without substance, the first visit by an American President since the 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square is tremendously important to Communist Party bosses in Beijing, largely for the way it symbolizes approval of their rule. Playing host to the President of the United States, and doing it well, shores up the legitimacy of Chinese leaders before their own people.
For this reason, some of China's critics in Washington have called on Mr. Clinton to avoid, at the very least, participating in a welcoming ceremony in Tiananmen Square -- the traditional red-carpet welcome that Beijing insists upon. Many members of Congress argue that China should be punished for its abysmal record on human rights and arms proliferation. In response, Mr. Clinton made the case last week that sticking to a policy of cooperation and engagement with China offers more reward than risk.
But both sides of this debate gloss over the larger and far more important reality: contacts between the two countries are now primarily characterized by a deeply enmeshed commercial relationship -- not to mention an array of educational and cultural exchanges -- that leaves the two governments to play a steadily smaller and less significant role.
In 1972, President Nixon's visit to China was critically important to any Chinese or American citizen who wanted to do business or even travel between the two countries. In 1998, whether or not President Clinton travels to China will have little noticeable effect on the billions of dollars of goods now traded in each direction, or on the hundreds of thousands of Chinese and Americans who travel between the two countries to work, study and teach. To them, President Clinton's visit represents little more than an affirmation of an economic reality that is streaking far ahead of politics.
The countless Chinese consumers who sip Coca-Cola and wear Motorola pagers reflect the commerical ties between China and the United States that are here to stay, no matter what Congress or the White House has to say. Even if the United States were to revoke China's normal or "most favored nation" trading status -- a step no Administration has taken since it was first granted in 1980 -- the only effect would be higher American tariffs on some Chinese exports, while American sales within China would no doubt continue to roar ahead.
 
Smile
With this economic reality as the backdrop, and with Mr. Clinton's visit concerned with gloss over substance, he and his Chinese hosts next week will likely concentrate on camera angles.
The ideal, for Chinese leaders, is a seamless cascade of televised images showing Mr. Clinton in one picturesque Chinese setting after another, alternately wowed by the majesty of the Great Wall and charmed by the humble kindness of villagers -- and, most important, standing shoulder to shoulder with President Jiang Zemin, as they look out on the world as equals.
The nightmare, in the Chinese view, would be an unexpected disruption of Mr. Clinton's trip by political dissidents. That could be interpreted by the Chinese people as an embarrassing sign that their leaders are not in control.
That nightmare actually occurred when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union visited China in May 1989. Student demonstrations engulfed Beijing in the weeks before his arrival, and during his five-day visit protests spread to cities throughout the nation. It wasn't until weeks later that the democratic clamorings were brutally subdued.
Both dissidents and the authorities are mindful of the Gorbachev experience. Dissidents in China know that when a major foreign leader comes to town, the authorities are loath to crack heads in public, making it a good time to get out a message. And the authorities know they know. So China's security services are now working overtime to snuff out any flicker of dissidence well before Mr. Clinton's arrival.
Such repression and the overall importance that China's leaders attach to the Clinton visit are measures of how insecure they are, not only regarding their own authority, but also regarding China's place in the world. China plays an odd role on the world stage, wielding veto power at the United Nations in a way that the West generally views as responsible, even as Beijing is having a hard time shedding its reputation as a rogue inclined to irresponsibly traffic in arms and missile technology.
China's ambiguous international stature may reflect a deeper conflict in its sense of itself. Despite the nation's size and growing economic power, its leaders mix an ancient sense of superiority with a more modern realization that China is inferior to most of the world in terms of wealth and technology.
Mr. Clinton's visit is indeed largely symbolic. But looking good is important when the situation is imperfect.
