HEADLINE: China Officially Lifts Filter on Staggering Pollution Data

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 13

 BODY:
For 20 years, local officials carefully measured this city's air pollution levels and equally carefully hid the results -- fearing that the truth might tarnish the capital's image or lead to social unrest. This continued even as Beijing's famously blue sky turned ever more gray and its surrounding hills disappeared behind an acrid mist.
So it seemed a small miracle when, on Feb. 28, Beijing joined 38 other Chinese cities that have started to issue weekly air quality reports in the last year. In newspapers and on television, they parade a sometimes eclectic mix of statistics -- from levels of nitrous oxides produced by car exhausts to the concentration of tiny particles from coal burning in the air. And Chinese citizens for the first time have hard information on the air they breathe. 
 Despite technical flaws, the tangled mass of data has confirmed what many Western scientists have suspected and at times measured: that the air in China's cities is among the most polluted in the world, and contains the highest levels of pollutants harmful to health. Recent research suggests that bad air causes 178,000 premature deaths a year.
The severity of the pollution, now openly acknowledged by the Government, has propelled environmental issues onto the agenda of the Chinese-American summit meeting that is to take place later this month. Chinese officials say they are eager to have Washington's technical help in the battle for cleaner air.
But more than that, the Government's candor has created a new political dynamic between the Government and its people, feeding an environmental consciousness.
"The air is bad -- you can read it in the newspapers," said Zhang Jiyan, from her roadside bathing-suit stand in downtown Beijing. "Look, you can't even see tall buildings a few streets from here."
People who six months ago might have peered out the window and seen fog, or wu, now realize that it is pollution, or wuran. And their anger in turn has encouraged local governments to develop more ambitious, if not always realistic, efforts -- for example, requiring car owners to install catalytic converters.
"Releasing the numbers is a revolutionary concept for the people and the Government," said Lu Xinyuan, of the State Environmental Protection Agency. "We were worried that the people would complain that air pollution is too serious. Instead, the consciousness of people has been raised. And they feel the Government trusts them with the facts, so we are gaining points by doing this."
Others suggest another motive: the weekly barrage of frightening statistics has generated popular support for otherwise unpalatable Government moves, like shutting down inefficient state-owned enterprises, with the inevitable loss of jobs.
"Why are they being so open about this?" asked one Western diplomat. "It's because it dovetails with their economic agenda. This way when the factory gets closed, the people want it to be closed, even though the real reason it has to be closed is not for pollution but for economics."
These days in Beijing, everyone is complaining about the air. Since the weekly air quality reports began three months ago, the city's air has ranked 4 on its 1-to-5 pollution scale (5 being the worst) every week but two, said Yu Xiaoxuan, deputy director of the Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau.
Level-4 pollution can have serious health effects on people with heart or lung problems, and could make others feel uncomfortable as well.
Many Beijing residents suspect that the truth is even worse -- after all, theirs is a leadership that until a few years ago shaved degrees from summer temperatures in news reports in the name of morale. Elderly people who used to exercise outside in the early morning -- when pollution is usually worst -- are postponing their exercises until later in the day, and "fresh air" tours of the countryside have become popular.
At the Beijing Children's Research Clinic, mothers carrying hacking children and newly prescribed medicine are quick to complain. Two-year-old Long Fei "often gets sick with colds and infections," said his mother, who identified herself only as Lin. "You see it on TV. The air is not good, that's the problem."
According to the World Bank, 5 of the world's 10 most polluted cities are in China, and despite some recent successful efforts to combat the problem, pollutant levels are two to five times the World Health Organization guidelines for safe exposure.
"China is still among the world's most polluted countries," said Qu Geping, chairman of the National People's Congress's Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Committee. "Among 600 cities, 70 to 80 percent can't even meet our own air standards."
For years now, Mr. Qu has campaigned for greater openness in this field, prodding China's cities to abide by a generally ignored 1987 law that required them to release data about their air. But last year the State Council stepped up the pressure, and starting with Nanjing in May 1997, dozens of cities have now complied.
Still, many experts worry about the reliability of the reports, according to Todd Johnson, an environmental economist at the World Bank, since local environmental bureaus are often understaffed, relying on old equipment and techniques.
Experts also find the reports sometimes incomplete or confusing. A number of cities, including Beijing, report only some of the vast number of statistics they measure. And many report air quality according to an "air pollution index," with scores derived from a formula that combines harmful and innocuous pollutants in such a complex manner that even specialists have trouble interpreting its significance.
Dr. Wang Lihua, a professor of environmental health at Beijing Medical University, and her former student Dr. Xiping Xu, now at the Harvard School of Public Health, have been studying pollution in Beijing more than 15 years. They say they do not entirely understand how Beijing determines daily rankings.
"I don't always trust the data," Dr. Xu said. "But in the end, whether the number is 100 or 150 is not so important -- we know it's very high. And this is a very good step to publish the information, to let people gain knowledge."
The most serious pollutant in most Chinese cities is tiny airborne particles, measured as total suspended particles, produced primarily by the burning of coal and, increasingly, car exhausts. Mexico City's notoriously bad air contains different types of pollutants, mostly small chemical compounds that are not thought to be as dangerous to health.
In China, coal also produces sulfur dioxide, the source of acid rain. Cars add nitrous oxides.
In terms of suspended particles, "Chinese cities are among the worst in the world -- that's just a fact," said Mr. Johnson, the World Bank official. "Because they are so dependent on coal, I can't think of any city in the world that's as bad as the worst cities in China."
In China, which has only limited access to oil and natural gas, coal powers huge factories, fuels restaurant stoves and heats homes. In Beijing, where coal produces 80 percent of energy, mountains of it fill courtyards, especially in winter, and bicycles towing carts piled with coal briquettes are everywhere.
On top of that, there are 1.3 million cars registered in Beijing today, compared with 200,000 a decade ago. And the average Chinese car produces 10 to 15 times the exhaust of its American counterpart.
Medical researchers have begun to document the toll that air pollution is taking on human health here.
In studies, Dr. Xu of Harvard and colleagues in China have found that urban air pollution contributes to increased deaths, premature births and low birth weight. They have also found that breathing Beijing's air depresses lung function in otherwise healthy individuals and that on polluted days, the number of hospital visits skyrockets.
"In a city like Beijing, you've got 20,000 excess deaths at the end of the year," Mr. Johnson said. (Beijing's population is 12 million.) "You throw in a few badly polluted days and the old person dies a few months earlier than otherwise."
The asthma rate has reached 5 percent in some areas around factories. Specialists at Beijing Children's Hospital now see 60 wheezing, coughing children a day.
Dr. Hu Yiji, the hospital's director, said he believed secondhand cigarette smoke was the biggest culprit, but acknowledged pollution as a problem. "We tell parents if they smoke, to quit," he said. "And then we advise them to take the kids to the suburbs when they can."
The central Government recently announced plans to spend 1.2 percent of the G.N.P. on pollution control and is desperately seeking an alternative to coal. It is pumping natural gas to Beijing from Shaanxi Province. It is negotiating with Russia to import gas. It also has plans to close down urban factories and convert coal into electricity near the coal mines to keep the pollution out of the cities.
At best, these changes could reduce reliance on coal to about 65 percent in 2000, from 75 percent this year. But they could have a big impact on urban air pollution.
Cars have proved an easier problem to tackle. As of Jan. 1, Beijing has banned the sale of leaded gas, and as of next year all new cars must have catalytic converters. The police recently started spot checks of tailpipe emissions, and fewer than 40 percent of cars tested on the first day passed. Polluting owners have their licenses revoked and are instructed to install catalytic converters, at a cost of about $100.
Beijing has long required yearly emission checks, but enforcing such laws is difficult. In a poor country like China, there is persistent tension between wanting cleaner air and not having the money to pay for it.

LENGTH: 1443 words

HEADLINE: Lilco Is Dead, but Its 'Curse' Lives in Uproar Over Officials' Payouts

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 13

 BODY:
Like St. George slaying the dragon, Gov. George E. Pataki finally vanquished the dreaded beast that had terrorized Long Island's economic and political landscape for decades. The Long Island Lighting Company, notorious for the highest electricity bills in the continental United States, was gone at last.
Or so it seemed on May 28, when Lilco officially went out of business, sold its electricity service to the state and merged its remaining operations with Brooklyn Union Gas to form the Marketspan Corporation. 
 But then, like a surprise ending in a horror movie, the monster sprang back to life for one more rampage -- with the revelation that Lilco had dished out $67 million in special payments to 26 executives, including $42 million for its unpopular chairman, Dr. William J. Catacosinos, who is continuing in the same role at Marketspan.
Politicians across the state were outraged, led by the angry and embarrassed Governor himself. Mr. Pataki denounced the payments as "outrageous" and "disgraceful" violations of the takeover agreements. He demanded that Dr. Catacosinos (whom he now pointedly called "Mr.") return the money and be removed as Marketspan's chairman.
"It's the old Lilco curse -- it never seems to go away," said Richard M. Kessel, who started fighting the utility as a consumer advocate 25 years ago. He now heads the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency that took over the electricity service.
While the current furor is capturing statewide attention, it is but the latest chapter in the seemingly unending saga of Lilco.
Over the years, the Lilco phenomenon even drew the attention of the White House: President George Bush once urged the opening of the company's nuclear power plant at Shoreham. That ill-fated project was destined to become the only nuclear plant in the nation to be completed but abandoned before it produced power commercially.
Lilco made history right up to the end. The recent state takeover entailed the nation's largest municipal bond issue -- $7 billion -- more than double the previous record. And the bond sale itself has touched off a Federal investigation into how the underwriters were selected.
Founded in 1911 from the merger of several smaller companies, Lilco grew to become one of the nation's biggest -- and most troubled -- utilities. Its service area extended from the Rockaways in Queens through Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and it served a population of nearly three million.
When Lilco expired, it had about 5,000 employees. Under a no-layoff policy, all of them transferred to Marketspan and never missed a day's pay.
But only Dr. Catacosinos and the other 25 executives got special payments, which were authorized by the board of directors and defended as their contractual entitlements. The payments are being investigated by the State Attorney General's office, the Public Service Commission and the State Assembly, and are being challenged in shareholder lawsuits.
Dr. Catacosinos has repeatedly declined to respond to telephone requests for interviews. The payments have been defended by Joseph McDonnell, a Marketspan spokesman and a former Lilco executive who also received a payment. He said they were proper under the executives' contracts with the company.
For Lilco's 96,000 stockholders (about a third of the individual share owners were Long Islanders), the company provided roller-coaster investment chills and thrills.
When Dr. Catacosinos took over in 1984, the company's stock price had dipped to $3.75. By the time the company was disbanded, it had climbed to $29.81.
The roots of Lilco's troubles date to the mid-1960's, when company officials began their plan to build Shoreham.
That project, originally estimated at $65 million, eventually cost 100 times more -- about $6.5 billion. (As in most other Lilco issues, not everyone agrees on what the project actually cost.)
Public opposition to the Shoreham plant grew over environmental, safety and cost concerns. At one point, hundreds of suburbanites rallied at the plant's gates, and protesters scaled the fences. Reflecting the mood of voters, politicians won elections railing against Lilco.
Despite such opposition, Lilco forged ahead with construction and won a Federal license to operate the plant.
In the end, public opposition was so great that Lilco struck a deal with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1989. The company closed the plant and sold it to the state for $1. In return, Lilco was guaranteed rate increases to pay off the Shoreham debt.
But that debt became an albatross to Lilco. Its electricity rates soared, costing the typical homeowner $100 a month and cutting into the bottom line of local businesses.
Even as they attacked Lilco, local politicians added to its costs by jacking up the assessments on its power plants, including the one at Shoreham. Lilco passed the high property taxes on to its customers in their monthly bills.
As exasperation with Lilco grew, the State Legislature created the power authority to confront the problem. Under Governor Cuomo, the authority made several unsuccessful bids to take over the company.
In 1994, Mr. Pataki -- who had attacked the idea of a state takeover -- ousted Mr. Cuomo, helped by strong support on Long Island.
Mr. Pataki had a change of heart on the takeover issue, however, after a court ordered officials in Suffolk County to refund Lilco more than $1 billion in excess taxes levied on Shoreham. The refunds could have meant huge tax increases in Suffolk.
The purpose of the takeover deal was not only to lower electricity bills, but also to prevent those tax increases, sparing Suffolk officials -- most of them Republicans like the Governor -- much political pain.
After the takeover, the power authority immediately cut electricity rates by an average of 20 percent. It also plans to send refund checks of $101 to each customer in Suffolk and $232 to each customer in Nassau and the Rockaways.
Much of the savings is due to the authority's use of low-cost, tax-free bonds for financing.
Ralph Nader has called the deal a prime example of "lemon socialism," meaning the use of public money to bail out private sector failures, and opponents see it as a giveaway to Lilco shareholders.
Critics say that because of the authority's plan to delay debt repayment, the rate cuts cannot be sustained.
They also contend that because the authority has long-term contracts for Marketspan to supply electricity and operate the old Lilco system, the monopoly has simply been locked in under a new guise.
Even in the latest Lilco chapter, the critics say the executive payments are a mere side issue to a multibillion-dollar folly. They blame Mr. Pataki -- not Dr. Catacosinos -- and say that the Governor's attacks on the payments were a pre-emptive strike to deflect charges that he was fooled by Lilco.
For the Governor and Mr. Kessel, the head of the power authority, "to express outrage and shock about the benefit package is totally disingenuous," said Jack Kulka, chairman of the Initiative for Competitive Energy, a coalition of opponents of the takeover. "The $67 million revelation proves they were both outsmarted by Catacosinos, so now they are practicing political damage control."
Assemblyman Paul E. Harenberg, who wrote the law creating the power authority, said: "Just last week they were all shaking hands, but unfortunately the Governor and Kessel were asleep at the switch while Catacosinos was robbing people blind. They ought to reopen the negotiations."
Mr. Kessel defends the deal, saying it will provide "the biggest across-the-board rate cut in the nation."
But he conceded that "the good news is temporarily overshadowed by Lilco's last act of greed."
And Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said: "Governor Pataki gave Lilco billions of dollars, and some of it found its way to Catacosinos's pocket. If there is somebody Long Islanders should be angry at, it is George Pataki, not Bill Catacosinos." Mr. Catacosinos's responsibility was to the shareholders, Mr. Shapiro added, "and he did a good job of that."
Many of Lilco's former customers are delighted to be rid of the company but are wary of the new arrangement, judging by random interviews.
As for Dr. Catacosinos, public hanging is one of the more polite suggestions customers made.
"I'm certainly glad Lipa took it over," said Randy Daub, a security chief from Oyster Bay, "but I'm very unhappy with Catacosinos and his $42 million. I'd be glad to see more of a rate cut, but anything was better than having Lilco. The service was fine, but the rates were outrageous."

HEADLINE: Speakers Stress Racial Healing At Service for Dragging Victim

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: JASPER, Tex., June 13

 BODY:
In an overflowing Baptist church where his small-town family shared pews with big-city politicians, James Byrd Jr. began his odyssey today from victim of a gruesome racial slaying to symbol of the nation's need for racial healing.
Speaker after speaker at Mr. Byrd's funeral said his death last Sunday -- which the authorities say came at the hands of three white men who beat him and dragged him in chains from a moving pickup truck, dismembering his body -- should bring whites and blacks together in outrage and determination to end racial violence. 
 "Dr. King would say that unearned suffering is redemptive, that there's power in the blood of the innocent," said the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has been at the side of the Byrd family for most of the week. "Brother Byrd's innocent blood alone could very well be the blood that changes the course of our country, because no one has captured the nation's attention like this tragedy."
Mr. Jackson said that Mr. Byrd had entered the pantheon of the nation's racial martyrs and victims, and he proposed that the town of Jasper erect a monument in his memory as a tangible protest against hate crimes.
Several of the politicians and national black leaders who spoke acknowledged that Mr. Byrd's family was uncomfortable with the idea of turning him into a national symbol, and would have preferred to have had a quieter service without the political rallying cries. But they said the need to invest this death with meaning was too great.
"We know, Clara, that you wanted to be left alone," said Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater, referring to one of Mr. Byrd's sisters, Clara Taylor. "But we can't. We have to be with you. We have to be with this family and we have to be here in Jasper. Because we can ill afford to have what has happened here happen any place else across this land."
The Byrd family had already given up its hope for a truly private funeral, although it did ban reporters and photographers from Greater New Bethel Baptist Church, where Mr. Byrd's father is a deacon and his mother a Sunday school teacher. Only 200 people could fit in the sanctuary, leaving 600 others to listen to a public-address system outside.
Most of the speakers -- including Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican, and Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat who serves as chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus -- had never met Mr. Byrd, an unemployed 49-year-old man whose ambles about this town of 8,000 made him a familiar figure to many of its black residents. Neither had many of the black mourners who came from around Texas, or the presidents of regional N.A.A.C.P. chapters, or advocates like the Rev. Al Sharpton from New York.
But the random brutality of Mr. Byrd's death seemed to strike both fear and a sense of responsibility in many black leaders, several of whom said any member of the community could have been similarly violated.
One of the few speakers who knew Mr. Byrd well was the pastor of the church, the Rev. Kenneth O. Lyons, who grew up across the street from the Byrd family in east Jasper. Alone among those who spoke, he declined to make his old neighbor into an explicit symbol, instead preaching an old-fashioned eulogy in answer to a question Mr. Byrd asked him long ago about the message of his church.
"We need to talk Jesus," Mr. Lyons said, to rousing responses from the audience inside and out. "We tried everything else, so brothers and sisters, we need to try Jesus." He made only an indirect reference to the violence of the crime when he reminded his listeners that Herod had beheaded John the Baptist.
There were several white residents at the funeral, and throughout the day, many townspeople wore yellow ribbons and kept their car headlights on. Flags in Jasper, which is about 30 percent black, flew at half staff at several shopping strips. But later in the day there was a reminder that not everyone was viewing Mr. Byrd's death with the resolute serenity asked for in the church.
About 15 black men dressed in paramilitary uniforms and carrying rifles and shotguns marched from the sheriff's office into Mr. Byrd's neighborhood, urging black residents to arm themselves.The group of gang members, followers of the Nation of Islam and members of an organization calling itself the New Black Panthers, was led by Khallid Muhammad of New York, a former aide to Minister Louis Farrakhan. They drew little attention from Mr. Byrd's neighbors, who preferred to remember a gentle friend in the way his family most desired.

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '98;
Who Needs Ronaldo? Germany Has Bierhoff

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: NICE, France, June 13

 BODY:
While the Americans have camped at an isolated vineyard for the World Cup, with only Beaujolais grapes to keep them company, Germany has chosen the fun and sun of the Riviera.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl dropped in for a visit on Friday. And Coach Berti Vogts has brought along classical music to the Cote d'Azur, better to help him relax by the pool while he works on his tan. 
 And why shouldn't Vogts be so serene? While the Americans are desperately looking for someone -- anyone -- who can put the ball into the net during Monday's opener in Paris, the German team enters the match with four of the best forwards in the world.
Vogts will choose two, most likely Jurgen Klinsmann, making his third World Cup appearance, and Oliver Bierhoff, the latest scoring sensation in the Italian League who has revived a career that once seemed destined to end without the slightest hint of international recognition.
It was not the great Ronaldo of Brazil who led Italy's Serie A in scoring this season. Nor was it Gabriel Batistuta of Argentina. Nor was it the Italian stars Roberto Baggio or Alessandro Del Piero. It was the tall, slender Bierhoff, an economics student, who plunked in 27 goals for Udinese, earning himself a handsome $12 million transfer for next season to help resuscitate the fallen giant AC Milan.
"It's a bit strange to be called a superstar in the same breath with those other athletes," the 30-year-old Bierhoff said. "I hope I am able to bear the pressure and perform to expectations."
At 6 feet 2 inches, he is tall for a striker. While Klinsmann roams the flanks, Bierhoff is a classic center forward who waits like a poacher in front of the goal for the chance to score. Like a basketball forward, he is an expert at backing in and using his arms in the low post. For each goal that he scores in the World Cup, he said, his sponsors will contribute a total of $6,700 to Unicef.
"You have to be aware that he uses his body and his arms to push you away," said Thomas Dooley, the American sweeper who was born in Germany. "He's very tall, so it's easy for him. He's very good in the air; you have to try to hold him when he jumps."
Upon signing with AC Milan, Bierhoff said he hoped to outscore Ronaldo in the World Cup, just as he outscored him in the Italian League. He said he felt the need to get noticed. Perhaps that is because he went so long without recognition. Playing in the World Cup seems almost like a dream, he said.
"Sometimes I think I have to wake up," Bierhoff said.
His father, Rolf, is the director of a regional power company. As a young player in Essen, Germany, Bierhoff admittedly played like the rich kid that he was. He was reluctant to dive on the ground for balls, he said, and at the end of every match, his jersey remained an unstained white. His father cured him of this fastidiousness by having him dive 50 times in a row onto wet grass covered with a scrim of ice. Three or four repeats of this drill convinced the shivering teen-ager that daintiness was not an admired trait in soccer.
"I had to learn to get dirty," he said.
Still, he kicked around the German Bundesliga for years, moving from one team to the next without exciting anyone, and finally, during the 1990-91 season, Bierhoff struck out for Austria, where he scored 23 goals in 32 league games for Salzburg. That got him a ticket to the Italian League, but Inter Milan farmed him out right away to Ascoli in the second division. Ascoli didn't want him either. Bierhoff told Agence France-Presse that one day about 100 fans surrounded his car, spitting at him and issuing threats and insults.
The team's president told him not to bother coming back to practice, Bierhoff said. Stubborn, he would not leave. A new coach came in and encouraged him and, a season later, Bierhoff led Italy's second division in scoring with 20 goals. That got him a promotion to Udinese for the 1995-96 season, and caught Vogts's attention when he was putting together Germany's team for the 1996 European championships.
"That was my baddest experience but my most important experience," Bierhoff said of Ascoli. "Now, if I have some difficulties, I'm not falling down. I have only to think about that time."
Bierhoff scored only twice in the 1996 European tournament, but he delivered his second goal in sudden death overtime to defeat the Czech Republic in the championship game. Once a nobody, he was now a national hero.
"I was so low, I could only go up," Bierhoff said.
He added, "It was very important to do something on the international level."
Bierhoff has improved his conditioning, and the explosiveness in his legs, by using weights, and his goal scoring has provided him with muscular confidence. He has scored 17 goals in 26 appearances with the national team.
As for the Americans, Bierhoff said he knew little about them, except that it was important for Germany to play its own game. The three-time World Cup champions tend to start slowly and build throughout the tournament. "But we've been warned," Bierhoff said. "The Americans aren't some little team. They've beaten Brazil. We know we have to be 100 percent now. But at the end we are one of the favorites, and we have to accept it and show that we're a good team."

HEADLINE: BENEFITS DWINDLE ALONG WITH WAGES FOR THE UNSKILLED

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Since the 1970's, the gap in wages between skilled and unskilled workers has widened sharply. But new research shows the inequality does not stop there.
Discrepancies in job benefits and the quality of work life have also grown, pointing to a bigger chasm than previously recognized. 
 "Unskilled workers get the short end of the stick -- and it's getting shorter," said James Heckman, an economist at the University of Chicago.
Study after study has shown that the gains from post-1970's economic growth have eluded unskilled workers. The median wage of those with only a high school diploma fell by 6 percent, adjusted for inflation, from 1980 to 1996, while the earnings of college graduates rose by 12 percent. Though there have been indications in recent months that a scarcity of workers in the surging American economy has begun raising wages for those on the low end, the gain has been modest so far and not enough to counter the decades-long trend.
Besides, wages alone provide an incomplete picture of a worker's standing. Though economists have long recognized the need to incorporate working conditions and fringe benefits in any comprehensive analysis, they have been stymied by a lack of detailed data.
Until now. Brooks Pierce, an economist at the United States Department of Labor, used confidential data regularly collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from businesses to measure trends in total compensation. The results are striking: While specialists had long assumed that benefits acted as a leveling influence, particularly because of Government-required benefits like Social Security and unemployment insurance, the opposite is true.
In 1982, people in the top one-tenth of the work force made $24.80 an hour, 3.95 times the $6.28 an hour for workers in the bottom one-tenth. By 1996, the wage gap had widened, with the high-end workers averaging $25.74 an hour, or 4.72 times the $5.46 an hour of those at the bottom. Wages for the purposes of Mr. Pierce's study are all expressed in 1997 dollars to account for inflation.
The decline among unskilled workers is hardly surprising given the increasing demands of an information-driven economy. But to understand it requires a look at total compensation, which places a value on benefits like health insurance, vacation time and pension plans.
By Mr. Pierce's calculation, the total compensation in 1982 of workers in the top 10 percent -- $35.16 a hour -- was 4.56 times that of workers in the bottom 10 percent -- $7.72 an hour. Fourteen years later, the ratio had increased to 5.43 to 1, with highly paid workers having gained $1.73 an hour and low-end workers having lost 93 cents an hour.
Benefits led to a greater discrepancy in earnings between high- and low-wage workers in both 1982 and 1996. Moreover, they were responsible for one-tenth of the increasing disparity between the working elite and the working poor over the 14 years.
Benefits have long been perceived as a great equalizer. In percentage terms, after all, a bare-bones $3,000 medical insurance package adds more to the compensation of a worker making $20,000 than a full-frills $10,000 package for an executive earning $200,000.
The catch, according to Mr. Pierce, is that a growing number of workers at the bottom of the pay scale have lost access to key employer-provided benefits.
More than 80 percent of workers received paid holidays and vacations in 1996, but less than 10 percent of those in the bottom tenth received paid leave of any kind. Similarly, about 70 percent of workers have pension plans, while less than 10 percent of those in the bottom can count on any employer-financed retirement benefits. Access to health insurance follows a similar pattern.
Employers generally cannot deny benefits to lower-wage workers without putting the tax-exempt status of those benefits at risk. So how is this disparity in benefits possible?
Henry Farber, an economist at Princeton University whose own research on medical benefits confirms Mr. Pierce's findings, points to loopholes that allow companies to deny benefits to workers just starting out and to workers not classified as full time. "Employers are figuring out all sort of ways to discriminate between employees they wish to keep and those who come and go," he said.
None of this would come as news to Mary Mendez, a 40-year-old single mother who sorts apples in a packing plant in Wenatchee, Wash., for $7.71 an hour. Her employer takes such a strict view toward paid absences that she was docked for the hours she missed while recovering from a minor accident at the plant. And while the company does offer health insurance in an industry where fringes are rare, she must contribute $21 a month to cover her child.
In other cases, employers have turned to temporary and contract workers, whose pay packages do not include time off and other benefits. United Parcel Service even endured a strike in which a big issue was the company's desire to use more part-time workers to hold down costs.
Perhaps an even bigger surprise than the lack of benefits is how little people with especially demanding or unpleasant jobs are compensated for difficult working conditions.
Job hazards, everything from working in extreme temperatures to working a dangerous, lonely night shift at a highway convenience store, would seem to command higher wages than similar work under less taxing circumstances.
Lillie Reed says her job as an aide in a nursing home in Stamford, Conn., is dirty, sometimes dangerous -- and getting harder.
A few years ago, each nursing assistant cared for seven patients. Today, it could be as many 16 on weekends. "The people coming to the home are older, sicker and angrier," she adds. "It's really tough lifting them, dressing them and keeping them clean."
By looking at arguably the best measure of job conditions, the risk of injury, a new study by Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at the University of Texas, found that workers on the low end of the wage scale were falling ever further behind.
In 1979, workers in the top quarter of wage earners lost 38 percent more days to on-the-job injuries than workers in the bottom quarter, Mr. Hamermesh found. By 1995, the pattern had reversed. High-wage earners lost 32 percent less days than low-wage earners.
It is hard to believe that only workers at the top end of the wage scale are interested in their own health and safety. One possible explanation for the failure to reduce injuries among low earners, suggests Alan Krueger, an economist at Princeton University, is the declining power of labor unions.
While employers may know how dangerous a job is and how much it would cost to make it safer, individual workers rarely do. A union may be able to even the playing field by tracking health and safety issues and negotiating improvements.
Another explanation, favored by Mr. Hamermesh, is that all unskilled workers -- union and nonunion -- have lost much ground over the last two decades as skilled workers added so much more to corporate productivity. "Over all, workplace safety hasn't changed much," Mr. Hamermesh said. "High-paid blue-collar workers with hazardous jobs have simply become low-paid blue-collar workers in hazardous jobs."
In sheer number, construction workers are probably the group most affected. Asbestos workers in New York City are a good illustration. In the late 1980's, the union wage for removing asbestos insulation from old buildings was $31 an hour. But in the 1990's, an influx of largely Polish immigrants eager for even hazardous jobs led to a rise in nonunion removal companies and a collapse in wages for both groups.
"Contractors had no trouble getting workers for $12 to $15 an hour -- and workers willing to do the job without respirators," said Pawel Kedzior, the business manager for Local 78 of the Asbestos, Lead and Hazardous Waste Laborers.
The local has made a comeback under new leadership, recruiting 1,200 Polish and 500 Hispanic members. But the current union wage of $19.90 an hour for asbestos removal -- sometimes with little effort to protect workers from asbestos detritus -- is the contemporary reality of the market for unskilled labor.
After making some assumptions about the value of job safety, Mr. Hamermesh found that the increased risk of injury between high-paying and low-paying work had significantly compounded wage inequality. By his calculation, the change in injury rates magnifies the growth in the wage gap by as much as 30 percent.
To many advocates for the poor, such evidence underscores the importance of enforcing health and safety regulations and of encouraging employers to provide benefits to low-wage earners. Economists do not disagree, but they say that the relatively low productivity of unskilled workers is the root of the problem and warn that it is not so easily solved.
An increase in amenities and benefits for these people would almost certainly lead to downward pressure on wages or increased unemployment. "There's no obvious way around it," said Mr. Krueger of Princeton. "At the end of the day, mandated improvements in working conditions would most likely be paid for by wage cuts."

HEADLINE: Manhattan's Real Estate Boom Spreads to the West Side, With or Without a Stadium

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The West Side of Manhattan south of 42d Street has been the subject of intense real-estate speculation in recent years. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said that a proposed baseball stadium over the rail yards at 33d Street and 11th Avenue would unleash a torrent of new development.
But some of that is already under way, according to real estate brokers and developers. In the latest example, David Werner and Credit Suisse First Boston emerged on Friday as the winning bidders for the Starrett-Lehigh Building, a mammoth green and red building near the West Side Highway in Chelsea that serves as a landmark to the city's disappearing industrial past. 
 Mr. Werner, his partner Mendy Wolfe and First Boston bid slightly more than $150 million, a surprisingly high sum for the aging, 19-story, 1.9 million-square-foot building. But it is another indication that industrial buildings on the West Side have become hot commodities as midtown rents soar and office tenants look west for less expensive space.
Mr. Werner outmaneuvered some rival developers, Larry Silverstein, Douglas Durst, Richard Kalikow, and Laurence Gluck of the Stellar Management Company. All the bidders were planning to renovate the building and increase rents from $10 a square foot to about $25, which is still well below the midtown average.
"It's the latest example of the unchecked appreciation of New York real estate values," said Peter Hauspurg, the chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties. "There's a strong move west now, and it looks like some office development may actually take hold."
The Starrett-Lehigh Building, which is owned by Leona Helmsley, was built in 1932 as a freight terminal and warehouse for steel, tire and even wine companies. Train tracks once ran under the building, which covers the block bound by 26th and 27th Streets, between 11th and 12th Avenues. Trucks can descend from driveways on 27th Street to gigantic elevators that carry the tractor-trailers to various floors for deliveries. The upper floors offer spectacular views of the Hudson River.
Over the last year, Mrs. Helmsley has sold more than $1.2 billion worth of the real estate holdings of her late husband, Harry B. Helmsley.
Benjamin V. Lambert, the chairman of Eastdil Realty who organized the sale for Mrs. Helmsley, confirmed that a top bidder had been selected, but he declined to provide details. Real estate executives, however, say that Mr. Werner had the high bid and would be the most likely buyer.
The new owner will have to invest as much as $80 million to make the landmark building attractive to office tenants, real estate executives say. There are only four passenger elevators in the 19-story building. The lobby needs to be refurbished, and the heating system and steel windows need to be replaced.
The current tenants range from a printing company to an advertising photographer's studio. Nearly one-third of the building is vacant.
Demand for office space in the area is expected to increase because there is little new construction. Indeed, prices for buildings in the garment district south of Times Square have more than doubled over the last year as office tenants have taken over showroom buildings and lofts.
Although many developers who pushed over to the West Side during the last real estate boom were hammered during the recession in the early 1990's, the new crop of speculators believe the risks are worth it, especially at the Starrett-Lehigh Building.
"It's one of the last great opportunities to buy space at a low price per pound," said William V. Adamski, director of the real estate finance group at First Boston.

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2161 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Does Shakespeare Really Need B12 Shots?

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
THERE probably isn't a scholar or critic in the world who would rate "Henry VIII" as one of Shakespeare's great history plays. It possesses no grandly iconic heroes or villains of diabolic ambitions. It contains no patches of soaring verse and commemorates no single splendid event that forever changed the course of the British monarchy. It is essentially a patched-together propaganda piece.
The general belief today is that Shakespeare himself wrote less than half the text, and that John Fletcher and others were responsible for the rest. Part pageant, part history, the play seems to have been composed quickly and to order, possibly to celebrate the marriage of James I's daughter in 1613. 
 Yet as presented by the Royal Shakespeare Company during its recent 18-day residency at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, "Henry VIII" is suddenly revealed to be a vivid and compelling theatrical artifact. Here is an emotionally charged, early-17th-century docudrama, gorgeously designed and costumed, acted cleanly and without affectation, as engaging to the intellect for the history it omits as for the history it embraces.
This production is the kind of discovery that is expected of the giant, financially besieged R.S.C., which maintains three theaters in Stratford-on-Avon and two at the Barbican Center in London, tours regularly in Britain and abroad and has 29 productions in its current repertory. Certainly, "Henry VIII" is the most fully realized of the three Shakespeare productions in the company's five-play touring repertory, which, following its Brooklyn engagement, is now at the Kennedy Center in Washington through July 5.
Though this tour was designed to show off the R.S.C. to advantage (and could, if successful, become a recurring event), it also demonstrates why London press support for the company has eroded. Some English critics argue that the R.S.C. isn't adventurous in either its choice of plays or approach to the productions it chooses to stage. They also worry that many of its productions simply aren't good enough.
Because Americans aren't often bombarded by competing conceptions of "King Lear" or "Henry V" or "Hamlet," we're inclined to be grateful for any halfway decent Shakespeare that comes along. We can't easily yawn at the prospect of another more or less conventional "Julius Caesar" when we haven't seen any major productions of "Julius Caesar" in years.
Thus the Americans' surprise and disappointment when the R.S.C. comes over and, in addition to the seldom seen "Henry VIII," presents fancified though indifferently performed productions of "Hamlet" and "Cymbeline." Even its production of Samuel Beckett's "Krapp's Last Tape," starring Edward Petherbridge, is a letdown. It is a perfunctory staging of the classic that David Kelly of the Gate Theater of Dublin performed so exquisitely during the 1996 Lincoln Center Festival. (I missed "Everyman," the medieval morality play that is also in the R.S.C. touring repertory.)
Unlike "Henry VIII," which was presented at the comparatively intimate Majestic Theater, both "Hamlet" and "Cymbeline" were seen in the cavernous BAM Opera House, where, even if you are seated in the middle of the orchestra, you seem to be miles from the stage. Spoken words have a way of going astray when lobbed from the stage out to the distant audience. Acoustics, however, are not the only problem. Concepts also interfere.
The R.S.C.'s cinematically inspired "Hamlet" begins promisingly, though irrelevantly, with home movies (Hamlet as a small boy, playing with his father in the family compound). It then jumps to "the present": what looks to be a madcap Long Island evening party, complete with a large swing band, on the occasion of the marriage of Claudius and Gertrude. Pay no attention to the dialogue, which still contains references to kings and queens and such. Claudius could be the new head of his late brother's brokerage firm, Gertrude a bored, middle-aged socialite who winters in Barbados, and Hamlet a Yale student who drinks too much.
As with so many attempts to update and find contemporary associations to the classics, this concept has no place to go once it is established. It simply gets in the way. Reducing the members of this lusting, neurotic royal family to the status of the haute bourgeoisie, circa 1950, also reduces the stakes, makes the governing passions seem petty and renders the violence more wanton than inevitable. The concept doesn't seem to have been thought through. When Laertes comes on carrying a rifle and looking for Hamlet, you might think he had been hunting squirrels.
The language is all but lost amid these bizarre images. Alex Jennings's Hamlet is likely to be remembered more for his wardrobe, his decadent good looks (and the white-painted face he affects at one point) than for anything he says. This is a "Hamlet" in which the gravedigger sings "September Song," Ophelia wears red shoes in her mad scene (evoking Judy Garland in "The Wizard of Oz") and the Ghost turns up in a dinner jacket. Every now and then, when you hear a familiar speech, it seems to be a mistake, as if the soundtrack from another movie were butting in.
Performances are impossible to judge in these circumstances. Susannah York, a most appealing and sexy actress on the screen, appears to be distant, small and unnaturally quiet as Gertrude. This isn't necessarily her fault: the entire play is like a badly edited film composed entirely of longshots. Matthew Warchus, who staged the hit productions of "Art" in London and New York, is the director.
Adrian Noble, the R.S.C.'s artistic director, is responsible for "Cymbeline," though one wonders how he finds the time to direct individual productions when he is also expected to administer the company's $50 million yearly budget, attend to the needs of its 750 employees, oversee 2,100 annual performances and, in his spare time, raise private money to supplement the company's ever smaller state subsidies.
However he budgets his time, "Cymbeline" is something of an improvement over "Hamlet," if only because the production's concept affects only the costumes and the spare but handsome set design. The inspiration is said to be Kabuki, but it looks to be almost as Chinese as Japanese. The nobly born characters wear great, handsome kimonolike costumes, while the servants are dressed in the sort of trousers, jackets and pillbox hats worn by coolies in old movies of "Shanghai Express" vintage.
No matter, since reality isn't the point. "Cymbeline" is a shimmering fairy tale, far less difficult to follow than it is to synopsize, being about (among other things): a foolish king (Cymbeline); his virtuous but spunky daughter (Imogen); her doubting husband (Posthumus); her evil stepmother; Posthumus's treacherous, lecherous friend; banishments; mistaken identities; long-lost children; decapitation; resurrections from the dead, and, ultimately, forgiveness for almost everyone.
Mr. Noble's production looks good, but it slides too smoothly through the fanciful events of the play without ever finding the appeal or truth of its characters. With two exceptions, most of the principal performances are astonishingly superficial, composed of actorly readings and the sort of royal gestures you may not have seen in years. Note Cymbeline and his queen as they sweep around the stage, declaiming in their voluminous kimonos and kicking their trains behind them. Watching this production you might suspect that train-kicking is taught along with fencing at British drama schools.
In the pivotal role of Imogen, Joanne Pearce is pretty, spirited, husky-voiced and commanding, very much the modern woman that George Bernard Shaw admired in the character. The other noteworthy performance is that of Guy Henry, who plays Cloten, the queen's dimwitted twit of a son. Mr. Henry doesn't let his broadly comic lines go without savoring them a bit too long, but he is in touch with his role and with the sense of the play.
Though Shaw wrote that "Cymbeline" is "for the most part stagy trash of the lowest melodramatic order," he also admitted, "I pity the man who cannot enjoy Shakespeare." He was sufficiently hooked by the play to write his own substitute last act, published in 1938 as "Cymbeline Refinished." According to Shaw, the emancipated Imogen refuses to be reunited happily ever after with her Posthumus and goes her own way.
O rare G.B.S.!
(Though "Cymbeline" is infrequently performed, New York will be seeing a second one in August when Andrei Serban's version opens at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park as part of the New York Shakespeare Festival.)
Compared to "Hamlet" and "Cymbeline," Gregory Doran's production of "Henry VIII" is a vigorous, clear-eyed, unhackneyed delight. Its focus: the plight of Katharine of Aragon, Henry's first wife, whom he's in the process of dumping in favor of Anne Bullen (Boleyn), soon to be the mother of Elizabeth.
That such a play, written so soon after Queen Elizabeth's death in 1603, could present a strong, sympathetic portrayal of Katharine seems odd, especially since the play ends on the triumphant note of Elizabeth's birth and christening. Poor, soon to be headless, Anne figures hardly at all in the drama, which also deals with the fall from favor of Cardinal Wolsey.
"Henry VIII" or "All Is True," as it was known to contemporary audiences, is a treasure trove of what today look like contradictory political impulses.
The familiar Holbein portrait of Henry is recalled early in the production, but the role, and Paul Jesson's measured performance of it, are otherwise free of cliches and, for that matter, all idiosyncratic particulars. Instead of leaving a vacuum at the center of the play, this creates a kind of mystery that prompts not boredom but speculation. Like the god he was when he ruled, Henry appears to be accessible while remaining unknowable.
Jane Lapotaire is very fine as the abandoned wife who tenaciously fights Henry all the way to her eventual house arrest in a second-class castle. It's a tough, proud, unsentimental performance by the actress who, four years ago, starred in the R.S.C.'s memorable revival of "Ghosts." If you have the chance, note also Ian Hogg's excellent portrayal of Wolsey, the worldly prince of the church who was both perpetrator and victim.
"Henry VIII" is a most entertaining minor drama about which we know even less than we do about Shakespeare. One fact is documented: it can be incendiary. In the course of a performance of the play on June 29, 1613, the Globe Theater burned to the ground, the thatched roof apparently ignited by the debris from a fiery special effect.
 
'Once in a Lifetime'
 You have to run if you want to catch the Atlantic Theater Company's nifty revival of "Once in a Lifetime," which closes on Thursday. This is the seminal 1930 George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart sendup of Hollywood, about moviemakers at the time they were blundering into the sound era. Imagine a bunch of chimpanzees who have found a camcorder and you get the idea.
It's not likely you will see another such revival anytime soon. As "Once in a Lifetime" lethally satirizes the manners (and business practices) of Hollywood in the late 1920's, the play itself reflects the economics of Broadway in 1930. The revival, directed by David Pittu and designed by James Noone, is a marvel of ingenuity. It employs 21 actors to play the 45 characters who appear in five separate, more or less realistic settings.
Playwrights in those days didn't have to condense and foreshorten. When they needed more characters or additional changes of scene, they just typed them in. This often resulted in a looseness of structure, but it also made possible the sort of well-populated farces that were the Kaufman and Hart specialty.
Nuts abound in "Once in a Lifetime." Two of the most endearing: Herman Glogauer. the alternately bullying and smarmy chief of Glogauer Studios, played by Larry Bryggman in one of the funniest performances of the year to date, and Rudolph Kammerling, an intense German director who just happens to make the wrong movie. Peter Jacobson is exceptionally comic in this role.
Give credit also to John Ellison Conlee, Johanna Day and Tony Carlin. They play three ex-vaudevillians from New York who seek new careers as voice teachers in Hollywood, but accidentally save Glogauer Studios instead. Some of the comedy's more vivid characters don't even appear on the stage: the 12 powerful Schlepkin Brothers who, as described, sound very much like the Warner Brothers. There were only four Warners, but the way they threw their weight around they seemed like an entire squad.
"Once in a Lifetime," the first of the string of Kaufman and Hart collaborations, isn't nonstop hilarity. It has its calm spots, but it also has the intelligence and wit you don't often find in what passes for farce in today's entertainment manufacturing business.

HEADLINE: Future Shock

BYLINE: By Jack Hitt; Jack Hitt is a writer at large for GQ magazine.

 BODY:

COLD NEW WORLD
 Growing Up in a Harder Country.
 By William Finnegan.
 421 pp. New York:
 Random House. $26. 
 Mindy, the protagonist of one of the four nonfiction reports in William Finnegan's "Cold New World," is a teen-ager living in a Los Angeles suburb so down on its luck that the abandoned tract houses are routinely used by Hollywood directors when they need to blow up something big. Mindy is looking for an ideology, a set of beliefs, a religion -- something that might make sense of her condition in contemporary America. She settles on Mormonism, Finnegan tells us.
Then he deploys a narrative tactic that he uses to great effect throughout the book. He drops in a few deadpan sentences that plunge the story into one of the uncommon worlds he explores with the determination of Stanley on his search for Livingstone. "Actually," Finnegan writes, "before Mindy became a Mormon, she had wanted to become Jewish. But that had turned out to be too much work. Becoming a Mormon was relatively easy. All this was before Mindy got addicted to crystal methamphetamine and became a Nazi, in the ninth grade."
Mindy becomes Finnegan's native bearer, as he calls her, leading him to a scary remote crossroads in our bustling economy, Antelope Valley, Calif., where "widespread white insecurity and downward mobility intersected with significant black and Latino upward mobility."
In another story in the book, Finnegan uses the same tactic to introduce a onetime box folder in New Haven named Terry: "He started fingering a pile of not-yet-folded pizza boxes. 'I love these things,' he said dreamily. 'I got really good at folding boxes at Kevin's Seafood. The better you fold 'em, the more you can do.' At Kevin's, Terry was earning about $50 a week. Then a friend of a friend offered him work that paid $1,000 a week." So Terry becomes a drug dealer, and Finnegan's guide to America's crack economy.
Each part of "Cold New World" latches on to small figures caught up in forces larger than they are and far beyond their comprehension. Finnegan describes a high-tech drug assault in a tiny East Texas town, Operation White Tornado, that deployed 200 agents and found only five ounces of cocaine. The raid managed to sweep many financially independent blacks into the pen for long unforgiving stretches, and Finnegan points out that it was supported by some whites who "simply didn't like the idea of blacks' getting uppity -- a prejudice that 'drugs' covered nicely."
Yet another section of the book, and my favorite, concerns the troubles of a Mexican-American tough named Juan. It reads like a novella, and the contradictions at play in this story alone are worth the price of the book. No illiterate street punk, Juan is smart and clever, like his girlfriend, but he lacks her ambition and so breaks up with her. His ethnic pride is so convoluted that he mocks all things Mexican; he claims to loathe the food. Juan is not from a broken home. He has two parents, long married, hard-working, decent to the core. He's in trouble with the local gangs, but it's because he refuses to join one. Lost in his parents' adopted land, he exhausts his talents on fighting and drinking.
Finnegan's ability to plumb his characters' complexities is due to his documentary style. He settles upon a character and a place, and then he just keeps coming back for more and more visits, sometimes for years. Minor problems arise from such long-term reporting. Terry's story is so old that there is a creakiness to the slang -- as when Terry boasts that he's "livin' large" and looking "dope." But Finnegan's hanging-around technique yields riches among the kind of people that most reporters would strenuously avoid. His stories do not concern a trial of the century, a perfect storm or the ascent of a tall mountain. Instead, they are about powerless people left battered and grounded by an economy that may be richly rewarding the educated, but is cruelly punishing many others.
Finnegan ranges widely in the lives of his subjects. In the case of Mindy, we meet her mom, her friends, several boyfriends, pen pals, her mom's boyfriend and her mom's boyfriend's son. We also meet Mindy's enemies, particularly Heather, the "Aryan Mother" who threatens to kill her for befriending Darius, a skinhead of color.
Professors of journalistic ethics might object, but Finnegan becomes personally involved in the lives of these people without too much hand wringing. In a moment of unintended comedy, he finds himself chauffeuring nine assorted skinheads to a rave in his rental car. After they arrive, a fight breaks out and one of Finnegan's passengers bolts toward the rental, reaches under the seat and retrieves a knife. Finnegan later lectures the boy, expressing his anger that he and his car were used to transport weapons.
The cumulative effect is to create an unusual kind of sympathy for the characters he describes. It's not the stereotypical liberal sense of pity. Rather, Finnegan convincingly connects the wayward events in these people's lives to the messages and forces they detect around them -- whether from a fractured home, a school tracking system that subtly winnows out the losers from the gifted or just the plain despair inherent in what Finnegan calls our national religion of "liberal consumerism."
We see how and why these people make their wretched choices and the seeming inevitability of it all: it's not that their dreams reach beyond the grasp of their capabilities, it's that they don't dream at all. The pipelines of opportunity leading out of the lower end of our economy are being shut off, Finnegan says. He offers statistics revealing that per-pupil spending in California's once-celebrated educational system -- seventh in the nation in the mid-1960's -- has plummeted in three decades to 47th. Fairly half the state's 2,150 public libraries were closed in that time. Given recent tuition hikes and enrollment cuts, and the cancellation of affirmative action programs, the state's colleges and universities have evolved into economic aeries for the privileged children of the upper-middle-class taxpayer. Since 1970, Finnegan reports, the poverty rate in California among children doubled while "poverty among the state's elderly was nearly wiped out." And California is just leading the way for the nation. "It is clearly no coincidence," he continues, "that the 1996 budget of the Children's Defense Fund, the leading national lobby for children's interests, was $15 million while the equivalent lobby for the elderly, the American Association of Retired Persons, in the same year spent $449 million."
Although the four sections of Finnegan's book are seemingly unrelated, there is a larger structure at work here. The first account, about Terry's drug dealing, really concerns a cunning youth making an end run around the limits he senses blocking him. His story is not nearly as unsettling as Juan's, with his mysterious absence of faith in his own talent and future -- mysterious in that it appears to have no origin and no end.
But by the time you get to the last story -- to Mindy and the dark lives of skinheads, boneheads, heshers, punks, Goths and tweakers -- the future has turned truly bleak and frightening. Theirs is a world where the only input comes from Jerry Springer, crude comic books and word of mouth. They are practically medieval in the way that they let the forces of superstition and rumor guide the day-to-day events of their lives. They spend their afternoons spinning out increasingly more paranoid racial theories to explain their own economic imprisonment.
Glimpsing Mindy's world actually makes the reader yearn for the comfort of Terry's rational, if corrupt, decision to become a crack dealer. His motives belong to the familiar sphere of liberal consumerism. He can be reasoned with, possibly persuaded to take some other work. After all, he's just trying to make a living.

HEADLINE: From the Dustbin of History

BYLINE: By Scott McLemee; Scott McLemee is a contributing editor at Lingua Franca.

 BODY:

HOW IT ALL BEGAN
 By Nikolai Bukharin.
 Translated by George Shriver.
 Introduction by Stephen F. Cohen.
 Illustrated. 345 pp. New York:
 Columbia University Press. $28.95. 
 OF all the early Soviet leaders, Nikolai Bukharin had perhaps the greatest range of interests and talents. He was a lifelong student of the natural sciences, a gifted painter and caricaturist and an experienced journalist. He read widely in literature (Russian, European, American). His writings on economics from the early 1920's are among the most sophisticated theoretical works by a Bolshevik; they display a close familiarity with contemporary Western sociology, which Bukharin did not (like his peers) dismiss as mere bourgeois mystification. And all this intellectual vigor was joined to a warm and unpretentious personality. In the document usually called his "Testament," Lenin noted that his young protege was "rightly considered the favorite of the whole party."
But brilliance and charm are no match for raw cunning -- in politics least of all. During the intraparty struggles following Lenin's death, Bukharin joined Stalin in an alliance against Trotsky's "left opposition." Whereupon Stalin did a volte-face to isolate another danger: the "right opposition," namely Bukharin and his co-thinkers, who wanted a mixed economy incorporating both state-run industry and a vigorous market in agricultural products. Politically neutralized -- his policies consigned to the dustbin of history by the forced collectivization of the peasantry -- Bukharin nonetheless remained an important functionary for the Soviet Government through the mid-30's. Then, at the Moscow trials, he was named a major co-conspirator in numerous acts of sabotage, espionage and assassination. His performance in the docket was strange, almost playful. While confessing to most of the charges, Bukharin contested the details of the case -- calmly tearing it to shreds.
The trial's outcome was never in question. Sixty years ago this March, Bukharin was taken to an execution cell, shot, then effectively written out of Soviet history. Abroad he was remembered, if at all, mainly as the prototype for Rubashov in Arthur Koestler's "Darkness at Noon." He began to resume the dimensions of a figure significant beyond the circumstances of his death only with Stephen F. Cohen's "Bukharin and the Bolshevik Revolution" (1973). This detailed account of Bukharin's political career and policies also elucidated his distinctive Marxism, with its heterodox emphasis not on violent change but on the tendency of societies toward equilibrium, even in post-revolutionary periods. A tiny but persistent movement to rehabilitate him came to fruition in 1988 when, under Mikhail Gorbachev, he was finally exonerated.
A few years later, Cohen, a professor of politics and Russian studies at Princeton University, was granted access to a portion of the archival material on Bukharin, including four substantial works composed while he was in prison: two works of Marxist theory, a collection of poems and an unfinished novel. The novel, now published in George Shriver's solid English translation as "How It All Began," is a work of very lightly fictionalized autobiography. It seems that Bukharin intended to take the story of his alter ego, Kolya Petrov, up to the 1917 Revolution. But the manuscript breaks off just before the revolution of 1905, with Kolya in his teens -- barely conscious of politics, though that is about to change.
With its swarm of well-delineated minor characters (and their families), "How It All Began" is very much the work of a man with a feel for the 19th-century novel. Kolya Petrov, like his creator, is a product of the intelligentsia. His parents meet as schoolteachers; his father, in particular, is a "type" very familiar from Russian fiction: liberal-minded but ineffectual and vague. After losing his teaching position, Ivan Antonovich becomes a civil servant in a rural town, where his disinclination to torment the Jews arouses suspicion. Bukharin depicts the mediocrity of the provincial middle class, not in the tones of a commissar sentencing it to oblivion, but with humor -- as when describing one of Ivan Antonovich's all-night card games: "Tottering, the honorable gentlemen would make their way, like shellshocked soldiers, into the yard, where shivering from the morning cold, they would stare at the sky that was growing pale and in which the stars could be seen barely twinkling; they saw to their natural needs, then returned once again to poisoning themselves, others and the air with cognac, tobacco and the heat of the game."
The family's steadily declining fortunes barely impinge upon Kolya's awareness of the world. The novel is episodic, like childhood itself, and most of the episodes are very happy -- a series of friendships, hobbies and misadventures, somewhat reminiscent of Mark Twain (whom Kolya reads, along with Moliere and Tolstoy and books on science). Quite a few pages are given to lush and detailed descriptions of flora and fauna in the Russian countryside. Eventually Kolya realizes that not everyone leads such an idyllic life. Unlike some of the peasants he meets, he eats meat every day, and the thought fills him with anger and shame. The discovery of class differences is handled believably, as one element in the gradual development of Kolya's psyche, rather than as some apocalyptic episode in which the Bolshevik-to-be is formed.
If not quite a great novel, it is certainly a very good one: more evidence of the man's exceptional talents. In the introduction, Cohen recounts how the prison writings were unearthed and gives an expert account of their place in Bukharin's intellectual biography. And he notes that the manuscript of "How It All Began" contains very few corrections. Bukharin wrote it at high speed, in barbarous conditions -- with all the vividness of a life flashing in front of his eyes.

HEADLINE: Be Fruitful and Subtract

BYLINE: By Ann Hulbert; Ann Hulbert is the author of "The Interior Castle: The Art and Life of Jean Stafford."

 BODY:

MAYBE ONE
 A Personal and Environmental
 Argument for Single-Child Families.
 By Bill McKibben.
 254 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $23. 
 It has become a bipartisan habit to turn vexing public problems into child-centered causes whenever possible. Poverty, health care policy, budget priorities, tobacco companies: the list of issues we must address out of concern for the fate of children keeps growing. Bill McKibben now urges us to address the fate of children out of concern for the issue he cares about most, the environment. In "Maybe One," he brings anxiety about global warming down to earth -- right to your hearth -- by casting it in terms of an intimate childbearing choice. We have until 2050 or so, he gauges, to "stabilize climate at the current level of disruption" and prevent a precariously balanced world from getting utterly out of whack. Since "cleverer technologies and more humble aspirations" may not do the job fast enough, stabilizing the population can serve as a safeguard. If more Americans stopped at a single child, he proposes, we might buy time to "salvage what we can of our relationship with the earth, keep things from getting any worse than they have to be."
McKibben once again proves himself an expert recycler. Ever since he left The New Yorker a decade ago, he has plowed events in his simple Adirondack life into his ecological writing, and plowed elements of each book into the next one. He recently had a daughter, and a vasectomy. Hence this repackaged variation on the "think small" theme of both "The End of Nature" (1989) -- in which he and his wife, worrying about global warming, tried "very hard not to think about how much we'd like a baby" -- and "The Age of Missing Information" (1992), a hymn to rustic, television-free life.
A hair-shirt alarmist in his youth, McKibben has acquired some Snugli-inspired optimism that an ecological consciousness need not be apocalyptic. "It is possible that we face unavoidable calamity," he still fears; "but it's also possible that we'll see remarkable change," he now hopes. McKibben tucks his ecological case for a lower birth rate, slower economic growth and reduced immigration into the middle of his slim book. It won't win over "cornucopians" convinced that there are no limits to the earth's carrying capacity. But readers unnerved by the weird weather, and by the recent invasion of sport utility vehicles, are well primed to nod at green sentiments served up so gently -- and to nod off at the big statistics he sprinkles here and there. Who on earth can say whether McKibben's dream scenario for the United States -- a birth rate of 1.5 children per woman, combined with annual immigration of 400,000, for a population of 230 million in 2050 -- is the answer? He himself only ventures that it "could be crucial, I think, in reducing our environmental damage."
In fact, he's counting on his readers not to trouble their heads too much with the math. One paradox of the think-small creed is that much of its authority rests on the kind of large, abstract calculations that it deems properly beyond human ken. But McKibben's smallest number, that 1.5 birth rate (down from the current 1.9), merits a closer look, since it's the linchpin of the rest of his book. Given the proportion of women the Census Bureau reports as already having zero or one offspring, there's an easier way to arrive at McKibben's goal than to concoct a campaign to persuade -- not, he emphasizes, coerce -- a large portion of the rest to have only one child. He could just urge women who have three or more children to stop at two. (In fact, his campaign for one threatens to undermine his own cause. It's a good way to guarantee that the environmentalist ethic wanes as green-minded nurturers, who are likely to rear little recyclers in their own image, produce a minority of America's children.)
But the just-say-two line is old hat, and would deprive McKibben of the "personal" part of his argument. In it, he employs intimate confession (he bares all in detailing his vasectomy) and parenting advice -- two popular genres -- to sell an environmental message of restraint that Americans, despite his best efforts in the past, have failed to take to heart. His marketing sense is that it's "easier to change fertility than life style. For better or for worse, we live in a culture that can say 'that's enough' in regard to children at least as easily as it can regarding cars."
He could well be onto something: a new baby's gas problems, unlike those of a new Ford Bronco, can keep an owner up at night. McKibben now appreciates that an effective call to conscience, in America at least, should not entail too much inconvenience. It's even better, of course, if the ecologically enlightened path is an upscale alternative of sorts. According to the ruminations on family matters with which McKibben begins and ends "Maybe One," that's just what the one-child choice turns out to be for both child and parents.
In the stroll through psychological literature about only children that opens the book, he has fun showing how they have been unfairly stigmatized as spoiled, lonely oddballs. The child study enthusiast G. Stanley Hall and his disciples planted the stereotype just before the turn of the century in "A Study of Peculiar and Exceptional Children," which McKibben judges "anecdotal, lamebrained and meaningless," and unduly influential. Actually, as he later admits, these conventional prejudices may not have been so misplaced back in an era when many families were very isolated. And by the 1920's, "reputable studies" began challenging anxieties about onlies. McKibben rounds up the data with a zeal Dr. Hall would have approved of, allowing himself only a passing giggle over such sophisticated modern measurements as an Anomie Index and an Index of Richness of Past Experience. But challenging the bias against singletons by showing that they seem basically indistinguishable from other children -- no more anomie than average -- isn't quite enough for this proudly solicitous father of one. The exceptionalist stereotype lives on as McKibben somewhat immodestly hints now and then that such intensively nurtured children may have a leg up in life.
He spends the last section of the book rescuing the parents of only children from the reputation of being selfish, soulless, immature hedonists. McKibben (a Sunday-school teacher in his spare time) tours centuries of religious, especially Christian, arguments about celibacy and fecundity more reverentially than he does the psychological findings about onlies, but emerges equally satisfied with both journeys. His conclusion is that the earth being full enough, thank you, those who selflessly, maturely and soulfully choose to be less fruitful and multiply only once can consider themselves holier than thou. They have more precious time to devote to their child, to their careers and to good causes. "The technologies of contraception," McKibben informs his readers, "can be used as technologies of indulgence and self-obsession, but they can be the technologies of humility as well."
McKibben's real accomplishment in "Maybe One," appropriately enough, is humbler than his sometimes sanctimonious tone suggests. He's highly unlikely to start a one-child trend (or, let's hope, a vogue in vasectomy memoirs). As he himself acknowledges, index-laden psychological studies of family health and success won't clinch the case for most people, unless, like McKibben, they've already made up their minds. Such generalizing misses the chastening yet also inspiring wisdom the second child brings: the daily reminder that no two children, or their relations with their parents, are alike. In any case, the great bulk of McKibben's natural audience of fellow baby boomers is already well embarked on childbearing. His best shot is to sway choices at the margins -- forestall that "afterthought" third child, those post-40 fertility treatments to give No. 1 a sibling. By reminding us that an only child is only and completely a child, not a freak or part of an unfinished family, he makes two children seem like a lucky luxury. A small revelation, it is all McKibben's own case for cutting back requires.
