HEADLINE: What to Do About China

BYLINE: By James Webb; James Webb was an Assistant Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Navy in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
For more than a decade many concerned observers have warned of the dangers in reaching a one-sided rapprochement with China. Invariably, such trepidations have been minimized by "pragmatic" political voices, or shouted down by business leaders who were seduced by China's vast potential market only to become hostages should our policies toward that country turn more confrontational.
The past several years have seen an acceleration of this willing self- deception. The Clinton Administration, buttressed by endorsements from former Republican officials, speaks wanly of a strategic partnership with China. Our crucial alliance with Japan has been strained. Our position in the rest of Asia is being undermined as we shift longstanding trade patterns away from countries with strong preferences for the free market and democracy in favor of China. 
 Meanwhile the Chinese Government's repression and blatant economic corruption have been explained away as internal matters, particularly by American business. Its courting of Muslim nations like Iran, Pakistan and Libya and attempts to penetrate the American political process through campaign donations have been dismissed as presenting no long-term threat.
In the past few weeks the folly of this benign approach became evident with the emergence of both India and Pakistan as nuclear powers. Our failure to censure China for its unremitting effort to help Pakistan become a nuclear power has dramatically altered the strategic world order, and the role the United States must play in it. The implications of world inaction in the face of China's audacity are of the utmost gravity, far beyond such matters as gang warfare in Somalia, petty dictators in Haiti and even the irredentist bloodletting in the Balkans that have thus far sufficed as foreign policy threats to this Administration.
The actions of the Chinese Government in this turn of events loom much larger than Pakistan's or India's. It would have been impossible for Pakistan to develop a nuclear capability without the illicit aid of the Chinese. And while one can justly condemn India for having fired the first shot, the reality of China and Pakistan combining forces in such a manner makes its actions understandable if not commendable.
American Government and business leaders are thus left with the unavoidable truth that China, despite its constant protests to the contrary, can no longer claim to be a non-expansionist power. And they must now prepare for the future consequences of that reality.
They can begin by putting American relationships with Japan, India, Israel and Russia on a much firmer footing. Along with the United States, these four countries possess the key ingredients of geography, military and economic power, and technological superiority to insure that China's future conduct conforms to international norms.
First, Japan. Despite continual bickering over trade policy and its recent economic problems, Japan remains our single most important bilateral relationship. At the same time, Japan to date accounts for nearly 10 percent of direct investment in the Chinese economy, and 30 percent of China's external borrowing. Through its power to reorient these activities, Japan has the standing to influence China's economic and military conduct, particularly with American backing. As relations with China enter a new phase, we should work to strengthen this most important of alliances.
Second, Israel. It stands to lose greatly through the strategic axis China is developing with the Muslim world. The first foreign official to visit Pakistan after its detonation of nuclear devices was Iran's Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharrazi, who proclaimed that "Muslims now feel more confident that Pakistan's nuclear capability would play a role of deterrence to Israel's." Though he later played down this statement, the world must consider it in the context of Iran's attempt to develop nuclear weapons of its own, also with Chinese -- and Russian -- assistance. The United States and Israel must keep the rest of the world focused on this, and should not rule out pre-emptive military strikes if there is evidence that Iran is building a weapon.
Third, Russia. Its assistance to Iran and even to China seems based on its own economic need in the absence of a national strategy, as opposed to China's conscious designs. With respect to these two nations American foreign policy has reached a true historic paradox. Having brought the Soviet Union to its knees, we watched Russia struggle with democracy at the same time we were flooding nondemocratic China with an excess balance of trade. As a result China now is rich enough to short-cut its rise as a superpower by buying Russian hardware and technical assistance off the shelf.
A principal goal of American foreign policy should be to offer Russia incentives to cease providing China and other nations with such capabilities. Russia itself should need little coaxing. The Soviet Union developed a strategic alliance with India in the early 1970's partly as a counterpoint to then-evolving Chinese power. Russia has a history of immigration and boundary disputes emanating from 2,600 miles of shared border with China, and remains at risk in its sparsely populated and mineral-rich eastern territories.
Fourth, India. Its importance to our strategic interests deserves fresh scrutiny. Although American businesses have become India's main trading partners, it has long been ignored by United States policy makers. India, a democracy with a legal system based on English common law, has the demographic makeup and geographical position to become an important ally, as well as a trading partner on a much larger scale. Its population of nearly one billion represents a potential consumer base almost as large as China's.
Our past tensions with India can be understood in part by choices made during the cold war, when both India and Indonesia sought warmer relations with the former Soviet Union based on their mutual fear of China's move toward regional dominance. Although India signed a security treaty with the Soviet Union in 1971, it did so when the Nixon Administration was vigorously pursuing fresh relations with China. Nor should stronger relationships with India be interpreted by Pakistan as a rejection of our interests in that country, any more than Pakistan's closeness to China has been viewed here as a rejection of the United States.
In addition to invigorating these relationships and holding on to its traditional base of European allies, the United States also must clean its own house in terms of technology transfers and acquiescence in the face of irresponsible Chinese conduct.
Beyond doubt, China will object to such a refocusing of policy with accusations of an attempt to "contain" legitimate Chinese interests. But every expansionist power in this century has made similar claims against those who have tried to quell their aggression. And it is China, through its internal repression, encouragement of nuclear proliferation, and even the possible manipulation of our political process that has made such efforts necessary.

HEADLINE: A Bilingual Way to Attract Viewers

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
With a rising number of the nation's Hispanic television viewers now bilingual, a handful of programs are being broadcast that use varying degrees of both English and Spanish.
The emergence of such programming on Spanish-language networks and in high-profile local programming reflects efforts by television executives to reach a younger, more culturally attuned niche of the nation's eight million Hispanic households. Though the networks have been slow to attract this population, other media like magazine publishing, radio and music are flourishing with crossover content that reflects the Latin experience. 
 "It's overdue," said Bruce Silverman, executive vice president of Western Media International in Los Angeles, a buyer of media time.
The newest program is from Telemundo Group Inc., which with a 17 percent share of the Spanish market is a distant second to Univision Communications Inc., with 83 percent. Telemundo affiliates in 60 markets recently began broadcasting a daily variety show whose host is the Cuban-born actress Maria Conchita Alonso, who often strays into Spanglish, a hybrid of English and Spanish. In the program's first month, Telemundo has seen national ratings for its time slot increase about 10 percent, according to A. C. Nielsen.
The show was in the works even before the announcement in November of Telemundo's planned sale to Sony Pictures Entertainment and Tele-Communications Inc. But it reflects Sony's intent to update the look and content of the network's programs, said Alan Sokol, a Sony senior vice president. "We think advertisers have a tremendous hunger for programming other than novellas," he said, referring to the lurid, low-budget, foreign-made soap operas on both Spanish networks.
Tomorrow, ad agency representatives in New York will get a look at Telemundo's first Sony-backed season lineup. Sony's acquisition of Telemundo is expected to receive regulatory approval next month.
Sony is already a steady program supplier to network television with shows like "Dawson's Creek" and "Vibe." The company has financed a dozen Telemundo pilots and intends to put into weekly production enough programming to revamp at least one full night in prime time. The shows will include one-hour dramas and be only in Spanish. "We hope and believe the bilingual audience will come back," Mr. Sokol said, "but we don't want to risk alienating the Spanish-dominant audience."
Last week, Barry Diller's USA Networks Inc. began Citi Vision, a local programming effort at the Miami station WAMI. Its lineup includes "Generation n," a bilingual magazine show based on a locally popular English-language magazine.
Last fall, Univision's cable network, Galavision, began broadcasting a group of programs on Sunday night that are nearly all in English seasoned with Spanish phrases. The programs include "Funny Is Funny," a comedy, and back-to-back reruns of "Que Pasa, USA?," a 20-year-old Miami-based sitcom from the Public Broadcasting System.
The results are telling. In the first six weeks, about 55,000 viewers tuned in who do not normally watch the Spanish-language cable network, which is available to 1.7 million Hispanic homes, said Anne H. Corley, a spokeswoman for Univision.
Economics and politics are forcing Hispanics to embrace English more quickly, said Alex Nogales, chairman of the National Hispanic Media Coalition, an advocacy group. The decision this month by California voters to ban bilingual education in schools underscores that, he said.
"The media is 10 steps behind what the world is made out of," said Mr. Nogales, a former television producer who was consulted by Sony on its Telemundo pilots. Because they rely on foreign shows, Spanish networks are losing young viewers to mainstream networks, he said, while insularity at national networks produces fare like Fox's "Culture Clash" and ABC's "Common Law," programs aimed at Hispanic viewers that did not survive a season.
Jeff Valdez, producer of "Funny Is Funny," added: "We have more Latinos than Canada has citizens. How can you ignore this market?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maria Conchita Alonso and Dan Guerrero, who produces her show. (Chris Pizzello for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Trying To Assure Optimism

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
It has been a tough year for Republican tax cutters. President Clinton effectively put the budget surplus off-limits by claiming it for Social Security. Efforts to pay for a tax cut by slashing spending have run into a wall of political opposition. Other potential sources, like money that would be generated by the proposed anti-smoking bill, are not yet certain enough to be counted on.
So it was no surprise when Speaker Newt Gingrich and his top lieutenants lashed out in frustration last week at the Congressional Budget Office, whose estimates of the nation's fiscal condition over the past few years have proved consistently too pessimistic. Angry that the budget office's projections have regularly underestimated the room Congress has to cut taxes even after dealing with Social Security's looming insolvency, Mr. Gingrich and his team vented in the form of a letter to the House Appropriations Committee. 
 But rather than just listing their criticisms, Mr. Gingrich and the leadership team suggested that they would seek to cut the budget office's financing if its tax and spending estimates were not revised to show bigger surpluses in coming years.
"The C.B.O. must address this problem," Mr. Gingrich wrote. "If it does not, I believe we must review the structure and funding for the C.B.O. in this appropriations cycle."
The pressure campaign brought a storm of criticism from Democrats.
"Three years ago," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the Budget Committee, "the Republican Congress shut down the Government, insisting that the President use C.B.O. estimates. Now the House Republican leaders want to shut down C.B.O. because they do not like C.B.O. estimates."
The Democratic leader in the House, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, called the letter "just another blatant attempt by the Republican leadership to artificially pump up the surplus to serve as a political piggy bank for their grab bag of special-interest tax cuts."
Mindful of the morass they risked being pushed into, the Republican leaders on the Appropriations Committee sidestepped Mr. Gingrich's demands. Representative James T. Walsh of New York, the chairman of the subcommittee that finances the budget office, agreed to put in this year's spending bill a demand that the office report on why its forecasts have proved wrong. But he took no steps to review or cut the office's $25.7 million budget for next year.
Mr. Gingrich's criticism was brushed aside by June E. O'Neill, the director of the budget office, who said that coming up with a totally accurate surplus or deficit forecast for a $1.7 trillion budget was no easy task in an ever-changing economy.
"C.B.O. is used to being a scapegoat and a punching bag," she said in an interview. "We're the accountants, and while your personal accountant might be directed to provide an answer that's beneficial to you, we can't do that."
Bashing the office is a time-honored tradition, indulged in by Democrats and Republicans alike. (Ms. O'Neill noted that a Democratic Congress had been miffed at one of her predecessors, Alice M. Rivlin, now vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, and denied the office use of a car to take officials around town -- a prohibition that remains.)
Mr. Gingrich has consistently pressed the budget office to adopt a new way of estimating tax receipts, one that assumes that tax cuts will unleash higher rates of economic growth and therefore generate more revenue for the Government.
But in this case his pique seems mostly a manifestation of frustration over how difficult it has been to accomplish something that Republicans had assumed would be so easy: returning to taxpayers at least some of the projected budget surpluses, which, after all, are nothing but excess tax payments.
And if there was a lesson for both sides, it was that budget politics in the age of surplus are proving just as rough-and-tumble as they were in the dark days when fiscal profligacy seemed destined to reduce the United States to an economic has-been. Then the budget office usually took a dimmer view of the economy than did Presidents of either party, and deficit hawks praised its restraint, accusing Administrations of falling to the siren song of someone called Rosy Scenario.

HEADLINE: Albanian Separatists Kill 2 Serbian Officers

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 14

 BODY:
Ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo killed two members of Serbian security forces and wounded seven in ambushes today. The attacks heightened tension on the eve of NATO air exercises that are intended to press Serbia to back off from its crackdown in the province.
Serbian officials said the dead were both police officers. Five of the wounded were soldiers in a Yugoslav Army food convoy attacked by the separatist Kosovo Liberation Army, they said. 
 The Albanian-run Kosovo Information Center accused Serbian forces of attacking ethnic Albanian villages in the western part of the Serbian province over the weekend. It reported at least four Albanian dead in attacks on Saturday.
The Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, is expected to visit Moscow on Monday. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has said he would try to mediate to reduce the violence. NATO, trying to force a cease-fire, has planned a show of air power for Monday over Macedonia and Albania, which both border Kosovo.
Serbia and the smaller Montenegro are the only republics that remain in Yugoslavia. Ethnic Albanians account for 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.8 million population and once had a degree of autonomy. But since a crackdown by Serbia, the population increasingly supports the guerrillas' demands for independence.
The Serbian Deputy Prime Minister, Tomislav Nikolic, said any NATO plan to attack Serbia would be insane. He said Mr. Milosevic's talks with Mr. Yeltsin would "contribute to the final settlement of the Kosovo problem."
The air maneuvers were ordered by NATO and the Western Contact Group that is coordinating international mediation efforts as a warning to both sides, but especially to Mr. Milosevic, of NATO's ability to intervene militarily.
The conflict has entered a critical phase, with the United States and its European allies in the Contact Group piling pressure on Mr. Milosevic to stop fighting that the West fears could engulf the southern Balkans.
The West has threatened air strikes against Yugoslavia but there were growing doubts whether attempts to gain United Nations approval for such attacks would survive Russia's veto in the Security Council.
Russia, also a Contact Group member and often a Serb ally, has criticized Mr. Milosevic's handling of the crisis but has refused to endorse economic sanctions that the West has imposed against Yugoslavia or the use of force.
Mr. Milosevic has not reacted publicly to demands that he withdraw the police from Kosovo, allow thousand of refugees to return to their homes and start serious negotiations with Kosovo Albanian leaders on autonomy for the province.
But Serbian Government ministers have warned that Yugoslavia will defend itself against any NATO military intervention in the air or on the ground. Dozens of Yugoslav Army vehicles, including anti-aircraft missile carriers, were seen moving in the border regions over the weekend.
Mr. Nikolic said that there had been "insane calls to attack Serbia" but that he did not expect military intervention because "such a demand cannot hope to win majority backing in the U.N. Security Council -- no one who has any sanity can support it."
He belongs to the extreme-national Serbian Radical Party, a partner of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party in the Serbian government. The hard-line party expects to join the federal Yugoslav Government in a coming reshuffle.
"The Contact Group's demand that all action by our security forces should be suspended while Albanian terrorists are attacking us is effectively a demand that we turn that part of Serbia over to the separatists," Mr. Nikolic said. "This we will not and cannot do as the people of Serbia have granted us no such mandate."
Kosovo Albanian politicians have denied any formal links with the guerrilla army but some have hinted at being able to influence it.
Fehmi Agani, an adviser to a major Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, said on Saturday that a cease-fire could be won from the rebels if Serbian security forces returned to their barracks.
He said the Albanians would not object to the Yugoslav Army remaining to protect the borders with Macedonia and Albania although this would risk clashes with the guerrillas if they continued to run men and arms into Kosovo from safe havens in northern Albania.

Map showing the location of Kosovo: Albanian politicians in Kosovo deny formal links with guerrillas.

HEADLINE: Japan Sinks Into Recession

 BODY:
Japan is now officially in recession, and its Government continues to dawdle about responding. The risk is that Japan's problems may cause further damage to its already weak Asian neighbors.
The first priority for Japanese officials must be to save the country's sick banking system, which is still burdened by bad loans left over from the bubble economy of the late 1980's. In February the Government announced a large and badly needed bank bailout plan, but almost nothing has been done to institute it. The Government needs to close weak institutions while enabling the stronger ones to put their bad loans behind them. The scandal at the Ministry of Finance, which some had hoped would make reform easier, instead seems to have produced paralysis. 
 The banks, having belatedly awakened to how bad their situation is, have created a huge credit crunch by cutting back on loans to avert further losses. Worried Japanese consumers are reluctant to spend, making things worse. Money is flowing out of the country as savers seek safe haven in foreign banks and foreign bonds. So despite a big trade surplus the yen is tumbling, having fallen 21 percent against the dollar in the past 12 months.
Japan's current economic woes reflect the limits of national monetary policy in moving an economy, particularly in this age of global financial flows. Japan's central bank has pushed interest rates about as low as they can possibly go. Short-term rates are under 1 percent, and the yield on 10-year Japanese Government bonds has fallen to 1.3 percent. It is hard to imagine how credit could be cheaper.
But the banks are afraid to make loans, and much of the borrowing has been by foreigners, who have used the cheap funds to speculate in foreign securities markets. Japan's low rates have stimulated rising stock and bond prices in the United States but have done nothing for its own economy.
The Japanese Government has put together a fiscal stimulus package, which should help. But more needs to be done to allow Japan to play the needed role of locomotive for the rest of Asia. Right now, Japan is acting as just one more brake on an already stalled regional economy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Crisis Center: Good Sense Or Good Joke?

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
A HURRICANE sweeps up the Eastern Seaboard toward New York City, packing 100-mile-an-hour winds.
A bomb blast destroys a power plant, plunging Brooklyn and Queens into darkness. 
 A terrorist group vows to release nerve gas in a crowded subway station, pushing the city toward hysteria.
Such crises could happen, and a metropolitan center like New York is particularly vulnerable, which helps account for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plans for an emergency control center. As the Mayor explains it, the city needs the control center so that its leaders can respond to disasters with all the speed and effectiveness that cutting-edge technology can provide.
So why is everyone laughing?
No sooner were the Mayor's plans for the $15 million command bunker revealed over the weekend, than the visionary scheme became a target for practically every would-be humorist in the city.
Curtis Sliwa and Ron Kuby devoted four hours of their radio program to lampooning the project on Saturday morning. During the show, listeners participated in a name-that-shelter contest, which produced such winning entries as "Rudy's Nuclear Winter Palace" and "The Nut Shell."
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, joined in the not-quite-harmless fun, noting that "the Mayor's actions are increasingly bizarre." He added, "If he wants to build a bunker for the only people he trusts, all he needs is a phone booth."
A clearly delighted former Mayor Edward I. Koch declared, "It's the joke of the week."
In a highly symbolic business like politics, it is sometimes the truly consequential blunders that matter, and sometimes just the ones that make good sense metaphorically. Had George Bush ever laid eyes on a supermarket scanner before that fateful day in 1992? Probably he had.
Did Dan Quayle know the correct spelling of "potatoe"? Quite possibly.
Does New York City need a state-of-the-art emergency control center, with enough water to last a week, a secure line to the President and a ventilation system that can be closed in case of a biological attack?
Who cares?
In the course of his eminently successful career, Mayor Giuliani has already done more than his fair share of unsettling things. Whether dressing up in sequins or harassing hot dog vendors, his actions have often been characterized by an element of excess, a "l'etat, c'est moi" quality that has left even his critics slightly agape.
But rarely has he seemed, symbolically speaking, on such dangerous ground.
It is not that the center is, on the face of it, an outrageous project, or even that its most grandiose elements are out-and-out absurd. Who knows, maybe it would be useful to be able to hold a video conference with the President during a bomb scare, a flood or a really ugly sewer-main break.
THE trouble is that the project seems to speak too clearly to the Mayor's fears and, worse still, his hopes.
Mr. Giuliani has always governed as if from a bunker, with chaos threatening from all sides and enemies all around. On some deep level -- well, maybe not so very deep -- one senses that nothing would please him more than having an antagonist truly worthy of his energies instead of just a ragtag bunch of disgruntled taxi drivers, street artists and unemployed strippers.
As soon as the news of the multimillion-dollar command center got out, aides to the Mayor did their best to quash the story. The Mayor was not building a Strangelovian bunker, they said, noting that it was going to be equipped with only a fold-out couch. They also disputed charges that the bunker was being built in secret, pointing to a one-line entry on page 995 of the city's capital budget.
"It's clearly laid out in the budget for anyone to inspect and review," said Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor.
Aides even objected to the term "bunker," with its paranoid cold war connotations; it is "not a bunker," insisted Jerome M. Hauer, director of the city's Office of Emergency Management.
Mr. Giuliani, at a news conference on Saturday, defended the bunker with characteristic vigor, accusing critics of playing politics with the safety of millions of New Yorkers. And he made a special point of correcting the notion that in planning for disaster, he was thinking about himself.
"It's not for the benefit of the Mayor," he said. "It's for the benefit of New York."
So will everyone please stop laughing?

HEADLINE: Congress May Lift Ban on Wheat Sales to India and Pakistan

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Under pressure from farmers, the Government is poised to re-allow the sale of wheat to India and Pakistan despite economic sanctions by the United States against those countries for their recent nuclear tests.
Allowing wheat sales would seem to undermine Washington's moral outrage against India and Pakistan, but a movement to skirt the sanctions on wheat has caught on in Congress, and President Clinton encouraged the movement on Friday as he sought greater flexibility in exercising sanctions around the world. 
 "Farmers in the United States provide a significant percentage of Pakistan's wheat imports," Mr. Clinton said in a statement on Friday. "Cutting off that supply would only hurt the citizens of Pakistan and American farmers, without furthering our goals of nonproliferation of atomic weapons."
Although many in Congress have denounced the nuclear explosions, they are also sensitive to their important farm constituents as the November elections approach. Congressional action was introduced in each house last week by lawmakers from wheat-rich Washington State -- Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, and Representative George R. Nethercutt Jr., a Republican, both of whom are up for re-election. The state sends 37 percent of its wheat to Pakistan, which pays Washington farmers about $500 million a year.
Ms. Murray and Mr. Nethercutt introduced bills to pass a waiver that would allow wheat -- actually, wheat credits guaranteed by the Government and extended to farmers -- to bypass the sanctions, which are automatically imposed on a country if it tests a nuclear device.
The Arms Export Control Act of 1994 cuts off trade credits, private bank loans, loans from international institutions and loan guarantees to American companies doing business in the country in question.
But increasingly, politicians and foreign-policy analysts are questioning the value of unilateral sanctions because they can conflict with other national interests.
The sanctions imposed last month on India and Pakistan, for example, came at a time when 11 percent of the world wheat market was already off-limits to American farmers because of sanctions. Wheat prices have plunged to a seven-year low because of excess supply, in part because of improved per-acre yield techniques but also because of reduced exports. This tension has injected a new urgency into the questions of what purpose sanctions serve and whom they hurt.
"There are a lot of interests in any one country, not just the one issue on which sanctions are based," said Sidney Weintraub, a political economist with the Center for Strategic and International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. "The Administration is trying to take in the full range of interests, and not giving up markets is one of the interests."
The halt in American wheat credits has prompted Pakistan to buy wheat from Australia, said Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. Every day that the sanctions are in place, he said on Thursday at a meeting of the Senate Appropriations Committee, "we'll lose sales, and they are sales we can't recover."
Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, decreed without a vote that the committee would seek a waiver from the Senate, provided it did not cost anything.
The House Appropriations Committee had a more heated debate. That committee voted 7-5 on Wednesday to seek the waiver over the objections of its senior members, including Representatives Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the committee, and David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the top Democrat.
Many said that the United States should stand firm on its principle of exacting a price for what it considers a moral outrage, regardless of the cost. Others, including many in the Administration, support a more pragmatic approach. This view holds that the United States can influence a country more through engagement than by isolation.
But complicating this picture are two other factors. Although the law mandating sanctions was passed in 1994, the regulations to implement them were never written. The Justice Department made an internal ruling this week, in response to a request from the National Security Council, that the wheat credits are covered by the sanctions and would take an act of Congress to override. Thus, the President cannot simply declare the wheat credits allowable.
In addition, between the House committee vote on Wednesday and the Senate committee vote on Thursday, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that lifting the sanctions for agricultural products would cost $30 million to $50 million in Government subsidies for credits to the farmers. Many senators, though, questioned whether the move would cost anything.

HEADLINE: Federal Grants To Colleges Are Resurging

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
This year the University of West Alabama will receive a grant of $300,000 from the Department of Agriculture for research on the disposal of poultry carcasses. The University of Maine will receive $220,000, also from the Department of Agriculture, for research on low-bush blueberries.
These grants are among more than 200 Federal outlays set aside by Congress for specific colleges and universities without benefit of competitive or merit review. Although the grants may or may not meet genuine public needs, they are widely derided as pork-barrel boondoggles. 
 All told, Congress authorized $495 million for academic earmarking for fiscal 1998, according to the 10th annual study of the practice by The Chronicle of Higher Education, an independent national newspaper. President Clinton, making limited use of the line-item veto, reduced the appropriation to $483 million. The June 19 issue of The Chronicle, which reports on the study, will be on newsstands beginning today.
After appropriations dipped to $296 million in 1996 as Republican legislators slashed earmarks as prime examples of wasteful spending, the practice is on the rise again, according to The Chronicle.
The peak, according to The Chronicle, came in 1993, when the value of earmarks was placed at $763 million. Over the last decade, nearly $5 billion has been spent on such projects.
University leaders whose institutions benefit from earmarking were muted in their criticism. Cornelius J. Pings, president of the Association of American Universities, which has traditionally opposed earmarking, said the increase was "a bit troubling, but not alarming."
"All colleges and universities together receive somewhere between $15 billion and $16 billion from the Federal Government," Mr. Pings said. "Earmarking accounts for only 3 percent of that total." The other 97 percent, he explained, is for competitively reviewed projects.
James D. Savage, an associateprofessor of government at the University of Virginia and the author of a book called "Funding Science in America: Congress, Universities and the Politics of the Academic Pork Barrel," to be published next year by the Cambridge University Press, said that the reason for the increase in earmarking was that Congress has more money available because of the booming economy.
"The more they have, the more they get to earmark," he said.
Professor Savage said the solution to the problem lay in electing lawmakers who will fight the practice.
But academicians must also be held responsible, Professor Savage said. "Peer review is the norm in academic life," he said. "We have it in tenure, promotion, allocation of resources and publication. There is no such norm in politics, where the object is to get elected and then help your friends. The leaders of higher education must educate the politicians."

HEADLINE: This Time, Los Angeles May Lose Water War

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: KEELER, Calif., June 12

 BODY:
"It's not that you can't breathe," said Mark McCall, with gallows humor befitting a prematurely grizzled 49-year-old resident of this dusty village in the Owens Valley. "You just don't want to."
Mr. McCall's backyard abuts the dry bed of Owens Lake, a crusty lunar landscape of brackish pools and flaky salts and toxins that is the worst source of airborne pollution in the United States. The parched patch of 110 square miles is all that is left in the center of a once-fertile farming and mining community. Even the talc mill where Mr. McCall once worked is closed, and he is unemployed. 
 There is no mystery about where the water went: For 85 years, gravity has pulled it through a 223-mile man-made aqueduct to build and sustain the artificially verdant sprawl of Los Angeles, and today it still supplies just over half the water for the nation's second-largest city.
But for the first time in the longest-running water war in the West, Los Angeles, under intense pressure from state and Federal regulators, may be forced to put some of the water back to help control dust storms that can carry 20 times the particle pollution allowed by Federal law. That would be a precedent-shattering concession of complicity in one of the most celebrated water grabs of all time.
"We think that this is sort of David and Goliath meets 'Chinatown,' " said Ellen Hardebeck, air pollution control officer of the Great Basin Unified Air Pollution Control District, the state-chartered agency here that last year ordered Los Angeles to cover about one-third of the lake bed, partly with water, partly with four inches of gravel, and partly with vegetation, in an effort to hold down the dust. In fact, the struggle is the stuff of legend, and Ms. Hardebeck was referring to the classic 1974 movie. "Chinatown" was inspired by the stealthy -- though legal -- efforts of Los Angeles city fathers to buy up land and water rights here early in the century so the city could expand into land that they were buying outside Los Angeles.
When William Mulholland, the visionary Los Angeles water czar who saw the potential of the Owens River's mountain runoff, officially opened the Los Angeles Aqueduct in 1913, he watched the water gush down into the San Fernando Valley, then on the far northern outskirts of his fledgling city, and proclaimed in what remain fighting words here to this day: "There it is. Take it."
By the mid-1920's, Los Angeles was taking so much water that the lake dried up, and the city has resisted giving the water back. In December, it offered a counterproposal to do less than half of what the Owens Valley wants, and when officials here rejected that, the city appealed to the state Air Resources Board, which has the final say because the state owns the lake bed.
The board took no action at its meeting last month and gave negotiators for the valley and city until the next board meeting, on June 25, to try to reach a compromise. If a state-approved plan is not in place by fall 1999, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has vowed to impose its own plan for bringing pollution within acceptable levels.
"Clearly, we have a responsibility to deal with the problem," said Gerald Gewe, executive assistant to the director of water services for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. "But it's not a problem that was created overnight or that's going to be solved overnight."
Officials from both sides spent the end of this week in secret negotiations, and the outcome is hard to predict. But their last public positions were far apart, and the staff of the State Air Resources Board has recommended a ruling in favor of Los Angeles.
"The staff did not feel that Great Basin's modeling work in tests for the plan was really sufficient," said Allan Hirsch, a board spokesman. The staff members questioned whether there was enough proof that the plan would reduce pollution.
The basic problem is not in dispute. On most days, the air here is splendidly clear, with breathtaking views across the valley to Mount Whitney, at 14,496 feet the highest point in the contiguous 48 states, and in summer, the lake bed is as hard and dry as concrete. But on some two dozen days a year, mostly in spring and fall, residual moisture makes the lake's crust churn into crystals that become a whirlwind -- of fine clay particles, salts, arsenic and other substances deposited over geologic time -- covering cars, seeping through windows and threatening the lungs of perhaps 40,000 area residents. The rough grass that fills Mr. McCall's yard is so sharp, he said, "it's like razor wire."
The trouble has come in agreeing on a solution. A 1983 law requires Los Angeles to take "reasonable" measures, but city and valley officials have distinctly different views of what that means. In its order, Great Basin proposed treating the worst 35 square miles of the lake with the mix of gravel, vegetation and water, which it estimated would take 50,000 acre-feet of water a year, or about 15 percent of what the city takes from the valley each year. An acre-foot is the amount needed to cover an acre of land a foot deep, or about 325,000 gallons.
After six months of negotiations, Los Angeles countered last December with an offer to work on 9 square miles, requiring about 20,000 acre-feet of water, with a promise to assess its progress and make adjustments after three years. The city says the valley's proposal would cost it $58 million a year to replace Owens Valley water from other sources, probably the Sacramento Delta in the north, and to finance operations at the lake, along with $25 million annual debt service on the capital improvements that would be needed to put the plan in place.
Mr. Gewe of the Los Angeles water agency said that would mean a total cost of $75 million to $80 million a year out of the agency's overall revenues of about $400 million, and he warned that such increases would have to be passed on to customers in Los Angeles. "That's a pretty significant hit," Mr. Gewe said. "But my concern is that it has not been demonstrated that these measures will work, and then we've got to spend even more money trying to find a solution."
Great Basin officials here contend that they are proposing simple measures, ones that mimic natural geologic processes. They say they have tested and rejected everything from spraying chemicals (environmentally unsound) to rigging sprinklers (the dust clogs them) to building low walls of sand as windbreaks (wind patterns are hard to predict).
"We've tested a lot of things out there, and some of them were pretty pie in the sky," said Theodore Schade, the engineer who is the Owens Lake project manager for Great Basin. "The lake has been dry since the mid-20's, and in that time, there are some limited areas that are starting to repair themselves, and generally by the mechanisms we're proposing, through some natural revegetation over time, for example."
Mr. Schade acknowledged that the sheer scale of the problem made it daunting. "It's the size and the money," he said. "If this was somebody's vacant lot, they would just go out and fix it."
Mr. Gewe, the Los Angeles official, suggests one possible area of compromise by noting that substantial nondrinkable groundwater may be percolating below the lake and could be pumped up to help carry out some of the valley's proposed solutions.
"We want to go forward in a phased approach that doesn't write a blank check," he said.
But Ms. Hardebeck of Great Basin is impatient with such talk.
"The district and the city have been jointly studying this problem since 1979, so when they say, 'We don't know enough,' or 'We need to study some more,' how long is long enough?"
Residents here remain skeptical that big changes will come. After all, even their ancestors' early efforts to dynamite the aqueduct could not keep the water from flowing away to serve a city of millions.
"That lake has been dry for almost 100 years," said Geizel Rice, the postmaster in Keeler, where the roadside sign says the population is 50 but she says it is actually a bit more. "Do you think they're going to really put it back? I don't think they ever will. I think it's too late."

HEADLINE: School Ruling Shakes Milwaukee

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, June 11

 BODY:
It was the last week of school, and students and teachers were absorbed in final exams and celebratory field trips. The biggest local story was the invasion of 100,000 motorcycle riders for the 95th anniversary of Milwaukee's own Harley-Davidson Inc.
Not exactly the perfect time for an education bombshell. 
 So when the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that taxpayer money could be used to send Milwaukee students to religious schools, the most significant school voucher ruling in the nation to date, the decision sent currents of excitement through some parts of the community, and alarm through others.
Proponents said it would completely transform education in Milwaukee, letting parents choose where to send their children and revitalizing parochial schools. One champion, Brother Bob Smith, the principal of Messmer High School, a Roman Catholic school, said, "This is, in my mind, the equivalent of winning the Super Bowl."
Opponents decried what they saw as the breakdown of democratic principles, the crippling of the public schools, the ascendancy of religious agendas in education, and what they feared might be an exodus of good students from the public schools or a streaming of whites and blacks to what would become essentially segregated schools.
"Will a Timothy McVeigh start the next church in Milwaukee and see this as a profit-making venture and solicit enrollment and succeed?" said John Benson, the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, Wisconsin's highest education official, who called for a moment of silence after the decision to memorialize the loss of religious liberty.
Much still needs to be determined about how the court's decision will be implemented, but it may be that in practice the changes will be more incremental than either the heraldic trumpets or the apocalyptic pronouncements suggest.
"At first blush we certainly were very concerned about it," said Alan S. Brown, the Superintendent of the Milwaukee Public Schools. "Then when you start getting into the numbers, it doesn't look as bad."
"It's going to take years," said Dan McKinley, the executive director of Partners Advancing Values in Education or PAVE, a group that has been behind the school choice movement and has been using private money to send children to private and religious schools. "A lot of the schools that we work with are struggling. Many of them don't have good science programs. . . . Many of them can't retain good teachers. They have a long way to go before they're really strong vital schools."
The Milwaukee Parental Choice Program, begun in 1990 as the nation's first voucher program, allows poor families to send their children to the school of their choice at state expense. About 1,500 students attend 23 nonsectarian private schools.
The crusade to expand Milwaukee's program to include religious schools, which make up the majority of the city's private schools, was waged by an unlikely coalition of habitual political enemies.
There was State Representative Annette Polly Williams, a black Democrat from Milwaukee's inner city, whose legislation created the program. Frustrated with a public system with a graduation rate of 45 percent and a controversial busing program, Ms. Williams said she wanted to give "low-income families some power" to choose schools.
And there was a group of conservatives, including the Bradley Foundation in Milwaukee, the Institute for Justice in Washington, and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, who led the legal team two years ago, when the State Supreme Court deadlocked on the case.
"They needed us to legitimize them," said Ms. Williams, adding that she is wary of conservatives' desires to promote religious schools and to include people who are not poor. "We needed them because they control the media, they control the money, they control everything."
Their opponents included teachers' organizations, the American Civil Liberties Union, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and black leaders who feared the draining or de facto segregation of the public schools. The plaintiffs have said they will appeal to the United States Supreme Court, but the expanded program is expected to start this fall.
Under the expansion, up to 15,000 students, or about 14 percent of the 104,000 students in the public school system, can attend private schools, nonsectarian or religious. At about $5,000 per pupil, that could mean that more than $70 million would be siphoned from the public schools.
This prospect makes people like Donelle Johnson, a teacher at Elm Creative Arts School, an inner-city magnet school, feel "like my legs had been cut out from underneath me. You're going to have to have layoffs and huge, huge classes."
Other teachers, like Gary Hanneman, chairman of the physical education department at South Division High School on the south side, worry that because many private schools do not have programs for special education students and do not have to take such students, the public schools will end up with more difficult pupils.
Dr. Brown and others suggested that these effects were likely to occur slowly, giving public schools time to compete for students.
About 4,400 of the 15,000 potential slots would be filled by students who are already in private schools, either through the state's secular program or through the privately financed program led by Mr. McKinley. While 110 schools will participate this fall, Mr. McKinley said Milwaukee's private schools now have space for only about 3,600 more students. He predicts that other religious schools will spring up to accommodate the 15,000.
But questions about what religious schools are required to do may temper some schools' enthusiasm for the plan. The law says students can decline to take part in religious observances.
"If the rules include abandoning religious observance, we may not be able to participate," said Tom Hage, the principal of Resurrection Catholic Academy, a school that has accepted so many public school students whose tuition was privately subsidized that they now make up about half the enrollment of 240. Mr. Hage said all students attend church once a week during school hours.
The program also does not require private and religious schools to hire certified teachers or use standardized state curriculum and tests, or to adhere to the same rules of accountability that public schools do. It is not clear whether the state will try to change those rules.
It is also unclear how dissatisfied parents are with the district.
"The reality is there aren't that many parents you interview who are really upset," said Emily Van Dunk, a research coordinator for the Public Policy Forum, a nonpartisan group, which found that most parents say they are happy with their child's school, whether public or private.
Empirical studies have been less than conclusive. One, conducted by a Princeton University economics professor, Cecilia Rouse, found that students in the school choice program performed better in math, but showed no gains in reading.
Professor Rouse also compared "choice" schools with public schools that had small classes and other enhancements and found that the public school students did as well in math and better in reading.
That suggests to some on both sides that public schools can find ways to compete.
"We will probably become more market oriented now in terms of how we display to the community our successes," Dr. Brown said.
Parents' views vary. Some, like Jennifer Evans, a religious education director at a Unitarian church, a public school parent and a plaintiff in the voucher lawsuit, said she feared some public schools would be cash-strapped and left with students "whose parents didn't have the resources, whether financially or emotionally or whatever, to get them into a different school."
Others like vouchers because they promote religious schools.
But several focused on their own pragmatic circumstances.
Vivian Watts, who works in a public school cafeteria, pulled her sons out of public school three years ago because Marquess, now 11, was suspended several times for discipline problems, and Remy, now 12, had low grades. With PAVE's help, she placed them in Resurrection Catholic Academy, where they "have more one-on-one with the teachers."
Claudia Coleman-Brown moved her sons, Kenneth, now 15, and Trent, now 14, from public school to a secular voucher school to a Roman Catholic school and back to public schools, depending on how she felt about the teachers, the principal and her children's needs.
"When something doesn't work," said Ms. Coleman-Brown, an administrative assistant for the county government, "you move on."

LENGTH: 1573 words

HEADLINE: A New Sign in the Suburbs: Sold Out;
Buyers Are Scrambling to Find Houses in a Booming Market

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Buying a house was not how Ron Shriberg planned to spend his Sunday morning.
Rising at dawn, he was quickly where he wanted to be, at a marina in Bayville, N.Y., getting his speedboat ready for the cruises of summer. But a sudden rainstorm forced him to head back to the nearby home of his in-laws, where he and his wife were spending the weekend. On the way, he passed an open-house sign in front of a fetching four-bedroom Cape Cod-style house in Bayville. 
 "It had that warm, appealing home look, something you could move into and really feel comfortable," said Mr. Shriberg, a 29-year-old office-equipment salesman from Woodside, Queens.
In the superheated real estate market of 1998, where he had already lost a house to a cutthroat rival, Mr. Shriberg went into overdrive. He rustled his wife, Laureen, out of her pajamas and drove her over to look. Four hours after first seeing the Cape, they made an offer of $260,000 that was accepted just moments ahead of two rival bids.
"We realized that if we saw something we truly loved, we needed to act fairly quickly," Mr. Shriberg said, not quite appreciating his own understatement.
Just as in New York City, where co-ops and condominiums are being snapped up soon after they go on sale, houses in New York City's suburbs are moving faster than ice cream in July. Once an aberration, the house that goes on the market and is spoken for the same day is becoming routine. As a result, houses are selling for more -- sometimes substantially more -- than their asking price, and bidding wars that would warm the heart of a Sotheby's auctioneer are becoming an everyday occurrence.
"It's not a market in which you want to dillydally," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "If you like the house and the price is right, you should act, because if you don't act, it may be some time before you find another property."
Many reasons are being given for the frenzied suburban market, in which house sales in areas like Westchester and Fairfield County, Conn., are up more than 20 percent from a year ago and prices are up as much as 15 percent. The economy is humming, the stock market is bullish, and interest rates for some types of mortgages are below 7 percent. As a result, far more people have the wherewithal to buy. Mr. Shriberg's fourfold jump in income over two years allowed him and his wife to consider moving out of their Queens apartment.
With the co-op and condo market in New York City also sizzling, it is easy to cash in an apartment and buy that longed-for Tudor on a cul-de-sac where the kids can learn to ride a bicycle and kick around a soccer ball. At the same time, more suburban homeowners have the money to trade up to that bigger house with the guest room, the third bathroom and the large kitchen they have always craved.
Not surprisingly, the madness is fueled by a tight supply of houses. The seven slow years of the late 1980's and early 1990's left many houses languishing on the market. But about two years ago, they began to move, and now the inventory, as they are referred to in the real estate trade, is depleted.
In the first quarter of 1998, only 3,945 single-family houses in all of Westchester were on the market, a 24 percent decline from the 5,171 listed in the first quarter of 1997. As a result, the average price of a house in Westchester -- $403,020 -- is 7 percent higher than it was a year ago. In Nassau County, the number of homes for sale has dropped to 5,979 this April, from 8,132 in April 1997, and the average price is up 13 percent. In Fairfield County, where inventory figures were not available, the average price of a single-family house is $320,475, a 14.9 percent increase from a year ago.
In such a market, it helps to pounce.
Darlene Bandazian, manager of the Weichert Realtors office in Ramsey, N.J., recalled how one of her agents received a listing on a recent Saturday for a $290,000 house in Mahwah. He scheduled an open house for the next day and, having no time to place a newspaper advertisement, posted a dozen fliers on lampposts and street signs. Fifty couples showed up, three of whom made offers. The house was sold at its asking price.
In such a market, it even helps to bribe -- legally, of course.
Karla Renz-Mcleod and Steven McLeod of Forest Hills, Queens, fell in love with a three-bedroom house in Stamford, Conn., with a flagstone patio and a lush garden. But they mistakenly decided to compare a few other houses before making an offer. By the time they returned that afternoon, another couple -- in a Mercedes -- was inspecting the house.
"I could see the wife was making these motions like, 'This is where the second floor can be expanded,' " Ms. Renz-McLeod said.
The McLeods put in a bid of $285,000 but couldn't match the one by their rivals.
"They're using cash for the deal, all inspections waived," Ms. Renz-McLeod said. "How can you compete with that?"
Similarly, Vera Blendermann, a broker for Houlihan Lawrence in Bronxville, told of a large Colonial on one acre that went on sale on a Thursday for $1.5 million. A half-dozen written bids came in, and when they were opened on Sunday, the highest was from someone who had not only offered more than $100,000 beyond the asking price but was also willing to put up enough assets to forgo a mortgage approval and an engineer's inspection, and to close on the house whenever it suited the seller.
"What better terms can you give than removing your mortgage contingency, removing your engineering inspection and closing at the convenience of the seller?" Ms. Blendermann said.
Of course, some buyers say they feel betrayed by sellers unable to resist better offers. In March, Mr. Shriberg shook hands with the broker on a $230,000 deal for a waterfront ranch house in Oceanside, in Nassau County. Mr. Shriberg signed a contract and sent in an $11,500 deposit, but the seller never put his signature on the contract or cashed the check. Instead, the owner sold the house privately -- no broker was involved -- to a remote acquaintance who came up with $250,000 in cash. Though they got their deposit back, the Shribergs were left in the lurch.
"These days, people have a lot more money," Mr. Shriberg said. "The seller's friend realized, 'I better step up to the plate or I'll lose the house.' "
 Though not every broker agrees, Mary Grimm, a veteran broker for C. S. McClellan in Pelham, in Westchester, said the current market is giddier than even the bustling market of the mid-1980's. And it seems to touch most locations and price ranges. Denise Smith, a spokeswoman for Weichert Realtors, said that sales are at their most feverish in the "classic suburban bedroom communities as opposed to the more urban and rural areas." In western Bergen County, N.J., for example, the hottest locations are Wyckoff, Ramsey, Mahwah, Allendale and Franklin Lakes. In Westchester, suburbs like Scarsdale, Larchmont and Pelham are hopping.
The mania has changed the way brokers, buyers and sellers behave. Rather than merely worry about how to best articulate the features of a house, brokers have to concentrate on convincing the suspicious buyer that the race is to the swift.
"They have to be on top of the market," said Jackson B. Browning, president of Julia Fee Realty, which has offices throughout Westchester. "It's not a part-time job. They have to be active, have to know what's coming on the market the minute it's in the computer."
Patricia Lampl, a broker at Wykagyl/Rittenberg Realty in New Rochelle, said she tried to avoid putting overt pressure on a client she took to houses in Scarsdale and New Rochelle. But experience provided a telling lesson.
In Scarsdale, the Tudor was swarming with brokers -- upstairs, downstairs, in the attic, in the yard. They peered, poked, sniffed, opened and closed closets and then were briskly off to examine other prospects. Ms. Lampl coolly escorted her pregnant client, Gail Herman, through the frenzy, pointing out the three-bedroom house's low taxes, good school district and proximity to the Scarsdale train station.
But the Scarsdale house vanished the same day, before Mrs. Herman had even considered making an offer. Mrs. Herman, a 30-year-old school psychologist who has been living with her stockbroker husband, Michael, in a one-bedroom apartment in White Plains, was not disappointed. Just that morning, she had seen a 1940's white Colonial cottage with red shutters in a congenial neighborhood in New Rochelle, a house with offbeat moldings, dormered ceilings and lots of nooks and crannies.
"Charming. Gail likes charming," Ms. Lampl had already noted.
So Mrs. Herman took her husband, weary from a day of work, to see the house that same evening. The next day, she showed it to her mother. On the third day, she made an offer. It was too late, of course. In the frantic market of 1998, three days might as well have been three years. Someone else had beaten her to the punch.
Mrs. Herman was stoic. "There will always be another house," she said. But Ms. Lampl said she would not be surprised if Mrs. Herman took a different tack the next time.
"It puts me in an awkward position," she said of the hot market. "I don't want to pressure people and don't want them to feel they have to hurry up, but when things like this happen, then the second time around they act a lot more quickly."

HEADLINE: Flint Journal;
City G.M. Built Looks Ahead Warily

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., June 12

 BODY:
It is easy to overlook the two major highways crisscrossing this city as just a pair of well-worn roads.
But these roads are emblems of a rich slice of American history. One is named the Chevrolet-Buick, in honor of the General Motors Corporation, which began its automobile empire here, putting food on the tables and cars in the driveways of generation after generation. The other highway is called the U.A.W., a tribute to the labor giant, the United Auto Workers, that rose here in a legendary 1936 sit-down strike on the factory floor of a now shuttered General Motors assembly plant. Together, the roads are ordinary yet glaring symbols of just how tightly this city is gripped by its two most famous offspring. 
 "G.M. owns Flint," said Brad Kirfan, who co-owns a chain of convenience stores, "and the U.A.W. is the town sheriff."
The history that binds Flint, General Motors and the labor union is as long and layered as the miles of factory smokestacks that dot this city's desolate landscape. Depending on who is talking here, that tortured relationship is either wholly or at least partly at fault for the bitter tone of simultaneous strikes by 9,000 auto parts workers at two G.M. plants. Negotiations between the company and U.A.W. locals at the two plants recessed Sunday without an agreement, and were expected to continue on Monday.
The disputes have led to the layoffs of more than 50,000 auto workers throughout North America. And they have focused the eyes of the nation on Flint in a way that has not been done since the 1989 documentary "Roger and Me," the film by Michael Moore that chronicled his efforts to find out why Flint was losing tens of thousands of General Motors jobs.
These days, everyone here seems to have an answer to what is going on in Flint. On one side are residents and G.M. employees who say that the company is trying to abandon the town it built. On the other side are small-business owners who talk in whispers about how the U.A.W. seems to be determined to drive Flint's largest employer out of town. Both groups blame city officials for not doing more to wrest Flint from the shadow of the auto maker and the union.
"Everyone knows it's coming," said Kevin Jennings, referring to the widely held belief that G.M. is quietly preparing to close its 18 factories and offices here. Mr. Jennings, 30, whose father works for G.M., is the manager of Dale's Food for Health, one of only a handful of businesses scattered in a three-block area of boarded-up storefronts in the downtown section. "I wish they would just leave and get it over with," he said.
When Mr. Jennings was a boy, G.M.'s presence loomed so large that he and some friends, also children of G.M. employees, nicknamed the company Mother Motors, the breast that feeds Flint. In fact, it is difficult to find anything here that has not been created or influenced by the world's largest auto maker. G.M. and its 33,000 employees in Flint contribute about 60 percent to the local economy. Many of the classrooms in the five colleges and universities here are filled by the company's employees and their families, all of whom receive tuition assistance from the auto maker. One of the schools was started by G.M. to help train its workers for management and engineering positions. Now privately run, the school is the alma mater of at least 16 current G.M. executives.
And with more than 41,000 G.M. retirees and surviving spouses in the Flint area, the company and the union supply much of the customer base for the city's growing health care industry. Auto workers enjoy one of the most generous health care plans in the nation, paying for virtually nothing even after they retire.
Mayor Woodrow Stanley says G.M. has been both savior and oppressor to Flint. "It's one thing to be a one-company town. But it's far more difficult to be a town with one company in one industry," he said. "The very large presence of G.M. has retarded the growth of this community. It's not something you can change overnight."
No matter how long the strikes linger or how they are resolved, Mayor Stanley says the outcome for Flint is clear: "There is no greater microcosm of the auto industry than Flint. And if that industry is steadily leaving America, as we're seeing, it only stands to reason that they're going to leave Flint." Union officials predict Flint will lose 11,000 jobs over the next two years if workers do not win job security demands at the striking plants and other factories.
It seems to matter to almost no one that the auto maker plans to invest $1.5 billion here through 2001, including a $500 million engine plant. The flight from Flint is all that people seem to talk about, with many of them trading stories about how they plan to beat the company out of town.
"I'm going to New York. I'm going to be a singer," said Tanesha Fanter, a 22-year-old welder walking the picket line. Ms. Fanter said that although she supported the strike, she doubted G.M. would always be in town.
"I could be like everybody else," she said, "stay here and collect a paycheck, but it's not worth it. This work is hard. I've got burns all over my chest. I don't want to spend my whole life fighting just so I can keep working in a plant. There is more to the world than G.M. and Flint."

LENGTH: 1693 words

HEADLINE: PLAN TO GO PUBLIC AT GOLDMAN, SACHS

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company, Wall Street's last big private investment bank and by many measures its most successful, plans to announce today that it will end the firm's 130-year partnership by becoming a public company, according to people close to the firm.
Goldman's top executives were still meeting late last night to work out some details of the move, which would make Goldman a prime player in the financial industry's rush to consolidate. In recent years, that trend has turned nearly all of America's venerable finance partnerships -- which each formerly had a distinct culture and investment philosophy -- into homogenized financial giants. 
 The move would also be an indicator that some of Wall Street's savviest financiers believe there may never be a better time to capitalize on the bull stock market and on the public's love of finance houses with global ambitions.
Based on the stock-market prices of some other big investment houses, a decision to become a public company by issuing shares of stock could give the company a value as high as $30 billion and give each of the partners a stake that might eventually exceed $100 million.
Goldman's six-man executive committee was still meeting late last night to work out an agreement in principle to end the private partnership by selling at least part of the company. People at Goldman said that the firm's 190 partners, in weekend meetings that they described as passionate, had been almost evenly divided about the merits of ending the private partnership -- torn between the near-term riches and global heft that would almost certainly follow and the satisfaction of working within a tight-knit group whose decisions are not subject to the whims of outside shareholders.
Yet the partners left the final decision in the hands of the firm's six top executives, knowing full well that most of the executive committee favored the plan to go public.
As the firm's partners and 11,000 employees around the world anxiously awaited the results of the executive committee's deliberations last night, Jon S. Corzine and Henry M. Paulson Jr., Goldman's co-chairmen and chief executives, had scheduled a conference call with Goldman employees for early Monday morning. Barring last minute surprises, the two were expected to announce the decision in principle to take the company public, with details to be presented to the full partnership in a month or so.
Even though that decision would mark the end of a private firm founded in New York in 1869 by a German Jewish immigrant, Marcus Goldman, the game of musical chairs now played on Wall Street is a global one, and Goldman is determined to keep its seat. It is enjoying record profits, earning about $1 billion in each of the last two quarters. But it does not have stock, the chosen currency for mergers and acquisitions, and is now smaller than its leading rivals. It is also ill-prepared to seize opportunities at a time when walls between brokerage firms, bank and insurance companies are crumbling.
As a public company, Goldman bankers say they would seek to buy other American and foreign finance companies. And the firm itself, considered Wall Street's crown jewel in terms of profitability and the track records of the companies whose stock offerings it underwrites, will likely receive a flood of merger proposals -- some of which might allow Goldman to take over a larger commercial bank or insurance company.
Also underlying the decision is a fear that if the company does not go public during the current bull market, Goldman partners might lose an opportunity to capture the extraordinary value the market now places on well-run securities companies.
To some market watchers, Goldman's decision might be taken as a sign that the partners believe the stock market has reached a high. Indeed, Morgan Stanley and Bear Stearns, two rival, first issued shares to the public in 1986 and 1987, close to the peak of that era's bull market.
Goldman has long engaged in its own version of Hamlet -- to go public or not to go public -- deciding half a dozen times, most recently in 1996, to stay private. But people at the bank say a confluence of factors, including the bull market, the global competitive challenge, and the fact that the firm has had two of the best years in banking history, have now tipped the balance in favor of ending the partnership.
It was not a clear-cut choice. At their two-day retreat at the Palisades Executive Conference Center north of New York City on the Hudson River, a complex patrolled by security guards, the partners engaged in what was described as a Quaker-style meeting, where all 190 partners were invited to state their views about the firm's future.
In a long open session Saturday morning, more than 100 of them did so, with some later describing this gathering of mostly male white-shoe bankers as emotional and draining.
"For people who have devoted their lives to this place it was exhausting, but in some ways amazing," said one person who attended. "People did not hold anything back."
Mr. Paulson and Mr. Corzine remained officially neutral through the discussion, said people who attended. But several top partners who worked with Mr. Paulson to devise a strategic plan made strong cases in favor of taking Goldman public, emphasizing concerns that the partnership structure is too plodding and cumbersome for a bank with thousands of employees and the need to make snap decisions in scores of countries.
Others, including John L. Thornton, a member of the executive committee, spoke with equal determination against any public sale of shares, people there said. The prime fear was that a public company could never replicate the close-knit culture of a partnership, where financial rewards are measured in lifetimes instead of months.
In the end, no formal vote was taken. The partners were given a questionnaire in which they were asked to state their views on a public offering and several other issues, each requiring a written answer. Partners left the meeting Saturday afternoon without knowing the results of that poll. Reviewing the comments was left up to the executive committee, which met Sunday and continued discussion over dinner Sunday night.
At the weekend retreat, Goldman executives presented several ways of valuing the company, and their estimates covered a wide range of $15 billion to $35 billion, people who attended said. The firm has not yet developed a detailed plan for going public and would not put a price tag on the firm until they do.
Some analysts expect that the firm is likely to value itself between $25 billion and $30 billion, considered a rich but not implausible figure given the way the market values other securities companies. But some bankers argue with that figure and say that Goldman, given its reliance on some outside investment capital as well as partners' capital, would have to settle for less, perhaps $20 billion to $25 billion.
How the firm spreads that wealth is likely to be a matter of discussion in the weeks ahead. But several people within the firm expect that with a possible valuation of $30 billion, existing partners will take between $20 billion to $22 billion, or an average of $105 million to $115 million apiece. Goldman's 6,000 nonpartner executives would split between $6 billion and $8 billion, this person said. The rest would be reserved for the firm's outside investors and limited partners.
Several at Goldman have stressed that the plan to go public is not only about how to stuff the already bulging wallets of top executives. It is also about how to prepare the firm for a new era -- one in which only the most global banks with the resources to fight for business in any major economy will prosper. Increasingly, these people say, Goldman's private partnership is a handicap in that race.
In particular, a partnership cannot compete with public companies in the acquisitions game because it does not have stock, which is often a much cheaper way of acquiring other companies than cash. For that reason Goldman has tended to grow organically or to make only small purchases while some of its rivals have entered giant mergers or made multibillion dollar purchases to expand their business.
By some standards, Goldman is the most profitable investment bank in the world, and it competes for the top slot in all of its major businesses. But executives say they cannot ignore Merrill Lynch & Company's global acquisition binge, Morgan Stanley's merger with retail broker Dean Witter, Discover, or Salomon Smith Barney's proposed incorporation into a putative banking behemoth called Citigroup.
"On any one of these things, we can say, 'Oh, O.K., we don't need to do that,' " says one Goldman executive. "But you put them together, all these little punches, and you start to feel a little uneasy. It weighs on you."
But that straightforward reasoning underestimates the almost cultish attachment to partnership at the firm. It is an anachronistic vestige of 19th century, family-centered company organization, but a gilded one: A Goldman partnership is one of the few ways a Wall Street professional can become independently wealthy, with many earning as much as a top corporate boss or successful private entrepreneur.
Yet the firm also maintained a rare balance between fabulous monetary rewards and tight team discipline. One Goldman banker described this as "getting rich slowly." There are stars in the Goldman system. But they get smaller up-front rewards, and less public recognition, than they might get elsewhere.
Every company talks of teamwork, but Goldman elevated it to a commandment, bankers there say. Because partners' own money is at stake in every deal, the firm operates by consensus, with top executives often able to trust other partners implicitly. Scores of Goldman people participate in decisions that one or two bosses might make in other firms.
"The teamwork thing is not just propaganda -- it is emotional and real," says one person at the firm. "It was really the one thing that made this place special -- something other banks don't have."
