SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1863 words

HEADLINE: Most Approve Of Microsoft, A Poll Shows

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR with MARJORIE CONNELLY

 BODY:
The Government's antitrust battle against the Microsoft Corporation has not tarnished the company's reputation as an outstanding business that makes high-quality products. But according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, a majority of Americans do think that Microsoft is a monopoly and that the Justice Department should continue to investigate the company and its business practices.
Both in a nationwide telephone poll last week and in follow-up interviews, people again and again expressed deep admiration for the accomplishments of Microsoft and William H. Gates, the company's famous co-founder and chairman. Yet the same people repeatedly said there was an important role for the Government to play to make sure that fair play was maintained in the high-technology economy that Microsoft has come to symbolize. 
 "Bill Gates has made an enormous contribution to this nation's economy, creating jobs and wealth," said Richard Denoyer, a 65-year-old education consultant in Evendale, Ohio. "But you've got to give others a real chance to participate in these high-tech markets as well. And it's the Government's responsibility to check things out, to make sure that Microsoft is playing by the rules."
In the court of public opinion, the burden of proof clearly rests on the side of the Government to show that Microsoft has done anything illegal. Fifty-five percent of Americans surveyed said that they had a favorable opinion of Microsoft, while only 15 percent held an unfavorable opinion. (The remaining 30 percent had no opinion on the matter.) Most people said their opinion of Microsoft had not changed as a result of the Justice Department's investigation.
"People give Microsoft enormous credit for what it has accomplished, but they also recognize that bad things could happen and that market power can be abused," said Nicholas Donatiello, president of Odyssey, a market research firm that studies how consumers view technology companies. "It's pragmatic and entirely sensible."
The Times/CBS poll, conducted June 7 to 9, surveyed 1,126 adults nationwide.
When asked about Microsoft's business practices, 54 percent of those polled said they agreed with the statement that "Microsoft uses legally acceptable business tactics to sell and distribute its products."
By contrast, only 19 percent said they agreed that "Microsoft uses illegal sales and business tactics to force people to buy its products and keep other products from being used" -- a pivotal point in the Government's antitrust case. The remainder agreed with neither statement or had no opinion.
Even the 60 percent of people who say the Justice Department should continue to investigate Microsoft are not necessarily convinced that the Government was justified in bringing a major antitrust case against the company last month. The Justice Department has contended that Microsoft has used unfair practices to defend its monopoly in the market for personal computer operating-system software, the program that controls the basic operations of a computer, and to try to gain an edge in the new markets of Internet software and commerce.
Public opinion, to be sure, plays no direct role in antitrust policy. Yet it is inevitably a consideration when bringing a major case like the suit against Microsoft. Congress controls the Justice Department's budget, and a big case that is seen as too far out of step with public opinion could bring pressure from Congress.
So when the Microsoft suit was announced in Washington on May 18, Attorney General Janet Reno appeared before a battery of television cameras.
"Part of that exercise is to convince people that what the Government is doing is in the interest of the consumer," noted Robert Litan, a former senior official in the Justice Department's antitrust division.
Public opinion, he added, also sets the limits of Government action. The Justice Department, for example, has not moved to break up the big software company, as was done with the Bell System in 1984 and as some industry analysts have advocated in the Microsoft case.
"The public is not ready for something that drastic, certainly not yet," said Mr. Litan, who is the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution.
People are split almost evenly on whether the Government did the right thing in filing suit against Microsoft, with 35 percent saying it was right and 27 percent saying it was a mistake. The remaining 38 percent were undecided or were not aware of the case.
People who said the investigation should continue but thought the Justice Department was mistaken in filing the antitrust suit tended to view the appropriate role for government more as a referee than as a prosecutor. They also regarded some of what they had heard of Microsoft's aggressive business practices as part of the rough-and-tumble of capitalism.
Dianne Tytell, a 48-year-old office manager of a dental practice in Virginia Beach, Va., said: "Bill Gates probably did overstep a few boundaries. If you're powerful and on top, that's what you do. He should get the equivalent of a parking ticket for that. But I don't think he's really done anything dishonest. And after all he's achieved, I think it's wrong for the Government to try to tear down someone like Bill Gates."
The Times/CBS poll does illustrate the high regard that most Americans have for Microsoft and for Mr. Gates. Nearly five times as many people have a favorable opinion of Mr. Gates as have an unfavorable opinion -- 39 percent to 8 percent, with the rest undecided or unfamiliar with Mr. Gates. The favorable-unfavorable split for President Clinton in the same poll is much more evenly divided: at 45 percent favorable, 37 percent unfavorable and the rest undecided.
In the case of Microsoft, familiarity breeds respect -- or at least familiarity with its products. On almost every Microsoft question asked in the poll, the more that people used computers, the more pro-Microsoft their answers were. For example, among people who not only use computers but have installed software on their own, 78 percent had a favorable opinion of Microsoft compared with 55 percent of all those questioned for the poll.
The high approval ratings for Microsoft, according to public opinion analysts, owes much to the perception that the company is a standard-bearer of a resurgent American economy in the 1990's, led by high- technology industries. "Microsoft is the symbolic company and Bill Gates is seen as the personification of America's recent success," observed Daniel Yankelovich, the public opinion analyst. "The captain of our side is Bill Gates."
Most Americans are technological optimists, according to the Times/ CBS poll, with 59 percent saying that computers solve more problems than they create, while 29 percent say they create more problems than they solve. Among computer users, 71 percent see the machines as solving more problems than they create. And two-thirds of Americans now use a computer either at home or at work, according to the survey.
Still, many Americans appear to be embracing the information age tentatively, if not fearfully. More than half of all computer users, 52 percent, say they have never installed a software program -- a basic step in computing. While technology enthusiasts never tire of extolling the virtues of computers as personalized tools of empowerment, the Times/CBS poll suggests that a large share of the computer-using public has no interest in tailoring their machines or changing them.
The portrait of many people as passive recipients of computer technology may also cast some doubt on one of Microsoft's arguments in its dispute with the Government. The Justice Department, Microsoft says, has overstated the advantage the company enjoys because the main desktop screen that users see when they turn on their machines is Microsoft's Windows. That first screen can be easily changed or modified, Microsoft insists.
It can, but the poll indicates that fine-tuning software is beyond many people.
Microsoft's market power is viewed with both ambivalence and pragmatism, according to the Times/CBS poll. Monopoly, it seems, is no longer regarded as an economic evil. A majority of those questioned say Microsoft is a monopoly -- a label Microsoft itself shuns -- but 77 percent also say Microsoft makes high-quality products. And 58 percent of computer users and 67 percent of people who have installed software themselves consider Microsoft's dominant role in the software business to be good for consumers.
A certain ambivalence about big, successful companies, and what the Government's role should be in policing them, has been a theme of American public opinion for decades, analysts say.
Consider Christopher Rogers, a 25-year-old medical student in Philadelphia, who seems little concerned by the dominance of Microsoft's Windows operating system.
"Microsoft's Windows is a great product," he said. "It is a monopoly but not in the traditional sense of controlling markets to raise prices."
Still, Mr. Rogers, like others polled, is skeptical about whether consumers would benefit if Microsoft were to control the market for software used for browsing the Internet -- a market that is a focus of the Justice Department's case. Only 8 percent of those polled said it would be a good thing if Microsoft dominated the browser market, 41 percent said it would be bad, 39 percent said it would make no difference and 12 percent had no opinion.
"Microsoft pushing its Internet browser onto the market with every copy of Windows does seem like a domineering thing to do," Mr. Rogers said. "And I do think that's something worth investigating."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 7 to June 9 with 1,126 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for the 315 most sophisticated computer users in the sample it is plus or minus six percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
A Muslim Artist and Hindu Images: It's a Volatile Mix

BYLINE: By Somini Sengupta 

 BODY:
For the second time in less than two years, India's most famous artist, Maqbool Fida Husain, has become a target of the country's most militant Hindu activists. Early last month, members of the far-right Bajrang Dal, upset at a stylized portrait of a Hindu goddess, slipped into Mr. Husain's Bombay apartment, destroyed one painting and mauled several canvases before being arrested by the police.
Since then, high-ranking officials of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party, while distancing themselves from the attack, have asked him to refrain from what they call his perverted works of art, while many of the country's most prominent artists and writers have rallied around him, criticizing attempts to fetter free expression. 
 Mr. Husain himself, however, seems unruffled, taking what he euphemistically called a philosophical approach to the whole furor. "It's very minor," he said impatiently in a telephone interview from London, where his paintings were being offered at Christie's auction house. "The door was open. I went out. Some people came." When pressed for details, he demurred. "My house is an open house," he said. "Everybody is welcome. They are my people. I belong to them."
Perhaps. But Mr. Husain, a Muslim who has filled many a canvas with scenes and portraits taken from Hindu mythology, has recently become the most prominent whipping boy for his country's Hindu militants. In November 1996, a mob ransacked one of Mr. Husain's galleries in Ahmedabad over another painting, a partly nude representation of the Hindu goddess of arts and letters, called Saraswati, bringing loud cries against censorship.
The gallery has since closed, but even his shows abroad have not been immune. Last summer a display at A Gallery on West 23d Street in Manhattan drew a small clutch of peaceful protesters. For his part, Mr. Husain, whose long and prolific career has mirrored the boom in Indian contemporary art over the last 10 years, expressed little surprise. At 83, he remembers the Hindu-Muslim antagonisms that preceded India's independence in 1947, the year he displayed his first canvas in public. "Even in the British time, I saw riots in Bombay," he recalled, adding that India is steeped in religion. "It is the one thing that you should not touch. I touched it. But they misunderstood it.'
In fact, Mr. Husain's brush has always touched religion. The portraits that have set off the Hindu militants in recent years were done several years ago. He has painted a long series based on "The Mahabharata," the Hindu epic, and also completed a series on the world's 10 major religions, including humanism. Recently, his imagination has turned to the movies, which in India can be as vital as matters of faith. "As Woody Allen says, 'Cinema is the only reality,' and that is more true in India," Mr. Husain observed. "Imagine what violence if there was no cinema. And I mean popular cinema, not the arty-arty, which is dull.'
These days, he is busy at work on what he calls an experimental Hindi-language opera, starring the pouty Bombay bombshell Madhuri Dixit, who, much to the dismay of many critics, has become Mr. Husain's latest obsession. He has painted more than 200 portraits of Ms. Dixit and seen her films over and over again, sometimes with an easel on his lap. "It was," he offered, "almost like a meditation."
Though he has only recently aroused the anger of Hindu militants, he is no stranger to controversy. Mr. Husain, whose paintings are bought by Indians at home and abroad as quickly as they are created, has attracted almost as much attention from the very spectacle of his life as from his brush.
"Even the way you live," he said the other day, "is an art form." For years he insisted on traveling barefoot; he was forced to don sandals only recently, after fracturing his toes repeatedly. In a 1995 show in Calcutta, Mr. Husain painted six canvases in front of an audience over six days, and then obliterated them all with a coat of white paint. Last month he offered his Hindu fundamentalist detractors the ultimate of Hindu sacrifices, agni pariksha, or a test by fire. He suggested that a panel of judges composed of an art critic, a lawyer and a member of a Hindu nationalist organization review his works. Any painting they deemed offensive, Mr. Husain said, he would simply throw into the flame.
His most avid collector in the United States, Chester Hirwitz, compared him to Andy Warhol, a likeness only heightened by Mr. Husain's shock of silver hair and a handsome, lean frame. "It's the way he sees the world," Mr. Hirwitz said. "It's a kind of wit, out of which comes a revelation of a fantastic kind of art."
By his own estimate, Mr. Husain has produced 40,000 to 60,000 paintings, famous for the brilliant reds and indigos that are as reminiscent of Indian landscapes as the black and white films of Satyajit Ray. His works have been included in Sotheby's auction of Indian contemporary paintings for the last two years in New York. Though he is relatively unknown in the United States, where the art market tends to favor the subcontinent's classical works over contemporary art, for many moneyed subcontinentals, a Husain canvas has become an important status symbol.
"You buy a Rolls-Royce, you buy a Husain," the artist observed. "There's nothing wrong. It's good for the artist." It wasn't always that way. Only in the last decade has Indian contemporary art gained notice, and that largely in India alone.
Mr. Husain, born in a small town in Maharashtra in 1915, began painting at 11. But his uncle, wanting him to pursue a practical trade like becoming a tailor, destroyed his earliest works. Pressed, he became a tailor's apprentice but soon ran away to Bombay to paint movie billboards for a living. In the years before India's independence, he helped found the Progressive Artists Group, a collective devoted to the creation of a modern Indian esthetic, founded on the principles of Cubism and infused with the colors and textures of India. It was to be free, he recalled, from both a Victorian British tradition as well as from the classical Indian miniatures. "Those two forces," Mr. Husain explained, "we tried to demolish."
But there was no market for the work, although occasionally an embassy official from Europe or the United States would buy a painting. In the late 1970's, India's business tycoons also started buying. By the late 1980's, the auction houses in London and New York took notice. As the Indian economy opened to foreign investment and Indian expatriates grew in number and wealth, the art market blossomed.
These days, a Husain opening is noted in society columns. People wait in line for hours. "It's all so cinematic," Mr. Husain said the other day. "I lost my identity because of this. I have become McBool!"

HEADLINE: 3M to Trail Forecasts, and Its Shares Fall

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, June 15

 BODY:
The stock of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company skidded $5.8125, or 6.7 percent, to $81 in active trading today, after the company said its second-quarter earnings would be below estimates.
Earnings are likely to be between 90 cents and 94 cents a diluted share, the company said, short of both the figure of 99 cents a year earlier and an analysts' consensus of $1.05 from the First Call Corporation. 
 Attributing the earnings pressure to weak Asian economies, modest domestic growth and the strengthening dollar, L. D. DeSimone, chairman and chief executive of 3M, said in an interview that the company might look into layoffs to cut costs. 3M will explore a "whole series of cost cuts," he said.
Mr. DeSimone noted that employment had gone down to about 75,000 employees from about 90,000 in the early 1990's. "We're doing a lot more business now than then," he said. "We've got 15,000 to 17,000 fewer people. It's something you keep working on."
Mark R. Gulley, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said in a research note last week, in which he downgraded 3M to neutral from outperform, that growth in productivity was slipping.
"Head count was essentially flat in 1Q '98 but needs to decline to meet 8 percent per annum productivity goals," Mr. Gulley wrote.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Even as Stocks Plunge, Treasuries Soar to 30-Year High

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term Treasury rates fell to their lowest level in 30 years yesterday while other Government bond yields, including those that affect home mortgages, dropped sharply.
The drop in rates, which has seen the 30-year yield fall half a percentage point since the end of April, could help support economic growth by helping the housing industry and making loans for capital investment cheaper. 
 Stronger growth would make it more likely that Federal Reserve policy makers would raise interest rates to prevent a resurgence of inflation.
But yesterday's sharp fall in the stock market, the latest in a string of declines that left the Nasdaq composite index down 10.5 percent from its recent high and the Dow Jones industrial average off 6.3 percent, has some analysts wondering about the near-term economic outlook.
A prolonged fall in the stock market, or even just a long period of inconclusive ups and downs, could have a chilling effect on consumer spending, as investors decide they may not be as wealthy as they had thought.
"The equity market is key," said Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "If equities don't hold up it would neutralize the effects from interest rates."
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last week that such a cooling in the stock market was one way that the Fed could get the slowing in growth policy makers say they need.
Analysts pointed to the economic turmoil in Asia, problems in Russia and, possibly, some new doubts about the American stock market, for reasons why investors seemed to be rushing to the safe harbor of the American bond market.
The 70-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average after 3:30 P.M. yesterday that pushed the day's decline over 200 points came as the yield on the 30-year bond dropped from 5.61 percent to 5.58 percent, down from 5.66 percent Friday. The price of the bond, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 16/32, to 107 26/32.
According to Salomon Brothers, the yield is the lowest for long-term Goverment rates since the fall of 1968, a time when interest rates were rising sharply because of the Vietnam War and inflation.
The yield on the 10-year note, used in the setting of mortgage interest rates, also fell, dropping to 5.35 percent, from 5.42 percent Friday. That is the lowest for 10-year yields since the fall of 1993. In January of this year, when the 10-year yield fell to 5.36 percent, mortgage rates were at four-year lows.
Shorter-term interest rates have also fallen sharply recently, partly in response to the foreign money coming into the American market. The yield on the two-year Treasury note fell to 5.38 percent yesterday from 5.43 percent Friday and 5.57 percent in the last week.
Where interest rates go from here is unclear. Analysts said they could fall further if the turmoil in Asia continued and foreigners sent more money here. But some think that there are not enough data yet proving that the economy is slowing from its recent, rapid 4 percent-plus pace to warrant a further big decline in long-term rates.
"In order to go below 5.5 percent on a sustained basis, there will need to be more evidence that the economy is slowing on a sustainable basis, not just a flight to quality," said Donald J. Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.

HEADLINE: Adrift in Japan's Sea of Unknown Intentions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
For the last 10 months the Clinton Administration has warned that a full-blown recession in Japan could prove the time bomb of the Asian crisis, setting off a sharp fall of the yen and, in turn, a second wave of the economic contagion that is spreading to investors around the globe.
Now that appears to be what is happening. But Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, weary of jawboning their Japanese counterparts, say the United States has very little leverage remaining over Tokyo. In fact, in internal White House arguments in recent days, some of Mr. Clinton's advisers have argued that Japan's hidden strategy is to let the country's currency fall -- making Japanese goods less expensive in the United States -- even if the fall undermines other countries in Asia that are struggling to emerge from a yearlong nightmare, or worsens troubles in Russia and Latin America. 
 In fact, the yen's tumble is acting as something of a double brake on other economies around the world. Japan's recession is making it nearly impossible for other Asian nations (to say nothing of American car makers and other manufacturers) to export more goods into Japan. Meanwhile, as the yen falls, Japanese goods push out products that other ailing Asian nations are trying to export to the United States and Europe, particularly Korean cars, steel and semiconductors.
"What is happening in Japan is hitting all of its neighbors -- Korea, Thailand -- and it is triggering a huge amount of instability around the world," Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said in an interview today. But when asked what the United States could do, Ms. Barshefsky, a veteran of five years of trade wars with Japan that have yielded modest changes but not the sweeping economic deregulation that Mr. Clinton once championed so publicly, offered little new.
"We need to keep putting pressure on them, both bilaterally and through our allies," she said. At the same time she conceded that the threat the United States had occasionally wielded in trade disputes -- closing the American market to cars or computer chips, for example -- would probably only accentuate Japan's troubles if used to compel Tokyo to speed up economic reforms.
In private, Administration officials have long referred to Japan as "the last firewall" of the Asian crisis, and contended that if that wall were breached, it was only a matter of time before Asia's troubles leaped the Pacific. It is an unproven thesis -- many said Korea was the firewall during the depths of the first wave of Asian economic trouble in December -- but clearly investors harbor the same worry. The evidence came today on Wall Street, when last week's selloff accelerated into a 207.01-point drop in the Dow industrials, prompted largely by news that the dollar had touched an eight-year high against the yen.
All of this is bound to complicate President Clinton's first trip to China, which begins next week.
At the insistence of the Chinese, he is making no stopover in Japan, America's strongest military ally in Asia. That deprives him of a natural chance to drive home to a Japanese public -- one highly critical of its own leadership -- America's prescription: rapid deregulation and a bailout of Japan's banks modeled on the United States' handling of the savings and loan crisis in the 1980's.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton is facing accusations from the Chinese that the United States and Japan are engaged in an economic conspiracy to let the yen fall, creating further troubles in the rest of Asia. "Why are Japan and the United States letting the yen slide?" China's state-run daily, The Financial News, which is controlled by China's central bank, asked this morning. "Mainly because a falling yen suits the two countries' economic interests now, and is beneficial in passing on their domestic economic problems to other countries," the paper concluded.
That commentary underscores an oft-expressed view in Asia these days: that the United States is not unhappy with Asia in crisis, especially as the American economy keeps charging along.
China has long worried about American efforts to "contain" its power, both military and economic. The falling yen and rising dollar, in the view of some nationalists, are means to this end. The currencies' shifts benefit the Japanese by making their exports far more competitive against their rivals.
And a strong dollar benefits American companies by making it possible for them to snap up assets across Asia -- companies, factories, banks -- at fire sale prices. One of Asia's most voluble nationalists, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, warned recently that foreign investors who bought up Asian assets were risking a huge political backlash.
The opposite view -- that the Asian crisis poses a rising threat to the United States -- is voiced almost daily nowadays by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, even though he may have, intentionally or not, accelerated the recent run on the yen.
Time and again the Treasury Secretary, who once supervised currency trading at Goldman, Sachs & Company, has repeated that the only way to strengthen the yen is for Japan to enact the economic and market reforms the United States has long advocated. "Over time, currencies follow fundamentals," he told Congress last week. He has repeatedly infuriated Japanese officials by refusing to threaten imminent intervention in the currency markets, and he has not backed away from his mantra that "a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States."
Investors have interpreted those comments as a license to sell the yen, without fear that the United States would join Japan in an effort to bolster the yen. They are probably reading him correctly. "The Japanese wasted $20 billion last month trying to intervene to keep the yen in the 130's," one senior Administration official noted recently. "Bob knows that running against the markets only delays the fall of a currency; it can't stop it. So he wants to pick his moment."
That is a fine strategy as long as the Japanese really fear the effects of a devalued yen.
Mr. Rubin still believes they do. He argues that although Japanese businesses want a weak currency so that they can increase exports, Japanese authorities are fearful that a weak yen could topple Japanese banks that are struggling to remain solvent.
Inside the Administration, though, some officials have begun to question whether Mr. Rubin has read the Japanese correctly. In meetings last week and phone conversations over the weekend, they have begun to argue that Japanese authorities now realize they can no longer prop up the yen -- so they might as well just let it fall, and hope that exports will surge. The fate of many of Asia's economies may hinge on who is correctly divining Japan's intentions.

HEADLINE: Lewis H. Young, 73, Former Editor in Chief of Business Week

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Lewis H. Young, a former editor in chief of Business Week who expanded the horizons of business reporting, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 73 and lived in Ossining, N.Y.
Mr. Young died of a heart attack as he was leaving his office at the Cahners Publishing Company, where he was editorial director of Electronic News, his wife, Joanne, said. 
 Trained in engineering and physics, Mr. Young was among the first business magazine editors to emphasize coverage of technology, electronics and computers. At Business Week, he was in charge during a period when economic news was frequently prominent, including an Arab oil embargo, recession in the mid-1970's and the New York City financial crisis.
He was also editor in chief of Electronics Magazine, which, like Business Week, was a McGraw-Hill publication. He also started several other business and electronics magazines.
He was active with Catalyst, a national advocacy group for the advancement of women in business and the professions, for a number of years and became chairman of its board in 1982.
After 15 years as chief editor, he left Business Week in 1984. Mr. Young moved to Hong Kong and started the magazine Far East Business. In 1989, he joined the Cahners Publishing, a unit of Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch information company.
He directed Asian operations of Cahners and was editorial director of Cahners's Electronic Business Asia, based in Hong Kong. In 1992, he became editorial director of Electronic Business, a Cahners monthly based in Boston. He moved to Electronic News as editorial director last year.
Mr. Young was born in Philadelphia. He received undergraduate degrees in mechanical engineering and physics at Purdue University. After college, he was a physicist with the Bettis Atomic Power division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. He earned a master's degree in business administration from New York University. He was a first lieutenant in the Army Corps of Engineers from 1943 to 1946.
In addition to his wife, Joanne Root Young, he is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Anne Albanese of Norwalk, Conn., and a sister, Pauline Schamberg of Buffalo Grove, Ill.

HEADLINE: Delinquency Rate on Credit Cards Is Higher

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Consumers' credit card delinquency rate rose slightly in the first quarter of this year over the final quarter of 1997, the American Bankers Association reported today.
Some 3.11 percent of card accounts were at least 30 days overdue for repayment in the first three months of 1998, compared with 3.04 percent the previous quarter. However, the most recent figure was down from 3.51 percent a year earlier, it said. 
 Its chief economist, James Chessen, said, "The delinquency rates are still high enough to warrant concern, and banks will no doubt continue the pattern of tighter lending standards for higher-risk customers."
"I'm pleased that Congress is reforming the lax bankruptcy laws that allow individuals to ignore obligations, when many have the ability to repay a portion of their debt," he said of last week's House vote to overhaul the bankruptcy laws.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
For Sellers To Japanese, Worse Ahead

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
As the Japanese yen continued its slide toward the abyss yesterday, stock markets around the world trembled. So much for the idea that Asian problems could be contained.
Shares of many big multinational companies that do business in Asia fell yesterday on fears that declining sales there would hurt profits. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, for example, lost 6.7 percent of its value. I.B.M. was down 3.4 percent. 
 But share prices of some companies with large exposures to Japan's incredible shrinking economy do not yet reflect the dark reality of what is happening there. Yes, these companies' shares have fallen, but they are likely to fall further in coming weeks as the bleak news sinks in.
Businesses with big Japanese exposure range from Tiffany & Company, the elite New York-based jeweler that produces 27 percent of its sales in Japan, to the discount retailer Toys "R" Us, which has 111 stores -- one-tenth of its worldwide total -- in the Pacific Rim. The company has 64 stores in Japan alone.
Other players in Japan include Aflac Inc., a life insurance concern based in Columbus, Ga., which generates 60 percent of its earnings in Japan. Particularly hard hit is Nu Skin, a marketer of personal-care and nutrition products that gets 70 percent of its revenue from Japanese operations.
Cosmetics makers are also vulnerable: Estee Lauder generates 13 percent of its operating income from the region; 16 percent of Avon Products' sales and 10 percent of its pretax income come from the Pacific Rim.
In addition, Japan is the largest market for Gucci, the luxury-goods retailer. And LVMH, the Parisian purveyor of high-class perfume, luggage, Champagne and Cognac, reported that sales fell 30 percent through May at its duty-free goods unit as Japanese customers cut back on travel.
The setback in Japan is a paradox for the American companies that battled for years to penetrate the country's relatively closed consumer society. Because Japan was willing to open its borders only to some, not all foreign companies, it may not be immediately obvious to investors which companies will be hurt most by problems there now. The businesses that never broke through Japan's barriers can now count their blessings.
The damage is not limited to companies that do business in Japan. The entire Pacific Rim looks like poison. The yen is dragging down currencies elsewhere in Asia, in places like South Korea, Indonesia and Hong Kong, as it falls in value.
Companies with significant operations in Japan and elsewhere in the Pacific Rim are reeling from a double punch. First, sales of goods made overseas generally decline when a nation's local currency is in a free fall; that's because the currency's lower value makes foreign goods more expensive there than they once were.
The second punch comes when these companies repatriate earnings made in a country whose currency is weak to one with a strong currency -- in this case, the dollar. Although these companies try to hedge their currency risks, almost no one had predicted that the yen -- down 8.5 percent against the dollar since May 15 -- would drop so steeply.
Many managers of concerns with exposure overseas say they will make up any shortfall there by stepping up operations elsewhere. For example, Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH, told the French business weekly Le Journal des Finances, that the company would expand in the United States to offset slowing sales in Asia.
Maybe so. But it takes a long time to build business. Any increases that LVMH and other companies hope to generate from new or expanded markets will not be evident for several quarters. Sales declines, on the other hand, can happen overnight, especially in a country whose currency -- the yen in this case -- has fallen almost 4 percent in the last week alone.
Wall Street analysts remain mostly sanguine about these companies' prospects. That's no surprise, given how hard it is for executives to dispense bad news. And many analysts, perhaps waiting for the yen to stabilize, have not updated their estimates to take into account the its recent tailspin. Mr. Arnault of LVMH, for example, said at last week's shareholder meeting, it remained his objective for the company to report a profit rise in 1998. But his hopes are pinned on a yen value of 130 to the dollar, not the current 146.
Another reason these shares have not crumbled further: Investors may think Japan's problems are temporary -- a dangerous view. Craig Chudler, Japanese market strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, expects the gross domestic product in Japan to contract 1.5 percent this year, more than double last year's decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent. Continued weakness in Japan's stock market, down 1.3 percent yesterday, will make consumers there even more likely to cut back on discretionary spending.
With some of these stocks down, they may look cheap. But with few willing to predict how low the yen can sink, and with the Japanese Government doing little to address its problems, this is no time for bottom-fishing.

HEADLINE: In Booming Economy, Poor Still Struggle to Pay the Rent

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Despite the economy's robust growth, low-income families continue to face record-level problems in the most basic of economic transactions: paying the rent.
Two studies released in the past two months have found that, unlike past economic recoveries, the boom times of the mid-1990's have done nothing to ease the housing problems of the poor. Indeed, the affordability problem may have grown worse. 
 Though housing costs vary widely by region, the severe and growing shortage of affordable apartments persists from east to west; in central cities, suburbs and rural areas, and among all racial and ethnic groups. The new data suggest that, through boom or bust, the gap between the incomes of needy renters and their shelter costs has become an abiding feature of the modern economy.
The study released today by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research and advocacy group, added fresh details to the discouraging picture. The study primarily covered 1993 to 1995.
In 1993, 4.1 million poor families spent more than half their income on rent and utilities, the study found. By 1995 that figure had grown to 4.4 million families.
Similarly, in 1993, the count of needy families outnumbered affordable apartments by 3.8 million. But by 1995, the gap grew to 4.4 million.
In 1995, the typical family of poor renters spent about 60 percent of its income on shelter, twice the percentage the Government considers affordable, the study found. That figure was the same in 1993.
The center's findings echo those of the Government. An April report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development similarly concluded that a growing economy had done nothing to ease the housing problems of the poor.
The department report said that for low-income families, housing affordability had become a "a fundamental structural problem," despite "robust economic growth."
"The center's study mirrors many of our own findings," said Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "Unfortunately, there are a lot more $6-an-hour jobs than $6-an-hour apartments."
The center's portrait of low-income housing did contain one bit of encouraging news. The number of dilapidated apartments continues to decline. In 1985, 22 percent of poor renters lived in substandard homes, like those lacking reliable plumbing. A decade later, that figure had declined to 14 percent.
The problems of needy renters rest at the intersection of three distinct trends. One, their incomes have stagnated. Two, shelter costs are growing faster than inflation as a whole. And three, the Government has not been expanding the supply of subsidized housing.
"There is general agreement about the magnitude of the affordability problem," said John Weicher, who served as an assistant housing secretary under President George Bush and now is a housing analyst for the Hudson Institute, a conservative research organization. "The disagreement is over what to do about it."
The Clinton Administration is asking Congress to offer rental subsidies to an additional 100,000 families this year. During the heyday of Government housing programs, 1977 to 1981, the Government added about 260,000 families a year to its roster of subsidized renters. During the Administrations of President Ronald Reagan and President Bush, that number still grew, though more slowly, averaging 70,000 a year.
But since 1995, when the Republicans took over Congress, the Government stopped expanding the pool of subsidized housing for the first time in modern history. Much of the cutback has been budget-driven. It costs about $6,000 a year to keep an average family in subsidized housing. And with repair costs rising for aging apartments, Congress has been reluctant to finance new ones.
Though about 15 million households now qualify for Federal housing assistance, only about 4.5 million families get it. Of those families, about a third live in conventional public housing projects. The others have subsidies that allow them to live in private housing. In each case, tenants contribute 30 percent of their income toward the rent, and the Government provides the rest.
While the Government's efforts have slowed, the crux of the problem remains in the economics of the private market. Demolition and gentrification have destroyed many low-cost housing units. And the cost of replacing them simply outstrips the ability of the neediest renters to pay.
Market forces can supply the poor with cheap clothing or food. But many housing costs are fixed, like land, taxes, utilities and interest. The ability of builders to economize, therefore, is limited.
From 1991 to 1995, the average rent paid by a low-income renter rose 21 percent, the center's study found, compared with a general inflation rate of 9 percent.
While the housing problems of the poor may seem a perennial concern, they have undergone a sea change in the past generation.
In 1970, there were about 300,000 more cheap apartments than there were needy renters -- 6.2 million renters and 6.5 million apartments. By 1995, however, there were 10.5 million needy renters, and just 6.1 million cheap apartments.
(The study defined a cheap apartment as one where rent and utilities cost less than $300 in 1995, and a needy renter as one earning less than $12,000 a year. It adjusted the 1970 figures to account for inflation.)
The study found that about 80 percent of poor renters spend more than 30 percent of their income on shelter. And about 60 percent spend more than half their income on rent and utilities. Leaving aside those with subsidies, the numbers grow even more discouraging. The average poor renter not receiving a subsidy spends 77 percent of income on shelter.
While Mr. Weicher agrees that the economic recovery has been slow to ease the housing problems of the poor, he predicts a less discouraging report when more recent data is made available from the Census Bureau.
"I'd expect some improvement from 1995 to 1997," he said. "This recovery was slower than previous recoveries to reach people at the bottom."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Japan Goes, So Goes the Neighborhood

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, June 16

 BODY:
As countries throughout Asia try to pick up the pieces of their economies, they are increasingly confronted with the disconcerting reality that recoveries are vulnerable to the frail Japanese economy and the downward path of the yen. What worries them is that both are completely beyond their control, and more worrying, perhaps beyond the control of the Japanese authorities.
China, Hong Kong, Thailand and other countries have called on Japan to stem the yen's fall, and there is growing apprehension that the yen's decline will lead China to devalue its currency as well, perhaps spurring a rash of competitive devaluations. 
 The yen has been declining relentlessly in recent weeks. In late New York trading Monday, the dollar cost 146.15 yen, the first time in nearly eight years it has surpassed 146 yen. In Asia trading today, the yen weakened further before rebounding a bit to 145.35 yen. It took just under 80 yen to buy a dollar at the yen's peak in April 1995.
The fear is that the recession in Japan's economy, which is twice as large as all the rest of Asia, will cause a currency crisis that wrecks Asia's fragile recovery from the initial plunge in currency values nearly a year ago. The effects of Asia's weakness have already shaved profits at companies across America, and another currency crisis could have a deeper and wider impact.
"We have reached another stage," said Rajeev Malik, regional economist with Jardine Fleming International Securities Ltd. in Singapore. "Asia will not turn its course until Japan does."
It is not clear how the Japanese Government can exert influence over the market forces pushing the yen down. "We cannot move the market by ourselves," Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told Parliament on Monday.
Japan's Vice Finance Minister, Koji Tanami, reiterated at a regular weekly news conference on Monday that the Japanese Government may take coordinated action with other countries to halt the yen's decline. His words had little effect.
One reason for the yen's decline is that Japanese investors are selling yen and buying dollars. Figures released Monday showed that Japan's market liberalization had encouraged investments overseas.
The figures showed that in April, Japanese investors sent a record amount of capital abroad. About 3.74 trillion yen, or $25 billion, went into equity and bond investments overseas, the Ministry of Finance said, the largest amount since the Government started compiling such data in 1980.
The tide of money changed into dollars could continue. Japanese investors are sitting on 1,200 trillion yen in individual savings, even though bank deposit rates here are less than three-tenths of a percent.
The Government has begun loosening foreign exchange regulations and so now it is easier for Japanese savers to turn their savings into dollars or marks and invest in the United States and Europe to get higher returns. In Japan, the benchmark 10-year bond earns 1.18 percent, compared with 5.37 percent on 10-year United States Treasuries.
Japan's recession makes it hard for other Asian economies to recover, partly because Japan has a potentially huge appetite for Asian exports. About one-fifth of China's exports, for instance, go to Japan. With the weak economy and the weak yen, however, Japan is less able to absorb such goods.
The yen's weakness also raises pressure on other Asian countries, particularly South Korea and Taiwan, to devalue to keep their exports competitive. This could set off a round of competitive devaluations, particularly if China then devalued its currency, the renminbi.
"Beggar thy neighbor policies, or competitive devaluations, are more serious and more immediate, compared to a downward spiral of the economy," said C. H. Kwan, a Tokyo-based economist specializing in Asia at the Nomura Research Institute. The weakening yen is "already hurting currency and stock markets in the whole region."
"If we have a devaluation of the renminbi," he added, "we have more trouble ahead. The crisis is going to linger."
China has repeatedly said it will not devalue the renminbi but has given indications of a reappraisal. Last week, Dai Xianglong, China's central bank governor, said the yen's weakness was "having a very negative impact on Chinese imports and exports and the utilization of foreign capital." One major risk is that a debilitating tailspin in the currencies of other Asian countries could prompt Asian governments to defend their currencies by raising local interest rates, a move that could choke off any recovery or cause more severe economic declines.
Not everyone in Asia is so discouraged, though. Kim Min Hong, a manager at Kyung Duck Electronics in Seoul, South Korea, makes magnetic heads for credit cards, as well as machines that read the cards. His product costs one-fourth the price of similar machines from Japan.
"In terms of competitiveness with Japanese products, our products are still much cheaper," he said. "Japanese products account for more market share around the world, but we do not feel the effects of the yen depreciation yet."
Lee Jin Ho, an analyst at the Korea Foreign Traders Association, which represents steel, auto and semiconductor exporters, said South Korean companies were still coping, but not necessarily for long.
"Korean exports still have some breathing room," he said. "But when the yen depreciates to 150 yen to the dollar, that will definitely have an impact on Korean exports over all."

German Bank Deal
TOKYO, June 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- The struggling Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. said today that it had sold a major operation to a German bank for $1.57 billion.
Long-Term sold its aviation and shipping financing division, with operations in London and New York, to Deutsche Verkehrs Bank, hoping the move would help strengthen its capital base.
The Japanese bank, troubled by big debts and losses, has faced heavy pressure, particularly in the last week, after its share price was badly hit as investors sold off their stocks fearing it would cancel a major tie-up with the Swiss Bank Corporation.
At the end of last March, Long Term's assets totaled 26.6 trillion yen, or about $18.2 billion, down from 29.5 trillion yen the previous year.
In 1996 Deutsche Verkehrs, owned by German savings and agricultural banks, had assets of 9.1 billion marks, or about $5 billion.

HEADLINE: DOW TUMBLES 207 IN GLOBAL DECLINE

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Renewed fears that Asia's economic crisis will stall growth in the profits of American companies sent United States' stocks plunging yesterday, the worst in a string of recent selloffs that has now erased the gains of the last three months for the Dow Jones industrial average.
Since crossing the 9,000 mark in April -- a level almost 1,100 points above where the blue-chip average began the year -- the Dow has faced trouble sustaining that height. 
 The barometer of the nation's top industrial companies fell 207.01 points yesterday, to 8,627.93, a 2.3 percent drop that left it down 6.3 percent from its record high. Some other market gauges have fallen even more, suggesting that a stock market correction -- a drop of 10 percent or more -- is under way.
Investors are increasingly concerned that Asia has not reached the bottom of its economic cycle. Distress signs there have worsened.
Japan, which many hoped would be the region's rescuer, announced last week that its economy shrank sharply in the quarter that ended in March, amounting to its steepest annualized decline since World War II. The yen, a barometer of Japan's economic weakness, fell to another eight-year low against the dollar yesterday, further elevating fears throughout Asia. Page D8.
Prices on the Japanese stock market and at other exchanges across Asia fell sharply in response, setting the stage for a decline when trading began on Wall Street.
"What you're really seeing is a truly global market," said Anthony Conroy, a managing director at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management. "If you catch a cold in Asia, it really becomes a flu almost everywhere else."
For American companies that do business in Japan and throughout Asia, the prospects are growing dimmer for a recovery anytime soon. Yesterday, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the maker of Post-It Notes and Scotchgard fabric protector, became the latest American company to warn investors that earnings would be disappointing this quarter because of Asian problems.
Earlier this year, analysts predicted that Asia's troubles would hurt global companies in the first half of 1998 but that earnings would pick up in the second half. Now, more analysts are pushing back their estimates of a recovery.
Although companies have been reluctant to say much about how Asia will lower earnings, Boeing, National Semiconductor, Ford Motor, Callaway Golf, and Analog Devices have all hinted that profits will continue to be pinched in the second half.
Through Friday, 64 percent of the companies that have warned analysts to revise their profit projections for the second quarter have suggested that the estimates be lowered, according to the First Call Corporation, a Boston-based firm that tracks analysts' earnings estimates. In an average quarter, only 57 percent of companies give such negative advice, First Call said.
For the year, analysts now expect profits at the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 to rise 9.2 percent, down from a 13.9 percent estimate at the beginning of the year, according to a survey by First Call.
Those projections may still prove optimistic. Profits in the S.& P. 500 actually rose 3.8 percent in the first quarter and are now expected to climb 4.7 percent in the second quarter, First Call said. That estimate is down considerably since the first of the year.
A flight to quality has helped the American financial markets all year, but only the Treasury market benefited yesterday.
In Asia, the Nikkei 225 average of Japanese stocks fell 1.3 percent yesterday. Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index was off 5.72 percent, to its lowest level since Jan. 30, 1995. European stocks fell as well. In early trading today, Japanese stocks fell slightly and Hong Kong stocks were up a bit. Other Asian markets were little changed.
"Asia is a double-edged sword," said Charles Johnson, a managing director and head equity trader at Blaylock & Partners in Baltimore. The problems have dimmed the possibility that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates soon -- stable or falling rates are generally viewed as positive for stocks -- but "the other edge is corporate profits," which are under pressure, Mr. Johnson said.
In uncertain times, United States Treasury securities are seen as a haven, and yesterday a surge in demand for bonds sent the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury to a record low of 5.58 percent.
The 207-point fall was the fifth biggest ever for the Dow, but in percentage terms, the 2.3 percent decline was not even among the 20 steepest declines. The Dow is still up 9.1 percent for 1998.
Some analysts said that the blue-chip stock gauge was merely beginning to reflect the declines already evident in the broader market.
The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology stocks, fell 29.30 points yesterday, to 1,715.75, a 1.68 percent decline. The index is now off 10.5 percent from its April 22 high. The Russell 2000 index, another broad gauge, fell 7.73 points yesterday and is now off 11.7 percent from its high on April 21.
"The overall stock market is acting much more poorly than the blue- chip indexes," said Steve Shobin, chief technical analyst at Lehman Brothers. "Yes, there's really a correction going on."
According to a Salomon Smith Barney study, through June 2, more than 43 percent of the stocks in the Nasdaq composite index have dropped 30 percent or more from their 52-week highs. That compares with 10.2 percent of S.& P. 500 stocks and almost 18 percent of stocks on the Big Board. During that period, the average drop in a Nasdaq stock has been 30.1 percent from its 52-week high.
When looking at stocks with price declines of at least 10 percent -- the usual measure of a correction -- the percentages are even higher. In Nasdaq stocks, 84 percent are down by that amount, as are more than 58 percent of S.& P. stocks and almost 69 percent of Big Board issues.
Mr. Shobin of Lehman Brothers said his indicators pointed to more trouble ahead. Fewer stocks are posting new highs now than in mid-April, he said, and trading volume is off. "Most corrections do not end until volume rises sharply," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fall to 3-Month Low On Growing Asian Concerns
The turmoil in Asia has sent United States stock markets tumbling, wiping out the gains of the last three months for the Dow Jones industrial average. Yesterday, the Dow fell 207 points, or 2.3 percent. Some other market gauges have fallen even more, suggesting what Wall Street calls a market correction -- a drop of 10 percent or more -- is under way.
Investors are increasingly concerned that the economic crisis in Asia has yet to reach bottom. Japan, which many hoped would be the region's savior, announced last week that its economy shrank sharply in the first quarter, amounting to its steepest decline since World War II. Page A1. 

Long-term Treasury rates fell to their lowest level in 30 years. The yield dropped to 5.58 percent, from 5.66 percent Friday. D12.
 
Sunbeam Dismisses Chief Executive
Albert J. Dunlap, who has gained a reputation as a turnaround artist by downsizing many companies, was dismissed as chief executive of Sunbeam. The board of Sunbeam, the consumer appliance maker, said that 1998 earnings would be much worse than anticipated and that outside directors had lost confidence in Mr. Dunlap's leadership. A1.
 
Asian Nations Want Japan to Act
The governments of China, Hong Kong, Thailand and other Asian countries have called on Japan to stem the fall of the yen, which has been plummeting lately and has reached an eight year low. D8.
 
Hong Kong Suffers From Turmoil
The falling yen has caused concern in Hong Kong, where stocks fell 5.7 percent -- the lowest level in more than three years. But the market steadied somewhat early today. D9.
 
Microsoft and Compaq Buy Stakes
Both Microsoft and Compaq Computer are investing $212.5 million for 10 percent stakes in Road Runner, a high-speed cable modem Internet venture. D4.
 
MCI Offers to Sell Internet Units
Worldcom and MCI Communications have offered to sell more of MCI's Internet business to win approval for their merger from regulators. MCI agreed last month to sell parts of its Internet business to Cable and Wireless for $625 million. D2.
 
G.M. Forced to Close More Plants
The North American operations of G.M. moved closer to being shut down completely, as strikes at two Michigan parts factories forced the auto maker to idle 13,000 more workers and partly close a host of other parts and assembly plants. The strikes have now sent 63,100 workers home and closed more than 40 assembly and parts factories in the United States, Mexico and Canada. D5.
 
3M Warns About Lower Earnings
Shares of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing fell 6.7 percent, to $81, after the company said second-quarter earnings would be below estimates. The shortfall was attributed to weak Asian economies, modest domestic growth and the strengthening dollar. 3M said it would consider layoffs as well as other cost-cutting measures. D9.
 
Giant New Jersey Mall Planned
Glimcher Realty Trust plans to build a giant shopping mall on 110 acres in Elizabeth, N.J., near Newark International Airport. The mall will have an entertainment complex designed by Michael Ovitz. B12.

HEADLINE: $100 Million in Legal Services Funding Is Placed in Doubt by a Supreme Court Ruling

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
A sharply divided Supreme Court today cast constitutional doubt on state programs that generate $100 million a year for legal services for poor people by pooling the interest on some of the money that clients deposit for brief periods with their lawyers.
That interest is actually the property of the clients, the Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision that raised, but did not answer, the question of whether channeling the money for legal services amounts to an unconstitutional "taking" of private property for a public purpose. 
 That question will now be answered by the lower Federal courts or by the Supreme Court as the case works it way back up through the legal system. Reaction today was sharply split over whether the Court's handling of the initial property question foreshadowed an eventual ruling that the program is unconstitutional.
The case, a challenge brought to the program in Texas by property rights advocates, represented the leading edge of a debate that has taken place largely out of the public eye but that has galvanized the organized bar in support of programs.
It is also the latest chapter in the long-running, ideologically charged battle over the fate of publicly funded legal services programs, which conservatives in Congress have been trying to kill or curb sharply for the last 20 years. According to a brief filed by the American Bar Association, money generated by the programs is second only to the Federal Government as a source of funding for legal services, accounting for as much as a quarter of the legal services budgets.
The Court split along ideological lines. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by his four most conservative colleagues: Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, Sandra Day O'Connor, and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices David H. Souter, John Paul Stevens, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen G. Breyer dissented.
In declaring the interest to be clients' property, the Court rejected arguments put forward by the chief justices of all 50 states, the American Bar Association, 35 state attorneys general, and numerous government groups. These groups argued that properly understood, the interest should not be seen as the clients' property because it would be nonexistent, eaten up by transaction costs, except for the pooling arrangement that courts and legislatures in all states have adopted under a program known as Interest on Lawyers Trust Accounts.
The idea for the program, usually referred to by its initials as Iolta, began in Australia in the 1960's. Its adoption in the United States was delayed until 1980, when Congress first authorized banks to pay interest on checking accounts for certain types of depositors. Before then, lawyers typically deposited short-term client funds, like escrow or settlement deposits, in non-interest bearing accounts.
Once interest-bearing checking accounts became available, the American Bar Association and other lawyers' groups were quick to promote adoption of the Australian idea of directing the pooled interest to legal services. They reasoned that for clients, the interest was largely theoretical in any event, because the costs of opening an account and dealing with tax forms would quickly cancel out the earnings from all but sizeable deposits. When actual net interest to a client was a possibility, that client's deposit would not be pooled, but would go into an individual account for the client's benefit.
The Texas Supreme Court adopted an Iolta program for the state in 1984. All states now have the programs, which flourished at the same time that Congress was cutting the budget of the Legal Services Corporation and placing restrictions on the types of cases that lawyers who work for the federally funded programs can bring.
The case against the Texas program was brought by a conservative public interest law firm, the Washington Legal Foundation. It challenged the program both as an unconstitutional taking of private property and as a form of compelled support for causes not of a client's choosing, in violation of the First Amendment. That aspect of the case was not before the Supreme Court but can be renewed in the lower court proceedings that will follow today's ruling.
Chief Justice Rehnquist, in his majority opinion today in Phillips v. Washington Legal Foundation, No. 96-1578, applied a rule of English common law that "interest follows principal." Because there was no dispute that the principal on deposit was the property of the client, the Chief Justice said, it followed that "any interest that does accrue attaches as a property right incident to the ownership of the underlying principal."
This was the case, the Chief Justice continued, even if at the end of the day there was no net interest for the client to receive. "We have never held that a physical item is not 'property' simply because it lacks a positive economic or market value," he said, adding that: "The government may not seize rents received by the owner of a building simply because it can prove that the costs incurred in collecting the rents exceed the amount collected."
Whether the use of the property was a "taking" within the meaning of the Fifth Amendment or, if so, whether any "just compensation" would be due to the clients, were questions for another day, the Chief Justice said.
In a dissenting opinion, Justice Souter objected that the Court had announced "an essentially abstract proposition" that "may ultimately turn out to have no significance" in resolving the ultimate constitutional question. If the amount of "just compensation" turned out to be zero, he said, "there would be no practical consequence" to having recognized a property right in the first place.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, which found the interest to be property in its 1996 ruling but stopped short of deciding the other questions, will now consider the case again. "We're 90 percent of the way home," Richard Samp, the Washington Legal Foundation's chief counsel, said today in predicting that his group would win the next phase.
The program's supporters were more tempered in their predictions. Jerome J. Shestack, president of the American Bar Association, said in an interview that Iolta programs were "more vulnerable, but still alive" under the ruling today. Mr. Shestack speculated that if there had been a solid five votes on the Court to decide the ultimate issue against the programs, the majority would probably have done so now rather than preserve the issue for another day.

Rush in Cuba for U.S. Visas
Hundreds of Cubans crowded post offices in Havana on the first day that they could mail in applications for a lottery for United States visas. The visa lotteries were set up in 1994 by the American and Cuban Governments to end the the flow of hundreds of thousands of Cubans who set off for the United States on rickety rafts and boats. The agreement promises at least 20,000 visas a year and to return any Cubans intercepted on the high seas. (AP)

A strike halted many of London's subway trains. The subway system said about 60 percent of trains were running. The union that represents about one-third of the subway staff walked off the job on Sunday over benefits for workers after the system becomes partially privatized. The strike was set to last 48 hours. (AP)
